HEADLINE: Staving Off the Silencers

BYLINE: By Anthony Lewis; Anthony Lewis, a Times columnist, is the author most recently of "Make No Law: The Sullivan Case and the First Amendment."

 BODY:
AMERICANS HAVE MORE freedom to think what we will and say what we think than any other people on earth. We can denounce politicians in uninhibited language. We can read books banned in Britain or Israel. We can even burn our flag, as a political protest, without fear of punishment.
All this we owe to the unflinching guaranty in the First Amendment: "Congress shall make no law . . . abridging the freedom of speech, or of the press." Those bold words were added to the Constitution, along with the rest of the Bill of Rights -- the first 10 amendments -- on Dec. 15, 1791. We approach the anniversary secure in the knowledge that Americans have been free to speak and publish without fear for 200 years. 
 So we believe. But it is not so simple. The First Amendment did not make us free when it was ratified in 1791. Far from it. Not until 1927 did anyone claiming a constitutional right to freedom of speech or press win a case in the Supreme Court. Those clauses of the First Amendment have been given meaning only by a turbulent history.
Just seven years after the First Amendment was adopted, we had a close brush with the tyranny of silence. The President was John Adams, a Federalist, and the Federalists controlled Congress. In the summer of 1798, they pushed through a Sedition Act that made it a crime to publish false, malicious comments about the President or Congress. It did not reach nasty attacks on the Vice President, Thomas Jefferson -- who was the leader of the oncoming opposition, eventually to be the Democratic Party. It was partisan legislation, designed to silence the opposition in the run-up to the election of 1800. Indeed, the law was to expire on the next Inauguration Day, March 4, 1801.
Just how repressive the Sedition Act could be was made clear by the first prosecution under it. Matthew Lyon, a Jeffersonian Representative from Vermont, had written a letter to the editor of a Vermont paper saying that President Adams was engaged in "a continual grasp for power, in an unbounded thirst for ridiculous pomp, foolish adulation and selfish avarice." It was characteristic political slanging of the day -- or any day in this country. But an indictment charged that the words were "scurrilous, feigned, false, scandalous, seditious and malicious." Lyon was convicted and sentenced to four months in prison and a fine of $1,000, a huge sum then and one that he could not pay. He remained in prison.
Jefferson and James Madison, who had drafted the First Amendment as a member of the House, worked to arouse the states against the Sedition Act. Worried that they would be prosecuted themselves, they acted in secret. Such was the mood of fear created by the act.
Madison wrote the classic American argument for freedom of political speech, passed by the Virginia Legislature as the Virginia Resolutions. "The Sedition Act," he said, "ought to produce universal alarm, because it is leveled against the right of freely examining public characters and measures, and of free communication among the people thereon, which has ever been justly deemed the only effectual guardian of every other right." He went on to make a fundamental point about the American political system. "In this country," he wrote, "the people, not the Government, possess the absolute sovereignty." He was drawing a distinction from Britain, and the distinction is still true today: Parliament is sovereign, and the people have no rights in law if Parliament restricts their freedom.
Madison's argument added up to a theory of not only the First Amendment but the entire constitutional structure. If the people are sovereign, they must be free to examine and criticize those whom they choose to govern from time to time. It is the premise -- the Madisonian premise, it is fair to say -- of democracy.
Not everyone agreed with Madison, of course. John Marshall, later the great Chief Justice, was a Federalist candidate for Congress in Virginia in 1799 and defended the Sedition Act. The state, he said, must be able to protect itself "from the attempts of wicked citizens to disturb the public repose." Government could not be secure "if by falsehood and malicious slander it is to be deprived of the confidence and affection of the people." It was a paternalistic view, and very English. If it had prevailed, this would be a different country.
The constitutionality of the Sedition Act was never tested in the Supreme Court before it expired. But it provoked a great political test. The Adams Administration used the act to prosecute the owners and editors of all the leading Jeffersonian newspapers. The tactic proved to be disastrous. Public outrage, spurred by Jeffersonian talk of tyranny, helped Jefferson to defeat Adams in 1800. When he took office, Jefferson pardoned all those who had been convicted under the Sedition Act.
FOR MORE THAN A CENTURY AFTER that episode, the speech and press clauses of the First Amendment lay essentially dormant. The Supreme Court, starting in the latter part of the 19th century, read the Constitution more and more to protect property. It was hostile to claims of free expression. How hostile became evident when the United States entered World War I and Congress passed an Espionage Act that made it a crime to obstruct the war effort or military recruitment.
In 1918, Eugene V. Debs, five times the Socialist Party's candidate for President, was charged under the Espionage Act for a speech in which -- in passing -- he expressed sympathy with men jailed for counseling others on how to avoid the draft. He was convicted and sentenced to 10 years in prison. He argued that the conviction violated his rights under the First Amendment. But the Supreme Court unanimously rejected the claim, in an opinion by Justice Oliver Wendell Holmes Jr.
Think of the Debs case in comparison with what happened during the Vietnam War, when hundreds of thousands of Americans opposed the war and none went to prison for mere words. How did we get from the Debs decision to where we are today, when dissidents can rail against Government policy in wartime? How has the received meaning of the First Amendment so changed?
An extraordinary process has taken place, starting just a few months after the Debs decision in 1919, when another Espionage Act case came along. Three anarchists and a socialist had protested President Wilson's dispatch of troops to intervene in Russia after the Bolshevik Revolution, throwing leaflets from the top of buildings in the garment district in New York. For that, they were convicted -- three sentenced to 20 years in prison and the fourth to 15. The Supreme Court again found no protection for their expression in the First Amendment. But this time, Justice Holmes, joined by Justice Louis D. Brandeis, dissented. It was the first Supreme Court opinion arguing that freedom of speech had been unconstitutionally abridged.
"Persecution for the expression of opinions seems to me perfectly logical," Holmes wrote. "If you have no doubt of your premises or your power and you want a certain result with all your heart, you naturally express your wishes in law and sweep away all opposition. . . . But when men have come to realize that time has upset many fighting faiths, they may come to believe even more than the foundations of their own conduct that the ultimate result desired is better reached by free trade in ideas -- that the best test of truth is the power of the thought to get itself accepted in the competition of the market. . . . That at any rate is the theory of our Constitution. It is an experiment, as all life is an experiment. . . . While that experiment is part of our system I think that we should be eternally vigilant against attempts to check the expression of opinions that we loathe and believe to be fraught with death. . . ."
Over the next 10 years, Holmes and Brandeis, in dissent, wrote many moving tributes to free speech. Brandeis: "Those who won our independence . . . believed that freedom to think as you will and speak as you think are means indispensable to the discovery of political truth. . . . Fear of serious injury alone cannot justify suppression of free speech. . . . Men feared witches and burnt women." Holmes: "If there is any principle of the Constitution that more imperatively calls for attachment than any other it is the principle of free thought -- not free thought for those who agree with us but freedom for the thought that we hate."
Gradually, over time, those dissents became the law of the First Amendment. Holmes and Brandeis, and other Justices after them, persuaded the country -- and the Court -- that freedom of expression was a paramount constitutional value.
HISTORY CAME FULL CYCLE IN 1964, WHEN the Supreme Court returned to Madison's spacious vision of the First Amendment. The case was New York Times v. Sullivan. The Times had published a full-page advertisement seeking support for Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and the struggle to win blacks the vote and other civil rights in the South. The ad spoke of brutal tactics by the police and other white officials to put down the civil rights movement. It named no names; but L. B. Sullivan, a city commissioner of Montgomery, Ala., sued for libel, claiming that brutality would be attributed to him because he was in charge of the Montgomery police. An all-white jury awarded him all he had demanded in damages: $500,000, the largest libel verdict in Alabama history. Other Alabama officials sued over the advertisement, and across the South officials seized on libel suits as a new way to keep the national press from covering the civil rights struggle -- by intimidation.
The press then was playing a crucial part in the civil rights debate, reporting more fully than ever on the savageries used to keep blacks segregated and powerless in the South. As Americans learned about those realities, the pressure for national political action grew. Congress passed a series of civil rights laws. Blacks began to vote in substantial numbers, and the politics of the region was transformed.
In short, the system worked as Madison thought it should: an informed public shaping Government policy. It could not have worked in the same way if Sullivan's libel suit and the others that followed had succeeded in scaring away press coverage of the racial issue in the South. The suits were, therefore, a profound challenge to the Madisonian view of the First Amendment -- to its function of assuring open political discussion. But when the Sullivan case came to the Supreme Court, there was a great historical obstacle to applying the First Amendment to it. Libel had always been treated as outside the amendment's protection. No libel judgment, however extreme, had ever been held to violate the Constitution.
Justice William J. Brennan Jr., writing the opinion of the Court in the Sullivan case, cut through that obstacle. The form of a libel action could not obscure the reality, he said, the reality of an attempt to foreclose expression "on one of the major public issues of our time."
Did the First Amendment, then, protect critical comments on Southern officials? Justice Brennan made the Sedition Act of 1798, and the battle against it, the crux of his analysis. He quoted Madison on how the act interfered with the right to examine "public characters and measures." He concluded: "Although the Sedition Act was never tested in this Court, the attack upon its validity has carried the day in the court of history." It was an extraordinary moment: 163 years after the Sedition Act expired, the Supreme Court held it retrospectively unconstitutional.
We live in a society of "uninhibited, robust and wide-open debate," Justice Brennan said, and public officials must live with "sometimes unpleasantly sharp attacks." Because error is inevitable in free debate, not even mistaken criticism can be grounds for an official's libel suit, so long as the misstatement was not deliberate or made with awareness of its probable falsity. Sullivan's $500,000 judgment was reversed, and all the other Southern libel suits that threatened to keep the press away from the civil rights story fell away.
In the years after the Sullivan decision, the Supreme Court applied the Madisonian principle of free expression to a wide range of factual situations. When the Georgia Legislature refused to seat Julian Bond as an elected member because he had sympathized with draft resisters during the Vietnam War, the Court held unanimously that Bond's First Amendment right to free speech had been violated. The facts were remarkably similar to those in Eugene Debs's case; the result was the opposite.
"Freedom for the thought that we hate," which Holmes had urged in dissent, became a reality. The Supreme Court reversed the conviction of a Ku Klux Klan speaker who said that "the nigger should be returned to Africa, the Jew returned to Israel." The Court held that a speaker may not be punished for advocating even the use of force or illegality unless the speech is intended to incite imminent lawlessness and is likely to. A lower Federal court held unconstitutional local ordinances designed to block a march by American Nazis through Skokie, Ill., where many survivors of the Holocaust lived.
Savage ridicule of the eminent is also protected now by the First Amendment. Hustler magazine in 1983 published a parody of a Campari advertisement suggesting that Jerry Falwell, the minister and leader of the Moral Majority, had had a drunken incestuous rendezvous with his mother in an outhouse. A jury awarded Falwell $200,000 in damages for intentional infliction of emotional distress. The Supreme Court held unanimously that the First Amendment protected Hustler. There could be no damages for ridicule, Chief Justice William Rehnquist said, however savage, unless readers would take an attack as factual and it was deliberately false. And no one would take the Hustler parody as a statement of facts.
Finally, there were the two flag-burning cases in 1989 and 1990. Majorities of 5 to 4 held that burning an American flag as a political protest was expression protected by the First Amendment. President Bush called for a constitutional amendment to protect the flag. Congress at first seemed ready to agree, but more and more members -- and their constituents -- came to doubt the wisdom of tampering with the First Amendment. The flag amendment fell short of the necessary majorities in Congress, and the issue disappeared -- perhaps a sign that Americans, or a good many of them, now really accept the idea of freedom for the thought that we hate.
BUT HISTORY IS SELDOM A NICE progressive curve upward, and the modern history of First Amendment interpretation has hardly been that. There have been many dark passages.
Fear of Communism led to successive waves of repression. In the Palmer raids of 1920, Federal agents arrested 4,000 supposed radicals in a single night. Joe McCarthy and other Congressional demagogues feasted on anti-Communism after World War II. Security checks carried out by grossly unfair and inaccurate methods were imposed on Federal Government workers. Blacklisting savaged the entertainment world. And the Supreme Court did very little to hold these outrages up to the light of the First Amendment.
The low point in the Court's modern record was probably its 1951 decision sustaining the conviction of American Communist Party Leaders for conspiring to teach the necessity of overthrowing the Government. A majority, rejecting First Amendment claims, said this group of pathetically ineffectual figures presented a danger serious enough to justify overriding the principle of free speech for ideas that we loathe. The premises of that decision have been eaten away since the Sullivan case, vindicating Justice Hugo Black's dissenting hope that "in calmer times, when present pressures, passions and fears subside, this or some later Court will restore the First Amendment liberties."
WHERE, THEN, DOES THe FIRST Amendment stand as it approaches its 200th birthday? How true are we to Madison's vision of sovereign citizens informed on public matters and freely debating them? How free are we to speak and write what we will?
For me, the most worrying contemporary threat to First Amendment values is the growth of secrecy in the Federal Government. The fear of Communism and the reality of the cold war led successive Administrations to say that national security required more and more of their business to be done in secret. The national security claim was no doubt sincerely made in many instances, but there is no doubt, either, that it was greatly exaggerated. Officials naturally find life easier if they do not have to explain and defend their policies.
The Supreme Court has been at its worst in dealing with the growth of secret government. Rather than applying the independent scrutiny that the First Amendment ordinarily evokes from judges, the Court has bent over backward -- cringed might be a better word -- to defer to national security claims by the Government.
The Court ignored First Amendment interests in the important case of Frank Snepp. A C.I.A. official in Vietnam during the war, Snepp was distressed that at the end the United States left behind many of our Vitnamese intelligence sources -- and files containing their names, which made it certain that they would be mistreated. He wrote a book, "Decent Interval," criticizing high United States officials, and published it without first submitting it to the agency for review, as he had promised to do. The Government sued him.
A majority of the Supreme Court was so moved by the C.I.A.'s secrecy claims that it decided the case against Frank Snepp without letting his lawyers brief or argue the case. The Court held that his promise to clear any manuscripts was a binding contract and that for violating it he must turn his gross receipts from the book over to the Government: nearly $200,000 so far, an amount far larger than the penalty for many grievous crimes. The Court did so even though the Government conceded for purposes of the case that Snepp had disclosed no classified information in the book. It also put Snepp under a lifelong injunction requiring him to clear with the C.I.A. anything he proposes to write or speak about Vietnam or intelligence matters. He has had to clear book reviews and the manuscript of a novel.
On the strength of the Snepp case, the Reagan Administration asked hundreds of thousands of Federal employees to sign secrecy agreements, promising not to write or speak about their work without official approval, even after leaving the Government, for the rest of their lives. We have always relied on former officials to give us insights into the Government. But when their words are submitted to censors, there will always be a tendency to remove the merely embarrassing. Two former Directors of Central Intelligence, William Colby and Stansfield Turner, wrote books after leaving office, submitted them for clearance and complained that C.I.A. censors had removed harmless passages.
In a broader sense, growing secrecy has taken us away from the Madisonian vision of a Government accountable to the sovereign public. The result is a profound departure from the Madisonian -- the constitutional -- premise of accountability. For example, the Framers of the Constitution took particular care to assure that Americans would know how public money was spent. They wrote this exceptionally explicit provision into Article I: "No money shall be drawn from the Treasury, but in consequence of appropriations made by law; and a regular statement and account of the receipts and expenditures of all public money shall be published from time to time."
In violation of that clause, the C.I.A. and other intelligence agencies are financed in secret, with no published account of their spending. Billions of dollars more are spent on secret weapons projects in what has been called "the black budget." The claim is that secrecy is required by national security. But unwise policy also thrives in the dark, where there can be no criticism or correction, and so do waste and corruption. The hearings on Robert Gates's nomination to be Director of Central Intelligence showed that the C.I.A. had persistently exaggerated Soviet economic and political strength -- an analysis that would surely have been corrected if it had been subject to wider critical examination.
But the Supreme Court, when it had the question of the constitutional clause requiring public accounting of public money before it, once again deferred to the claim of secrecy, It held that members of the public have no standing to challenge the flagrant violation of the clause, so that guarantee has become a dead letter.
The American press has, on the whole, done well in recent decades from the Surpeme Court's renewal of Madison's vision. Emboldened by New York Times v. Sullivan, it has tried harder -- if not consistently -- to penetrate the surface of Government rather than accept official statements as gospel. The First Amendment is not much help when the Government closes off access to the facts, by silencing a source like Frank Snepp or keeping reporters away from the fighting in the Persian Gulf war. But when the press finds something out, the Supreme Court has said the First Amendment ordinarily keeps the Government from stopping publication. The Court allowed The New York Times and The Washington Post to print the Pentagon Papers despite Government claims that grave national security claims would be disclosed -- claims that former officials now admit were nonsense.
The conservative shift in the Supreme Court in recent years has not so far brought any fundamental weakening in the protection of free speech and a free press -- with one menacing exception. In the case of Rust v. Sullivan last term -- the gag rule case -- a 5-to-4 majority upheld a Reagan Administration regulation forbidding doctors in family planning clinics financed in any part by the Federal Government to discuss abortion with patients or even refer them to doctors who would. The precedent is worrying because so many private institutions in this country now rely on Federal funds; universities, public libraries, scientific laboratories, museums and other arts institutions. May officials in Washington now tell all of them what subjects may be discussed in their halls?
THERE CAN BE no permanent assurance of safety in the speech or press clauses of the First Amendment, or in any provision of the Constitution. We rely on our fundamental law, and rightly so, but history shows that the words have to be given meaning by each generation of judges -- and citizens.
But this is a good time to celebrate the First Amendment, for reasons quite apart from the anniversary. In a place and circumstances remote from what James Madison could have imagined, his premise that free speech and a free press make democracy possible has just had a dramatic demonstration.
The Soviet political system, which had ruled by repression for nearly 74 years, was overthrown in days. And freedom of speech and press played a critical part in those stunning events. In five years of Mikhail Gorbachev's glasnost, all kinds of independent channels of communication had opened up: newspapers, magazines, television and radio. The first thing the coup plotters tried to do was to silence those voices, but they failed. Boris Yeltsin broadcast on makeshift equipment from inside the Russian Parliament building. Newspapers somehow were printed. The facts got out. From them, and from the experience of freedom, people drew the courage to resist tyranny.
Speaking truth to power is never going to be easy, not even after 200 years. Indeed, the very idea of unregulated speech remains daring. "The constitutional right of free expression is powerful medicine in a society as diverse and populous as ours," Justice John Marshall Harlan wrote in 1971. But it is, as Holmes said, our great experiment.

HEADLINE: The Seven Days of Kwanzaa

BYLINE: By ERIC V. COPAGE; ERIC V. COPAGE, an editor with The New York Times Magazine and a member of the steering committee of the New York Kwanzaa celebration, is the author of "Kwanzaa: An African-America Celebration of Culture and Cooking" (Morrow).

 BODY:
ON the day after Christmas 25 years ago, a small group of black Americans in Los Angeles began a nonreligious seven-day celebration commemorating black culture worldwide, particularly the importance of the black community and family.
Since that first unassuming observance, Kwanzaa, which means "first fruits of the harvest" in Swahili, has been adapted into the holiday celebrations in some manner by more than five million African-Americans. And with increasing frequency small, community-oriented events have been paralleled by lavish festivals held at colleges and universities, museums and public institutions across the United States. 
 "Kwanzaa fills a gap," said Larry Crowe, manager of the African-American Book Center in Chicago, who has celebrated Kwanzaa since 1974. "Previously African-Americans didn't have a celebration in which we could recognize our strength as a people, where we could cite the best things about us and try to live up to them."
Kwanzaa is not a substitute for Christmas. In fact, most people who celebrate Kwanzaa also celebrate Christmas. The philosophical bedrock of Kwanzaa, which was developed by Dr. Maulana Karenga, chairman of black studies at the University of California at Long Beach, is the Nguzo Saba, a framework of seven principles for black people to live by all year. The principles, in Swahili and English, are: umoja (unity), kujichagulia (self-determination), ujima (collective work and responsibility), ujamma (cooperative economics), nia (purpose), kuumba (creativity), imani (faith). Kwanzaa is a time to rededicate one's efforts to putting those principles into daily practice. A black, red or green candle on a seven-branched candelabrum is lighted on each of the seven days of Kwanzaa, and each day a family member discusses one of the principles. Deborah Graham, public events manager of the Missouri Botanical Garden in St. Louis, said the garden decided to sponsor its first Kwanzaa celebration this year after a study showed that many people in the city, which is 49 percent black, hungered for more ethnic programs.
"We are holding our program on Dec. 28, Ujima, the third day of Kwanzaa," said Ms. Graham, who worked with the St. Louis Kwanzaa Committee in creating the event. "Since that day focuses on collective work and responsibility, all programs require audience participation and help by parents." There will be jewelry-making, tie-dying and other workshops, as well as story telling that requires call and response.
A similar program will be held for the sixth year at the Arts Exchange in Atlanta. The first half of the five-hour event, to be held on Dec. 28, will include arts and dance workshops, and a workshop in capoeira, a form of martial arts created by blacks in Brazil; capoeira is so graceful that Brazilian slaves could, on the appearance of a slavemaster, make it appear they were dancing. The second half of the program will include an original drama with music about Soweto given by a professional youth ensemble. For information about other Kwanzaa celebrations in Atlanta call (404) 621-2686.
Travelers who would like to visit public Kwanzaa or pre-Kwanzaa celebrations -- which typically include the foods of black people all over the world, handicrafts and artwork from local merchants, dance and music performances, and books -- should tune in to the local black radio station, pick up the local black newspaper, or look for fliers in black establishments. In Washington, D.C., a 24-hour Kwanzaa Line provides continuous updates at (202) 310-1430.
Here is a sampling of Kwanzaa and pre-Kwanzaa celebrations around the country.
New York. -- There will be a Kwanzaa Holiday Expo Dec. 13, 14 and 15 at the Borough of Manhattan Community College. And on Dec. 27, 28, 29 and 30, there will be food, entertainment and Kwanzaa workshops at the 14th annual Kwanzaa Celebration at the American Museum of Natural History. For more information call (212) 219-4510.
Los Angeles. -- The African American Cultural Center, headed by Dr. Karenga, is holding a number of Kwanzaa events throughout December, one being the candlelighting ceremony on Dec. 26, where canned goods and blankets will be collected and distributed to the homeless. On Dec. 31, the Us Organization holds its Annual Kwanzaa Karamu, or African feast. Information: (213) 299-6124.
Washington. -- Dec. 7 and 8; Dec. 14 and 15 at the University of the District of Columbia's Carnegie Library. During the opening ceremony ministers from Christian, Islamic and traditional African faiths will discuss the meaning and interpretations of Kwanzaa.
Chicago. -- About 1,000 people usually show up on Dec. 28 for the African Market sponsored by the Ujamma Family, a black economic self-help organization. At the market, one can buy food, handcrafted items such as kente cloth, and listen to jazz or traditional African music. More information : (312) 994-1801. On Jan. 1, a program sponsored by the Chicago chapter of the National Black United Front will be held from noon and 6 P.M. in the International Hall of Kennedy King College. Information: (312) 268-7500, extension 154.
Philadelphia. -- The Kwanzaa Cooperative, a clearinghouse for information in the Philadelphia area, will sponsor lectures on Dec. 7, 26 and 28. On Dec. 26, for example, at Temple University, the speaker will be George A. Stallings, founder of the Imani Temple and the African-American Catholic Congregation. For more information call (215) 769-7324 or write Kwanzaa Co-operative, 1542 Fontaine Street, Philadelphia, Pa. 19121.
New Orleans. -- The New Orleans Kwanzaa Coalition oversees a communitywide celebration sponsored by local organization and businesses over the seven days of Kwanzaa. The celebration culminates with a Kwanzaa Ball. More information: (504) 561-0036.

HEADLINE: Clearing a New Path for T. Rex and Company

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS

 BODY:
Hall by hall, exhibit by exhibit, pterosaur by phytosaur, the American Museum of Natural History is shutting down the dinosaur dream rooms for renovations. Visitors have only until Feb. 1 to climb to the last of the dusty dinosaur halls on the fourth floor and pay their respects to such scarifying old friends as Tyrannosaurus rex, that intemperate but improbably beloved icon for generations of children.
But while old favorites are being systematically sealed behind plywood, a five-story-tall Barosaurus is being unveiled. On Wednesday, the tallest free-standing dinosaur exhibit in the world, the first of the museum's new dinosaur displays, will open to the public. 
 The looming sauropod, a dinosaur never before seen in any museum, appears to be trampling the 150-million-year-old landscape of the Southwest as it defends its young from an Allosaurus. The Barosaurus skeleton, 55 feet tall on its base, is a resin-and-foam replica, since the fossilized bones are too fragile to be mounted vertically to such a height; the original reptile would have weighed 25 tons.
The Barosaurus display is the drum roll for the museum's $45 million reorganization, restoration and replacement of its fossil-vertebrate exhibitions, the most extensive renovation project in the museum's history. Over the next five years, six more fossil halls will be unveiled.
Although some dinosaurs will remain on view during the redesign, there will be a serious dinosaur dearth in Manhattan until two new halls open in December 1994. When the renovation is finished the next year, it will be "the most important and comprehensive display of vertebrate fossils in the world," said Dr. George D. Langdon Jr., president of the museum since 1988.
Curators are marshaling new exhibition technology and scientific knowledge to present more than 700 fossil specimens in significantly different groupings -- according to shared physiological characteristics (what paleontologists call the cladistic approach) rather than a strictly chronological arrangement. In making such a change, they want to do nothing less than alter the way museumgoers think about their mammalian heritage. They hope to help visitors realize that mammals' lineage is as ancient as the dinosaurs'. The renovation also marks a rededication to the scientific mission of the museum. Instead of merely showing off the collection, the designers are trying to relate the new halls to research work conducted at the institution, which has a science staff of 200, including curators, researchers and post-doctoral students.
At the same time, the restoration is an opportunity to rediscover and celebrate a long-lost chapter in the architectural heritage of the museum -- a congeries of 22 structures built over 122 years. Architects are stripping away false ceilings to reveal original windows and ornate Victorian columns and arches of the Romanesque Revival halls, which were built in 1896 by Cady, Berg and See, also the architects for the original Metropolitan Opera House. In addition, the museum is constructing an eight-story library, on the West 77th Street side of the building, to house its 450,000 volumes, the largest natural history collection in the Western hemisphere.
If the renovation marks a rebirth for the dinosaur halls, the museum also hopes it will be a sign of regeneration for an institution that is the largest privately owned and operated science museum in the world. The stakes are high; the need for new donors and greater visibility in the competitive museum universe became painfully evident after city budget cuts last summer, when the museum suffered a 33 percent reduction in operating money (the city owns the museum's land and buildings). Nonetheless, New York City has committed $10 million to the renovation.
"It was very important for us to undertake this project as a symbol of how the museum is moving ahead," said Dr. Langdon. The museum felt pressure to exert more of a leadership role in helping to interpret the recent revolution in dinosaur scholarship to a dinosaur-hungry public.
"We wanted to send a message not only about dinosaurs but also about the future of the museum," Dr. Langdon said. "We think it's unparalleled anywhere for a museum to recreate six new halls in such a short time."
Dr. Langdon's urgency is driven by the desire to showcase a collection that is important not only for its scholarly excellence but for its mythical significance. Since the displays were unveiled at the turn of the century, they have been synonymous with the museum; the specimens themselves are embedded in the city's cultural history. They are symbols of evolutionary catastrophe, emblems of ecological mystery, artifacts of cultural ritual and, perennially, reptilian fantasy pals for visiting schoolchildren.
The fossils are also pawns in a great game, the objects of scientific debate in the controversial world of vertebrate paleontology. And, purely on an economic level, the dinosaur halls help draw three million visitors a year to the museum.
How do you tamper with such a celebrated exhibition? "Carefully," said Samuel Taylor, the museum's director of exhibitions. "We asked people, 'What do you love and what do you hate about the dinosaur exhibit?' And the thing that people love about our halls is that they haven't changed in the last 50 years. They were there when people first came into the museum, and they're old and stuffy and comfortable. But then we asked, 'What do you hate about the dinosaur exhibits?' And people used exactly the same words -- that they haven't changed in 50 years."
The reinstallation was necessary because the exhibitions "were physically old and the information about dinosaurs was really outdated," said Dr. Taylor. "We've long awaited a time when we could address all the problems in the halls."
With only a few dinosaurs on view after February, the museum is hoping that the titanic Barosaurus will close the dinosaur gap for much of the renovation. The cast of the giant herbivore, from the Jurassic period (208 million to 144 million years ago), will stand in the Theodore Roosevelt Memorial Hall at the main entrance, on Central Park West and 78th Street. The protective Barosaurus is frozen at the instant it begins to drop down in an attempt to crush the attacking Allosaurus with its massive front limbs.
The pose of the Barosaurus is scientifically provocative. "This is a spectacular mount," said Dr. Lowell Dingus, project director of the renovation program, "but we're trying to use it to make a point. Could this animal have reared up in this way to protect its young? Would it have actually taken care of its young? The entire exhibition will provoke these kinds of questions."
Although other museums have invested heavily in noisy, colorful, attention-grabbing computer-animated dinosaur models, "we didn't want to be entertainment-oriented," said Dr. Michael J. Novacek, the museum's vice president and dean of science. "We wanted to stay away from bells and whistles. We think the dinosaurs themselves are so alluring that they'll draw adults and children into the science of it."
Originally, the museum considered adding a new dinosaur wing, tacking it onto the existing museum. "But it would have taken too long to get it done, and we wanted to move ahead now," said Dr. Langdon.
The designers planned to build the new dinosaur halls "within a black box, so we could control the lighting and the exhibit environment," said Dr. Taylor. "When we began punching holes in the walls to see what was there, we discovered, to our delight, that all the original architectural detail was intact." A year ago, the museum decided to liberate the original architecture as it reinstalled the collection.
"Our guiding principle has been to open all the halls up to their former grandeur, and to let the architecture shine through," said Dr. Dingus. In the new Early Mammal Hall, the designers will expose the original cast-iron columns and 20-foot-high, floor-to-ceiling windows, some of which overlook Central Park.
The architect for the renovation is Kevin Roche John Dinkeloo Associates, which designed the master plan and new wings for the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The project designer is Ralph Appelbaum Associates. Hardly the least of the blessings they will bring to the new halls is that most practical of accessories, air-conditioning: for the first time the collection will benefit from climate controls to protect the specimens.
The new fossil halls will form a continuous loop so that visitors can experience the sweep of paleontological history. There are to be two halls of dinosaurs, a hall focusing on fossil fish and amphibians, and two halls of fossil mammals; museumgoers will begin in the new Orientation Center, where the logic of the rooms will be explained. The halls will contain interactive displays and exhibits examining evolutionary puzzles and the mysteries posed by fossil records.
The halls are designed to illustrate the history of vertebrates according to the cladistic approach, a choice criticized last year by Dr. Edwin H. Colbert, a former curator of vertebrate paleontology at the museum. Dr. Colbert argued that fossils should be grouped chronologically. But the new exhibition's designers defend the alternative system.
"The revelation of the cladistic approach is that our lineage is as old as that of the dinosaurs," Dr. Dingus said. "Mammals and dinosaurs probably arose at roughly the same time, about 200 million years ago."
There will also be new specimens to accommodate the cladistic organization. Among them will be a 15-million-year-old, bearlike carnivore, Amphicyon, shown at the moment it springs on its prey, the antelopelike Ramoceros.
Familiar specimens will be remounted to reflect scientific discoveries that have overtaken their original presentation. For example, Tyrannosaurus rex was mounted in an erect posture on a steel armature in 1910. "It's not impossible that T. rex would have been in that position," said Dr. Dingus, "but it wouldn't have walked regularly that way."
Now Tyrannosaurus will be portrayed in what is believed to be its stalking position: head down, tail up, moving at top speed. The head will be placed so that its ferocious skull looms just above the heads of visitors, "so they can get a sense of what it would have been like to have this thing coming after them," said Dr. Dingus.
More startling, the Brontosaurus, which has come to define the very image of the dinosaur, isn't really a Brontosaurus. It is most accurately called an Apatosaurus and will be so labeled in the new exhibition. The former Brontosaurus has been in place since 1905, but with the wrong head. Furthermore, when the specimen was first assembled, the neck of the Apatosaurus was too short, "so we needed to add several neck vertebrae," said Dr. Dingus.
Adding such vertebrae can be challenging. "The larger cervical vertebrae weigh 250 pounds," said Phillip Fraley, the supervising assistant in charge of rebuilding specimens. "The left femur weighs 850 pounds. We have to be concerned about the effect of dismantling the current specimens, which can be damaged even by the vibration of the tools that are used to take them apart."
For the museum's Vertebrate Paleontology Laboratory, it is a time of frenzied preparation. More than 1,000 specimens are being readied for their presentation in the new halls, or prepared for storage. "This a laboratory where one person might work on one specimen for six months, getting the fossil out of its matrix," said Jeanne L. Kelly, the supervising exhibition assistant. "So you can imagine how tight our schedule is."
The nightmare of many working on the project is, of course, the classic scene in the 1938 film "Bringing Up Baby," in which Katharine Hepburn, the madcap heiress, brings down the dinosaur skeleton assembled by the absent-minded zoologist played by Cary Grant. Said Mr. Fraley: "You tend to think about that scene when you do this sort of work." He smiled. Ruefully.

GRAPHIC: Photo: An Allosaurus, left, attacks the Barosaurus in a new installation at the American Museum of Natural History. (Keith Meyers/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Q and A

BYLINE: By Carl Sommers

 BODY:

Getting Super Bowl Tickets
Q. I would like to attend the 1992 Super Bowl but am wondering how to get tickets. Any help? -- Leonard Kudlack, Clifton, N.J. 
 A. Super Bowl XXVI will take place Jan. 26 at the Hubert H. Humphrey Metrodome in Minneapolis. Tickets are always difficult to get for a Super Bowl, as many are reserved by the National Football League and by corporations. But there are companies, which often advertise in newspaper sports sections, that sell tickets either as part of a tour package or separately. Here is a sampling.
Regal Sports Vacations, 3029 West 39th Street, Suite 3011, Indianapolis, Ind. 46208, (317) 291-9500, offers Super Bowl packages for $1,495 a person with two or three in a room. Included are three nights and four days lodging in a "first class" hotel (quality like a Sheraton, the company says) and transfers to and from the game. All seats are on the sidelines, not in the end zones, the company says. The company also offers a package for $1,199 a person, that includes lodging outside Minneapolis and seats that may be in the end zone.
National Travel Vacations, 916 Pleasant Street, Norwood, Mass. 02062, (800) 525-5009, offers packages, $1,899 a person in double occupancy, that include air fare, five nights at the Americinn Motel, in New Richmond, Wis., four Continental breakfasts, four dinners, transportation to and from the game, end zone seats, and tours of various sites in and around the Twin Cities.
Great Atlantic Travel and Tours, 518 Laskin Road, Virginia Beach, Va. 23451, (800) 888-8233, offers packages including game seats at three price levels: $975 a person in double occupancy, includes three nights at economy lodging, an economy rental car and end zone or better seat; $1,495 a person, with three nights in a Marriott or similar hotel, and daily Continental breakfast; and $2,150 also at the Marriott with daily breakfast plus airport transfers, pregame brunch, transportation to and from game, entry to the pregame gala and a game souvenir.
Murray's Tickets, 740 West King Boulevard, Los Angeles, Calif. 90037, (800) 333-9336, sells tickets separately, from $650 on the end zone to $1,500 for near midfield. Packages including three nights at the Country Suites by Carlson hotel, daily breakfast, pregame brunch, and end-zone seat are $1,649 a person in double occupancy.
 
 
Volunteering on Vacation
 Q. Six of us in our late 50's or early 60's would like to volunteer our labor for a short time doing something like painting where we could work together in exchange for food and possibly board. One of us is a skilled craftsman. -- Nancy Strong, Newtown, Pa.
A. One possibility is Habitat for Humanity International, 121 Habitat Street, Americus, Ga. 31709, (912) 924-6935, which builds and rehabilitates housing for low-income people in the United States and abroad. Domestic projects are organized by more than 680 local affiliates in all 50 states; the central organization will supply a directory (ask for affiliate placement) and you can check with affiliates that interest you. Housing and meals are also arranged locally, often through churches, and a donation of $50 to $200 a person may be asked. The Americus office organizes foreign visits, mainly in Central America, Africa and Asia, sending groups of 10 to 15 people for projects lasting 10 days to three weeks. The participants may live together in pension-type arrangements or be put up in local homes. The cost for a two-week work camp in Latin America averages $900 to $1,000 a person, and for three weeks in Africa or Asia, $2,000 to $2,500; the cost includes air fare, lodging and meals and a contribution toward the materials for the home being built.
The Council on International Educational Exchange organizes work camps, in which about 10 volunteers from different countries serve two or three weeks on a community service project in the United States or abroad. Examples include building a community center or playground or renovating low-income housing. The groups are provided with a place to live together, and the group itself works out arrangements for cooking and other chores. The council says that most volunteers on these projects are in their early 20's, though older people often enjoy living and working with the younger ones. More information: C.I.E.E., 205 East 42d Street, New York, N.Y. 10017; (212) 661-1414, extension 1131.
The council publishes a book, "Volunteer!," that describes more than 170 organizations in the United States and abroad with opportunities for service. The book can be ordered from the Publication Department of C.I.E.E. at the address above. Orders must contain a check or money order for $8.95 plus $1.50 for mailing book rate or $3 first class.
 
 
Vermont to Montreal by Rail
 Q. I saw a map that indicated Amtrak stops at White River Junction and Montpelier, Vt. on a route up to Montreal. However, the Amtrak clerks say there is no such route, nor is there one on the Amtrak schedule map. Is there such a route? -- Frank C. Eckmair, Buffalo
A. There is a train, running between Washington and Montreal, that makes stops in Vermont. It is the Montrealer, which, heading north, stops in Brattleboro and Bellows Falls, Vt., Claremont, N.H., and then back in Vermont, in White River, Montpelier, Waterbury and Burlington. The northbound train -- ask for No. 60 if the clerk cannot identify it -- leaves Washington daily at 4:10 P.M., stopping at New York at 8:20 P.M., White River Junction at 5 A.M. and Montpelier at 6:15 A.M., reaching Montreal at 10:45 A.M. The southbound train, No. 61, leaves Montreal daily at 5:10 P.M., stopping at Montpelier at 9:15 P.M. and White River Junction at 10:40 P.M., arriving at New York at 7:24 A.M. and Washington at 11:36 A.M.
Train service on part of the route was halted in April 1987 because of poor track in some sections, and buses carried passengers between Springfield, Mass., and Burlington, Vt. Trains returned to the route in July 1989.
A ticket from Washington to Montreal is $98, plus $93 for a roomette or $152 for a bedroom. From New York to Montreal, the cost is $67, plus $69 for a roomette or $117 for bedroom. More information: (800) 872-7245.
 
 
Rain in Spain?
 Q. I will be in Spain during January, a week each in Madrid, Barcelona and Andalusia. What kind of weather can I expect? -- R. L. Cohen, Long Island City, Queens
A. In January, the average daily high in Madrid is 47 degrees and the low is 35. In Barcelona, the high averages 55 and the low, 43. In Andalusia, Seville has an average high of 59 and a low of 42. The weather is relatively dry. Madrid and Seville average eight rainy days in January and Barcelona, five. New York has 12 rainy days in an average January.

HEADLINE: Q and A

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:

Right to New Windows
 
Question: I am one of several tenants who chose not to buy when our building was converted to a co-op. Recently the apartment owners were offered an opportunity to buy double-glazed windows through one source at a discount. New windows are badly needed to block the cold and decrease street noise.
Some of the rental tenants asked to be allowed to buy new windows but have been refused. As rent-stabilized tenants, do we have the right to be able to buy new windows? . . . Brian Glasser, Manhattan 

Answer: Maybe. Joseph D'Agosta, an assistant commissioner with the state's Division of Housing and Community Renewal, said your possible right to the new windows would not be covered in the rent code.
"The rules that mandate equal treatment and services have not been violated here," he said."There has not been a reduction in services or facilities and the landlord would not be required provide new windows."
A provision of the New York State General Business Law (Sec. 352 eeee) says that "managing agents shall provide nonpurchasing tenants all services and facilities as required by law on a nondiscriminatory basis." The state Attorney General's office expressed uncertainty whether this rule would apply.
 
An Overflowing Creek
 
Question: My house is about 25 yards from a creek. Several years ago the town put a corrugated pipe in the creek and covered the land in preparation for development. Since then the creek has backed up whenever there are heavy rains, flooding my property. Would I have a claim against the town for some sort of tax adjustment or reimbursement for the damage? . . .Theodore Hoogenboom, West Islip, L.I.
 
Answer: Maybe. Guy W. Germano, a Uniondale, L.I., lawyer specializing in real estate matters, said that in general a municipality in New York may be held liable for acts that damage private property. However, your claim may be too late because under the General Municipal Law, (sec.50-i) suits against a town must be begun within one year and 90 days of "the happening of the event upon which the claim is based." The New York Court of Appeals, Mr. Germano said, has interpreted this to refer to the act of the municipality and not to the cuse of action. In your case, the statute of limitations began to run when the town installed the pipe.
"As to the possible reduction in assessment," said Mr. Germano, "the owner must establish, by the expert testimony of an appraiser that the flooding has caused an actual reduction in the property's value."
A grievance concerning property assessment in Suffolk County must be filed with the Board of Assessment Review of the town in which the property is located by the third Tuesday in May.
 
Lien Against Co-op Shares
 
Question: I own a co-op apartment. A rupture of the plumbing in the walls of my apartment caused damage to the apartment below. The co-op board claims I am responsible for paying for the repair work. I have refused because the problem was not due to my negligence. But the board has put a lien against my stock certificates. Is this legal? . . . Wei Mon Auyoung, the Bronx
 
Answer: Maybe. Philip Sharfstein, a lawyer specializing in real estate matters, said the by-laws of co-ops typically provide that the corporation has the right to put a lien on shares for any indebtedness it is owed by a shareholder. However, proprietary leases of most co-ops say that the co-op is responsible for repairs to pipes within walls. The exception, Mr. Sharfstein said, would be if the pipes were installed by the shareholder or if the internal leak was caused by the shareholder.
"If the shareholder is responsible for the broken pipe," said Mr. Sharfstein, "the cost incurred by the co-op in making the repair may be charged to the shareholder together with interest."
Mr. Sharfstein suggested that if you feel the repair cost should not be yours you consult a lawyer and review the co-op's casualty insurance policy and any policy you may have.

HEADLINE: Perspectives: Housing the Dependent;
Times Square Hotel as the Biggest S.R.O.

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
METAMORPHOSIS is under way once again at the Times Square Hotel, on the northeast corner of 43d Street and Eighth Avenue. It has housed tourists and the poor, transients and low-income workers, welfare tenants and the frail elderly. It has had problems.
Now the partially occupied hotel is in the midst of reconstruction into a permanent residence for low-income single adults, including many dependent on a high level of social services. With 652 rooms, it is more than three times larger than any other project financed by the city's S.R.O. Loan Fund. A $16.1 million rehabilitation is under way. Completion is scheduled for November 1993, but new tenants should start arriving by next September. 
 A key issue is whether the nonprofit owner will succeed in attracting the significant proportion of unsubsidized tenants that its rental plan envisions. These tenants are expected to provide both fiscal support and social balance. With or without them, the project will be a test of how well a large building with a heavy concentration of dependent individuals can function in the sometimes turbulent Times Square environment.
The Times Square Hotel was built in 1922 as a tourist hotel for men, with 1,000 rooms. In the 80's it was bought by Covenant House, which provides housing and other services to runaway youngsters and owned neighboring property. Then Covenant House sold it to New York International Hostel, taking back a mortgage. The hostel company went into bankruptcy, Covenant House defaulted on its mortgage (from Charles Keating's Lincoln Savings & Loan), and the property fell into the hands of the first mortgagee.
That partnership, headed by Arthur Schwebel, who ran the building from 1962 to 1981, negotiated a sale to a newly formed nonprofit housing company, Common Ground Community Inc., which won the support of Mayor David N. Dinkins for city acquisition and reconstruction financing. The sale price was $9.5 million.
Mr. Dinkins approved the project over the objections of economic development officials, who were concerned over the possible impact on the Times Square redevelopment plan. Housing officials also had reservations, and insisted on substantial funding to assure against failure if expected rents fall short.
The Mayor's approval was a tribute to the efforts of Rosanne Haggerty, the founder and executive director of Common Ground, and her success in mobilizing support. A 31-year-old graduate of Amherst College, Ms. Haggerty was the director of the housing office of Brooklyn Catholic Charities for seven years before leaving to become a housing consultant. Working with Bruce Becker, an architect whose firm, Becker & Becker Associates of New Canaan, Conn., has designed S.R.O. housing for other nonprofits, she put together the proposal to buy the hotel.
"It is being called the 'mother of all S.R.O.'s,' " she said with a smile, although it is not a conventional single-room-occupancy building since all the rooms will have private baths and kitchen facilities.
The size does not faze her. "Covenant House had almost 700 permanent tenants and it wasn't troublesome until transient homeless families started coming in," she said. "We said, 'Let's improve the physical plant and the social services."'
Common Ground's rental plan reveals the challenge it faces.
LIVING in the building currently are 200 long-term tenants. Some are retired people with a steady source of income. Others are low-income elderly people who are probably entitled to housing vouchers and have been encouraged to come forward to report their income and obtain them.
Of the currently vacant apartments, 226 will go to homeless individuals from the city's transitional shelter system. Fifty of these tenants will be AIDS victims; 130 will be people who have a history of treatment for mental illness. Tenancy standards will bar any tenant with a recent history of drug abuse. The remaining 46 tenants from the shelter system will either be employed or in training for employment.
Finally, there will be a component of 226 new tenants who are not from the shelter system. Under the plan, 96 will be subsidized individuals with incomes under $15,600 (60 percent of median income for a single individual in the metropolitan area) and 130 will be unsubsidized tenants whose incomes will have to be below $22,700 a year (80 percent of median). These tenants will have to be willing to report their income even though they have no housing subsidy.
The expectation is that the 130 unsubsidized tenants will produce about $1 million a year in rent. Common Ground plans to use money it will raise through tax-credit financing to contibute to a substantial reserve to assure stable operations even if the unsubsidized rent projections fall short. The goal is $12 million to $15 million in private funding, made possibvle after a generous allocation of tax credits from the state Division of Housing and Community Renewal only last week. Also, the Department of Housing Preservation and Development has financed the project beyond the level needed for acquisition and construction. The total commitment is $28.8 million.
Will unsubsidized tenants be willing to rent at the hotel? Mr. Schwebel, the former owner, predicts that once it is renovated the building will be able to rent out 150 to 200 rooms at $450 to $600 a month. "I don't think it will be a problem," he said.
BUT doubters are not hard to find among people with experience in housing management. "It is not realistic to think that people will live in an institutional setting if they have a choice," said Robert C. Rosenberg, president of Grenadier Realty Corporation, one of the city's largest managers of lower-income housing. "And in a soft market they have a lot of choice."
All the rooms will have upgraded private baths and kitchen facilities. The rooms are mostly 110 square feet, not including the bath. The heating system will be changed to hot water from steam, sprinklers and a new fire-alarm system will be installed, all the windows will be replaced and the 7,200-square-foot lobby will be will be painted and restored. There will be seven-day-a-week, 24-hour-a-day security coverage at the entrance at 225 West 43d Street.
Common facilities will include a library, exercise room, game room, TV lounge and a 7,000-square-foot roof deck. But the city's housing agency insisted on fiscal restraint, vetoing, for example, a 15th-floor kitchen and dining room. Common Ground, however, hopes to be able to pay for this improvement with private funds. It would free street-level commercial space for leasing, Ms. Haggerty said.
There will also be 10,000 square feet of space unobtrusively placed on the mezzanine level as offices and program space. Columbia University Community Services will provide the tenant services under contracts with state and city agencies. There will be a fulltime social-services and mental health staff of about 40 when the building is fully occupied, said Anthony Hannigan, director of Columbia University Community Services.
Mr. Hannigan is a member of Common Ground's board of directors. The chairman is Douglas Lasdon, executive director of the Legal Action Center for the Homeless. Among the other members are Patrick Horvath, managing attorney for the Legal Action Center for the Homeless; the Rev. Donald Sakano, director of the Housing Development Institute of the Archdiocese of New York; the Rev. Laura Jervis, director of the West Side Federation for Senior Housing; and Ellen Baxter, director of the Broadway Housing Corporation.
The Times Square Hotel project calls attention to the S.R.O. Loan Program itself. It has committed $110.4 million of city capital funds since 1987 to create 2,680 housing units for single adults in rehabilitated buildings run by nonprofit operators. The long-term plan calls for spending $268 million by 2001, for a total of 5,700 units.
The city typically spends about $7,000 a unit to buy a building; it paid $14,000 a unit for the Times Square Hotel. The larger building provides economies in construction and operations that compensate for the higher acquisition cost on a unit basis.
Nine of the 10 projects currently in construction will produce 700 apartments, or an average of 78 a building. The 10th is the Times Square Hotel.

HEADLINE: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester;
Signs of Life Stir in Connecticut Housing

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
AFTER three years of recession, signs of recovery are beginning to emerge in Connecticut's home building industry. "The decline in the numbers of permits is leveling off," said Chris Cooper, communications officer for the state's Department of Housing.
Permits were issued for 1,049 units in October, still 5.2 percent less than in October 1990. "But we started 1991 with a decline of 20 percent," Mr. Cooper said. 
 Sales are spotty and buyers fussy about style, quality and price and are showing a preference for new construction. Kendall Green, a 34-unit town-house condominium on 2.8 acres that opened in Milford last month, and Sinnott Farm, a 66-lot subdivision being built on 80 acres in Bloomfield, are typical of what is selling, slowly but steadily.
Older homes and condominiums, according to RE/Max Realtors in Milford, Compass Realty in Bloomfield and real estate agents throughout the state, are languishing, perceived by buyers as overpriced and outmoded.
Theresa Dauscher and Dan Fearnley will move into a $119,900 town-house condominium unit at Kendall Green after their marriage in January. Primed for the cautious 90's, Mr. Fearnley said:
"We don't want to rent. We want to build equity and we want solid appreciation in value. We both work during the day, go to school at night, so we don't want a lot of house to take care of but we want the feeling of living in a home."
They liked the quality of construction at Kendall Green, the neighborhood setting and the Williamsburg colonial style.
Lining both sides of a landscaped divider, 13 buildings separated by additional landscaped islands will contain two 1,100 square foot town houses each. Private side entrances, at right angles to one-car garages, have dark-red paneled doors topped with handsome pediments.
The units contain a living room, kitchen with dining area and access to the garage, and a half bath on the ground floor. One bedroom, a study or second bedroom, bathroom and attic are upstairs. Central air- conditioning, all appliances, landscaping, maintenance-free vinyl siding and double-paned vinyl windows are included. Eight flats in two more buildings will not have garages, and after Jan. 1 the base price will rise to $129,900.
IN the Bloomfield development, among the buyers are Jackie and Brian Richards from Des Moines, who are expecting their first child in March. Transferred to Connecticut in September by Mr. Richards's employer, they bought a house for $129,900 at Sinnott Farm "after an exhausting search of the area," Mrs. Richards said. They will move in on Dec. 13.
The 80-acre subdivision offers homes on lots of up to a third of an acre, with free use of an on-site recreation compound containing tennis courts, ball fields and a children's playground. The Richards's house is indistinguishable, except for size, from other homes that cost up to $258,000.
A minimum of 17 smaller homes are to be integrated into the total of 66 houses as a result of a Fair Housing Compact devised by the Capitol Region Council of Governments. Bloomfield was among 25 of the 29 Greater Hartford area communities to adopt the concept, created as enabling legislation by the state's General Assembly in 1989.
Committed to build up to 205 units of affordable housing within five years, Bloomfield is one of the first communities to carry out the plan.
When sales at Sinnott Farm fell prey to the recession, the builder, the Stich Development Group of Farmington, applied for permission to build smaller, cheaper units. Using the Fair Housing Compact, Thomas B. Hooper, Director of Planning for Bloomfield, said, "we modified our zoning to allow them to construct up to one-third the total number of houses with half the original floor area."
To protect the value of the larger homes, buyers of the smaller homes are supplied with a Stich plan for expansion that is pre-approved by the zoning commission. In addition, the builder cannot leave any part of the structure unfinished at the time of occupancy. Style, materials and landscaping must be in keeping with the rest of the neighborhood.
The basic 1,250 square foot, two-story house has a living room with bay window, kitchen, dining room and powder room on the ground floor, three bedrooms and full bath on the second floor, a porch, one-car garage, basement, landscaping and vinyl siding.
"It appeals to all kinds of people," said Kathleen Rose, vice president of marketing for the developer. The buyers of four of six homes sold expanded the houses before moving in. "They can't overbuild for the neighborhood because of the preponderance of higher- priced homes up to 2,200 square feet," she said.
Buyers cannot be forced to enlarge their homes, but if they do, they are free to use Stich or any other qualified contractor.
MARY AND PAUL LAPOINTE, a middle-aged couple with no children, moved into their Sinnott Farm home in November after adding a family room, a fireplace and an enlarged garage accommodating a second car, pushing the price up to $152,000.
"Compared with other developments this was the highest quality home we saw at the most reasonable price," Mrs. Lapointe said. "The architecture is interesting, the countryside is gorgeous and the lots have a good deal of space between houses."
Stich will build more of its luxury line at Sinnott Farm, "but we will continue to respond to the demand for smaller, less expensive homes up to our zoning limit," said John Garrison, vice president.
According to Mr. Hooper, the town planner, "Stich is not making money, but they are surviving, paying their bills and keeping their people employed. And they are opening up the only market that's moving, in the high $120,000's to low $130,000's."
The Kendall Green developer, Richard Benson of Westport, believes that "condominiums must go back to being lower priced than houses, without sacrificing quality." Total monthly charges for buyers will be $913 to $1,041, depending on down payments, which range from 5 percent for an F.H.A. mortgage to 20 percent on mortgages provided by the Union Trust Company, which offers a fixed rate of 7.62 percent with one point on a 30-year mortgage.
"Union Trust has my land loan, so they benefit by making financing available and getting their money back," Mr. Benson said. "No bank would finance construction. I raised $900,000 from friends and family." Proceeds from sales of the first units will be used to build the rest.
"I'm voluntarily paying my investors 12 percent, more than the bank charges," he said. "It's worth it."
