HEADLINE: Sports Authority Draws Criticism On Bond Proposal

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO

 BODY:
A PLAN by the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority to ask the state to issue $416 million in bonds to build a convention center in Atlantic City, upgrade Rutgers University's football stadium and pay off millions of dollars of authority debt is drawing harsh criticism from legislators, taxpayer groups and local officials.
Critics see the plan as an attempt to have taxpayers subsidize the 20-year-old authority, which has been suffering from declining revenue at the Meadowlands Racetrack, its chief moneymaking operation. Others say the plan is a move by authority officials to expand the authority's operations. The expansion is unnecessary and ill advised, they say, in light of the state's precarious financial condition and the potential for a $1 billion deficit in next year's budget. 
 And some critics say they are troubled that the plan is probably going to be rushed through the lame-duck Democratic Legislature, a contention that some Democrats do not deny.
Authority officials, on the other hand, say that by refinancing the authority's debt at lower interest rates they will ultimately save as much as $170 million. And by including construction of the convention center and renovation of the Rutgers football stadium in the package, they say, they will create hundreds of jobs and millions of dollars in tax revenue for the state.
They add that any expansion of the authority's responsibilities is a natural extension of its role as a statewide sports and exhibition authority.
The controversy is being played out against the backdrop of cautious political manuevering as Democrats prepare to relinquish control of both houses of the Legislature to Republicans for the first time in 20 years.
"This is really a little scam on the public," said Senator Henry P. McNamara, Republican of Wyckoff. "And in the long run it's going to end up costing taxpayers more money."
Mr. McNamara said the proposal was little more than an attempt by the authority to get the state to use its credit to back the authority at a time when neither the authority nor the state itself was in sound financial condition.
"Everybody says that Giants Stadium and the Brendan Byrne Arena are making money," Mr. McNamara said. "I don't think that's even partially true." Mr. McNamara said that while the stadium and arena might generate enough money to meet their operating expenses, they were actually losing money if debt service on the money borrowed to build them was taken into consideration.
"It's like a guy not paying his home mortgage," Mr. McNamara said. "He can live very comfortably until he has to make his mortgage payments."
Mr. McNamara said the sports authority's only real source of income has been the Meadowlands Racetrack, and that, he said, has been faltering in recent years.
"Over the years the cash cow was the race track," he said. "But that cash cow has been milked for a long time, and racing has kept on dropping and dropping. And now they're getting into a cash-short position." As a result, Mr. McNamara said, the authority as a whole is a losing proposition.
Sports authority officials disagree.
"That's just not true," said John Samerjian, a spokesman for the authority. "Over the years the complex, unlike any other complex in the country, has not only paid for its operations and its debt service but has returned money to the state."
Under an agreement the sports authority has with the state, the authority has been paying about $10 million a year into the state treasury. Mr. Samerjian acknowledged, however, that the payments had been discontinued and that this year the authority would have to dip into maintenance reserves to meet expenses.
Mr. Samerjian said the recent proposal would enable the authority to compensate for falling revenue at the Meadowlands Racetrack. Decreasing attendance, he said, is a problem at race tracks across the country. New Jersey, however, has been hurt more than most.
 
'National Decline in Racing'
 "The national decline in racing over the last 10 years has been accelerated in New Jersey by casino gaming and the expansion of the lottery," Mr. Samerjian said.
Under the proposal, he said, $223 million of the $416 million provided by the state would be used to retire authority bonds that now carry interest rates above 10 percent. They would be replaced with bonds that would carry 7 percent interest, for a saving of as much as $170 million.
In addition to refinancing the debt, the authority would spend about $168 million to build a 510,000-square-foot convention center in Atlantic City. Officials estimate that the convention center project will create 6,000 jobs, generate almost $60 million in state taxes and add almost $200 million a year to the local economy.
The authority proposal also provides $25 million to be used to rebuild the Rutgers football stadium in Piscataway. Improvements would include doubling the existing seating capacity to 45,000 and installing new lights and concession areas.
 
Partnership Termed Essential
 Mr. Samerjian said the partnership between the sports authority and the state was essential in order to float the bonds to raise the money that was needed.
"We don't have the ability to do it by ourselves," he said. "We don't have the equity up front to do it."
Senator John H. Dorsey, Republican of Boonton Township, said the current proposal sounded similar to the authority's 1987 attempt to build a major league baseball stadium in Lyndhurst by floating $185 million worth of state-guaranteed bonds. That attempt, which was placed on the ballot as a referendum, was defeated by voters by a nearly 2-to-1 margin.
"It's kind of like deja vu," Mr. Dorsey said. "Except this year it's not a baseball stadium, it's a convention center in Atlantic City."
Mr. Dorsey said that the sports authority, which he said was having difficulty making ends meet running the sports complex, the Monmouth Park race track and the new aquarium in Camden, should not stretch itself any further by building a convention center.
"These convention centers are not terribly successful financial enterprises," he said.
In fact, Mr. Dorsey said, if the sports authority is losing money, "maybe this is the time to break it up and sell off its parts."
 
State Budget Problems Cited
 He added that with the financial problems the state was now facing, it would be economically and politically foolish to allow the state to underwrite obligations of the sports authority.
"I don't think the people in this state are willing to take on another debt-ridden operation," he said. "I would guarantee you that if this issue were to go on the ballot today, it would be defeated the same as the baseball stadium was defeated in 1987."
Both Mr. Dorsey and Mr. McNamara say they suspect that the proposal, which is not a referendum but must be adopted by the Legislature, will be quickly ushered through the Senate and the Assembly before Democrats lose control in January.
"This will all happen miraculously between now and January 12th," Mr. McNamara said.
 
Public Participation Requested
 Samuel V. Parelli, state chairman of the United Taxpayers of New Jersey in Cedar Grove, agreed that the proposal would most likely be rushed through the Legislature. He said he was angered that such a major decision could be made without public participation.
"Can you imagine the logic of allowing this bond issue to go through a Democrat-controlled Legislature that was just rejected by the people of the state of New Jersey?" Mr. Parelli said. "There has been no proper debate on this. This authority just sits down and says, 'This is what we're going to do,' and they don't have to account to anybody."
Assemblyman Chuck Hardwick, Republican of Westfield, who did not seek re-election this year, took a middle ground in the debate.
"I would be supportive of the state guaranteeing the bonds for the sports authority to refinance at a lower interest rate, but I think that adding Rutgers and the convention center is a mistake," he said.
Mr. Hardwick said that while he had "tremendous respect" for the sports authority chairman, Robert E. Mulcahy 3d, expanding the reach of the authority was Mr. Mulcahy's "self-proclaimed mandate."
"If he's got a mandate to build a football stadium at Rutgers, then why not at every other state school?" Mr. Hardwick said. And with respect to the convention center, he said, "I don't see where they have either the mandate or the expertise to go into the convention center business."
 
Senator Backs Refinancing
 Senator Laurence S. Weiss, Democrat of Woodbridge, who opposed the baseball stadium proposal in 1987, said he would not object to the state's backing the authority in refinancing its debt.
"I've known for a long time that the sports authority is in difficult financial straits," Mr. Weiss said. "I have no problem with the state refinancing these bonds, but I wouldn't want to see money dissipated in other areas and then have the state come along and have to pick up the payment out of general funds."
If he could be shown that the other projects contemplated by the sports authority could be self-sustaining, Mr. Weiss said, then he could support the authority's proposal.
In response to suggestions that the proposal might be pushed through the Legislature before Republicans take control in January, Mr. Weiss said that if immediate action on the proposal was necessary it would be taken.
"If Mr. Mulcahy can make a case for it and prove that this is the time for it to move, it will move," he said. "If it's going to get done and there's a good reason to do it, it's going to get done by Jan. 12. They can call it whatever they want."
Senator Walter Rand, Democrat of Camden, said he was already convinced that the proposed Atlantic City Convention Center would be a major success. His optimism is increased, he said, by the presence of the sports authority.
 
'Great Confidence' in Authority
 "I have to tell you that it makes me feel even more comfortable when I hear that the sports authority is involved," Mr. Rand said. "I have great confidence in that authority."
Mr. Rand said that from what he knew of the proposal, it made sound economic sense as well.
"When you can refinance $223 million worth of bonds which were at 10 percent for 7 percent, I don't have to tell you how right that is as a business decision," he said.
Fred Gruninger, director of athletics at Rutgers University in New Brunswick, is also pleased that the sports authority wants to become involved in rebuilding the university's stadium. The timing coincides nicely with the university's entry into the Big East Football Conference, Mr. Gruninger said, and a more modern stadium with increased seating capacity may make it possible for Rutgers to attract World Cup soccer.
Some local officials, however, are not happy with either the plan or the way they learned of it.
 
'I Was Outraged'
 "I found out about it when I picked up the newspaper," said Lucille Tyson, a Piscataway Township Councilwoman. "I was outraged. As a township official, I was not even contacted by any official from the sports authority to ask how the residents of this town would feel."
Ms. Tyson said spending $25 million on rebuilding the stadium when students at Rutgers were fighting to keep tuition costs affordable was both arrogant and unnecessary.
"Rutgers stadium is never filled, even on homecoming," Ms. Tyson said. "Yet they want to double the capacity when they can't even fill the stadium they've got. They should be using taxpayer dollars to provide better education instead."

HEADLINE: Catholic Schools Face Financial Strain

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
THE barbed wire on top of the fence is the only sign that this is an inner-city school. Inside, Our Lady of Good Counsel elementary and high schools are models of the Roman Catholic school system, spotless and brightly decorated. More than 1,000 scrubbed, uniformed students listen quietly to teachers who have spent decades instructing the children of immigrants.
The cheerful confidence that a visitor senses among the staff of the school belies the fact that Our Lady of Good Counsel and other Catholic schools across New Jersey are under severe financial stress. 
 The state's Roman Catholic bishops recently released a pastoral letter calling attention to the problems faced by the school system, including a perception that "Catholic schools are in their twilight" because of rapidly rising costs, changing demographics and low salaries, which affect the morale of many in the system. The real nemesis, the bishops said, seems to be a loss of will.
The letter, which was distributed throughout the state, said: "It is clear that Catholic schools are needed more than ever. They are not only graduating academically qualified students, but also young people with values and principles."
The bishops called for greater financial and moral support for the state's 481 parochial schools from Catholic families, government and corporations "as a matter of justice and a matter of principle." They said parishes that did not have schools should help support those that did, through regional agreements. And they said Catholic colleges and universities should do more to help.
"Now is the time for Catholic institutions of higher learning in the United States to return to the parishes in some small measure what they have derived from the religious othodoxy of the elementary and secondary Catholic schools," the letter said. "In this regard, these institutions can provide invaluable assistance in educating future schoolteachers of our state at minimal or greatly reducedcosts."
The problem of low salaries is one that Our Lady of Good Counsel has had to contend with. The basic salary in the elementary school starts at $14,000, which is $1,200 below the guidelines set by the Newark Archdiocese.
Sister Anne William of the Sisters of St. Joseph, the principal of the high school, said the pay scale was "the pits." She said the top salary she could offer, $25,000, was the starting salary at some public and private high schools.
Despite the pay, the school has been able to attract and hold teachers. Margaret Manning has taught second graders for 26 years. Several years ago, her daughter, Phyllis Sierco, joined the faculty to teach the other second-grade class. Mrs. Manning said the salary was not so important because her husband had a job.
"People ask me if I get bored, and I tell them no," she said. "Every day the children are different, the day is different and I'm different."
Elaine Hudak, who attended both the elementary and high school, has taught sixth grade for 20 years and this year took on the added role of vice principal.
"Many parents send their children here because they feel it's safer," she said. "It's an oasis in the neighborhood. I stay because of a love of teaching and the warm environment. The children are affectionate and willing to accept help, and the parents appreciate anything you do for their children."
She said the teaching environment in some nearby public schools was too hectic. "It's so crowded they are literally teaching in the hallways," she said.
Of the 481 Catholic schools in New Jersey, 401 are elementary and 80 secondary. They have an enrollment of 139,581 students: 101,658 in elementary schools and 37,923 in the secondary system.
At Our Lady of Good Counsel, tuition for the 582 elementary school pupils increased this year to $1,500 from $1,300, and tuition for the 439 high school students rose to $2,000 from $1,700. The increases may seem modest, but they were enough to force several families to take their children out of the schools and send them to public schools.
"They had to choose between paying tuition or rent, and they have to pay rent," said Sister Linda Lukiewski, the principal of the elementary school.
When Our Lady of Good Counsel Parish in the city's North Ward near the Belleville border opened its schools more than 60 years ago, the area was "an Irish bastion," Sister Linda said. Over the years, different immigrant groups have arrived, established themselves and moved on to other towns.
 
Built Own Church
 The North Ward's large Italian population built its own church, Immaculate Conception. Most Italian families send their children to a Belleville school, St. Peter's, she said.
For the last 15 years, Our Lady of Good Counsel has taught the children of a large and diverse Hispanic population. First, there were Cubans who moved on to Hudson County and elsewhere. Then the Ecuadorians, Peruvians and Colombians arrived, and today the classes are filled with children whose parents are originally from Puerto Rico, the Dominican Republic and other parts of the Caribbean.
The school was one of the first to receive no parish subsidy. The church is in debt, and the school is keeping itself afloat with fund-raising activities and tuition, Sister Linda said.
"Most of our families come from the Caribbean, where the church is considered rich and they are poor," she said. "They are accustomed to receiving from the church, not contributing to it."
 
'This Is a Great School'
 Zoraida A. Arocho has four children in the school from the first through the fourth grades. "This is a great school," she said. "If I have to get an extra job to keep my kids here, I'll do it."
Mrs. Arocho, whose husband, Edwin, is a bilingual teacher in the Newark public school system, said, "Discipline is the most important thing in every school, and parents would rather make the sacrifice to send students to parochial schools because the conduct in some public schools is so crazy."
She also said she wanted her children to have a religious upbringing. "God is important in our lives," she said. "The students see that it is important to their parents and their teachers, and that's why the teachers and students are so united."
Even though their public school friends sometimes tease them about their school uniforms, several students said they wouldn't want to transfer to public school.
"Catholic school is so much better," said Maxine Lyle, an eighth-grade student. "My friends in public school have no discipline, no respect for education, and come and go as they please. Here, they teach us respect and things that will help us in the real world when we have to deal with people from different cultures and backgrounds."
 
Teachers Close to Students
 Mario Vaccari, an eighth grader, also talked about a lack of discipline in public schools and said a friend of his was attacked and beaten while he was waiting for a bus after school. "They scarred his face, and security guards standing nearby did nothing," he said.
Mario Escobar, a member of the student council, said teachers were close to the students and always willing to provide extra help, especially to those having trouble with English. "In public schools Spanish students keep to themselves," he said, "but here Spanish and American are mixed and work as one."
Ruth Velastegui arrived from Ecuador two years ago but speaks fluent English. She learned the language in a Catholic school back home. "Catholic schools are for everyone," she said. "You learn a lot of different things, including respect."
The Newark business community, in addition to contributing to a fund that provides grants through the Newark Archdiocese, is also thoughtful about offering direct help, Sister Linda said. "When they're changing their offices, they'll call and ask if we need any furniture," she said. "All we have to do is send a van and pick out what we want."
Sister Anne said a company had recently paid for new carpeting and painting in part of the high school. Both principals said that without the outside help, including the textbooks from the state, they would have to close the schools.
 
$47.6 Million in Aid
 Melvin Wyns, director of school finance for the New Jersey Department of Education, said Catholic schools received $47.6 million in aid for programs, including transportation, nutrition, textbooks, special education and home instruction. To avoid any possible constitutional problems, the money is sent to public schools, which provide the services to parochial school students in their districts.
In July, Gov. Jim Florio signed a bill that would provide $10 million for nursing services in Catholic schools. Sister Anne said the money that Our Lady of Good Counsel would receive for the one nurse who worked in both schools could mean a year without a tuition increase.
In their pastoral letter, to buttress an appeal for more public financial support, the bishops talked of the Catholic school system's growth through the support of generations of immigrants and its service today to Catholic and non-Catholic residents of the inner cities.
"With any analysis at all, it is clear Catholic schools have been the victims of widespread bias," the letter said. "While paying lip service to the merits of Catholic school education, many public officials refuse to give the schools their fair share of funding. All too often the church is called upon to assist in social programs, ecumenical dialogues and even political endeavors, yet requests for reciprocal assistance in securing aid for Catholic school parents and students are consistently rejected."
 
Support for Vouchers
 Archbishop Theodore E. McCarrick of Newark, the president of the New Jersey Catholic Conference, the organization of the state's bishops, released the letter, which was distributed to encourage Catholics to pressure their elected officials to find some means, perhaps through tax credits or a voucher system, to support parents who send their children to Catholic schools.
Archbishop McCarrick said he was encouraged by President Bush's proposal for a voucher system that would enable parents to send their children to the schools of their choice. The pastoral letter called the President's plan "a breath of hope for the parents and children of Catholic schools" and urged parents to lobby their legislators to support it.
Some educational leaders, including the heads of the two national teachers' unions -- the National Education Association and the United Federation of Teachers -- oppose the plan, saying it will undermine the public school system.
 
Concern on Public Schools
 Debbie Scott, a spokeswoman for the New Jersey Education Association, echoed that concern. "We support the type of choice that would allow parents to send their children to any public school within their districts," she said. "But allowing them to use public schools in other districts or send them to private or parochial schools would abandon the bereft schools and leave their problems to fester.
"There would be less money to take care of the problems in the poorer schools instead of providing the support to help them improve. After years of neglect, some urban schools are struggling to improve their school buildings, and their programs and the President's choice program would create chaos."
Ms. Scott also said the teachers' union could not support an increase in state aid to private schools at a time when money for public education was cut this year below expected levels. "Some schools are still playing catch-up and have a long way to go," she said.
But Archbishop McCarrick said that each year parochial schools gave the state "the great gift of $1.2 billion," the cost of operating the schools for 140,000 students. "In these tough economic times," he said, "I don't think anyone else is walking into the Governor's office and, in effect, laying a check for that amount on his desk."

McCarrick of Newark, president of New Jersey Catholic Conference, released letter encouraging Catholics to press elected officials to find ways to aid parents who send their children to Catholic schools (pg. 17) (William E. HEADLINE: County's Builders Fault Rutgers Study On Housing Needs

BYLINE: By TESSA MELVIN

 BODY:
A LITTLE more than a decade ago, the County Board of Legislators released its first comprehensive housing plan, calling for 50,000 units of housing to be built by 1990. Partly because of community resistance and a sluggish economy, only 34,000 units were built, mostly for people with middle income.
Last summer, amid pressure to provide affordable housing for people of lower income and to determine a policy that defined affordable housing need, the Board commissioned the Center for Urban Policy Research at Rutgers University in New Brunswick, N.J., to assess Westchester's housing needs. 
 That report, released in August, projected that Westchester would need only 4,826 new affordable housing units before the end of the century.
While legislators said they were delighted with the finding, an organization representing 1,000 builders in the region has emphatically challenged the Rutgers report.
 
'Glaring Deficiencies'
 In a news conference Tuesday, George Frank, executive vice president of the group, the Builders Institute of the Westchester and the Mid-Hudson Region, said the report had "glaring deficiencies." The county has an acute shortage of affordable housing, he said.
"We couldn't figure out how the need for new housing units could be as low as 4,826 when we all know that very little affordable housing has been built in the county in the last 10 years," Mr. Frank said. "The numbers just don't add up."
The builders and their consultant said "severe" methodological errors in the Rutgers study made it "unreliable as a guide to the extent of housing need" in Westchester "or to the extent to which public intervention is needed to meet these needs."
The consultant, Alan Mallach, the Director of Housing and Development for Trenton, N.J., said the Rutgers report was based on a "low-ball methodology," which he said too narrowly defined the housing region, the need for housing and the relationship between need and supply in the region.
 
Regional Approach Recommended
 The Rutgers researchers said the county should spend less for new construction but more for rent subsidies and rehabilitation projects. They also suggested a regional approach to housing needs, with nearby counties like Putnam and Dutchess accepting some responsibility because they are part of the regional commuting pattern.
Based on these assumptions, they said that the region would need 9,975 new affordable housing units in the next decade and that the county's share of responsibility would be about half that, or 4,826.
But Mr. Mallach said this approach does not take into account the 21,469 Bronx residents who commute to Westchester. If adopted everywhere, he said, this approach would mean that "all of New York City's housing needs are to be met within the boundaries of New York City," a conclusion he called "highly tendentious."
Mr. Mallach went on to call the Rutgers report "at best a partial and selective look at the region's housing needs," because it excluded the needs of Westchester's 4,000 homeless people and countless others living in group quarters like boarding houses and looked only at those renters paying more than 50 percent of their income.
George M. Raymond, a Tarrytown builder, who originally suggested that the builders assess the Rutgers study, accused county policymakers of deliberately using limited information to influence the outcome of the study. "There is a clear desire," he said, "to reduce the housing needs in this county to a number that is doable."
County policymakers "have failed to support an aggressive affordable-housing policy by requiring less-restrictive local zoning policies," said Mr. Raymond, who has served as a court-appointed monitor of housing policies in New Jersey in the aftermath of the Mount Laurel decisions, which held that municipalities have an affirmative obligation to produce their fair share of affordable housing.
 
'Doable Numbers'
 Timothy S. Carey, who heads the Board's Committee on Community Affairs and Housing, which sanctioned the Rutgers report and who attended the builders' news conference, defended the Rutgers study. The legislators were not deliberately seeking lower and "doable numbers," Mr. Carey said, and to say so is "totally unfair and inappropriate." He also said the Rutgers group's methodolgy had been upheld in similar studies in New Jersey.
Although Mr. Mallach agreed that the Rutgers methodology had been upheld, he said it had been criticized by a number of fair-housing groups in New Jersey and that its conclusions had been accepted only because they can be periodically reassessed within the context of a statewide affordable housing policy. New York, Mr. Mallach said, does not have a statewide policy.
Last week, the Rutgers researchers responded with a five-page defense of their own, which said that most of Mr. Wallach's comments were of "little validity."
The researchers defended their exclusion of the Bronx as part of the housing region because they said 10 times as many Bronx residents work in Manhattan as in Westchester. They also said their study was not intended to include the county's homeless population.
 
Hearings Will Be Held
 "The Westchester study does not deny that there are additional households in the region with housing-cost burdens," the researchers said.
For his part, Mr. Carey cautioned that the Board of Legislators had not adopted a revised housing policy and that hearings would have to be held before they do.
"What we are seeing here is an interest group, the Builders Institute, acting in their selfish interest," Mr. Carey added. "They don't believe the numbers reached by Rutgers, and they want to justify building more housing."

PUB-DATE: December 1, 1991

SECTION: Section 2; Page 4; Column 3; Arts & Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 380 words

HEADLINE: PBS;
'Much More Than TV'

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In his article "Public TV Takes Its Nose Out of the Air" [Nov. 3], Mark Schapiro chose to ignore the very reason that, for nearly four decades, public TV has been -- and continues to be -- among the most valued cultural and educational institutions in America. Contributions are at an all-time high, and support from Congress, educational institutions and other sources are strong. The reason is simple: public TV is much more than TV. It is a unique, education-based institution supported voluntarily by the money and sweat equity of millions of Americans in their local communities. 
 Mr. Schapiro points out that a number of stations have suffered cutbacks in state financing. Fair enough. Public-TV stations are part of the local economy and don't enjoy or expect insulation from a state or national economic crunch. But with limited resources, they do wonders, providing some of the best general-audience programs in the world and educational programming to two-thirds of America's schools, colleges and universities.
Public TV's funding mix (individuals, government, corporations, foundations, educational institutions and other sources), which Mr. Schapiro criticizes as creating "a spiral in which programs are produced to satisfy these sectors of the audience," does quite the opposite. Beholden to no single funding source, it gives public TV an editorial independence that, year after year, allows it to air some of television's most hard-hitting news and public-affairs programs.
 
BRUCE L. CHRISTENSEN
President, PBS
Alexandria, Va.
Mr. Schapiro replies: Mr. Christensen and I are in agreement that PBS produces some of the finest programming on television. Series like "Frontline," "The AIDS Quarterly" and "P.O.V." come to mind, while the services it provides to schools undoubtedly make a significant contribution to education.
However, my aim was not to promote individual programs but to illustrate the political and financial pressures on the system. The point is not that PBS is pushing a particular "political agenda," but that its hybrid status as a public-TV system without a steady source of independent financing means that a strong pull is exerted on programming by large donors who hold the purse strings.

HEADLINE: MAKING A DIFFERENCE;
Questions of Perception

BYLINE: By BARBARA PRESLEY NOBLE

 BODY:
C. Boyden Gray, the White House counsel, may have some doubts about the efficacy of affirmative action. But Joshua I. Smith does not. "Affirmative action and set-aside programs work," said the chairman of the Maxima Corporation, a computer systems and management information company that is one of the country's largest black-owned businesses.
Mr. Smith may be in possession of more information than Mr. Gray: he has spent two years as the unpaid head of the Federal Commission on Minority Business Development, a panel established by Congress to evaluate business programs for minority groups. 
 Mr. Smith has traveled the country listening to stories from the front lines of minority capitalism. The commission will hold its last formal hearing in mid-December and then spend six months writing a final report. Mr. Smith declined to say what the panel's conclusions would be but did say that the Small Business Administration may need more funding to handle the many responsibilities that Congress has given it.
"Overwhelmingly, there is a very negative perception of minorities in business," said Mr. Smith. "Even in Federal law, minority businesses have been referred to as 'disadvantaged businesses.' That negative perception has to be turned around."
Mr. Smith, 50, brought to the commission his experience of building Maxima, a 13-year-old concern in Rockville, Md., by knitting together Federal procurement contracts. Like many entrepreneurs, he is a proselytizer for economic self-determination. He started Maxima after working as a consultant: "I thought if I was so smart, why was I so poor and making other people rich."

HEADLINE: MAKING A DIFFERENCE;
Russia's Wild West

BYLINE: By BARBARA PRESLEY NOBLE

 BODY:
When Igor Klioutchnikov, an economist living in what was then known as Leningrad, began telling friends and colleagues the city needed a stock market, everyone insisted he was crazy. That was three years ago, when the Soviet Union was in a dystopian holding pattern. Last May, the less-than-crazy Russian rang the opening bell on the brand new St. Petersburg Stock Exchange, of which he is now executive director and chairman. "Step by step, people realized we need a market system," Mr. Klioutchnikov said during a recent trip to the United States. "You can't have a market system without an exchange."
Exchanges of various sorts, mostly dealing in commodities, have emerged in geometric profusion as free-market fever advances through the Soviet Union and the former Eastern bloc, but St. Petersburg -- its pre-revolutionary name was restored this fall -- has a tradition to live up to. Before the Bolshevik Revolution, "St. Petersburg was the financial capital of Russia," Mr. Klioutchnikov said, sounding tired after spending several intense days on Wall Street studying computer trading systems. 
 He concedes that the St. Petersburg exchange is at a primitive stage. "It's more like a little bazaar now, not like an American-style stock exchange," said Mr. Klioutchnikov, who is 42. But it has grown to 500 traders from a handful at the beginning. And it has added a small number of stocks in private companies, commercial banks and financial institutions to the bulk of its business -- contracts for future delivery of commodities.
The exchange is advised by the Soviet-American Securities Law Working Group, a New York-based team that includes experts in securities regulation and disclosure law as well as the Soviet legal system.
Securities legislation is pending in the Soviet Union. The Saslaw group is recommending an American-style system of self-regulation and oversight, but it may take years to put it into place. "We have to be realistic," said Richard Bernard, a lawyer at Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy who works with Saslaw. "It's the Wild West over there now."
Despite what appears to be enormous economic chaos as the Soviet Union goes the way of the ice on the River Neva in early spring, Mr. Klioutchnikov is optimistic. "The old bureaucratic system is disintegrating and we are in a process of reintegration," he said, adding, "There is a lot of uncertainty, but also opportunities."

HEADLINE: 'Re-Parent' the Young Workers? Not on Your Life

 BODY:
In an article on the Forum page on Nov. 17, Morris R. Shechtman wrote that many workers in their 20's and 30's are still adolescents emotionally and are less productive than the workers of other generations.
He said managers should be prepared to deal with their young workers in the same way they treat their teen-age sons and daughters at home. By using a strategy of "re-parenting," he said, companies may be able to increase self-absorbed workers' productivity to acceptable levels within two or three years instead of the six or seven years that might be required otherwise. 
 Here are some of the letters received in response to Mr. Shechtman's advice.

 
 
Dated Practices


To the Editor:
Mr. Shechtman's premise that a significant number of working people in their 20's and 30's are "adolescents emotionally" and should be "re-parented" is exactly the kind of thinking that has helped to create the relatively dismal competitive posture of many United States businesses today.
The advice Mr. Shechtman dispenses -- do not tax employees' attention spans, do not give out more than one task at a time and do not accept any exceptions to the rules -- reeks of dated management practices that have proved highly ineffective for today's fiercely competitive business environment. Following are examples:
* The principles espoused by the scientific-management pioneer Frederick Taylor, who recommended keeping tasks very simple and straightforward and giving simple directions so there was no room for human error. Workers' reaction to this management philosophy led to the rise and spread of the American labor union movement.
* The paternalistic, we-know-what's-best-for-the-kids style of management. The response by employees and children to this style is "Well, if Mom and Dad know what's best for us, then we will wait for them to tell us what to do." This treatment by management yields a dependent, lethargic, stagnant work force.
* The "command and control" theory of management, which says the managers are the experts and will make the rules and create the directives for everyone else. This philosophy creates status barriers, low commitment and a lack of motivation to perform.
In my 13 years as a management consultant, I have encountered many emotionally immature employees in their 20's and 30's. But I have also worked with just as many, if not more, employees in their 40's, 50's and 60's who are emotionally crippled because of their insatiable need for power, control, status and stability. Stereotyping segments of the work force puts people in boxes, which are very difficult to get out of.
Given the strenuous demands, conflicting priorities and scarcity of resources that managers have to deal with today, re-parenting is not a legitimate job responsibility. Managers who are expected to watch the bottom line, delight the customer, facilitate technological breakthroughs and serve as quality gurus do not have the time or patience to develop the emotional acumen of the work force.
Building a competitive, flexible, talented work force can be accomplished only by treating all employees, regardless of age, like adults. In an adult work world, business must do the following things:
* Insure the right fit between employee and job content. If an employee does not have the skill and ability to perform the job, train him or her. If the employee is not trainable, someone made a mistake in hiring.
* Set realistically high performance expectations for everyone and ratchet up those expectations as performance improves.
* Allow all employees freedom to make decisions about the shape, content and context of their work.
* Encourage employees to "grow the job." As market needs shift and change, so should employees and their job.
If employees of any age are treated like children, they will respond and perform like children. If employees are treated as mature rational adults, they will respond and perform like mature rational adults.
 
DIANE RIGGAN
Norwalk, Conn., Nov. 19
 
 
The author is president of Riggan & Associates, a management-consulting firm.
 
 
Insulting and Demeaning
To the Editor:
Mr. Shechtman suggests that to increase productivity among young workers, managers should use "strategies not unlike those that you use at home with your teen-agers." Such a recommendation is insulting and demeaning to young workers and will only worsen a productivity problem that many managers unknowingly cause in the first place.
Today's young workers are collectively more educated than the young employees of previous generations, and they consequently have more confidence in their abilities and greater career expectations.
Unfortunately, many managers waste this young talent and ambition by providing recent college graduates with unchallenging and unstimulating tasks that require doing, but not thinking. This produces boredom and dissatisfaction, which cause the productivity and motivation problems that Mr. Shechtman erroneously attributes to "adolescent traits like self-absorption, lack of commitment and short attention spans."
If you want to improve the productivity of your young employees, treat them as you would your more senior personnel. Establish challenging, yet attainable goals. Provide young workers with responsibility and the commensurate authority required to meet objectives. And create a supportive atmosphere that encourages learning and initiative.
Indeed, young workers will rise above their expected performance levels if their work is interesting and the career prospects are encouraging. That is the key to productivity; re-parenting is not.
 
LAURENCE PLAWSKY
Plainview, L.I., Nov. 20
 
 
 
Lowering Expectations

 
To the Editor:
As a recent college graduate who has held several temporary jobs in the past six months, I realize I am expected to be mature and responsible on the job, no matter what it is.
Companies do not lower their expectations or make allowances because of my "prolonged adolescence." Instead, I am given projects, brief instructions and advice as to their completion and then turned loose. Often the feedback is minimal or nonexistent, as completing the projects is fulfilling my obligation as an employee.
Admittedly, my living away from home with partial parental support has forced me to grow up quickly and lose the "work as play" attitude pervasive among many people my age. Pavement pounding and interviewing taught me that employers want employees who are willing to work, learn and carry out assigned tasks with little or no feedback, not employees who need or want baby-sitting.
I believe Mr. Shechtman's suggestions on how to "raise" young workers will only encourage and prolong adolescent behavior and attitudes among young staff. By lowering their expectations of young workers, companies are effectively lowering the expectations they have for themselves.
If a project requires three people three days to complete, it should take no longer. Employers should not break up meetings and projects for the benefit of their young staff but should instead expect their young employees to adapt to their management styles, not vice versa.
The strategies Mr. Shechtman suggests will cause rifts within the office, as older employees may resent supervising and babying young employees who require constant feedback. Older employees who have been with a company for more than 10 years often do not wish to slow productivity so they can explain tasks and provide feedback.
Young employees should realize that much of what is done in offices is thankless and goes unrecognized unless done badly or incorrectly. If feedback or advice is needed, the employee should be encouraged to seek answers either through his or her own research or by asking a senior employee.
I do not expect to be "re-parented" in my job. Instead, I expect to be treated as a young adult who wishes to grow in a company and will fulfill expected duties.
 
GILLIAN E. COX
Boston, Nov. 17
 
 
 
Behavioral Triage

 
To the Editor:
Mr. Shechtman addresses one of the most important aspects of our steady economic decline: the prolonging of adolescence and its damaging consequences in work and business.
But the strategies given for dealing with this problem are pathetic. In effect, Mr. Shechtman suggests that corporations must act as a sort of day-care center, patiently coaxing productivity out of people who despite their advanced education and degrees are little more than spoiled children.
This is not a cure and it does not address the cultural source of this problem: the "entertainmentization" of America. What good does it do to perform behavioral triage on workers of all levels when television and movies continue to promote irresponsible adolescence as an ideal state of existence?
As Neil Postman pointed out in "Amusing Ourselves to Death," the power of entertainment has infected many aspects of American life. Its most damaging aspect is on the American character: our addiction to image over substance, our susceptibility to slogans over reasoning, our simple-minded pursuit and adulation of shallow "heroes."
Until those who wield the economic power in America come to realize that they have a greater responsibility for the larger society than for improving the performance of their companies' stocks, they will find their resources incapable of stemming the tide of immature workers, ethically blind workers, unproductive workers, illiterate workers, substance-dependent workers -- and all of those whose characters are currently being crafted by the massive power of the amusement media and who are the potential workers of the next century.
 
MICHAEL CANUEL
Brooklyn, Nov. 17

HEADLINE: Nostalgia With a Look That's Now

BYLINE: By ANNE-MARIE SCHIRO

 BODY:
Anna Sui's inspiration may come from a Balenciaga suit in an old magazine, from a Barbie doll's traveling costume, from a photograph of Lady Diana Cooper working in her garden or from a length of vintage fabric. Then her imagination soars.
The Balenciaga suit ends up with raffia fringe and ruffled shorts. Barbie's straw hat and cork-soled sandals become accessories for striped denim sportswear, along with Lady Diana's gardening gloves and a mammoth bumblebee pin. The vintage fabric, a bold print from the 1960's, leads to a revival of palazzo pants. 
 "I like using nostalgic elements and adding things to bring them into this decade," the designer said. "What I love is to capture an old feeling and have it still look good."
 
Youth and Wit
 Although Ms. Sui has been running her own business for 11 years, interpreting the latest fashions for the junior market, she made a breakthrough in April with her first formal show, at which some of the world's top models cavorted in her youthful clothes and witty accessories. Fashion magazines featured her clothes; department stores put them in the windows. Her spring show last month was equally successful.
"Doing fashion shows has taken me to another level," Ms. Sui said, sitting in her New York showroom surrounded by samples of her spring clothing and accessories. "Last year I did $1.75 million. This year I'm doing much better than that. The way the economy is now, I'm getting a lot of attention because of my prices."
She keeps prices down by using less expensive fabrics like denim and pique and by having the clothes made in New York, where she can keep tabs on the factories and correct mistakes before they become costly.
Her fall collection sold out quickly at Bloomingdale's, said Kalman Ruttenstein, the store's vice president for fashion direction, who put her black chiffon dresses in the window with Harley-Davidson motorcycles in November. "She probably offers more fashion for the price than anyone else at that price range," Mr. Ruttenstein said, "and the customer responded."
While most of the new generation of designers is selling jackets for $400 or $500, sometimes much more, Ms. Sui's jackets are $200 to $300. "Part of the fun of my clothing is that it's not so precious," she said. "You can enjoy yourself wearing them because you don't have to worry about damaging a $2,000 jacket. What's fun about fashion to me is that it's always changing, and what I try to do is offer a new thing that's affordable."
Her instinct for capturing the fashion feeling of the moment is apparent in the spring collection, which includes tweed suits and gingham baby-doll dresses, long slit skirts and lacy, lingerie-like lace party dresses.
"She touches on all the newest international runway looks and adds her own touch," Mr. Ruttenstein said.
Bruce Binder, group vice president and fashion director of Macy's Northeast, plans to move Anna Sui's clothes from the junior department to New Signatures with the work of other hot young designers. "She has tremendous creativity, but she's willing to work with a store and make changes for us," he said. "Her accessories are such fun we'll be housing them together with her clothes."
Accessories are one way she puts her signature on her styles. Tweeds, gingham checks and 1960's prints are shown with matching hats, bags and shoes. The hats are made for her by James Coviello, the bags by Jill Stuart. Eric Beamon makes beaded jewelry, which Ms. Sui describes as part hippie and part David Webb, in colors to go with the clothes.
"I love accessories and working with accessory designers," Ms. Sui said. "I collect jewelry and bags and hats, even though I never wear hats."
Her knack for putting together a total look comes from the years she spent as a stylist for the fashion photographer Steven Meisel, who has been a friend since their days as students at the Parsons School of Design. She left her native Detroit to study design in New York but left school after two years to divide her time between designing for sportswear manufacturers and working for Mr. Meisel. As his stylist she met star models like Linda Evangelista, Christy Turlington and Naomi Campbell, who helped to attract other models for her shows.
"Last November I took time off and did styling with Madonna and Lady Miss Kier," she said. "For many years I couldn't decide between styling and designing. It's kind of a youthful fantasy that you can do everything, but you have to learn the business you're in. Basically, the most important thing, I've learned, is to ship the clothes on time with good quality."

HEADLINE: Who the Rich Are and What They Should Pay

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Gideon Fountain, criticizing the slogan "tax the rich" (letter, Nov. 17), asks what income level defines rich, "so we can all laugh." 
 I'll give him an answer few will dispute: $200,000 a year. For 1989, 790,000 taxpayers -- three-tenths of 1 percent of the population -- reported to the Internal Revenue Service adjusted gross income of $200,000 or more, a total of $409 billion. They were charged Federal income tax of $96 billion, a 24.1 percent rate.
In 1979, 10 years earlier, there were just 94,000 of these rich people, charged an effective rate of 45.3 percent on their adjusted gross income. The effective rate on their incomes was thus cut more than 20 percent.
Putting a surtax of 20 percent of adjusted gross income on these people would now yield $82 billion. A more modest surtax, on those with incomes between $100,000 and $200,000, would bring the total gain to more than $100 billion.
Much of the extra income would come from the super-rich -- those with incomes of more than a million dollars a year. Their number increased nearly 100 times, from 642 in 1970 to 3,601 in 1979 to 61,987 in 1989. In 1989 their adjusted gross income was $159 billion, on which they paid $39 billion, or 24.7 percent. In 1979, the millionaires paid 50.2 percent on their adjusted gross income.
To restore the earlier rate would mean a 25 percent surtax on these people, yielding $40 billion more.
There's no doubt that halving the taxes of the rich and super-rich had much to do with the extreme widening of income gaps during the last decade and, arguably, with the financial excesses that contributed to our economic difficulties. Not to speak of the increase in the tax burden on average citizens to more than one-third of their incomes.
A modest tax reform, restoring the rates of 1979 -- before the big cuts on high incomes in the following years -- would bring in the indicated $82 billion, which would finance a great part of the much-needed outlays for housing, health, education, environment and infrastructure, while permitting much-need tax relief for those with middle and low incomes, whose tax burden has risen substantially during these same 10 years.
For Mr. Fountain's state, Connecticut, and for New York, such surtaxes on wealthy taxpayers, whether levied nationally and distributed through Federal aid to the states or levied in part as state taxes, would end the state budget crises.
 
VICTOR PERLO
Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y., Nov. 20, 1991

HEADLINE: Small Business's Borrowing Lament

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Wanted: An Investment-Led Recovery" (Forum, Nov. 10) suggests ways to use tax law changes to encourage investment. A real problem for small businesses, which do a great deal of the investing for growth in this country, is their inability to take long-term advantage of today's low interest rates. 
 Commercial banks do most of the lending to small business, lending for a maximum of three to five years at variable rates tied to the prime. What goes up comes down and what comes down goes up. We all know that. If we borrow today at a relatively low rate to improve our businesses, and the Federal Reserve decides to move rates back up, all small-business borrowers will be in the soup.
The Federal Reserve should encourage commercial banks to give small businesses longer-term loans at fixed rates with some relationship between the bank's total small-business loans and its reserves. Large corporations can borrow via long-term bonds at fixed rates. Small businesses should be able to do the same. If they could, many small-business people probably would move quickly to borrow, lock in low interest rates -- and buy.
 
DAVID KRASHES
West Boylston, Mass. Nov. 18
 
The author is president of Massachusetts Materials Research Inc., a group of independent metallurgical testing laboratories.

LENGTH: 1219 words

HEADLINE: November Surprise;
Bush Takes Hits From All Sides, Including His Side

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Maybe it was the series of open challenges to the White House from the ranks of House Republicans. Maybe it was the panicky pleas from Republican political professionals to do something, anything, about the economy. Maybe it was the signed op-ed pieces and the on-the-record quotes assailing White House political operations -- not from Democrats, but from Republicans.
Whatever the moment, something fundamental changed in Washington last month. President Bush, who just eight months ago commanded the approval of 9 out of 10 Americans, suddenly seemed incapable of keeping his own party in line. The stricken economy, and the President's fumbling response to it, exposed many of the strains in the Republican Party. The coalition that drove politics in the 1980's seemed exhausted and frayed. 
 It is too soon to tell whether the Democrats, sapped by a decade out of power, will be able to capitalize on the Republicans' troubles. But the New York Times/CBS News Poll released last week showed that Mr. Bush was paying a high political price, with his approval rating plummeting 16 points in a single month, to 51 percent. Intensifying the nightmare for many conservatives and old Reaganites was a simple historical comparison: His economic stewardship was given the lowest approval rating, 25 percent, since Jimmy Carter's rating in the era of stagflation.
A recession is always dangerous for the party in power, but this one may be particularly so. It was, after all, the promise of a new, growth-oriented economics, fueled by tax cuts, that helped oust Mr. Carter in 1980 and create the Republican dominance that followed. "Economics was the glue that held the party together," said a Republican strategist. "It was the one thing that yuppies and evangelicals could agree on."
The collapse of Communism, which was another unifying theme for Republicans, made the economics issue all the more important. So does the abortion issue. As Supreme Court action to limit constitutional protection for abortion rights appears increasingly possible, many Baby Boomers have grown uncomfortable with the Republican Party's strict anti-abortion stand. Without a strong appeal to their economic interests, how long will these voters stay with the Republican coalition?
Given such high stakes, many Republicans have been dismayed at Mr. Bush's nothing-too-hasty approach to the recession. They watched in horror this fall as the Democrats began leading the call for tax cuts while the White House preached caution and promised to outline an economic growth package in the State of the Union Message -- in January. Many analysts say there are sound reasons for not rushing ahead with tax cuts, but the Administration seemed unable to make the case that its stance was a matter of good policy, not simply confusion or insensitivity.
Representative Vin Weber of Minnesota, a leading conservative in the House, said his personal nightmare in recent weeks was that the President would veto a major tax cut package on fiscal grounds. "Then you've got the transformation of the two parties," Mr. Weber said. "Then the Democrats become the party of prosperity and we become the party of austerity."
The President climbed onto the tax cut bandwagon before Congress left town last week, with the two tax-writing committees scheduling hearings for December. But Mr. Bush's move came only after weeks of conflicting signals from the White House. And it left both conservative and centrist Republicans worried that the President has yet to find a direction on domestic policy. This is a flaw that can be easily overlooked during an international crisis, like the Persian Gulf War, but is glaring during a recession -- and terrifying to his fellow Republicans as the election year approaches.
Some 80 House Republicans sent Mr. Bush an open letter last week urging him to "end the current impasse" and "intra-Cabinet turf battles" over domestic policy and make Housing Secretary Jack Kemp, a conservative favorite, his domestic policy czar. While praising Mr. Bush's international leadership, the Republicans wrote, "On the domestic scene the American people see a stagnant economy and an uncertain future."
In an Op-Ed article in The New York Times, Representative Dick Armey, Republican of Texas, laid much of the blame for White House drift at the feet of John H. Sununu, the chief of staff, and Richard G. Darman, the budget director -- a view that is widely held in the party. "This situation is serious," Mr. Armey said in an interview last week. "The poll results we've seen haven't surprised me a bit."
Don Sipple, a consultant who works for many middle-of-the-road Republicans, says that he senses a nervousness among them as well. Health care and the economy are the issues uppermost in many statewide races today, Mr. Sipple said. "They need some air support from the President right now on those issues," he said.
 
He's No Reagan>
 A veteran Republican strategist, who spoke on condition that he not be identified, predicted that the White House would right itself. "Once he has a campaign team in place, the politics will end up driving the policy," he said. "They will tell him that certain governmental actions are necessary if he's going to be re-elected."
But there is a pervasive uneasiness in the party, a sense that Mr. Bush, while he has reached heights of approval that Mr. Reagan never did, nevertheless lacks Mr. Reagan's steady and irreducible base of support.
 
An Aging Coalition
 There is a sense, too, that the Republican coalition is not what it was in 1981. It is aging, and showing the signs of age that the Democrats once showed when they were in power. There are demanding constituent groups, straddling leaders, ideological wings that believe the leadership is betraying the cause.
Already, some conservatives are gleefully rallying round Patrick J. Buchanan, the commentator and former aide in the Nixon and Reagan Administrations who is considering a primary challenge to Mr. Bush.
Governing coalitions, of course, can hold on for many years after the first cracks appear. And it is not at all clear that the Democrats will present a credible and appealing candidate who can build on the Republicans' vulnerabilities. The New York Times/CBS News poll found, for the first time, that voters are evenly divided between Mr. Bush and some unnamed generic Democrat. But the real Democratic nominee will likely be a novice to Presidential politics, and the Republicans could always revert to the argument that served them well in 1988: that the opponent is simply too untested to entrust with the Oval Office. A Republican poll taker, Neil Newhouse, argued, "Voters are saying they want some changes. When push comes to shove, they'll turn to Bush to make those changes because they trust him. Bush runs better against any known Democrat than he does against himself."
Even with their current problems, few dispute the Republicans' ability to run a masterful Presidential campaign. Still, strategy and tactics can only go so far.
"I worry that they will say inside, 'Hey, we were 17 points behind Dukakis and we jerked it out,' " Mr. Sipple said. "I think that may be over-simplistic, that they're going to win because they're going to just damage the other guy."

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
In a Changed Pacific, U.S. Forces Remain

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE

 BODY:

Why They're Still There
Half a century after Pearl Harbor, and more than 45 years after the end of the war that brought United States forces into the Pacific in large numbers for the first time, the United States Army, Navy, Marine Corps and Air Force remain a diminished but still visible presence from Japan to the South Pacific, and from Singapore to Hawaii.
Although Americans talk regularly of bringing home the troops from across the Atlantic, they make this demand less often for Asia, whose relative power is only growing and from which an increasing number of emigrants continue to arrive in America. 
 If the Soviet Union has faded as a shadow over Europe, it has all but disappeared in the Asia beyond Russia's borders. Barely five years ago, Mikhail S. Gorbachev went to the Pacific port of Vladivostok to urge the nations of the East to look on Moscow as a partner in development. Who around the Pacific rim remembers that now? Instead, the nations of East and Southeast Asia, where Tokyo's World War II Greater East Asia Co-Prosperity Sphere is still etched in memory, see a steadily resurgent Japan strengthening its economic power in the region. They wonder whether China will be drawn into a race for influence in those vast areas around its borders. And unpredictable India could also join the ranks of the powerful.
The United States could not rest secure, American officials argue, if another power came to dominate the Pacific, because in Asia there are no alliances on which to rely, as Washington relies on the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. The United States is on its own.
The duties of the Pacific Command have evolved subtly over the years, from a warmaking and then peacekeeping operation to one that, in its own words, tries to strengthen "political, economic and security cooperation" among the nations of the Pacific rim and the Indian Ocean.
The United States stormed into the Pacific in the 1940's as a combatant. But now its presence has taken on a more neutral coloring, and if some nations in the region, like Singapore or Indonesia, seem less than happy to see the American profile reduced, it is because it serves as a useful balance or deterrent against the growth of other potential powers.
 
 
WHERE THEY ARE

 
There were about 383,000 military men and women in the United States Pacific Command as of March 1991, about 17 percent of all Americans on active duty. The command, headquartered in Hawaii and stretching to the Indian Ocean, covers half the earth's surface, an area of more than 100 million square miles, touching 40 countries and
eight American territories.
 
Except as noted below, most of the Pacific Fleet's 237 ships are based in Seattle, San Francisco, San Diego or Long Beach, Calif., including most aircraft carrier groups and ballistic missile submarines. However, Subic Bay in the Philippines is a major Pacific installation, with 130 ships docking there each year for maintenance and resupply.
 
The roughly 300 fighter, ground attack and reconnaissance planes noted below in the Pacific Air Forces are supplemented by far larger fighter, bomber, airlift, communications and other forces in the continental United States and Alaska.
 
The General Accounting Office estimated in 1989 that the United States was spending $16.8 billion annually on Pacific theater forces.

HEADLINE: THE WOLRD;
Iraq: A Clear and Continuing Danger

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Nine months after the remarkably well-executed Desert Storm operation, and six months after it became clear that the allies had imposed on themselves an incomplete victory, a new debate is rising in Washington. As an unforeseen consequence of President Bush's decision last spring to leave Iraq's future to the Iraqis, rather than press then and there for the removal of Saddam Hussein, Iraq has become a time bomb both for the Bush Administration and for the 18 million people living in increasingly desperate conditions under Mr. Hussein's rule.
The problem is made worse for Mr. Bush by the fact that this time bomb is likely to be ticking all through next year's election campaign. If the President needed any evidence, it came in a bipartisan letter signed by 17 senators last week putting the President on notice that "it is increasingly clear that Saddam hopes to use the looming humanitarian crisis in his campaign to end the international sanctions against his outlaw regime." 
 The President's response to the senators' call for swift but unspecified action was to repeat that his Administration is dedicated to the overthrow of Mr. Hussein, a still formidable task and one for which Mr. Bush still lacks a concrete plan.
When he asked his National Security Council aides to give him some military options, the council consulted the Pentagon, where the intial reaction was: There is no military option that guarantees the overthrow of Mr. Hussein short of a major deployment back to the Persian Gulf, with allied support and international backing for a full-scale assault on Baghdad. In other words, Desert Storm II.
But Washington is buzzing with other ideas, most of them involving Iraq's minority of 3.5 million Kurds, whose divided leadership is lurching toward a decision on whether it would be willing to launch a civil war against Mr. Hussein if it was granted a measure of allied backing.
But such help has pointedly not been offered so far; the reluctance of the Pentagon and the State Department to back a civil war militarily stems from a strong belief that the Kurds -- as they showed during their brief uprising last March -- would need a great deal of allied support if they were to be effective against the Iraqi Army. Such backing would be all the more problematical since Turkey, which faces a Kurdish rebellion of its own, would certainly oppose arming Kurds or providing rear area bases for a Kurdish-based civil war against Baghdad.
Some Iraqi opposition figures suggest smaller steps. They want Washington to ground Iraq's helicopter fleet and then provide inducements for the Iraqi military to defect in large numbers into Kurdistan, where a provisional army and government could be built to march back to Baghdad and throw out Mr. Hussein. One inducement could simply be food, since regular army units in northern Iraq, unlike Mr. Hussein's Republican Guard, are poorly fed and outfitted.
Another idea, this one from Saudi Arabia, would be for that country and the United States to jointly provide covert financing for small anti-armor missiles with which the Kurds could defend themselves against Soviet helicopter gunships and tanks. One problem, of course, is that any missile that could shoot down an Iraqi helicopter could also shoot down a Turkish warplane.
Gen. Colin L. Powell, Mr. Bush's chief military adviser, has consistently voiced the deepest reservations about the quagmire a Kurdish adventure could turn into, and he has tried to keep the White House focused on what he sees as the fundamental problem: Mr. Hussein's power lies in Baghdad and to remove him would require sending American military force in large numbers. And even if that were done, who would pay for it?
Though the Kurdish option has been thoroughly discussed and repeatedly rejected by Mr. Bush's principal national security aides, the deteriorating conditions of hunger, deprivation and terror in Iraq are only expected to intensify during the 1992 Presidential campaign. Heading into the first postwar winter, there can be little doubt that Mr. Hussein is upping the stakes in his struggle against the American-led coalition.
 
A Scent of Jonestown?
 In Baghdad, where this reporter spent 10 weeks in several visits over the last year, the defiant and anti-American rhetoric that Mr. Hussein re-introduced this fall has engendered a political scent of Jonestown, where defiance became its own end. The late Jim Jones, like Mr. Hussein, boasted that his people would commit any sacrifice -- in the Jonestown case, revolutionary suicide -- to demonstrate that their faith in their leader was truly righteous and absolute.
Mr. Hussein's record shows that he can be expected to continue fighting with breathtaking tenacity for his own survival. If his last weapon is the sacrifice of millions of Iraqis to the horrors of starvation and disease until the Western alliance is shocked into saying "Enough!" and relaxing sanctions, then Mr. Hussein will not hesitate to reach for this weapon, many analysts believe.
In large measure, he has already done so.
During a round of interviews in Baghdad last month with Mr. Hussein's cabinet ministers, each sounded the theme of defiance. Iraqis would eat dates and grass rather than "surrender" to the allies' dictates, Trade Minister Mohammed Mehdi Saleh and Oil Minister Osama A. R. al-Hiti said. With chilling determination, the Health Minister, Abdul Salam M. Saaid, explained that he was cutting off programs in which international relief agencies were distributing food directly to Iraqis because this was giving too much comfort to the consciences of the "good people of Europe and the United States." In other words, the minister wanted more pain, not less; in doing so, he showed that the Iraqi leadership is unwilling to play by Western rules of politics and war.
To date, the somewhat cynical consensus in the State Department has held that the American people would be relatively indifferent to Iraqi suffering as long as Mr. Hussein was clearly to blame for it. This consensus, however, appears to be breaking up as the election season draws nearer. The prospect of television images of starvation in Iraq while Mr. Hussein's resilience in Baghdad allows the Democrats to tag Mr. Bush with a major foreign policy failure has sobered Republican strategists. For some, the possibility of mass starvation in Iraq presents a haunting reminiscence of Pol Pot's purges in Cambodia.
Sensing the debate, the Kurds have already approached Democratic Presidential candidates seeking to find advocates for their cause.
In the end, Mr. Hussein's postwar strategy, geared as it is to insuring his survival at all cost, may present the Bush Administration with some frightful questions: How long can the United States stand by and watch millions of Iraqis slowly starve because Mr. Hussein's Government refuses to submit itself to the intrusive United Nations regime for selling oil to pay reparations? Can a leader such as Mr. Hussein, defeated on the battlefield but not conquered or forced to surrender, be allowed to re-emerge and threaten his neighbors with whatever instruments of vengeance he can lay his hands on?
If either question is answered in the negative, toppling Mr. Hussein once and for all becomes a matter of methodology and Mr. Bush may be impelled toward choices that, up to now, have seemed too unattractive to consider.

PUB-DATE: December 1, 1991

SECTION: Section 4; Page 4; Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1123 words

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Delay on North Korea Leaves Nasty Choices

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
For more than a decade American intelligence experts scrutinized their satellite photographs as North Korea, piece by painstaking piece, assembled a giant nuclear complex in a river valley just outside a small town called Yongbyon. From the start, there was little doubt what the pictures meant: Kim Il Sung, North Korea's aging "Great Leader," was pursuing a dream to build the bomb, a dream that dates to the Korean War.
But only now, when Mr. Kim is frightfully close to putting together a weapon -- three years at the outside, say the experts, maybe much sooner -- is the Bush Administration declaring that a nuclear-armed North Korea would be "the most serious threat to peace and stability" in Asia. With great fanfare Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d recently urged a reluctant China to join Japan and the Soviet Union in a diplomatic effort to isolate North Korea until it abandons its nuclear ambitions, no easy task when dealing with what is already one of the world's most isolated nations. 
 And there is the lingering, unstated threat that if North Korea refuses to relent, Mr. Kim's project might be ended with a quick, pre-emptive military strike. On a trip to South Korea 10 days ago, the Secretary of Defense, Dick Cheney, ordered a sudden halt to American troop withdrawals from South Korea, saying it would "be unwise to proceed with major U.S. force reductions."
But Mr. Cheney and his staff have yet to answer perhaps the most embarrassing question: What took Washington so long?
"The U.S. Government has been smelling smoke in North Korea for almost a decade, but did nothing until the fire began licking at the door," Gary Milhollin, the director of the Wisconsin Project on Nuclear Arms Control, which lobbies for controls on nuclear proliferation, told a Senate panel last week. Now, Mr. Milhollin said, the Administration has to choose between economic sanctions that he believes will have little impact and a military strike that seems virtually unthinkable.
"Only because our Government failed to take effective action for so long are we forced to choose between watching a country cross the line to A-bomb making and starting a war to stop it," said Mr. Milhollin, who suspects that North Korea may soon add plutonium to the catalogue of weaponry it sells to other countries. "These are not decent alternatives."
Indeed, the problem is compounded by the fact that the North Korean project may now be so far along that it is unstoppable without a considerable loss of face for the 79-year-old Mr. Kim. A giant plutonium reprocessing plant is about to kick into action; some believe it already has at low levels. So even if Mr. Kim accedes to international inspections, something on which he has stalled since signing the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty in 1985, it will be too late to know with any certainty whether enough plutonium has already been produced for the North to assemble crude nuclear weapons.
In part, Washington's dilemma is one of the unforeseen consequences of the unravelling of the Communist Bloc. When the Soviets propped up North Korea they kept Mr. Kim in check. Now they have no leverage. Everyone assumes that China, too, doesn't like the idea of a nuclear North, but it has warned Mr. Baker against putting too much pressure on Mr. Kim.
American officials offer a variety of reasons for not acting sooner, but the most compelling seems to be that, until international inspectors uncovered Iraq's huge bomb project, they did not realize how little one learns from satellite photographs. That is why Mr. Cheney is now demanding the dismantling of crucial facilities in North Korea, rather than simply more inspections. "There is no new evidence," a top Defense Department official said during a visit to Seoul, "just new interpretations, based on what we learned in the gulf."
But the gulf experience may have limited applications. South Korean and American officials sometimes acknowledge that they do not think a pre-emptive strike against Yongbyon is a real alternative, and that the North Koreans know it.
 
The Limits of Geography
 Washington and Seoul may rattle the saber -- early next year, as part of annual exercises, they are bringing in Patriot missile batteries, F-117 Stealth fighters and crack airborne troops -- but geography offers a strong argument for a different strategy. Seoul sits only 35 miles from the Demilitarized Zone that separates North and South, and the rest of South Korea is dotted with nuclear power plants that would also be easy targets in any retaliatory attack by North Korea's Scud missiles. Though South Korea is getting ready to buy anti-missile systems, officials say they would probably not have a chance to work over such short distances.
The unpalatability of military alternatives leaves the carrot and stick of economics, where the best hope lies in Pyongyang's dreams of aid from Japan. "We think the North Koreans recognize that isolation is not in their interest, but it is hard to know," said a very senior Japanese diplomat. "If we can find a way for them to abandon the program without losing face, and to gain diplomatically, I feel there is the possibility they would opt for that."
Already, Washington and Seoul have given Mr. Kim some room for maneuver. In September, President Bush announced the withdrawal of tactical land and shipboard nuclear weapons around the world. In October, American officials made it clear that they would go beyond that in South Korea, taking out all nuclear weapons. That made Seoul nervous, but President Roh Tae Woo was persuaded to also promise that the South would never develop nuclear weapons or even a reprocessing plant.
Some day early next year, maybe during President Bush's visit in January, South Korea is expected to announce that it is now "nuclear free." Meanwhile the Administration is considering some kind of inspection system that would verify that no nuclear weapons are stored at its bases. The only step it will not take -- one that Pyongyang periodically demands -- is the removal of South Korea from the American nuclear umbrella.
Last week, the moves showed signs of having had some minimal effect. Pyongyang issued a statement suggesting that it might allow nuclear inspection under a series of vague conditions. "The pressure may be getting to them," said a senior Japanese official. "Or it could be a ploy for more time."
Exactly how much time Mr. Kim needs has suddenly become a matter of urgent concern to Washington. Like everything about North Korea, the answer only raises more questions. "I could put six analysts in a room and get seven opinions," a top American military commander lamented. "The fact is, we know very little."
