HEADLINE: Yeltsin to Finance Soviet Payroll to Avert Bankruptcy

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Nov. 30

 BODY:
Faced with the imminent bankruptcy of the Soviet Government, President Boris N. Yeltsin of the Russian republic agreed today to finance the Soviet payroll for the immediate future and to guarantee sufficient credits to meet the minimal needs of the Kremlin.
The 11th-hour agreement was reached at a meeting of Mr. Yeltsin and his top economic advisers with the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, and the head of the Soviet State Bank. 
Only a day earlier, the Russian Parliament blocked an emergency request by the central Government to issue another 92 billion rubles, and the governor of the State Bank, Viktor Gerashchenko, said he had only enough money left to carry on two or three days more.
 
Real Control Shifts
 Today's agreement marked a recognition by Mr. Yeltsin that however keen his desire to halt the growing and threatening flood of rubles, it was simply not possible to choke off an all-union government that still formally sustains a large portion of the national economy, ranging from the military to the scientific and academic establishments.
At the same time, Mr. Yeltsin's action underscores that real control over Mr. Gorbachev and his Government has effectively shifted to the Russian government, which has signaled its intention to barrel ahead with radical economic change with or without the rest of the former union.
[American experts and officials said that the accelerating takeover of economic authority by the Russian republic might slow the rising economic chaos, and that it would not disrupt Western food credits and debt assistance. Page 20.]
Mr. Yeltsin confirmed today that part of his new assertiveness was a response to the possibility that the Ukraine would go its own way after a referendum on Sunday, in which Ukrainian voters are expected to show a strong preference for independence.
 
Pile of Worthless Rubles
 Speaking briefly with reporters today after his meeting with Mr. Gorbachev, Mr. Yeltsin reiterated that he could not visualize any form of new political union without the Ukraine, especially if the Ukraine issued its own currency. Experts agree that this would prompt similar moves by other republics, leaving Russia buried under a giant pile of worthless rubles.
"If the Ukraine issues its own money, the whole money mass falls on Russia," Mr. Yeltsin said. "What is the union without the Ukraine?"
Mr. Gorbachev has also strongly urged the Ukraine not to abandon the union. The Interfax news agency reported that he had discussed the subject with President Bush by telephone today, warning him that to push the Ukraine toward independence "would bring matters to a catastrophe for the union, for the Ukraine itself and for Russia, Europe and the world."
The White House confirmed that the conversation had taken place but would provide no details. Mr. Bush described the United States Government's plan to develop relations with the Ukraine, Russia and other sovereign republics, but not in such a way that would harm moves toward a future union, Interfax reported.
The exchange grew out of reports that Mr. Bush said on Wednesday that he was prepared to "expeditiously" recognize Ukrainian independence if that was what the republic chose. The announcement dismayed the Soviet Government, which has been fighting a losing battle to maintain some semblance of union.
The agreement between Mr. Yeltsin and Mr. Gorbachev today was the latest manifestation of the rapidly waning authority of the central Government, the growing recognition of the Ukraine's determination to become fully independent of Moscow, and the Russian government's adoption of stern economic measures under a new team of managers.
Though today's decision was largely forced by circumstances, namely the crisis in Soviet finances, it also confirmed Mr. Yeltsin's effective control over the entire rump of the central Government.
Though Mr. Yeltsin may not have planned it to happen quite this way, the entire thrust of his recent policies has been to assume all the main functions and obligations that had not been specifically delegated to the central Government, including the State Bank.
 
Money for Diplomats
 As of Sunday, the critical Ministry of Finance comes under Russian jurisdiction, and Mr. Yeltsin has announced his intention to close down most other central ministries. In recent days, Mr. Yeltsin has also agreed to finance Soviet diplomatic missions, which were threatened by the money crunch.
Officials said today's agreement was also intended to prod other republics into footing their share of the central Government's bills. Earlier this month, all republics except Russia had agreed to allow the State Bank issue more money, apparently satisfied to let the Kremlin continue printing rubles to pay salaries inside the republics.
But Mr. Yeltsin's plans for a radical economic overhaul depend heavily on bringing the ruble under control, in part by allowing the ruble's foreign-exchange rate to be set by the market and in part by drastically cutting the glut of rubles printed to meet the Kremlin's growing budget deficit.
The announcement of today's agreement gave few details. It said Mr. Yeltsin and Mr. Gorbachev had agreed to coordinate their budgetary policies closely and to meet the Kremlin's fourth-quarter expenditures "on a consolidated basis." Government officials said this essentially meant that all-union bills would be paid out of the Russian budget, though Russia would still expect republics to assume a share of the all-union debt.
 
'Substantial Cuts'
 The presidents further agreed to make "substantial cuts in spending." They said the measures would allow a "maximum weakening of the destabilizing influences of the budget deficit of 1991 and to lay the foundation for budget policies for 1992."
"If these conditions are met," the statement said, "Russia will be willing to shoulder responsibility for guaranteeing U.S.S.R. State Bank credits granted to cover the coordinated minimal expenditure in the fourth quarter of 1991. The amount of credits granted by the State Bank will be taken into account when dividing the internal debt between sovereign states."
Though the agreement formally covered only the last quarter of 1991, of which only a month remains, the arrangement was widely viewed as a dress rehearsal for 1992.
Speaking briefly to reporters after the meeting, Mr. Yeltsin said the Government's budget would be substantially reduced. But he added that salaries would not be cut and that Russia itself had taken on responsibility for the full payroll of military, scientific, cultural and budget organizations.
While the agreement resolved the immediate budgetary crisis, it also demonstrated Mr. Yeltsin's recognition that in seizing control over much of the central Government, he was also assuming the enormous burden of a highly militarized and largely state-controlled economy.
Much of the debate over Russia's economic overhauls has centered on the impact of deep cuts in huge institutions like the military-industrial complex, in which 60 percent of the Russian republic's industry is involved.
Backing away from the Soviet Government's bankruptcy today, Mr. Yeltsin showed that he was not prepared for the far-reaching social dislocations that would occur if the Government stopped functioning.
In another indication of the political risk inherent in overhauling the economy, Mr. Yeltsin's vice president, Aleksandr Rutskoi, today openly broke with the Russian economic program, and especially with the "program for the destruction of the military-industrial complex." Mr. Rutskoi, a hero of the resistance to the failed August coup, said he would resign if Mr. Yeltsin continued with the program.
 
Foreign-Exchange Rate
 Mr. Yeltsin's new government, however, seemed determined to continue with the campaign to bring the glut of rubles under control. Starting next week, Russian banks will lift restrictions on the exchange rate for the ruble, currently set at 47 to the dollar for tourists changing their money. Set free, the rate is likely to rise rapidly to more than 100 to the dollar.
The Russian Information Agency reported that Russian banks would stop paying out any rubles other than salaries as of Monday, and that salaries would be frozen. The measure was intended to put a lid on the number of rubles in circulation.
The agency also quoted a "reliable source" as saying that prices in Moscow would be freed on Dec. 15 and in the rest of the republic on Jan. 1. The report could not be confirmed.

HEADLINE: Region Around New York Sees Ties to City Faltering

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT

 BODY:
The cultural and economic links that bind New York City and the sprawling region around it are weakening, and as the two areas grow apart, residents of the city are far more pessimistic about the future of their community than are their neighbors in New Jersey, Connecticut, Long Island and Westchester and Rockland counties, the latest New York Times Poll shows.
Indeed, so attenuated have the ties between the city and the region become that half of all regional residents say events in New York City have "hardly any impact" at all on their lives. 
 While once the region was dotted with bedroom communities that depended on the city for jobs, entertainment and services, they have gradually been evolving into increasingly self-sufficient enclaves. The new poll shows residents of the outlying region are twice as likely to work in their own county than in the city.
 
Spreading Urbanization
 As towns and cities around the region have matured and turned their back on New York City, they have, ironically, taken on many of the same characteristics that residents deplore in the city, and now many of the same problems and fears that affect the city afflict them too, the poll shows.
More than half the residents surveyed outside the city say, for example, that drugs are now a significant problem in their community, and a quarter say that AIDS is.
But even as the rest of the region begins to resemble the city more, the gulf between the way city dwellers and others view where they live, their neighbors and the services they receive remains enormous. Perhaps the best indication of this disparity is their differing visions of the future.
In response to the question "What's your long-range view for your community?" the majority of residents of the suburban counties say they believe their community will be the same or a better place to live 10 to 15 years from now.
 
Pessimism in the City
 In contrast, six out of 10 New York City residents say they expect their community to be a worse place to live early in the next century. This is the highest level of pessimism about the city's future that has been registered since poll-takers began asking this question in 1973.
In a striking illustration of a frame of mind, even the water tastes better to suburban residents than city dwellers -- despite the fact they drink the same water.
The New York Times Poll was conducted Nov. 2 to Nov. 12 and has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
As part of the wide-ranging poll, one of the most comprehensive surveys of regional attitudes conducted over the last decade, 2,550 adults were interviewed, roughly one-third of them from the city, and the rest from a 14-county area including Long Island, Westchester and Rockland Counties in New York State, Fairfield County in Connecticut, and nine New Jersey counties ranging as far south as Monmouth.
Margot Chase, a hospital collections officer who lives in the Bronx, was one of those surveyed who said in a follow-up interview that she thought the city would be a worse place to live five years from now. "Every year things get worse," she said. Housing and education, she said, were deteriorating, and the problem of drugs growing.
"To be in New York City," she concluded, "is the pits."
The poll shows economic worries to be pervasive throughout the city and its suburbs. Almost 4 in 10 city residents and 3 in 10 suburbanites say their financial situation has gotten worse over the last year.
 
Mistrust of Government
 There is something in the results of the poll to cause alarm to public officials in virtually every pocket of the New York City region.
For example, while 46 percent of New York City residents said local government corruption was a systemic problem, so did 39 percent of Long Islanders and 41 percent of the residents of northern New Jersey.
But New York City officials, it seems, have by far the most to be worried about. Not only were most city residents concerned about the future of the city and dissatisfied with its services, but also more than a third said their image of the city was "a bad one." In the surrounding counties, negative feelings toward the city were even higher; more than four in 10 said their image of the city was bad.
One suburbanite surveyed who said she had a negative image of the city is Connie Parris, who lived in Manhattan in the early 1980's and has since moved to Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.
"I've seen a lot of changes in the city in the last 10 years," Ms. Parris, a mother of three, said. "I see more crime, more homelessness. When I lived in the city, then I liked it. But I wouldn't want to move back there now."
 
Urbanization
Changing Face Of the Region
 The suburbs John Cheever wrote about, where the men took commuter trains to New York City and returned in time for cocktails, and a night out meant dinner and a Broadway show, exist more in the imagination than in reality.
These days, people who live in the New York City suburbs are more apt to work in their home county than in the city, and four in 10 see no need to go to Manhattan to attend the theater; they can do so, they say, closer to home.
According to the poll, 58 percent of the chief wage earners in the region outside New York City work inside their home county, while only 22 percent work in New York City. Thirty-five percent of families in those counties have a second wage earner, and of those, seven in 10 are employed in their home county.
 
Attractions Outside the City
 Leisure time is also being spent closer to home. Fifty-one percent of the residents of the suburban counties said they spent a day or an evening in New York City less frequently now than they did five years ago, a trend that may have been heightened by the recession. Only 14 percent said they visited the city more often than they did five years ago, and 32 percent said they visited it the same amount.
Twenty-six percent said that outside of work, they had not visited the city at all in the last year. Even shopping in the city appears to have lost its luster: city residents are more likely to go shopping outside the five boroughs than their counterparts are to go shopping in the city.
 
Fewer Ties
A World Apart Just Miles Away
 Spending less time in the city, the residents of the ring counties also feel less connection to its politics and its problems. Fifty-one percent of those surveyed said that events in the city have "hardly any" impact on their lives today, up from 39 percent who said the same thing in 1978.
The strongest interest in the city is found in Westchester and Rockland Counties. In Fairfield County, Conn., 59 percent of those surveyed said events in the city had "hardly any impact" on their lives, while in northern New Jersey that figure was 52 percent and on Long Island it was 51 percent. But in the Westchester-Rockland area it was a statistically significant 41 percent.
 
Fear of Crime
 Robyn Mittelsdorf, a housewife from Westhampton, L.I., was one of those surveyed who said she had not been to the city in the last year, and that events there had hardly any impact on her life.
In a follow-up interview, Mrs. Mittelsdorf, who was born in the city and used to take her four children to Radio City Music Hall, pointed to congestion and crime as reasons she no longer visited the city. "You just don't know what's going to happen there," she said.
 
Crime and Drugs
Suburban Towns, Urban Problems
 Residents of the suburban counties may increasingly avoid New York City, but they cannot avoid many of its problems: with the increasing urbanization of the region has come a sizeable dose of urban-style problems, the poll shows.
Thirty-seven percent of the respondents living outside the the city said that drugs were a "serious problem" in their community, and an additional 17 percent said it was "one of the worst" problems their community faces. In New York City, 32 percent of those surveyed called drugs a "serious problem" in their community and 32 percent more called it "one of the worst."
Twenty-nine percent of all suburban residents also called AIDS either a serious problem or one of the worst in their community, compared with 33 percent of New York City residents.
 
Worries in the Suburbs
 Increasingly worried about crime, 35 percent of all suburbanites say they worry a lot about people breaking into their homes, up from 29 percent in 1978.
One of those suburban residents who say they worry about break-ins, Martin Outlaw of Norwalk, Conn., said his neighborhood had grown increasingly dangerous over the years.
"I don't want my wife going out at night, even to get a pack of cigarettes," Mr. Outlaw, a corporate chauffeur, said. "I have to get out of bed and get them for her. This town is a nuts town at night. I just turn it over to them at night and stay in the house."
 
Concern Over Autos
 Yet people living outside New York City still feel far more secure in their neighborhoods than do city dwellers. Asked how much confidence they have in being able to walk in their neighborhoods without being bothered, 51 percent of all suburban residents said "a lot," compared with 22 percent of New York City residents.
Also, adults outside and inside the city still worry about very different dangers to their children.
Asked which problems affected more teen-agers in their area -- violent crime or automobile accidents -- 12 percent of suburban residents said violent crime, while 73 percent said car accidents. In New York City, 44 percent said violent crime, while 33 percent said automobiles. Adults outside New York City say alcohol is a bigger problem for teen-agers than drugs, while the reverse was true in the city.
 
Attitudes
Half Empty Vs. Half Full
 Perhaps the most telling differences between the city and its suburbs lie not in the problems, but in the levels of confidence. Even as the suburbs begin to experience many of the ills of urban areas, their residents remain upbeat about their communities, their schools and their futures. Residents of the city, in contrast, appear to be suffering from a kind of malaise that makes Jimmy Carter's warning seem understated.
The disparity in outlook between suburbanites and city dwellers is revealed in matters both mundane and profound. Asked to assess their roads, for example, 60 percent of suburbanites described the condition of the streets in their community as good or better, while only 24 percent of the residents of the city say that.
Seventy-three percent of the suburban residents rated their police protection as good or better, compared with 35 percent of city residents. And 45 percent of suburbanites said they had "a lot of confidence" that their children could get a good education in public school, while only 12 percent of city residents had such confidence.
 
Schools Faulted
 Joyce Billups of Queens was one of those who said she had no confidence in the city schools. Ms. Billups, a registered nurse, said her two older children had gone to public school, but that she would try to send the youngest, who is a year old, to private school.
"The money does not funnel into the schools," she said. "And very few teachers are devoted to teaching."
The disparity in attitudes shows up even where the services are virtually the same in the city and the suburbs. New York City and Westchester County, for example, share the same water system. But while 61 percent of the residents of Westchester say their water quality is good or better, only 50 percent of city resident say the same thing.
 
The Outlook
Divergent Views About the Future
 It is in their vision of their neighbors and their future, though, that city and suburban residents reveal their keenest differences.
Asked how much confidence they had that their neighbors would help them in an emergency, 60 percent of all suburbanites said "a lot." Only 32 percent of all city dwellers expressed the same faith.
Asked about their long-range outlook for their community, a majority of suburban residents predicted an upbeat or at least stable future. Twenty-six percent said they believed their community would be a better place to live 10 or 15 years from now and 39 percent said it would be the same, while 30 percent said it would be worse.
 
Confidence Dropping
 Among city dwellers, in contrast, the future was largely viewed with trepidation. Only 19 percent of all city residents expect that New York City will be a better place to live at the turn of the millennium, while 17 percent said it would be the same and 58 percent expect it to be worse.
The level of confidence about the city reflected in these figures is the lowest that has been recorded since the Times began asking New York City residents about their outlook in 1973. In that year, 38 percent said the city would be a better place to live in 10 or 15 years, 26 percent said it would be the same and 32 percent said it would be worse.
 
'The Place Is a Mess'
 One of those who said they expected the city to become a worse place to live, Charles Bissett of Borough Park, Brooklyn, said he believed many of the city's problems to be "insurmountable."
"The place is a mess," Mr. Bissett, a hospital administrator, said in a follow-up interview. "You see it everywhere. And I don't see the will or the way to really clean it up."
Mr. Bissett said that he thought that he would eventually have to move out of the city. "It's a shame, because I love New York," he said. "I just feel that a lot of things here are getting out of control."
 
 
 
HOW THE REGIONAL POLL WAS CONDUCTED
 The latest New York Times Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Nov. 2 to 12 with 2,550 adults, including 824 in the five boroughs of New York City and 1,726 in 14 counties surrounding the city.
Polling of the surrounding counties was organized with samples in each of four areas: 442 in Nassau and Suffolk Counties on Long Island, 429 in Westchester and Rockland Counties north of the city; 436 in Fairfield County in Connecticut; and 419 in the nine northern New Jersey counties of Bergen, Essex, Hudson, Middlesex, Monmouth, Morris, Passaic, Somerset, and Union.
The 14 counties surrounding the city are sometimes referred to as suburban even though some contain their own urban areas.
The new city and suburban poll was part of a broader project in which 3,212 adults were interviewed across the entire New York metropolitan region, including an outlying, more rural belt adjacent to the suburban counties in New York, Connecticut, and New Jersey. The project was designed so as to be comparable to a similar survey conducted by The Times in 1978.
The sample of telephone numbers called was generated by a computer, based on random digit dialing techniques. It was drawn by Marketing Systems Group of Philadelphia.
Within each household one adult was designated by a random procedure to be the respondent for the poll.
The results have been weighted to take account of household size and number of telephone lines into each residence. Within each major geographical area results have been adjusted for variations relating to race, sex, and age. Then each of the samples was weighted on the basis of population size to reflect an accurate balance between geographical areas within the metropolitan region.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20 the results based on such samples will differ by no more than a few percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all adults in the respective populations. For instance, the potential sampling error is plus or minus three percentage points both for New York City and for the surrounding 14-county area.
The potential sampling error for smaller subgroups is larger. For example, when individual areas in the region are examined separately, potential sampling error is plus or minus five percentage points each for Long Island, for the Westchester-Rockland area, for Fairfield County in Connecticut, and for the nine-county area in northern New Jersey.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the poll.

HEADLINE: In Brazil, Pessimism Starts to Keep Pace With Inflation Rate

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 30

 BODY:
Night after night, crowds troop across the marble and parquet floors of Brazil's former presidential palace here to watch a re-enactment of the suicide of President Getulio Vargas in 1954.
Written for history buffs, the gloomy play unexpectedly hit a wide vein of pessimism in modern Brazil. An initial run of three days stretched into three months as Brazilians watched their current President, Fernando Collor de Mello, struggle in vain with soaring inflation and a rebellious Congress. 
 Brazil's pessimism is all the sharper because of high hopes raised by Mr. Collor's election two years ago. Young, athletic and elegant, Mr. Collor made Brazilians dream again with promises to make the country a first-world power through free-market policies leading to low inflation, high growth and unfettered foreign investment.
But today, as Argentina, Chile, Mexico and Venezuela tame their inflation and resume economic growth, Brazil stands out as the major exception to Latin America's economic renewal.
Brazil's powerful Congress, controlled by opposition parties, shows little interest in approving tax bills and constitutional amendments intended to bridge a yawning, inflationary gap between Government receipts and Government obligations.
 
Rio Shops Are Looted
 Meanwhile, Brazilians watch their currency lose 1 percent of its value daily. Brazil will finish 1991 as Latin America's only nation with a rising, triple-digit annual inflation rate.
In Mr. Collor's first year in power, Brazilians' salaries shrank by 20 percent, a Government agency announced this month. Angry over the economic squeeze, street vendors and unemployed youths protested and looted shops last week in downtown Rio.
"Everyone took part in the economic miracle, now it's very difficult to accept a lower standard of living," Anna Veronica Mautner, a Sao Paulo psychoanalyst, said, referring to the golden years in the 1970's when the economy grew by an average of 9 percent a year. "Now we are in a denial phase. I deny my refrigerators are broken. I deny that I used to eat out every Sunday and now only once every three weeks."
Denial also takes place when Brazilian newspapers ignore a free-trade pact emerging between Mexico and the United States and ignore the recent successful visit to Washington by President Carlos Saul Menem of Argentina, Brazil's regional rival.
 
A Loss of Self-Esteem
 The latest slap in the face came from Chile, which historically clung to Brazil in a strategic alliance against Argentina. "Our goal is the world," Chile's former Economy Minister, Hernan Buchi, said, arguing that Chile should stay out of Mercosur, a Southern Cone common market. "Mercosur has countries like Argentina and Brazil, which together are only 2.5 percent of the world economy."
In a feat of diplomacy in Sao Paulo, Enrique V. Iglesias, president of the Inter-American Development Bank, managed to speak recently for half an hour on Latin America's "silent revolution," its free-market economic revival, without once mentioning his host country. Home to a third of Latin Americans, Brazil has the region's largest gross national product.
"The nation is living through a crisis of self-esteem that generates an ever greater pessimism," Roberto Duailibi, the head of a Sao Paulo advertising agency, said last week in one of two booster-ish newsweekly cover stories dedicated this month to optimism.
One optimist, Marcilio Marques Moreira, Brazil's Economy Minister, cautioned in an interview here Friday: "Brazil's psychology is pendular -- we swing from the Brazilian miracle to the Brazilian disaster. I believe the national mood is beginning to improve."
But a national crisis of self-esteem is most visible in the lines of potential emigrants that form daily outside the consulates of the United States, Japan and West European nations.
 
Thousands Move Abroad
 In the 1950's, the last period of mass immigration to Brazil, 590,000 people moved here. By contrast, in the 1980's an estimated 630,000, largely middle-class Brazilians, left the nation.
A survey by DataFolha in September found that 73 percent of the respondents predicted that unemployment would increase and 81 percent predicted that inflation would increase. Seventy-two percent said their purchasing power had diminished since President Collor began his five-year term in 1990. A poll by Ogilvy & Mather showed that "confidence" in the Government had dropped from 36 percent last year to 6 percent this month.
The number of companies filing for bankruptcy and the number of bounced checks are running at double last year's levels.
"We have something no one understands: recession and inflation at the same time," Joaquim Cabral, a Rio store manager, said as he stood among unsold Christmas baskets of liquor and snacks. To make a profit on the baskets, a traditional year-end gift here, Mr. Cabral said he had increased their prices 700 percent since last year.
 
Incompetence Is Charged
 With prices rising by 26 percent in November, Brazilians have resumed time-honored dodges to beat inflation.
On pay day, middle-class Brazilians flock to supermarkets to buy a month's worth of food. By charging purchases with credit cards, shoppers effectively get discounts of up to 40 percent because credit card bills come due as long as 40 days after a charge.
Next week, when a new 50,000 cruzeiro note enters circulation, it will be worth about $55, roughly half its value when printing was approved two months earlier.
"Inflation doesn't faze me at all," said Ricardo Frank Semler, a Sao Paulo manufacturer who was named this year's businessman of the year by Brazil's leading financial newspaper, Gazeta Mercantil. "Brazil has been in a hyperinflationary mode for seven or eight years now. Brazil is just having its development delayed by incompetence. The real question is, who can make things change? It's not the guy in power. Collor has run out of gas in his first two years."
Frustrated by the opposition-controlled Congress, Mr. Collor recently vented his anger.
One week, he called Sao Paulo's business establishment "cowards." The next week, he called Sao Paulo's left-wing unionists "miscreants." Most recently, he called a group of centrist members of Congress "spoiled brats."
"The big question is: How is this volatile personality going to play the end game?" said Thomas Skidmore, an author of Brazilian history books. "I think he is moving toward getting himself impeached."
On Sunday Mr. Collor told reporters that he did not expect Brazil to resume economic growth until 1993.
Much depends on the inflation rate. Many analysts here predict that after Christmas the President will decree yet another "summer package" of controls intended to rein in prices.
"The most probable scenario is that the Government will try to muddle through, going from one little victory to another," said Senator Fernando Henrique Cardoso, a centrist congressional leader who was one of the targets of the President's "spoiled brats" remark.
A good harvest and a renegotiation of Brazil's foreign debt, Latin America's largest, could bring economic relief next year.
"Brazil has to be compared to continental-sized countries like China and India; it is slower to turn around," said Mr. Moreira, the Economy Minister. He added that Brazil's Government had "a fighting chance" of lowering monthly inflation to 2 percent by the end of next year.
In a bleaker scenario, inflation could rise above 30 percent monthly. The street protests in Rio last week could presage wider urban revolts.
"The great masses would no longer have access to basic foods," said Helio Jaguaribe de Mattos, dean of the Institute of Political and Social Studies here. "Brazil would be shaken by great riots. Parts of the cities would be burned. The military would be called in to restore order."

HEADLINE: DUKE SET TO RUN, AN ADVISER SAYS

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30

 BODY:
David Duke, the former Ku Klux Klan leader defeated in the Louisiana governor's race two weeks ago, plans to enter several Republican Presidential primaries next year, a top adviser to Mr. Duke said today.
"He doesn't count on winning the nomination or anything," the adviser said. "But he wants to keep the issues alive, and he wants to have some influence on the process." 
 Mr. Duke is scheduled to announce his plans in Washington on Monday. Because of that event, the adviser agreed to discuss those plans only on condition of anonymity.
 
Given Little Chance
 Mr. Duke would be given little chance of defeating President Bush in the primaries. But he could prove more than a nuisance, challenging the President from the right and sounding many of the themes used by Mr. Bush in his 1988 Presidential campaign. Even during the recent governor's race in Louisiana, national Republican strategists complained that Mr. Duke had stolen their issues.
The Duke adviser, in a telephone interview, said Mr. Duke planned to file a declaration of candidacy with the Federal Election Commission next week. He said Mr. Duke hoped to qualify for Federal matching money to help finance the campaign. To do that, he must raise $5,000 in individual contributions of $250 or less in each of 20 states.
The adviser said Mr. Duke would concentrate on Southern states that will hold primaries on March 10, which include Louisiana, Mississippi, Oklahoma and Texas.
The adviser said Mr. Duke was considering running in Georgia, which plans to have its primary March 3, and in Michigan, which has a March 17 primary. But Mr. Duke has no plans to enter the New Hampshire primary, the nation's first, the adviser said.
In New Hampshire, Mr. Bush may face a conservative challenge from Patrick J. Buchanan, the former Nixon and Reagan White House aide who is now a syndicated columnist and television commentator.
 
More Than a Nuisance?
 Like Mr. Duke, Mr. Buchanan is not seen as a real threat to the President's nomination for re-election. But for a White House trying to rebound from recent political missteps and a stumbling economy, the challenges would be more than a nuisance, forcing Mr. Bush to engage in primary politics.
"We will oppose David Duke vigorously, no matter where he runs," said Gary Koops, a spokesman for the Republican National Committee.
Mr. Duke borrowed heavily from the national Republican organization's strategy in anchoring his campaign for governor on worries about crime, drugs, high taxes, affirmative action and the "welfare underclass."
With Mr. Duke in the race, analysts say, Mr. Bush would have to walk a fine line in dealing with those so-called wedge issues, which were powerful elements of the appeal that he, and Ronald Reagan before him, used to win the votes of the white middle class, particularly in the South.
Even in losing to Edwin W. Edwards in the election for governor two weeks ago, Mr. Duke left little doubt that he would seek a national stage for his views.
"The candidate may have lost," he said on election night, "but the message goes out loud and clear across Louisiana and across the country. The time has come to heal the liberal welfare system that is causing crime, causing poverty, causing drugs, destroying the very basis of our lives."

HEADLINE: Shaky but Resolute, France Is Gambling on European Unity

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Nov. 28

 BODY:
Troubled by doubts at home and shaken by its loss of influence abroad, France is gambling that it can find a new role for itself in a strong united Europe that can both compete with the United States and Japan and control Germany's expanding might.
More than any other member of the 12-nation European Community, France has emerged as the driving force behind the campaign for greater economic and political unity, which will be the focus of discussion when European leaders meet on Dec. 9 and 10 in the Dutch city of Maastricht. 
 President Francois Mitterrand has not minimized the difficulties that await the French economy. But he has argued that the country has no choice but to design its future in a European context. "France will grow through Europe," he said recently. "Its voice will be better heard."
Put differently, in a world abruptly transformed by the collapse of Communism, German unification, the Persian Gulf war and the emergence of the United States as the sole remaining superpower, France now sees a united Europe as its only hope of remaining a middle-ranking world power.
 
Leading Fight Against Britain
 At the crucial summit meeting in Maastricht, Mr. Mitterrand is therefore likely to take the lead in resisting Britain's efforts to slow down or weaken plans to enlarge the community's powers through creation of a single currency, a regional central bank and a common foreign and security policy.
For this, he is counting on the support of Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany, who is not only a convinced Europeanist but who over the last 20 months has given German backing to a series of French initiatives to accelerate the 34-year-old process of European integration.
Many European officials are already describing the Maastricht meeting as a high-stakes poker game between Mr. Mitterrand and Prime Minister John Major of Britain, both of whom have signaled that they might be willing to cast a veto if they are unhappy with the outcome.
While Mr. Major has pledged to guard Britain's sovereignty against European incursions, Mr. Mitterrand hopes to shake France out of its current malaise by convincing his countrymen that the country's prestige and prosperity have been assured by a giant new step toward European union.
So far, the 75-year-old French leader has sensed little encouragement at home. Polls indicate solid support for a stronger community, but they also show fear of the future and deep concern about unemployment, immigration and other domestic problems aggravated by an economic slowdown.
After 10 years in office, Mr. Mitterrand will arrive in Maastricht with his popularity at its lowest point since 1986 and with his Socialist Party facing likely defeat in regional elections next March and parliamentary elections in 1993. His own term in office ends in 1995.
In recent weeks the President has been trying to stir optimism. "I think we must dare to look to the horizon," he told a television audience this month. "We must begin to understand Europe, to love it. Europe is important economically, but also intellectually and spiritually.
"France will remain a great nation, but our future lies in Europe," he went on. "We must be able to speak to the Americans. We must be able to speak to the Japanese and we must be able to do so as equals. We can only do this through Europe. It is a great ideal."
 
Unperturbed Just 2 Years Ago
 Until two years ago, France seemed unperturbed about the future. It showed its independence from the United States by keeping its nuclear forces outside NATO and by developing its own ties with Moscow. It also enjoyed influence in the Arab world and virtually governed many of its former African colonies.
Having been defeated by Germany in the 1870 Franco-Prussian War and invaded by the Germans in this century's two world wars, France recognized in the 1950's that stability in Europe required close ties between the historic foes. So, with Germany anxious to end its postwar isolation, what became known as the Paris-Bonn axis was born.
Even before they were joined by Italy, Belgium, Luxembourg and the Netherlands as founding members of the European Community in 1957, the two governments worked hard to bury their past. By the mid-1980's, with Britain among the members, they promoted creation of a single regional market as of Jan. 1, 1993.
The alliance suited both governments. France tied its currency to the German mark and saw its economy expand in Germany's shadow, while an introspective Germany quietly accepted France's political leadership. As a team, they were able to set the agenda for the European Community.
When Communism crumbled across Eastern Europe in late 1989, however, France's self-confidence was shaken. By appearing to place obstacles in the way of German unification, Mr. Mitterrand not only irritated Mr. Kohl but gave the impression that France feared a resurgence of German power in Europe.
 
Embarrassment of Gulf War
 The Persian Gulf crisis further embarrassed France. It had long been Iraq's principal Western arms supplier, but it failed to persuade Baghdad to withdraw its troops from Kuwait and was subsequently unable to contribute more than 11,000 men and a dozen aging aircraft to the war effort of the American-led coalition.
As his domestic troubles grew, Mr. Mitterrand seemed to lose his touch in foreign policy. After long advocating a Middle East peace conference, for example, he has had to watch in frustration as the United States and Soviet Union co-sponsor talks between Israel and its Arab neighbors, further highlighting France's declining influence in the region.
Since April 1990, Mr. Mitterrand has viewed accelerated European unity as the solution to France's identity crisis -- as a way of anchoring a united Germany to Western Europe and counterbalancing the political weight of the United States and the economic threat from Japan.
After persuading Mr. Kohl that it was also in Germany's interest to be seen as a loyal European, Paris began working together again with Bonn, first toward a single currency and central bank and then toward "political union" with an eventual goal of a federal Europe.
There were occasional differences in that Germany favors strengthening the European Parliament and ceding more authority to the community's executive commission in Brussels, while France prefers closer cooperation between member governments in line with its traditional vision of a "Europe of Nations."
 
Keeping Talks on Track
 But over the last year, every time the negotiations faltered or Paris and Bonn seemed to drift apart, Mr. Mitterrand and Mr. Kohl met to give new impetus to the process. Last month, they even argued that the 12 should handle most areas of foreign relations as a bloc and consider forming a European army.
Just days before the Maastricht summit, it is unclear how far France and Germany can press their demands without risking a British veto. But Mr. Mitterrand has at least made it clear that his overriding priority is to give the community a political profile that matches its economic strength.
In this, while the President's language is European, his interests remain undisguisedly national: to use the community to amplify France's voice on the world stage, and to create strict rules so that even after new members join the community in the 1990's, German influence can be tempered.

HEADLINE: White House Memo;
Adrift in Bush's Circle Seeking the Common Man

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29

 BODY:
If Bush Administration officials were to place a "help wanted" advertisement, they would probably choose to run it in magazines like Four Wheeler, Hot Rod and Guns & Ammo, and it would read something like this:
"Immediate opening for a consultant who understands the common fellow. Good career opportunity for someone familiar with bowling alleys, pro wrestling and K Mart who can explain 'average' thinking to a group of old-line public servants planning America's future overseas and seeking to expand into domestic portfolio." 
 To paraphrase Jane Austen, it is a truth generally acknowledged that elite males in possession of large fortunes are in want of empathy with middle-class and poor Americans hurt by a recession. Anxious about polls showing a severe erosion of support for President Bush among middle-income voters, Republicans are searching for ways to make themselves appear more sensitive.
"We've got to find more people who have a more direct sync or tie or feel for the average-income person," Robert A. Mosbacher, the rich oilman turned Commerce Secretary who is expected to be the chairman of the Bush re-election campaign, told USA Today last week.
 
Fodder for the Democrats
 Referring to the late Lee Atwater, Mr. Bush's campaign manager in 1988, who used to take great pride in forays to diners, discount stores and pro wrestling matches and in reading The National Enquirer, Mr. Mosbacher continued: "We've got to have somebody like that. It isn't me, I admit."
And it apparently isn't Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, who when asked about the recession while on the NBC News program "Meet the Press" two weeks ago, said: "I think that the rush to judgment that this is the end of the Western world as we know it is entirely premature."
For the Democrats, the spectacle of a bunch of rich men huddled at the White House wondering how to connect with average Americans makes an irresistible target.
"Bush's idea of solving a domestic problem is to fire the maid and yell at the butler," Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa, the Democratic Presidential candidate, told the Chicago state Democratic chairmen the other day.
Ann Lewis, a Democratic consultant in Boston, said, "You've got a set of people for whom unemployment has always been a statistic, never a fear."
For the last decade, the Republican Party has tried to escape its elitist image as the party of big business and country clubs. It deftly co-opted the symbols and issues of populism from the Democrats, successfully wooing the middle class with flags, country music singers, speeches on the death penalty and law and order, and racially tinged messages.
 
Sununu vs. Atwater
 But George Bush, the first scion of the old-line Eastern establishment to run the country since Franklin D. Roosevelt, makes a sharp distinction between politics and governing.
During his 1988 campaign, he was willing to surround himself with operatives who had sandpaper personalities and middle-class backgrounds. But as President, Mr. Bush has has surrounded himself with friends and like-minded men, old-money millionaires, Ivy League tennis buddies and affluent businessmen.
The White House chief of staff, John H. Sununu, one of the few men in the President's ruling circle who is not a millionaire, has been little help in conveying the concerns of average Americans. Worried Republicans note that a chief of staff who can take a limousine trip to New York, spend nearly $5,000 at a stamp auction at Christie's and return to Washington on a corporate jet, is not a man who can help George Bush understand the pain of people in unemployment lines and soup kitchens.
Mr. Atwater, by contrast, ventured into a bikers' gathering in Luray, Va., in the spring of 1988 to test out on the Harley-Davidson crowd the story of Willie Horton, the convicted Massachusetts murderer who escaped while on a weekend furlough and raped a woman. Mr. Horton later became a favorite Republican symbol in the effort to portray Gov. Michael S. Dukakis as being soft on crime.
When Mr. Bush tripped on his Greenwich, Conn., roots and asked for "a splash" more coffee at a New Hampshire truck stop, Mr. Atwater was there with some refresher tips on avoiding "Ivy-speak."
But pork rinds, promoted by Mr. Atwater as a down-home staple of Mr. Bush's diet, have not been seen in the White House in nearly three years; Mr. Bush's favorite snack, it turns out, is popcorn.
Richard M. Nixon and Lyndon B. Johnson railed against the establishment and old-money types, proclaiming themselves men of the people. A Johnson aide, Joseph A. Califano Jr., recalled that President Johnson often upbraided him by saying: "That's a terrible answer. Tell me what you learned on the streets of Brooklyn; don't tell me what you learned at Harvard Law School."
John F. Kennedy, an affluent, Ivy League President whose money was not old or insider, brought in some upper crust officials but made a point to keep some old-style pols in the White House mix, the "Irish Mafia" of Kenny O'Donnell and Dave Powers.
Ronald Reagan had a kitchen Cabinet of self-made millionaires in California, but the Midwestern son of an alcoholic and often out-of-work salesman had perfect pitch when it came to the common touch.
At a recent Republican strategy dinner in Washington, one top Bush adviser talked about what his friend, the chairman of a Fortune 50 company, was saying about the economy. Mr. Reagan, by contrast, always talked anecdotally about what shop owners in the heartland were saying.
So Republicans at the dinner sat around trying to devise schemes to gain the confidence of "Joe Sixpack." Kenneth M. Duberstein, the savvy Republican consultant, suggested that Mr. Bush might signal his concern by jawboning the banks about consumer interest rates, on the theory that the average man may not understand the prime rate or the discount rate but comprehends the rate he sees on his credit card statements every month.
The next thing Mr. Duberstein knew, someone had relayed his inchoate idea to the White House, Mr. Bush suddenly had offered it in a speech, Senator Alfonse D'Amato of New York had proposed legislation to limit credit card rates, the stock market had plunged and the White House was in the political soup because it appeared to be lurching about with half-baked ideas.
 
Bowling, Not Golf
 "The smartest thing the White House could do right now is to declare Tuesday night bowling night and make everyone go to a bowling alley in suburban Virginia every week to spend some time with regular guys," said Michael McCurry, a Democratic consultant who is helping Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska with his Presidential campaign.
"Instead of wrapping himself in pig rinds, now George Bush is always on the golf course," said Representative Patricia Schroeder, Democrat of Colorado. "In their world, I guess, the golf course is the place where a lot of business gets done. But if they want to know about real folks, they should watch the Roseanne Barr show more. She's not out on the golf course."
Even Mr. Nixon has expressed disgust with the country-club image of Mr. Bush and Vice President Dan Quayle. The Los Angeles Times reported recently that the former President had told an associate that "the average guy is not on the golf course, the tennis court or a speedboat because he doesn't have one." Mr. Nixon, the paper reported, had "told Quayle directly that he should stop bringing his golf clubs with him as he travels around the world."
Some Democrats think that the White House tone deafness about the middle class may translate into a potent issue in the 1992 Presidential election.
"At the heart of this is the problem of what happens when policy is made by those people most insulated from the impact of that policy, and what happens when economic decisions are made by people who grew up with trust funds," Ms. Lewis, the Democratic consultant, said.
Representative Susan Molinari, Republican of Staten Island, says the problem is one of communication, not compassion. "The message that Joe Sixpack is hurting has gotten through to George Bush," Ms. Molinari said.
"But the White House has got to figure out how to communicate the President's real concern. The mood of the people shifts rapidly and hits hard. We have to be willing to intercept it immediately. That's where we've lost our way."

Mr. Brady, meeting with President Bush earlier this week, is a member of the affluent inner circle that concerns Republicans as they try to win back support from middle-income voters. HEADLINE: High-Tech Wood Rats Assist in Study of Species in New York

BYLINE: By HAROLD FABER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW PALTZ, N.Y., Nov. 27

 BODY:
With a radio strapped to his chest, an antenna in one hand and a stopwatch in the other, Edwin McGowan listened intently to a steady beeping.
"That's 10 beeps in 12.19 seconds," he said. 
 The signals came from a wood rat, one of 29 imported from West Virginia and released here in the Shawangunk Mountains in an effort to learn why the native species has disappeared in New York. Each was equipped with a small radio transmitter around its neck, a six-inch wire antenna for transmission and tags on its ears.
"It's alive, probably sitting or resting," Mr. McGowan said, interpreting the beeps, which reflected the animal's temperature, as a sign of health.
 
A Two-Year Study
 Mr. McGowan and Chris Naderefski, both wildlife technicians employed by the State Department of Environmental Conservation, have just begun a two-year assignment studying the life, health and death of the imported wood rats.
Despite the fiscal crisis in Albany, the wood rat project is going forward, at an estimated cost of $55,000, outside the state budget process.
About half the money came from the "Return a Gift to Wildlife" program in which New Yorkers volunteer contributions on their state income-tax forms. The remaining money came from the Federal Government, through a wildlife restoration fund derived from taxes paid by hunters on purchases of firearms.
"We don't believe that environmental concerns should grind to a halt because of current economic conditions," said Peter Nye, director of the state's endangered species unit. "It's part of our mandate to maintain the diversity of life forms in the state. The public has made it clear that it wants to protect endangered species."
 
Related to Deer Mouse
 The wood rat is no relation to Norway rats and others that have plagued cities and farms for centuries. It is a native American species, related to the deer mouse and somewhat similar to the western pack rat, which often steals and hides brightly colored objects.
When full-grown, it is slightly smaller than a squirrel, weighing less than a pound, grayish brown on top and white underneath. It has long whiskers, big ears and eyes, and, unlike other rats, it has hair on its tail.
The native animals were last seen in New York in 1987, when they were put on the official list of 34 endangered species that the state considers deserving of special protection and worthy of being saved for future generations. The wood rat is also listed as an endangered or threatened species in New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Ohio, Indiana and Illinois. The cause of its decline is unknown, but among the theories are a colder climate, a declining supply of acorns because of gypsy moth damage to oak trees and the spreading of the raccoon roundworm, which is fatal to wood rats.
 
Released in Nature Preserve
 The current experiment is aimed at determining the cause of the decline, not at restoring the species to the state, although that is possible in the future, said Thomas C. Jorling, the State Commissioner of Environmental Conservation.
In the experiment, the state released the 29 wood rats in September here on Bonticou Crag, a large rock outcrop in the Mohonk Preserve, a 5,600-acre private nature preserve west of New Paltzthat is cooperating in the experiment. Twenty-one of the wood rats are still alive, Mr. McGowan said. Three have been lost in the crevices of the rock formations where they like to live, he said. Of the other five, one was killed by a car, one by a predator, one by bites possibly by another wood rat and two by the raccoon roundworm, he said.
"It's premature to tell, but circumstantial evidence so far indicates that the roundworm appears to play a role in the disappearance of the wood rat," he said.
 
'They're Easy to Trap'
 Mr. McGowan, a 25-year-old graduate of Bowdoin College in Maine, said he was pleased with his new assignment.
"The wood rats are a great species to work with," he said, especially when compared with the moose that were his last assignment. "They're easy to trap with apples and peanut butter, they're easy to handle and you can work with a whole population in a small area, in contrast to the vast range of the moose in the Adirondacks."
Mr. McGowan and his associates say the wood rat is really a likable creature that has been maligned because of its name. "Some of our people think we should call them boulder bunnies," he said, referring to their preference for living in the rock formations. "That would certainly help their public image."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Edwin McGowan, a wildlife technician with the State Department of Environmental Conservation, is studying the behavior of wood rats near New Paltz, N.Y. (Alan Zale for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: West Sees Russia's Moves as Good

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30

 BODY:
A move by the Russian Republic today to bail out the Kremlin after the main central Government bank ran out of money might be an encouraging sign for Western governments, bankers and investors, American experts and officials said.
The accelerating takeover of economic authority by the Russian republic might halt rising economic chaos, they said, adding that it will not disrupt Western food credits and debt assistance. 
 "If I was a Western banker or a Western government, I would consider this an encouraging step," said Dmitri K. Simes, a Soviet expert at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.
The salary guarantee for Soviet bureaucrats pledged today by President Boris N. Yeltsin of the Russian republic and other recent actions "would say that essentially Russia is the lender of last resort and that the disappearance of the former Soviet Union doesn't mean the disappearance of the former functions," said William R. Cline, a senior fellow at the Institute for International Economics in Washington.
 
Accelerated Shriveling
 By paying the Soviet Union's bills, Mr. Yeltsin might gain the ability to determine which programs are bankrolled and thereby take over much of the central Government's political authority, said an American official who insisted on not being identified. "If you are paying the salaries of the government then you are the government -- just ask Congress," the official said.
The United States and its allies have been bracing themselves in the last month for an accelerated shriveling of the Soviet central Government. In an effort to insure repayment regardless of whether the union survives, Western countries have insisted successfully that not only the central Government but also the republics pledge to stay current on new and past loans.
The United States' $1.5 billion food aid package on Nov. 20 and the Soviet foreign debt assistance pact on Nov. 21 include detailed backup provisions for the republics to make payments and even distribute food if Moscow cannot.
"Just in case it did happen, worse comes to worst, we took some steps to insure against a default," said Roger D. Runningen, the Agriculture Department's press secretary.
The main Soviet bank, the Gosbank, halted payments from central Government accounts on Friday after exhausting its authority to print more rubles to finance the Kremlin's budget deficit. A separate Soviet Central Bank, the Vneshekonombank, handles foreign exchange transactions, including payments on agricultural credits and other Soviet foreign debts, but it has had to suspend for several days its domestic sales of foreign currency temporarily because of a cash shortage.
The printing of ever more rubles by Gosbank has fueled inflation and prompted warnings of possible hyperinflation. Whether the Russian bailout improves matters will depend on whether Russia pays for it by cutting Russian or Soviet spending, increasing taxes or ordering the printing of yet more rubles, Mr. Cline said.
The shift in economic authority this weekend might mean that for the first time in several months, a single person might be in a position to bring order to the country's crumbling economy.
"It enhances Russian credibility because there is someone in Moscow willing to say, 'The buck stops here,"' Mr. Simes said.
The paralyzed Soviet Government has been unable to impose a new monetary, fiscal and tariff system on the disintegrating country, but a Soviet Government discreetly controlled by the Russian federation might be able to do so without antagonizing other republics excessively, he said.
Friday's move by the Gosbank might also complicate further the distribution of food in the Soviet Union, as the cash-strapped central authorities have already been able to buy from farmers only half the usual quantity of grain. The result might be local food shortages and much higher prices, although no starvation, American officials warn.
If successful, the Russian effort now to slow inflation by curbing the Gosbank's issuance of currency could also help restore the confidence of foreign investors. Foreign companies and individuals continue to avoid investing dollars except in deals offering dollar-denominated profits or the export of internationally traded commodities like timber or oil.
While the August coup has transformed Soviet political life, the underlying economy remains deeply divided. A small sector does business in foreign currencies, while the rest of the country does business in rubles with very little access to foreign investment and technology, said Danielle S. Downing, the American owner of a small grain-trading company in Moscow.
"Nobody's really going in there with money for the infrastructure," she said.

HEADLINE: Going Slow on Economy Is Risky, Aides Tell Bush

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30

 BODY:
Despite President Bush's decision to cling to a go-slow strategy for economic revival, White House advisers are increasingly concerned about the risks -- to the economy as well as to 1992 campaign prospects -- of simply waiting for the anemic recovery to take wing.
When Mr. Bush suddenly endorsed a House Republican plan to cut taxes this week and challenged the Democrats to pass it, he was, in part, admitting that the issue of new economic initiatives had moved from "whether" to "when," a senior White House official said. Mr. Bush himself has promised to offer a fresh set of proposals to revive growth in his State of the Union Message, traditionally in late January. 
 But as expectations of growth have shrunk far below what was anticipated only a month or two ago, the White House has come to acknowledge that the risks may be greater than initially thought, the official said. To take out some political insurance, he said, advisers are actively exploring more potent remedies in case the President is obliged to propose stronger medicine than now considered.
The Administration has long had various proposals on the table, the centerpiece being a cut in the capital gains tax, which the White House has berated Congress for not adopting. What advisers are considering now are additional stimulative measures that could be put in place within the budget agreement, as well as more drastic measures that would break the agreement, if the economy gets significantly worse.
Michael Boskin, the Stanford professor who heads the President's Council of Economic Advisers, has begun detailed analysis of measures the White House might offer if the chances of at least modest recovery get much lower, said one person who met with him recently.
"I think they're still hoping against hope they'll get some good news about the economy," said James Annable, chief economist for the First National Bank of Chicago. "But that hope is just waning."
The Administration has not yet abandoned the view that the economy might still manage a modest recovery on the basis of natural rejuvenative forces, supplemented by cuts in interest rates by the Federal Reserve. That is by far the preferred scenario, as the short-term gains of acting now are weighed against the potential long-term consequences to the economy. These would include the risk of losing Wall Street's confidence by abandoning the discipline of last year's budget agreement to accommodate new tax measures.
 
Tax Cut Hearings Set
 Mr. Boskin, who is expected to appear Thursday at the first of a series of House Ways and Means Committee hearings on tax-cut proposals, still regards adherence to the 1990 budget deal as essential to maintaining the confidence of securities markets, without which interest rates would assuredly rise.
But he also contends that the budget-deficit problem is not as big as is sometimes portrayed and that there is some room for tax cuts without breaking the budget agreement.
As recently as a month or two ago, the consensus among private economists was that the gross national product would expand at a rate approaching 3 percent in the October-December quarter. Now, however, there is a widespread expectation that growth may be only 1 percent or so -- markedly less, in fact, than in the third quarter -- and at least one Presidential adviser does not rule out a negative figure.
Officials and financial authorities say the full effects of previous cuts in short-term interest rates have still to be felt, and they point out more are expected. They also note that the Congressional Budget Office, which earlier studied in detail the question of whether the Federal Reserve Board's help would be sufficient, determined that it probably would be.
Amid the numerous downbeat statistics on the economy these days there are indeed various gains, some directly related to lower interest rates. Housing starts, though scarcely robust, have climbed practically every month since January and sales are also up as lower mortgage rates helped make homes more affordable.
Other encouragement comes from data on orders for durable goods and for exports, both crucial to the industrial sector of the economy. The White House also notes that for various reasons, including the problems in the banking system and the relatively mild nature of the recession, it never expected the first year of recovery to produce more than half the 6 percent growth posted in the initial stage of the typical postwar rebound.
The White House also points to some impending benefit from the highway bill that passed this week, though containing more money than it would like, and from extended benefits for the unemployed that it fought to minimize.
But what some have called the "don't just do something, stand there" strategy has other rationales. One is the traditional Republican inclination to avoid interventions, believing not only that the Government has less ability to manage economies than is widely supposed but that short-term gain often produces harmful long-term consequences.
Another inhibition is the nation's budget deficit, which is so large it seems to preclude use of the usual antidote to recession -- a combination of tax cuts and increased Government spending. Except for the one in 1970, all eight postwar recessions have been countered at this stage by fiscal stimulus.
Mr. Boskin has noted that the average fiscal stimulus coming out of postwar recessions has been 1.5 percent of gross national product, or about $75 billion in today's economy.
With Federal stimulus nowhere near this large, and with fiscal drag at the state and local level twice as severe as usual, it could be necessary to put sums of this magnitude into consumer's hands. But an Administration official made clear that this remained only a contingency, and one it hoped to avoid.
Unlike the Federal Reserve, which can readily reverse course if it finds itself headed the wrong way, abandonment of the budget agreement would be a major "discontinuity," Mr. Boskin believes.
 
No Room to Maneuver
 "The reason for standing pat is because of the present condition of the budget," said Lyle E. Gramley, a former member of the Federal Reserve Board and now chief economist for the Mortgage Bankers Association. "You simply do not have room to maneuver."
Although both fiscal and monetary initiatives operate with lags, some extending six months or more, most private economists believe that there is relatively little risk in waiting until January for any new initiatives. They say they are extremely wary of what might be rushed through if Congress, which adjourned this week, were recalled to legislate recovery.
"If I were Michael Boskin, I'd probably go slow on economic and political grounds," said Robert Giordano, director of economic research at Goldman, Sachs & Company. Taking an extra six weeks to design a solid program should pay off on both fronts, he said.

HEADLINE: U.S. Reveals Sum of Aid It Withheld From Kenya

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ

DATELINE: NAIROBI, Kenya, Nov. 30

 BODY:
In an unusually blunt statement, the American Embassy has announced here how much Washington penalized Kenya this week when the United States and other aid donors held up new aid because of Kenya's poor political and economic performance.
The statement on Friday appeared to be an attempt to drive home the point that there was abundant American aid available for Africa but Kenya could not expect to benefit from it unless the Government curbed corruption and opened up the political system. 
 The embassy said the United States had been prepared to pledge $47 million in economic and social assistance to Kenya for 1992, an increase of $8 million over 1991.
Instead, Washington agreed to release only a previously agreed on $19 million for family planning, agricultural research and assistance to private humanitarian agencies, all programs that do not involve the Government.
The remaining $28 million intended to finance agricultural and market development programs was contingent on Kenya moving forward on political and economic reforms, the embassy said.
The $28 million was put on hold, the embassy said because of the "the Kenyan Government's failure so far to carry through with key economic refroms that had been promised earlier."
The United States Ambassador to Kenya, Smith Hempstone, has been the loudest Western critic of President Daniel arap Moi's insistence on clinging to the one-party system and his failure to clean up corruption. American officials have often stated that if Kenya moved forward on reforms, the country would receive at least twice what it has been getting from Washington in the last several years.
At the last two donor meetings, like the one in Paris last week, Kenya received about $800 million in development aid each year from internatonal financial institutions and donor nations. This time, the donors said Kenya would continue to receive aid already pledged but declined to specify any new amounts of aid. Instead, new aid to Kenya would be reconsidered in six months and would be linked to improvements in human rights and economic performance.
The Kenyan Government's reaction to the failure to get the much needed new aid has been muted. There have been no public pronoucements here.
Instead, Mr. Moi has called a meeting for Monday of the governing council of his ruling party, the Kenya African National Union, prompting intense speculation about possible reforms. While the donors were meeting in Paris, Mr. Moi had two of his closest political colleagues arrested in connection with the 1990 slaying of Foreign Minister Robert Ouko, an opponent of Government corruption. Also this week, Mr. Moi's Government dropped charges against a number of opposition leaders who were detained for organizing a rally.
The arrests of Nicholas Biwott, a powerful former cabinet minister and Hezekiah Oyugi, a former head of internal security, as well as the leniency toward the opposition leaders fueled speculation that Mr. Moi was planning to make some steps next week toward political pluralism.
Several opposition leaders and Western diplomats said it seemed possible that Mr. Moi might announce elections after the party meeting on Monday.
But as yet, no formal charges have been filed against Mr. Biwott or Mr. Oyugi, and President Moi has suspended the long-running judicial inquiry into Mr. Ouko's death at which allegations against the two men were being publicly aired.
At the same time that Kenya suffered from aid being held back, a group of American judicial experts who visited Kenya in July criticized the judicial system, which they said had been weakened by political interference.
"The administration of justice in Kenya is dangerously incomplete," the report said.

HEADLINE: A Rising Urgency for Neediest Cases

BYLINE: By J. PEDER ZANE

 BODY:
Even during the best times in the 1980's the streets of New York gave readier testimony to the spread of poverty than to the rise of wealth. Now, suffering and want have seeped behind the doors of thousands of homes, cutting the distance between security and disaster to anxious margins.
The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund begins its 80th appeal today as the economy seems to be contracting into an angry fist and people only whisper "depression" as if saying it aloud would make it so. For the seven charities it serves, the the appeal poses a simple but urgent question: Will New Yorkers who have less give more? 
 Already struggling under the needs of the city's chronic legion of sufferers, officials of the charities say they are being overwhelmed by requests for the most basic sorts of help -- food, shelter and clothing -- from newly impoverished individuals and families trying to brake their free fall into poverty.
 
Charities Cut Back
 Yet as more New Yorkers turn for a helping hand, shrinking financing and swelling caseloads are forcing the charities to disband or scale back programs that pull people out of poverty.
"We are performing triage on the most basic services," said David Jones, executive director of the Community Service Society of New York. "We are forced to decide whose needs are most pressing amongst a multitude in desperate need."
Some of the casualties include:
* A program that has enabled homeless people to renovate and eventually own abandoned buildings.
* A transitional living program that has taught the newly housed homeless how to take care of their new homes.
* A homemaker program that taught single teen-age mothers how to care for their babies and cope with the stresses of parenthood.
"These cutbacks mean hundreds, thousands of people who want to better themselves will not have the chance," said Donna Santarsiero, executive director of the Brooklyn Bureau of Community Service. "I don't think people know what a tremendous difference even a small amount of money can make."
The charities provide a wide range of services to a diverse population, including meals for people with AIDS who would otherwise go hungry at home, job training for disabled men and women who yearn for independence, counseling for child abusers who want to stop hurting their children and for substance abusers who to stop hurting themselves.
And they provide medical and financial support to a little girl named Vanessa Morris. Delivered at 28 weeks, weighing one pound, addicted crack and crippled, she has had three operations to bring life into her legs. Now 3, she weighs only 25 pounds. She is still not toilet-trained and cannot form sentences. But Vanessa's face brightens as she claps her hands and exclaims "Mommy, Daddy," when her foster parents, Jacob and Ida Edwards, who have raised her since she was 5 months old, enter her room.
To continue providing services to little girls like Vanessa, the charities said they must rely even more heavily on individual donations. However, so far this year contributions are remaining flat or are decreasing. The Children's Aid Society reports that its donations are down 7 percent this year. Plate collections have fallen 4 percent and unsolicited contributions a full 30 percent, at the Catholic Charities of the Diocese of Brooklyn. And despite a big campaign that has attracted 55,000 first-time givers, the United Jewish Appeal-Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York projects that it will only meet last year's fund-raising total of $125 million.
 
Fund Lags Last Year's Pace
 Similarly, The New York Times Neediest Funds Campaign is starting its campaign $16,000 behind last year's pace. Arthur Gelb, president of the Neediest Cases Fund and of The New York Times Foundation, said he was hopeful that contributors who might feel vulnerable themselves would respond to those in greater need.
"Compassionate giving is desperately needed to redeem abandoned children from our streets, to treat AIDS victims crowding our hospitals, to comfort the lonely and terrified who rarely leave their homes, and to nurture babies who received inadequate prenatal care and those were maimed in the womb by their mother's use of crack," Mr. Gelb said. "For the survival of these and other victims, the moral and financial support of all concerned New Yorkers are once again urgently required. The Neediest Cases Fund is a major avenue for generous giving."
Last year, the Neediest Cases Fund took in a record $4,439,093.47. That amount included donations from at least 15,580 individuals and organizations, the vast majority of which were less than $100. This year's drive starts with $1,064,955.86, largely representing grants from estates and foundations made since the last campaign ended on Feb. 28. This year's drive will also continue until the end of February.
The Neediest Cases Fund can be traced back the Christmas of 1911, when a shabbily dressed man asked Adolph S. Ochs, then publisher of The New York Times, for some money for a place to sleep. Mr. Ochs gave him a few dollars and asked him to come back the next day for a job.
The encounter inspired Mr. Ochs to assign a reporter to write profiles of the city's "100 Neediest Cases." The campaign, begun on Dec. 15, 1912, told readers of "a world of famine in the midst of plenty; of cruel heart and body hunger with bounty in sight but not in reach." In nine days, $3,630.88 was raised.
In 1912, more than a million immigrants, Italians, Poles, Jews and Central Europeans, came to America in search of a better life. Many found only penury, hunger and disease in the tenements of New York.
Today, America is in the midst of another great wave of immigration and these searchers, from Africa, Asia, Latin America and the Caribbean, are also struggling. Many of them are populating the city's poorer neighborhoods. Many live in modern tenements, sleeping three or four to a room. They cannot afford nutritional food for their children. And diseases like tuberculosis, a scourge in 1912, are ravaging their communities.
But the children and grandchildren of the earlier immigrants, and countless others who have risen from poverty in their own lifetimes testify to the fact that while the poor may always be with us, they are never the same people.
"People think there is some static thing called the underclass, inhabited by the same chronically poor individuals that are nothing else from cradle to grave," said Mr. Jones of the Community Service Society of New York. "In fact, only 5 percent of the population can be counted among the persistently poor. The vast majority are people who by some bad turn fall into poverty, and what often makes the difference for them is having a helping hand when things are tough."
