To delay may mean to forget.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Every Coach Needs a Lift Sometimes

BYLINE: By GEORGE VECSEY

DATELINE: CINCINNATI

 BODY:
RAY HANDLEY needs a helicopter. Sam Wyche needs a helicopter. All football coaches could use helicopters, not just for the mobility but for the decibels.
Handley of the Giants and Wyche of the Bengals, whose teams meet today at Riverfront Stadium, have had problems in those few minutes a week when they had to deal with civilians.
Football coaches really are a breed apart from baseball, basketball and hockey strategists, who spend more time socializing in public and less time plotting in sterile bunkers. 
 Not that other sports don't have their bullies and their blowhards. Billy Martin was as paranoid as any football coach, and Bobby Knight brings the ethos of the line of scrimmage to his every waking moment, and Tom Webster of the Los Angeles Kings deserved more than a 12-game suspension for chucking a hockey stick onto the ice last week.
Most football coaches don't know how to act in public because they are rarely there. This is a business that judges a coach as weak-willed if he knows his children's names. Dick Vermeil was well into middle age before he noticed there was such a thing as fall colors.
Football turns its coaches into warped Strangelovian dictators who spend most of their lives watching flickering figures on film, getting hit, getting up, oops, falling down again, backwards and forwards, for eternity.
Blinking like moles, or ponies who have spent a lifetime in a coal mine, coaches emerge for a few minutes a week, and often get themselves in trouble. Some, like Wyche, manipulate and cajole, and others, like Handley, stumble to find the right words.
Wyche's employers are weary of his feuds and diatribes, particularly last year when the league fined him for trying to ban female reporters from his locker room. He was afraid his lads might forget to wear a towel and therefore be so humiliated they could not put the whammo on their opponents.
With the Giants trying to gain a wild-card berth in the playoffs, Handley does not need distractions today, as Phil Simms starts at quarterback in place of Jeff Hostetler, who has several broken bones in his back. Handley has already made some gracious gestures to minimize his impulsive run for daylight last Monday. Less than 24 hours after fearing that Hostetler might be paralyzed, Handley was asked by a television newsman who would start if Hostetler were healthy.
The coach reacted as any other mortal might react on too much tension and not enough sleep. He walked out of his conference.
This is when coaches could all use a helicopter the way former President Reagan did. For eight years, the President would point to his helicopter and cup his hand to his ear.
What about unemployment? What about taxes? What about the Contras? What about arms to Iran? It was a classic vaudeville routine, the shaggy helicopter. If you could read his lips, the President was saying, "I can't hear you because of the helicopter." As in many other matters, President Bush has studied Reagan very well.
Why should football coaches have any less protection? They are used to observing their legions from towers overlooking isolated practice fields. They are at their most impressive leading tons of clomping, stomping players through the runway and onto the field, like MacArthur up to his waist in Inchon.
For reasons they do not totally understand -- maybe it has something to do with municipally owned stadiums and tax breaks for ownership -- the coaches must face the press. They suspect we wouldn't know a strong-side safety blitz from an entrechat, and they are right.
If the coach could activate the rotors of his waiting helicopter, he could duck the hard questions. It would not even have to be a real helicopter. They could copy the helicopter in "Miss Saigon," the one that takes the last Yanks out of the city.
It's all show-biz: the actors climb in the side door and secretly exit behind the screen before the pseudo-helicopter rises, emitting noise and wind, an extremely powerful ending to the first act.
In this high-tech age, what football coach would not like this little toy at his disposal? And at the end of the conference, Coach could climb on board, give a signal to a mock helicopter pilot, and slip out the back, jack, as the motor roars. They could blare a recording of "Hail to the Chief," and everybody would feel important.

HEADLINE: Rescuing Michael's Teeth

 BODY:
"Ahora, abre tu boca, Michael, como el dinosaureo."
The dental hygienist wants Michael to open his mouth wide, just like the gaping toy dinosaur she's wiggling. This is no ordinary dentist's office. It's a clinic on wheels, and every week it comes to Washington Heights on a rescue mission aided by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. 
 In tough times, trips to the dentist or the doctor are unaffordable luxuries for parents like Michael's, who have no health insurance. This mobile clinic, run by the Children's Aid Society, is here to save Michael's teeth.
"Ahhh, buen muchacho!" A very good 4-year-old, Michael opens his mouth wide, giving the dentist a perfect view of the two fillings he got last week. Actually, Michael and his dentist don't call them fillings: these are Teen-Age Mutant Ninja Turtle stars. In the front of the van, other children are having their vision and hearing tested.
First-generation immigrant children like Michael usually lack the benefits of fluoridated water and a good diet from birth. The hygienist presents him with a brand new toothbrush and the toy dinosaur to take home. In return, Michael flashes what anybody would call a million-dollar smile.
Because of the wrenching effects of the recession and cuts in public programs, thousands of children in New York City are in urgent need of basic health care. Poor diet increases the frequency of illness and dental caries. Measles and tuberculosis spread more quickly among the young in overcrowded, inadequate housing. When routine care is neglected, even the commonplace infections and diseases of childhood can lead to hospitalization, chronic health problems, even death.
Many children can be rescued now through The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, which begins its 80th annual appeal today. Donations are used to meet basic needs like immunization, eyeglasses and dental X-rays. Through programs like the health van, children are tested for life-threatening ailments like lead poisoning, tuberculosis and sickle cell anemia. The fund cares for children born infected with the AIDS virus and identifies and rescues victims of child abuse.
The fund, known as the Hundred Neediest Cases Fund when it was created in 1912, today reaches out to help many more. It passes every dollar to the neediest through seven private social service agencies; no money is kept back for administration or solicitation. Contributions to the fund are tax deductible to the extent permitted by law. Any amount is welcome.
Checks should be made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and mailed to Post Office Box 5193, General Post Office, New York, N.Y. 10087.

HEADLINE: What Foreign Policy?

BYLINE: By James Webb; James Webb was Assistant Secretary of Defense and Secretary of the Navy in the Reagan Administration.

DATELINE: ARLINGTON, Va.

 BODY:
The Democratic challengers to President Bush have apparently decided to cede him his experience in foreign affairs and instead to focus on domestic issues, particularly the economy. This would be a mistake.
Americans demand a President who is adroit in the international arena. The Democrats' retreat from an affirmative foreign affairs role since the middle of the Vietnam War coincides exactly with their failure in Presidential elections. Allowing Republicans to continue setting the foreign policy agenda while arguing from the back bench befits a legislator or perhaps a governor, but not a President. 
 We need this debate. In previous years, especially before the collapse of Eastern Europe and the unhinging of the Soviet Union, it was not necessary for leaders to outline the specific maxims under which they would conduct foreign affairs. Our economy was clearly the world's strongest. And despite sometimes vitriolic argument over the appropriate mix of military, diplomatic and economic levers, we were united in our desire to contain expansionist Communism.
The still fragile resolution of the cold war was in many ways a Pyrrhic victory for the U.S. We lost more than 100,000 young men fighting Communist soldiers in Asia. For the first time in our history we stationed large standing forces in foreign countries in peacetime -- almost one-third of our Army and nearly 40 percent of our tactical Air Force were assigned to Europe's defense alone. We bled our economy white and saw our standard of living decrease as countries benefiting from our protection refurbished, became our competitors and now threaten to become our economic superiors.
As new power centers emerge, the U.S. is frequently viewed as a passive observer. The European Community is moving toward fiscal and possible federal union. Asia is transforming itself, with Japan at the economic center and China the political and military fulcrum. Except for our military power, the U.S. is bringing less and less to the table.
Mr. Bush, while correctly rejecting renewed calls for isolationism, has failed to articulate the direction in which our country must move. Behind the constant motion, his foreign policy suffers the same disabilities as his domestic policy.
It is mostly reactive rather than visionary. Secretary of State James Baker deserves high marks for postwar efforts in the Mideast, and Mr. Bush should not be strongly faulted for his lack of specific policies to address rapid change in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union. But this Administration's policies have hardly been guided by concrete principles.
Here are some of the confusing "lessons" from the last three years:
The violation of a nation's territory is wrong when Iraq attacks Kuwait, but acceptable when we quietly cede Lebanon to a rearmed and unrepentant Syria.
Democratic evolution is vital when Soviet citizens take their government back from a hard-line coup, but not of consequence when the Chinese ask for continued most-favored-nation status after the slaughter at Tiananmen Square, or in the Arab nations that so cleverly made use of our military assets against Iraq.
We will normalize relations with Vietnam if it supports internationally supervised elections in Cambodia, but will not ask that it honor its commitment in the 1973 Paris Peace Accords to hold internationally supervised elections in Vietnam.
U.S. foreign policy lacks clear principles because it depends greatly on personal ties. Mr. Bush seems to believe in the existence of a fraternity of world leaders who can get along and make a deal, no matter the degree of their tyranny or the ideology that drives them. His courting of Hafez al-Assad is dangerous. In the time Syria has been our "ally" it has consolidated its hold on Lebanon, destroyed the Christian Phalange militia, acquired Scud-C missiles from North Korea, and is now rumored to be receiving arms shipments from the Soviets and nuclear assistance from China.
This is the kind of costly realpolitik that led to the two military engagements Mr. Bush has savored since becoming President: fighting against tyrants in Iraq and Panama who only a few years earlier had received the active support of Mr. Bush and our Government.
The President's curiously soft treatment of the Chinese has caused widespread reverberations. The East Asian land mass has grown even more repressive as Europe has become more free. China, with a fifth of the world's population, is asserting itself as the dominant military and political power in Asia, and is now a major arms dealer.
One of China's principal strategies is to erect an alliance against U.S. pressure for political liberalization. China seems also to favor nuclear proliferation, reportedly assisting Iran, Pakistan and possibly Syria in this regard.
The impact of the soft American treatment can be seen in China's recent rapprochement with Vietnam, a historic enemy. In 16 years the inept Hanoi Government has driven two million of its best and brightest people into exile, and destroyed an economy that today provides a per capita income of only $180 a year.
After the Tiananmen massacre, Vietnam's Communists conducted their own crackdown, the country's most brutal since 1975. They are vastly unpopular at home. They are also desperate for cash, Soviet aid having dried up almost completely over the past two years.
With no cards to play, Vietnam has also followed China's lead in maneuvering the U.S. into normalizing relations without having to liberalize politically. Mr. Bush's road map for normalization, conceived solely as a reward for Vietnam's cooperation in Cambodia and on the P.O.W.-M.I.A. issue, asks for no democratic reforms from one of the world's most repressive systems. This is an abominable failure, given our special responsibility to address the plight of those who stood by the U.S. in the war.
Nor does the policy mention the 1973 Paris Peace Accords, signed by the Vietnamese Communists, which guaranteed that "the South Vietnamese people's right to self-determination is sacred, inalienable and shall be respected by all countries," and that they "shall decide themselves the future of Vietnam through genuinely free and democratic elections under international supervision."
U.S. policy avoids facing new economic realities. Economic power directly correlates with national security. Mr. Bush and others ignore that, and particularly its relevance to Japan's rise, at our collective peril.
It is estimated that within two decades Japan will have the world's strongest economy. It has achieved this growth by adopting an aggressive national strategy, spearheaded by the Ministry of International Trade and Industry. Defying conventional wisdom regarding the ill effects of protectionism, Japan has protected home markets and dumped products at reduced prices abroad, driving out -- and in many cases destroying -- domestic competition until the only products available are Japanese. Mr. Bush and his allies like to call this "free trade."
Furthermore, the radical devaluation of the dollar agreed on by the U.S. in 1985 has not altered our trade imbalance. Rather, it has allowed Japan, which imports all its oil, an incredible windfall: since oil is bought with dollars, cheaper dollars mean cheaper oil. In 1981, Japan spent more than 5 percent of its gross national product on oil. That figure has dropped to about 1 percent, allowing Japan billions of excess dollars to spend on American capital assets.
Mr. Bush and "free trade" economists debunk concerns about the Japanese buying trend, pointing out that it creates jobs -- no matter that the profits from our labor go back to Japan, where they can be used to purchase even more capital assets. In the old days they called this "colonialism."
To date, Mr. Bush has neither the strategy nor the will to address these inequities. If they are not addressed, we must accept a grave national truth: we have become so dependent on the Japanese for capital investment and in the financing of our debt that we have lost our ability to protect our long-term interests.
These issues beg for debate. And no Democrat is likely to unseat George Bush without taking them on.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 10; Column 3; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 455 words

HEADLINE: Who the Rich Are and What They Should Pay;
We Need Productivity

 BODY:
To the Editor:
We can all criticize our economy, but it's much more important to offer suggestions that will improve it. In that vein, I offer these: 
 * Set a sales-tax limit that a state may impose on the purchase of a new automobile. Make that limit a maximum of 3 percent. Let the sales tax be federally deductible for domestically produced vehicles and let the interest also be deductible. Auto production is one of the pillars of our economy, and let us stop strangling it.
* Our country can make cameras, videocassette recorders, television sets and compact disk players. Let us do for these industries what we did for real estate construction: let us give a tax abatement. Here is how it would work. If a company decides to produce a 35 millimeter camera or any other piece of electronic equipment not made in this country, and sets up a plant for that sole purpose, the profits for that product would be free of taxes for 20 years. If that is not satisfactory, devise a sliding scale of taxes over 20 years. We are getting no jobs and no taxes from these products now. Worse, our engineers are losing the manufacturing expertise required for these products.
* We have to get the real estate and construction market moving again. First thing is to increase the terms of mortgages from 30 years to 40 years for people who want it. Second, balloon mortgages should become more in vogue for younger couples; that is, for the first five years, there would be a lower payment, and then a higher payment for the next 35 years. Most important, home mortgage rates must be driven down.
We can drive mortgage rates down by taxing pension funds on their profits, unless they invest a certain percentage of their portfolio in residential and apartment construction. This would take money out of program trading and put it where it is needed. These funds would drive mortgage rates lower. There are plenty of buyers and tenants out there; the problem is they can't afford it.
The name of the game is productivity. Family leave, credit-card interest, rebuilding our infrastructure are all very nice. You cannot rebuild your infrastructure unless there are profits and income to tax. Family leave is great, but you have to have a job to get leave from.
We can get this economy moving again. It takes ideas and leadership. We have a country with the most abundant natural resources, we have a skilled and willing work force and a risk-taking entrepreneurial class. There are inventions and methods waiting for us these next 100 years that will make the last 100 years pale by comparison.
 
HYMAN JATKOFF
Albany, Nov. 18, 1991
 
The writer is director of engineering services, State University Construction Fund.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 1; Column 3; Arts & Leisure Desk

HEADLINE: Japan and the U.S. Share an Uneasy Artistic Peace

BYLINE: By MICHAEL SHAPIRO; Michael Shapiro is the author of "Japan: In the Land of the Broken-Hearted."

 BODY:
From the bombing of Pearl Harbor to the purchase of Rockefeller Center, the relationship between the United States and Japan has been burdened with seminal moments. But one of the most revealing encounters took place not during combat or in a boardroom but on film.
The moment came in Ron Howard's 1986 movie, "Gung Ho," in which a Japanese car maker reopens an abandoned American plant. The Americans, unable to impress their Japanese employers, offer a deal: they will match the production record of their Japanese counterparts to keep the plant open. As they fairly kill themselves just to stay even, it becomes clear that nothing short of chicanery will help. Their shop steward confronts the austere company president, trying to make up for the missing cars with sheer enthusiasm. 
 There is a pause. Then, with words that tell more than any joint communique could about where matters now stand between America and Japan, the president looks at the shop steward and says: "I like you. You make me laugh."
Saturday is the 50th anniversary of the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor, the event that first made Americans see Japan as a power and a threat. For all of the books explaining Japanese ways to Americans, and despite Japan's embrace of American pop culture, the relationship remains one of two peoples who see the world and their places in it in profoundly different ways. Between them stir accusations, threats and stereotypes -- geisha and samurai; violent crime and Mickey Mouse. And in the darkest moments, memories of Pearl Harbor and Hiroshima come to the surface.
If the arts -- especially film -- have perpetuated some of the worst stereotypes and the most naive images, they have also provided moments of clarity, when the real fears felt on both sides of the Pacific come to life. Dealing in the realm of emotion rather than policy, creative artists can offer glimpses into the passions at the heart of the relationship -- the contempt and pity many Japanese have come to feel toward the United States, the fear and mistrust that the idea of Japan now conjures for many Americans.
 
After the War
Stereotypes Hide Shifting Truths
 If the Japan portrayed in recent American films has a parallel, it is the America portrayed in Japanese films of the 1950's and 60's. Each nation is cast as an invader -- Japan, now, devouring American assets; America, then, imposing itself on occupied Japan.
In Shoei Imamura's "Pigs and Battleships" (1961), America was embodied by whoring servicemen, pouring off their ships in search of Japanese prostitutes. There were also the faceless Americans who ran over and killed a Japanese gangster in Masaki Kobayashi's "Black River" (1957) and the brutal G.I. who enlisted a temple novice to abort his Japanese girlfriend's pregnancy in Kon Ichikawa's "Conflagration" (1958).
"In the 1950's, all American characters were portrayed as conquerors," said Keiko MacDonald, a professor of Japanese history and film at the University of Pittsburgh. "This situation completely reversed in the 1970's."
Indeed, in Hiroshi Teshigahara's 1972 "Summer Soldiers," a product of a wealthier and more confident Japan, America was represented by Vietnam deserters who were offered refuge in Japan. By 1979, in Hiroshi Yamada's "Tora's Dream of Spring," an American -- lost, broke and in need of a mentor -- could be seen sitting at the knee of the classic Japanese film figure Tora-san, a love-lorn peddler. And in Masahiro Shinoda's 1984 "MacArthur's Children," Americans became well-meaning soldiers of the Occupation, losing at baseball to a team of determined Japanese schoolchildren.
Until recently, Americans, still convinced that the Japanese wanted only to be like them, were largely unaware of the change. Even as Japan grew more powerful, Tokyo's official attitude toward the United States remained one of unflagging admiration and fidelity. That the movies were saying something very different was consistent with the Japanese notion of truth, which exists on two levels: "tatemae," truth that is spoken, and "honnae," truth that is meant. Film reflected the essential truth seldom spoken.
Back when Japan was seeing an all-powerful America on film, America saw Mickey Rooney in "Breakfast at Tiffany's" (1961), with buckteeth and glasses, as the embodiment of the Japanese man. And in Woody Allen's "What's Up, Tiger Lily?" (1966), the voices in a Japanese film were replaced by those of American actors for comic effect. On Dec. 7, 1966, the 25th anniversary of Pearl Harbor, "What's Up, Tiger Lily?" was playing in New York.
By the time of "Gung Ho," two decades later, the shift in the essential truth of Japanese attitudes had become so apparent that an American director could show a group of Japanese hovering around a broken scale model of an automobile, laughing at the "American car."
For Americans, meanwhile, Japan has become the world that the lone New York cop played by Michael Douglas in Ridley Scott's 1989 "Black Rain" found so threatening and impenetrable. Mr. Scott's vision of Japan was one of neon and shadows and powerful men. An underworld boss menacingly told the American: "You shoved your values down our throat. We forgot who we were. I am paying you back."
Even when not so dark, the images could be telling. The young Japanese couple in Jim Jarmusch's "Mystery Train" (1989), for instance, trudged through Memphis oblivious to urban decay, searching for the spirit of Elvis Presley and the 1950's America that the young Japanese so cherish.
 
Images of the Present
Conflict, Blame And Paranoia
 In movie houses and theaters today, the encounter between Japan and America takes other forms. A wealthy Japanese man battles with a jobless American auto worker in Hi roaki Yoshida's new film "Iron Maze." A Japanese-American apologizes to his aging aunt for not knowing that her husband had been incinerated at Nagasaki in Akira Kurosawa's forthcoming film "Rhapsody in August." And a paranoid American becomes convinced that the Japanese businessman taking over his company was once his prison camp guard in Jill Shearer's play "Shimada," scheduled for New York this spring.
"Iron Maze," in particular, makes vivid the conflict and passions between two peoples. A wealthy Japanese man "buys" a moribund American steel town and dispatches his son, Junichi Sugita, to see what can be made of it. Sugita, tall and dapper, arrives in a white Mercedes-Benz convertible with his blond American wife. He wants to replace the mill with an amusement park. To the steelworkers, led by a man named Barry, Sugita becomes "the Jap."
"From Sugita's point of view, the steel mill is just heavy rusting iron," Mr. Yoshida said in a recent conversation. "It's something useless. He believes he's doing a very good thing for everybody. But for the American, Barry, his grandfather and father had the same job he did. The entire town worked in the mill. For him it's like a church, a holy place. He doesn't want Sugita to treat the mill like garbage. You can't say which one is right or wrong."
Nor can you be sure just what to make of the title character in "Shimada," said the play's director Simon Phillips. When the play opened in Australia in 1987, many critics regarded it as a warning of the Japanese economic invasion. But Mr. Phillips insisted that it is designed to let audiences make up their own minds about Japan today.
"Shimada," Mr. Phillips said, goes to the heart of both Australian and American perceptions of the Japanese -- that they remain elusive and, with their growing power, threatening. "This is a play about perceptions -- how a culture is perceived by a people who have no understanding. Because we can't make the sum add up, there will always be a sinister idea."
Mr. Kurosawa, for his part, offers in "Rhapsody in August" a picture of a sensitive American -- played by Richard Gere, speaking Japanese -- who appreciates the suffering of the Japanese people. And the director is quick to poke fun at the generation approaching middle age, those who still fawn over a wealthy American cousin.
But what rankles many Americans who have seen the film is Mr. Kurosawa's avoidance of the issue of blame. The aging aunt delivers a speech blaming the suffering of war's victims on war itself, as if war were a player and not an act of players. In reality, victims of Japanese aggression in World War II are left to wonder when the nation will accept responsibility for its most heinous wartime acts.
The war, of course, remains at the core of the encounter between Japan and America, from questions of responsibility and relative degrees of suffering to the troubling but inevitable comparisons now drawn in America between Japan's military expansion in the 1930's and its economic domination today. As many Japanese angrily ask how often they have to apologize for the war, many Americans contend that they have not done so even once.
 
A Way to the Future
Being Different, And Accepting It
 Still, there is a growing sense that the issue is at last being engaged through the arts -- although that is not always the case. "Esthetics is a way to paper over those conflicts," said Stefan Tanaka, a history professor at Clark University in Worcester, Mass. Mr. Tanaka's work involves American perceptions about Japanese art. He argued that too often curiosity has not extended beyond an appreciation of the myths two peoples see in one another -- myths born of the images found in their art.
"It's kind of like the Dr. Feelgood approach," he said. "You avoid the issue. It's a fake understanding. We believe that if we talk to each other, we'll understand."
If theater and movies offer, at least in America, a new and sometimes troubling view of where the two nations find themselves, they also offer glimpses of what could be. Among the entries at the New York Film Festival this fall was Alan Berliner's "Intimate Stranger," the story of his grandfather. An Egyptian Jew who settled unhappily in Brooklyn after the war, the grandfather set off for Japan, where he resumed a career as a middleman in the cotton trade. He would spend 11 months a year in Japan, working slavishly for his company and all but ignoring his family.
When Mr. Berliner went to Osaka to make his film, he found that his grandfather had been rewarded not with a great deal of money or with friendship. Instead, Mr. Berliner said, his grandfather was called "honorable special foreigner." He was different, and people cared for him deeply. He embraced his role and recognized that fundamentally he was not the same as the people around him. And though that did not bring him complete acceptance, it at least brought contentment.

GRAPHIC: Photos: A scene from Akira Kurosawa's film "Rhapsody in August" with, from left, Tomoko Ohtakara, Sachiko Murase and Hidetaka Yoshioka--avoiding the issue of blame (Orion Classics) (pg. 1); Hiroaki Murakami, foreground, as Junichi Sugita in "Iron Maze"--"the Jap," to American steelworkers (Edward R. Pressman/Oliver Stone); Michael Keaton, right, pulls his Japanese boss, Gedde Watanabe, back to shore in "Gung Ho"--a shift in postwar attitudes (Paramount Pictures) (pg. 20)

SECTION: Section 10; Page 5; Column 2; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 1309 words

HEADLINE: Focus: New Orleans;
Builders Betting on Riverboat Gambling

BYLINE: By LETTICE STUART

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS

 BODY:
BETTING people in the real estate community here think the odds are excellent that riverboat gambling, approved by the State Legislature in July, will spur development along the Mississippi River waterfront downtown.
The law stipulated that construction of the boats could not begin until January 1992, and the first boats are not expected to begin operating until late in 1993. Nevertheless, real estate brokers and developers already have begun to prepare for what they think will be a daily influx of thousands of visitors. 
 Iowa, Illinois, Missouri and Mississippi have also passed legislation authorizing legal riverboat gambling. So far, the boats are only operating off Illinois and Iowa.
The biggest winner of all here may be a long-time local developer, Joseph Canizaro. The month before the gambling bill was passed, he signed a contract to buy a prime piece of downtown riverfront property where several boats are expected to dock, and he closed on the deal in September.
Mr. Canizaro bought the 72-acre tract next to the New Orleans Convention Center for $11 million from the Missouri Pacific Railroad Company and Upland Industries Corporation, both subsidiaries of the Union Pacific Corporation. Since then, he said, he and his two partners, William Goldring and Coleman Adler, both of New Orleans, have received dozens of offers from people wanting the property for gaming-related purposes.
Mr. Canizaro said that a prominent national developer has offered twice the purchase price for the entire parcel and that several gaming companies have offered even more.
But the 54-year-old developer, who has helped shape the downtown skyline with six office and hotel towers in the last 20 years, said he wants to develop, not sell, the property. His master plan includes docking facilities for several riverboats, a park along the river's edge, restaurants, child-care facilities, one or two hotels, parking, residences and, possibly, an amphitheater.
First, however, Mr. Canizaro has to settle a dispute with the New Orleans Exhibition Hall Authority, which wants to expropriate 23 of the 72 acres to expand its 700,000-square-foot Convention Center. Mr. Canizaro contends the 400,000-square-foot addition can be built on a 10-acre site at the other end of the building.
"The city had ample opportunity to buy the property before I did and they just can't prove that they need it enough to expropriate it," Mr. Canizaro said.
Mr. Canizaro is not the only one hoping to rake in big winnings from riverboat gambling. City officials estimate that the floating casinos will add 10,000 jobs, increase visitor spending by up to $200 million a year -- not counting the $75 million to $100 million expected to be spent at the gaming tables -- and create a need for more hotel rooms, parking, restaurants, stores and housing.
The law limits gambling boats in the state to 15, with a maximum of 6 in any one parish. In Orleans Parish, one boat is expected to dock in the French Quarter and four or five more along a one-mile stretch in front of and near the Convention Center.
EACH boat, which will cost $30 million to $40 million to build, will be about 300 feet long and hold about 3,000 passengers. They will leave from downtown and cruise up and down the river for about three hours several times a day. There will be no sleeping accommodations, but the boats are expected to serve food and drinks.
The riverfront activity is expected to have an impact throughout the adjacent historic warehouse district.
"There's more going on now on the riverfront and in the warehouse district than anywhere else in the metropolitan area," said Robert F. Talbot, a real estate broker. "We have people flying into town almost daily from other states and even out of the country to look at property here."
Several projects, including hotels, nightclubs and condominiums, already are on the drawing board, he said. Among these is the conversion of an old warehouse into residential condominiums by two local developers, Henry Lambert and Carey Bond.
Although Mr. Talbot thinks property prices will escalate, he does not anticipate a repeat of the speculative frenzy of the early 80's, when the riverfront and surrounding area of dilapidated 19th-century warehouses was designated as the site of the 1984 Louisiana World Exposition.
At that time, prices for rundown warehouses skyrocketed from $8 to $10 a square foot to $30 to $35 a square foot. But after the six-month-long exhibition ended in bankruptcy, and the city's economy plummeted along with the energy industry, prices fell to $10 to $15 a square foot, where they remain today, he said.
Several of those warehouses have been renovated into apartments in the last seven years and now about 2,000 people live in the former industrial neighborhood. The area's 1,200 apartments are 98 percent occupied at monthly rentals of close to $1 a square foot. Both the occupancy and the rents are record highs for the city.
Some restaurants, shops and art galleries also have opened, but riverboat gambling is expected to significantly increase commercial development.
Pres Kabacoff, who, with a partner, Edward Boettner, has developed nearly 600 apartments in the warehouse district, expects riverboat gambling to increase the demand there. He said the average salaries of those working on the boats will be $20,000 a year. And many of them, he noted, will be working late hours and want safe, affordable housing nearby.
Hotel owners seem to be the one group worried about the prospect of new development. Some say they fear a repeat of the overbuilding that occurred before the 1984 exhibition, when eight luxury hotels with more than 4,000 rooms were built in a 12-block downtown area. The resulting glut, along with the city's economic downturn, sent hotel occupancy to a low of 52 percent in 1985. Today, occupancy rates at downtown hotels average 70 percent, just barely above the industry's break-even point.
"But we're certainly not at the point yet where we can support any new large projects and certainly not any more luxury hotels," said Ray Liuzza, part owner of the 368-room Doubletree Hotel on Canal Street near the river.
LAST September, Mr. Liuzza announced plans to build the city's first new hotel since 1984. However, the 150-room, $10 million "limited facility" hotel will have no restaurant or lounge and average room rates will be a moderate $76 a night. The decision to build the hotel was based on the property's prime location across the street from the Convention Center and had nothing to do with riverboat gambling, Mr. Liuzza said.
The hotel will be operated by Mr. Liuzza's company, the International Hotel Management Company, but he said that he is negotiating now with both Holiday Inn Express and the Hampton Inn chains and that the hotel eventually will be a franchise of one of those. Construction is scheduled to begin in January and take 10 months.
Only days after Mr. Liuzza disclosed his plans, two hoteliers, Patrick Quinn and Edwin Palmer, announced the reopening of the Lafayette Hotel on St. Charles Avenue, five blocks from the river. The 44-room hotel has been closed since 1986, when the previous owners ran into financial problems after spending $7 million renovating the former skid-row property into a luxury hotel.
Mr. Quinn said he and Mr. Palmer bought the hotel not because of riverboat gambling but "because we were able to pick it up for a steal."
They acquired a 52-year lease on the property from the Resolution Trust Corporation for about $650,000 and spent $350,000 on cosmetic improvements. "We now have spent $1 million and have a hotel worth at least three times that," he said.
Riverboat gambling will benefit existing hotels close to the river but won't create enough demand to build new ones, Mr. Quinn said.

SECTION: Section 8; Page 1; Column 2; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 1301 words

HEADLINE: FOCUS;
Builders Betting on Riverboat Gambling

BYLINE: By LETTICE STUART

SECTION: Section 7; Page 14; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1371 words

HEADLINE: The Importance of Being Hirschfeld

BYLINE: By Terrence McNally; Terrence McNally's most recent play is "Lips Together, Teeth Apart."

 BODY:

HIRSCHFELD
Art and Recollections
From Eight Decades.
By Al Hirschfeld.
Introduction by
Alistair Cooke.
Illustrated. 306 pp. New York:
Charles Scribner's Sons. $50.  
 The Colleen Dewhurst I will always remember is to be found on page 252 of this exhaustive, but never exhausting, retrospective of Al Hirschfeld's drawings -- from his 1926 Sacha Guitry to Jonathan Pryce in last season's "Miss Saigon." Not only has the artist drawn Dewhurst in what proved to be her last Broadway appearance, as Essie Miller in Eugene O'Neill's "Ah, Wilderness!," but he has also got down on paper the very essence of one of the Broadway theater's greatest actresses, who died on Aug. 22. This is no sketch of an actress in a role. It is her biography as an artist. Looking at Al Hirschfeld's Colleen's Essie, one can also see and remember her Josie Hogan in "A Moon for the Misbegotten" or her Miss Amelia in "The Ballad of the Sad Cafe."
It's all there in the brief, quick Hirschfeld lines: the physical details of that strong face and powerful torso; the inner life that would swell to the surface and overwhelm us; the very soul of the actress, a soul she so generously shared with us play after play after play. Here, for all time, is that smile that lighted up a theater so that people in the last reaches of the second balcony could bask in it. Here forever are the eyes that crinkled with an inner radiance that made you feel more alive just to be in the same theater with her. And here again is that low, omni-celloed, contrabassooned voice to break your heart anew. Yes, you can actually hear Mr. Hirschfeld's Dewhurst. You don't even have to close your eyes. Quite the opposite: open them wide and just listen. You'll hear her again, only this time forever. An extravagant claim? I think not for anyone who saw Dewhurst or knows the extraordinary work of this visual chronicler of the American theater for nearly 65 years. I have seen thousands of photographs of an actress named Colleen Dewhurst. Some of them even look like her. But Mr. Hirschfeld's portrait is the only one that tells me something like the truth about what it was like to experience her in the theater.
No one "writes" more accurately of the performing arts than Al Hirschfeld. He accomplishes on a blank page with his pen and ink in a few strokes what many of us need a lifetime of words to say. He gets to the essence of his subject with an economy that should be the envy of most wordsmiths. For six decades he has been one of the theater's best journalists. I put him on a level with Kenneth Tynan and Walter Kerr, two writers of my experience who helped me see and hear performances I never attended. Much has been written about the transitory nature of the performing arts, especially the theater. Those performers lucky enough to have been captured by Mr. Hirschfeld's pen have escaped some sort of oblivion and become, instead, icons of the performing moment.
You have only to look at Mr. Hirschfeld's drawings of Ray Bolger in fantastic motion in "Where's Charley?" to feel you know more about that great dancer's performing style than any book or reminiscing elder could tell you. No wonder the ultimate accolade in the New York theatrical community has always been to be the subject of "a Hirschfeld." I know actors who would trade in their Tonys for a Hirschfeld. Fame is fleeting. A Hirschfeld is not. The fact that his name has become a noun should tell you something about the high regard in which his subjects hold him. I have even heard his name used as a verb. "I've been Hirschfelded!" a young actress excitedly told me in her dressing room. While I winced at her grammar, I celebrated her first hold on some sort of immortality.
The pleasures of "Hirschfeld: Art and Recollections From Eight Decades" are multiple. Mr. Hirschfeld as a writer on his art is as astute and to the bone as he is as a draftsman. His brief foreword gives us a clear statement of his goals and an illuminating discussion of drawing as the art of pure line in black and white. This is writing from the heart, humble and eminently understandable. If you are like me, you can count on one hand the number of artists or critics who write anything remotely intelligible to the layman about the visual arts. They are keepers of some secret flame. Not Mr. Hirschfeld. He gives us his "secrets," such as they are, plain and simple. I actually learned something reading Mr. Hirschfeld on the art of Hirschfeld.
There is also brief autobiographical material. Just enough to let us feel closer to the artist without knowing his secrets, if any, as a man. The origins of the now famous "Ninas," the name of his daughter hidden several places in each drawing since one Sunday in 1945, are revealed at last, as well as the episode when he included the name of his daughter's friend Lisa and he and his wife, the actress Dolly Haas, were inundated with congratulations on their new child.
Mr. Hirschfeld's full-blown mature style, the one by which we happily recognize him on lucky Sundays when his latest work appears in The New York Times, was reached in 1933, only seven years after his first published drawing, in a composite panel titled "Five Shows Currently on the Boards." The style is clearly his and the figures are easily identified. Ina Claire in "Biography" is all bobbed hair and swooping profile; Alla Nazimova in "The Good Earth" is more remote and mysterious (and looks more like Alla Nazimova) than she appeared in any film; Judith Anderson in "The Mask and the Face" is grand and tragic, a true presence, even in a pen-and-ink profile. It is hard not to feel nostalgic while looking at these theater drawings from over 50 years ago. Not just for the performers that are no longer with us (they live on in their Hirschfelds) but for the sheer abundance of plays and players, musicals and singers and dancers that were once Broadway.
There is an almost-Cubist, quasi-Constructivist Ethel Waters from 1927 that you will not recognize as a Hirschfeld. There are several experiments in style in the first few years of published drawings. The Sacha Guitry has the feel of a Gordon Craig woodcut. Harry Lauder is the work of someone who has seen Picabia. But these are the exceptions in this collection of an artist who seems to have known who he was and what he wanted to do and then to have set about doing it from his mid-20's until just last Sunday. There is not much "growth" in Mr. Hirschfeld's work; it doesn't get better and better. It hasn't declined in quality or become mannered in execution. He can't repeat himself, because his work is about the person he is drawing, not about himself. A Hirschfeld Streisand or Carol Channing or Katharine Hepburn is about the woman herself, not the artist's opinion of her.
Mr. Hirschfeld is never cruel. One cannot even mention him in the same breath as one does a savage drama critic. One draws what he sees; the other tells us how he feels about what he sees. One is called art, the other criticism. I never knew an actress to say she "dreaded" a Hirschfeld. His work is born of love, respect and enthusiasm for the performer. It celebrates and makes permanent the most transient moments of the theater: the performer and performance themselves. We who work in the theater are challenged every Sunday to live up to Mr. Hirschfeld. He has more than lived up to us.
I have never heard this distinguished artist referred to by anything but his last name. He is never "Al" but always "Hirschfeld." I would like to add a "Mr." to that. At age 88, and after a collection as magnificent as this one, he has, like Mr. George Abbott, earned it. Since this is a volume that will be on many people's Christmas lists, this is as good a time as any to say: "Merry Christmas, Mr. Hirschfeld, and thank you for your life's work and much gratitude for reminding us that what we mortals do up there on a stage is important. At times when working in the theater seems impossible and friendless and ignoble, there is always the possibility we will be 'Hirschfelded' for our labors. Hope springs eternal in the theatrical breast. Your work celebrates achievement. This collection celebrates you."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: PRESS;
Newspaper Jobs Vanishing As Advertising Disappears

BYLINE: By Alex S. Jones

 BODY:
IN the last 18 months, employment in the nation's newspaper industry has fallen on a scale probably not seen since the worst days of the Depression.
And a recent survey of newspaper executives by Alex. Brown & Sons, a Baltimore investment firm, suggests that more jobs may be lost because the Christmas advertising season looks "pretty grim" and that even a mild recovery is not expected to come any sooner than well into 1992. 
 While there have been periodic stretches of hard times for newspapers when advertising fell off, they have not led to widespread layoffs, employee buyouts and job freezes. For instance, the total number of newspaper jobs continued to grow from 1980 to 1985, despite the recession in the early 1980's.
"This one is a whole new story," said David J. Eisen, research and information director of the Newspaper Guild, who said his union had lost nearly 10 percent of its jobs since the middle of last year. The Guild represents mostly news, advertising and business-office workers at 140 newspapers and about 60 other news organizations.
After World War II, the number of jobs generated by newspapers has grown virtually without interruption. Indeed, newspaper jobs hit an all-time high of 479,000 in June 1990.
Advertising has since taken a nosedive and revenues declined sharply at many papers. To shore up profit margins, costs are being cut and jobs eliminated at many papers.
From June 1990 through September of this year, total newspaper employment has declined by more than 20,000 jobs, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
The number of jobs lost could easily go significantly higher. There was a flurry of announcements of newspaper layoffs and employee buyouts in October and November, and more jobs are certain to be lost. For instance, The Baltimore Sun recently asked for volunteers to leave the paper with an attractive severance package, and warned of layoffs if not enough employees came forward.
Other newspapers that have been reducing their work forces this year include The New York Times, The Los Angeles Times, The Boston Globe and The San Francisco Examiner.
Not surprisingly, the squeeze has been especially punishing for those seeking a first job in journalism.
Nearly 16 percent of those graduating in 1990 with majors in news and editorial studies said last fall that they were without a job, according to Gerald M. Kosicki, an assistant professor at the Ohio State University School of Journalism, who tracks employment of journalism school graduates. About half that percent were without jobs in 1989. Mr. Kosicki said the 1991 graduates were probably faring worst of all.
"We know anecdotally that it has been very tough this year on our June graduates," Mr. Kosicki said.
Cornelius F. Foote, minority affairs director for the American Society of Newspaper Editors, said many newspapers seemed to be taking pains to keep employees who are black, Hispanic, Asian and American Indian.
Newspapers have been under pressure to increase the representation of minorities on their news staffs, so the papers have apparently been extremely reluctant to lose the minority employees they have.
With overall employment going down, newspapers may be actually increasing the percentage of their minority employment, which totaled 8.7 percent of news staffs last year, by simply keeping the same number of minority positions.
But new jobs for minority journalists are scarce, and at minority-oriented job fairs -- down to 8 this year from 12 in 1990 -- most papers are offering only temporary internships.
Alex. Brown & Sons surveyed executives at nearly 200 papers regarding their economic expectations, and the findings are hardly encouraging.
"The Christmas season is expected to be dreadful," reported Kenneth T. Berents, who conducted the survey in October. He noted that two-thirds of the newspapers polled expected advertising levels below last year's.
The pattern is similar in all parts of the country. Newspaper executives were relatively optimistic about advertising when surveyed in January and grew steadily more pessimistic in surveys in July, April and October.
For instance, papers in the Northeast project retail advertising to decline by 7.2 percent this year from 1990 levels, and classified advertising to be down 10.8 percent. In January, papers in this region were projecting a retail ad decline of 2.7 percent and a classified ad drop of 5.8 percent.
Newspapers in California and the Southwest said in October that they expected 1991's retail ads to be down 5.2 percent and classified ads to be off 7 percent. In January, their predictions were relatively rosy -- a decline in retail ads of less than 1 percent and a 2.2 percent decline in classified.
Newspaper executives have also grown more pessimistic about when business will begin to improve.
About 68 percent said they expected the turnaround, albeit a mild one, to come in 1992. But 28 percent of the executives said they saw no recovery before 1993. In the July survey, only 13 percent thought they would have to wait that long.
For newspapers, the only silver lining in such glum projections is the belief that the industry will emerge leaner and ready for battle when the economy turns.
"As painful as it is right now, the newspaper industry will come out of this period tougher and more competitive than ever," said Cathleen Black, president of the American Newspaper Publishers Association.
But for now, the prospects of better days at an uncertain time in the future is cold comfort.

HEADLINE: Item Pricing Benefits Markets and Consumers

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your Nov. 18 report on the new battle over item pricing of groceries in New York State overlooks the most important issue. The average customer regularly purchases many items, perhaps from more than one store. These items typically have odd prices -- "two for $3.79" and such. The only way most customers can observe a price change is to compare the sticker on the new item with the sticker on the empty package it replaces. Few people are likely to save and compare cash register receipts. 
 Although sellers would like to escape the principle, free markets work for the consumer only when there is price competition. If customers do not generally know when a price rises or falls, there is no incentive for sellers to cut prices and no barrier to price increases every few months.
The main beneficiaries of hidden price changes are not grocery stores, who do compete with one another, but the sellers of leading brands who administer price increases to one and all. Displays of prices and price changes serve both markets and consumers.
 
ART HILGART
Kalamazoo, Mich., Nov. 18, 1991
 
The writer is an economist.

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: Coffee Pricing Meeting Set

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: LONDON, Dec. 1

 BODY:
Coffee growing countries will meet again this week to discuss proposals to stabilize prices.
Coffee importers and exporters that belong to the 73-nation International Coffee Organization will hold a round of exploratory talks on a possible new coffee agreement in London. 
 On Monday, Colombia will try to win support for a proposal matching exportable supply to import demand, said Nestor Osorio, Colombia's representative to the International Coffee Organization.
The proposal would regulate imports by requiring producing countries to keep output higher than predicted demand. Each country would be assigned an amount to be retained and the volume it could export.
But delegates to the talks said they doubted whether Colombia's plan would succeed. They said it was still not clear whether Brazil would cooperate.
Colombia, the world's second-biggest producer, urgently wants to reach an agreement to bring the coffee market back under international control. Mr. Osorio said the nation was concerned about the economic damage being done by low prices.
Supplies were regulated until July 1989, when the coffee market abandoned a system of export quotas because producing countries could not agree on an extension into the 1990's.
Delegates said the 25-nation Inter-African Coffee Organization also intended to present proposals this week, while the United States could also put forward ideas it circulated informally last year.

HEADLINE: Survey Sees No Hiring Gain

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: MILWAUKEE, Dec. 1

 BODY:
The hiring outlook for the first quarter of 1992 is flat, suggesting that the United States economy is growing but very slowly, Manpower Inc. reported today.
In its quarterly hiring survey of 15,000 businesses, the temporary employment agency said 15 percent plan to add workers in the first quarter and 15 percent plan reductions. 
 The zero gain is more promising than the 1 percent decline projected in the first quarter of 1991.
Net hiring gains are projected for the business sectors that employ 60 percent of all American workers: the manufacture of durable and nondurable goods, services and finance, insurance and real estate.
Lower employment is expected in construction, transportation and public utilities, public administration and education, the survey found.
Wholesale and retail trades forecast a significant seasonal hiring decline after the Christmas season. But conditions appear stable on a seasonally adjusted basis, with a stronger outlook than a year ago.
Regionally, businesses in the Northeast and the West expect a net hiring decline. A net hiring gain is forecast for the South, and the Midwest outlook matches the flat national trend.

HEADLINE: Retailers Expressing Tempered Optimism For Holiday Season

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
Although shoppers turned out in greater numbers than expected over the Thanksgiving weekend and sales in many stores seemed better than retailers anticipated, merchants around the country expressed only a tempered optimism yesterday about the holiday season.
Most said they would be hard pressed to achieve sales increases of 3 to 5 percent over last year, increases that would barely exceed the rate of inflation. 
 And those modest gains would be from the depressed levels of the last two holiday seasons, which were among the worst on record.
Strikingly, many merchants who normally insist that everything is coming up roses in the face of even the worst prognostications, are more circumspect this year.
At R. H. Macy & Company, for example, sales were up 8 percent from last year for the full week of Thanksgiving, said Edward S. Finkelstein, Macy's chairman and chief executive. But despite that relatively good showing, Mr. Finkelstein said yesterday that he was disappointed.
"Considering the efforts we have made in terms of promotions and the Thanksgiving Day parade, I thought we'd do a little better," he said.
At Younkers, a regional department store chain based in Des Moines and owned by the Equitable of Iowa Companies, the chairman, Thomas Gould, said: "We had strong sales earlier in the week, and I'd like to think that trend would continue through Christmas. But we planned for a difficult Christmas, and we're prepared for it."
In the Midwest, bad weather cut short a spate of spending last week. Mr. Gould said the ice and snow had forced him to close a few stores on Friday.
Younkers's sales on Friday and Saturday dropped 4 percent compared with last year's, he said, after surging 13 percent in the three days before Thanksgiving.
"The trend had been going up before the bad weather hit," Mr. Gould said. "It seemed as if we had some unexpected momentum."
If the weather caused some stalls in sales, many retailers welcomed the snow, frigid temperatures and ice. Sales of coats, sweaters, boots and other cold-weather gear, which had languished during two mild winters, suddenly took off, Mr. Gould and others said.
The department store divisions of the Dayton Hudson Corporation reported sales increases averaging about 15 percent over the weekend, despite a storm that dumped more than a foot of snow on the company's home turf in Minnesota. While Dayton's department stores suffered a sharp drop in business because of the storm, the company reported an unexpectedly large crowd of shoppers in its Hudson's stores, situated primarily in Michigan.
Kenneth A. Macke, the chairman of Dayton Hudson, said promotions, advertised specials and price reductions were driving consumer spending. Shoppers stood in line for two hours, for example, to see a Pinocchio exhibit in one Dayton's auditorium, he added.
Mr. Macke predicted Dayton Hudson would probably post a 3 to 5 percent sales increase for the holiday season. "Despite all the pessimistic forecasts we're seeing, I think when it's all over, the sleigh will have arrived and Santa will have alighted," Mr. Macke said.
 
Shorter Holiday Season
 Traditionally, the holiday sales season begins the day after Thanksgiving and ends on Christmas Eve. Because Thanksgiving fell late this year, some shoppers may have started buying gifts earlier in the week.
But however strong their sales were before the season officially opened, the shorter selling period has increased the anxiety of retailers.
"What retailers have to try to do is put 300 pounds of wheat into a 200-pound sack, and that's not so easy," said Clark A. Johnson, chairman of Pier 1 Imports Inc., a chain of stores based in Fort Worth that sells housewares, furniture and apparel.
Haunted by memories of the two Christmases past, when an overabundance of goods ate into profit margins, merchants have cut back their inventories. They have reduced the number of part-time workers they hire for the holiday season, using the money they save on salaries to increase the enticements to shoppers.
 
Careful Planning at Sears
 At Sears, Roebuck & Company, the nation's second-largest retailer after Wal-Mart, Matt Howard, senior vice president for marketing, told The Associated Press, "We planned for a difficult environmment, planned for consumer confidence to remain low, and we were aggressive going in."
Mr. Howard said shoppers responded well to products advertised during the film "E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial" on CBS Thanksgiving night and on the Telemundo Spanish-language network on Friday. Sales of Sega and Nintendo video games and wide-screen televisions, all of which were advertised during the movie, were brisk over the weekend, he said.
But some of the efforts that retailers have made to insulate themselves from a poor showing may lock them into a Catch-22 situation, said Stephanie Shern, national director of retail services for the accounting firm Ernst & Young.
 
Popular Items Selling Out
 Many merchants are already finding stocks of popular items depleted, eliminating any further sales opportunities. A pair of men's slippers advertised on Nov. 21 by F. R. Tripler, the men's haberdashery owned by the Hartmarx Corporation, was sold out two days later.
At Dayton Hudson's Target stores, an $80 string of ornaments that plays Christmas carols, called Santa's Marching Band, sold out by the end of the weekend.
"It becomes a self-fulfilling prophecy," Ms. Shern said. "Things are bad, so the retailer puts his goods on sale, and the customer holds out for bigger markdowns."
Reports of exceedingly low consumer confidence on the eve of Thanksgiving did not help calm jittery merchants.
"Consumers are reticent and anxious about their futures," Mr. Finkelstein of Macy said. "All the news about that reinforces everyone's worries, and there's going to be a real retailing push to overcome that."
 
Macy's Enticements
 Like many stores, Macy's spent millions of dollars on enticements to draw stubbornly stingy shoppers into its stores. Now, its executives are holding their breath, waiting to see whether their efforts will pay off. Mr. Finkelstein attributed Macy's gains to television advertising and strong sales in household goods and cosmetics.
Those consumers who were out buying this weekend showed a marked preference for traditional merchandise and items that could be used at home, from devices that toast sandwiches to sweatsuits and other clothes suitable for relaxing around the house.
"People are hanging out at home more, instead of going out to bars and restaurants for entertainment, so they're buying things they use in the home," said Teri Kula, a spokeswoman for the K Mart Corporation.
 
K Mart's Best Sellers
 She said before the weekend that K Mart was doing an unexpectedly brisk business in board games like Monopoly and Scrabble. Items like home security devices and cordless drills and ratchets were also popular, as was a gadget that cuts potatoes into corkscrew curls. Shoppers also bought in-line roller skates, basketball backboards, bicycle safety helmets and Carioci stereo systems, which give budding pop stars the opportunity to sing along with recorded music.
Regardless of price, holiday decorations, ornaments and other tree trimmings and merchandise adorned with Christmas motifs were best sellers. "Some of the research and focus groups we did earlier this year suggested that this was going to be a stay-at-home Christmas, so I think people are getting back in stock on things they might not have used in awhile," Mr. Johnson of Pier 1 said.
He said that sales at Pier 1 stores open at least a year rose an average of about 5 percent for the weekend and that he expected similar sales increases for the entire holiday season.

LENGTH: 1698 words

HEADLINE: McDonnell's Rich Taiwanese Backer

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Nov. 27

 BODY:
In a nook on the 29th floor of a new office building in this city is a two-month-old company whose 40 employees scribble memos, hold meetings and receive guests but have not yet manufactured a single product. Now the novice company is raising eyebrows, and a few tempers, with a plan to pay as much as $2 billion for a large chunk of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation.
The Taiwan Aerospace Corporation is no fly-by-night operation, but rather the high-priority venture of a Government with $76 billion in foreign-exchange reserves, more than any other nation. The prospect of Taiwan's buying a major interest in McDonnell, the largest American manufacturer of civilian aircraft after the Boeing Company, is a sign that this island's economy is coming of age and entering the world of international partnerships and investments. 
 In mid-November, Taiwan Aerospace signed a tentative agreement to buy 40 percent of McDonnell Douglas's ailing commercial aircraft operations for $2 billion. Opposition from some Government officials both in Taiwan and the United States has raised questions about whether the deal will go through, and, if so, on what terms. But many experts expect the plan to set the tone for a growing number of Taiwanese companies to go on shopping sprees in the United States.
"Before, we were lightweights; and 10 years ago, McDonnell Douglas wouldn't pay any attention to us," said Hei Youlong, a private consultant who follows the military industry. "The future trend is that Europe and the United States will start to listen to Taiwan's requests."
Taiwan apparently sees the McDonnell Douglas deal as a way to propel itself to the fore of the global aerospace industry. It ultimately aims to forge an Asiawide consortium, revolving around Taiwan and McDonnell, to build commercial aircraft for the region and the world.
"I think it's a brilliant stroke for them," said Peter Kurz, managing director at Baring Securities Taiwan Ltd. While there may be better sources of technology than McDonnell, he said, Taiwan has few practical alternatives for promoting its own industry.
Taiwan Aerospace intends to shift some production of crucial aircraft parts like wings and fuselages from the United States to Taiwan to learn manufacturing skills.
"With limited experience, the best way to enter the business would be to find a good partner who has been in the business for some time, like McDonnell Douglas," said Denny R. S. Ko, the president of Taiwan Aerospace. "The aerospace industry in general is very expensive."
 
Executive With U.S. Experience
 Mr. Ko, a jovial 51-year-old executive who was born in China and educated in the United States, has been so busy these days that lunches consist of noodle soup at his desk. He has never built planes before, but he worked at the Northrop Corporation and McDonnell Douglas, then established a high-technology consulting firm in California before coming back to Taiwan to establish Microelectronics Technolgy Inc., a maker of portable satellite-communications stations.
The roots of the McDonnell proposal lie in the Government's long efforts to nurture a civilian aerospace industry. One analyst here estimates that about 30 Taiwanese companies are involved in aerospace, in addition to Government-operated units that produce a spectrum of military products from small airplanes to missiles. Taiwan has made an air force trainer and labored for years on its own jet fighter, a prototype of which crashed in a recent test flight.
One factor that remains in Taiwan's favor is a strong and growing supply of engineers and skilled workers. Two years ago the Government dipped into a large pool of engineers and aerospace scientists educated and employed in the United States, recruiting a number of them to return home to help Taiwan expand its own aerospace industry. That, in part, was how Taiwan Aerospace came about.
 
Overture Was Made Last Year
 About a year ago, still without a company name, the nascent Taiwan Aerospace approached McDonnell Douglas about entering some form of cooperation. The Taiwanese start-up was also talking with other aerospace companies, signing 36 memorandums of understanding -- although none of the others have come to fruition yet.
Taiwan Aerospace was officially established on Sept. 27, and much of its current staff, including its chairman, David Huang, formally came aboard. Mr. Huang had worked at Rockwell International for more than two decades before returning to Taiwan to head a military research organization that had been developing the jet fighter.
For McDonnell Douglas, a major incentive is simple: cash. The company is planning to develop the MD-12, a wide-bodied jet that could carry about 600 passengers nonstop from East Asia to New York, and it needs help paying the development costs.
 
McDonnell Seeks Asian Presence
 But the American company will also receive a valuable Asian connection. "McDonnell Douglas is not only looking for the money," said Yang Shih-chien, director general of Taiwan's Industrial Development Bureau, a division of the Ministry of Economic Affairs. "The main goal is to get a higher market share in this region."
An Asiawide consortium comparable to the group that makes Airbus jetliners in Europe is an attractive notion for some people in aerospace because the Pacific, one of the fastest-growing markets for new aircraft, has no major manufacturer of commercial planes. While McDonnell Douglas has also apparently made overtures to companies in Japan, South Korea and Singapore, only the Taiwan proposal seems to hold promise so far.
Some officials in both Washington and Taipei have criticized the deal. Among American worries are the potential loss of commercial aerospace production to Asia, which might harm one of the most important industries in which the United States enjoys an overwhelming advantage. Some Taiwanese critics, meantime, worry that the Government is paying too much for too little technology.
"We don't believe there will be any technology transfer," said Tsay Fun-dow, a Taiwanese legislator with a background in jet propulsion engineering. "All McDonnell Douglas needs is capital. Why should they give us technology?"
 
The Military Technology Issue
 Although the purchase does not involve military programs at McDonnell -- the United States' largest military contractor -- Taiwan might also hope to gain skills useful in its military aerospace efforts. The United States, which maintains formal diplomatic relations with China but not with Taiwan, has withheld the sale of sophisticated military technology to the Taiwanese, particularly the F-16 fighter and powerful engines.
The Taiwanese deny that they are looking for any military payoff from the deal, and McDonnell Douglas has been careful to keep its civilian operations -- the purview of the corporation's Douglas Aircraft Company of Long Beach, Calif. -- separate from its military work.
"We didn't really talk about the military side," said Yang Shih-chien, director general of the Industrial Development Bureau. "It is very natural for people to have that kind of expectation, but it is not an issue included in this deal."
 
Other Criticisms
 Critics have also questioned whether McDonnell's unprofitable commercial aircraft business can be turned around even with $2 billion, and they point to an increasingly competitive market that may not be able to accommodate a relatively small manufacturer behind Boeing and Airbus Industrie.
Others suggest that Taiwan build its aerospace industry from the bottom up, tailoring it to Taiwan's strengths, rather than buying into a mature company that might not fit neatly into Taiwan's economy.
Part of the criticism of the current plan stems from Taiwan's history of developing industries through cooperation with foreign partners. Many people cite the experience of the automobile industry a decade ago, when Taiwan hoped that a deal with General Motors would someday make the nation a significant exporter of cars. Taiwan still does not produce a car of export quality, although it has a substantial industry in making spare parts and components.
 
Supporters See Virtues
 Supporters of the McDonnell deal say that buying into an existing company is the best and cheapest way of starting an aerospace industry. Even if Taiwan never makes a whole plane, an agreement to make aircraft parts may give Taiwan valuable manufacturing experience.
"We would do it to make components, to become a part of the world, to help elevate our traditional industry," said George Shen, president of the Intech Corporation, an aerospace consulting company. "From scratch, you don't know how hard it is," Mr. Shen said. "We can't wait to have a jump start."
Taiwan can offer not only a cheap source of capital but also manufacturing costs that could run 20 percent to 30 percent lower than in the United States.
Still, even with Government support, Taiwan Aerospace has encountered some early setbacks. Originally, it had expected an initial capital investment of $350 million, most of which it wanted to raise from private investors. But it was able to muster only $250 million, with the Government providing 29 percent through a development fund and a Government bank. Sixteen local private investors picked up the other 71 percent. Some potential participants, including a unit of the ruling Nationalist Party, backed out.
Some Taiwanese officials doubt that a final agreement with McDonnell can be struck before the Jan. 31 deadline set for the tentative deal, but both parties have said this deadline is not firm.
While McDonnell Douglas says the price for a 40 percent share is firm at $2 billion, Taiwan insists that everything is negotiable. In any case, for the Taiwan Government, even the $2 billion figure would not break the bank, given that the figure represents only about 2.5 percent of the country's official foreign-exchange reserves.
"If I had $1 million, I might take 2.5 percent of it to gamble," Mr. Shen said. "And that's just gambling. If I think McDonnell Douglas can do a good business, wouldn't I put 2.5 percent in the business?"

THE ECONOMY
Merchants around the U.S. expressed only tempered optimism about the holiday season, even though shoppers turned out in greater numbers than expected over the Thanksgiving weekend. Most merchants said they would be hard pressed to achieve sales increases of 3 to 5 percent over last year, increases that would barely exceed the rate of inflation. And those modest gains would be from the depressed levels of the last two holiday seasons, which were among the worst on record. [Page A1.]
Most senior Republicans and Democrats in Washington doubt there is much they can do in the next few months to bolster the economy. Yet Democrats are hurling thunderbolts at Republicans and vice versa, hoping the voters will not notice how perilously little scope for real action they have. News Analysis. [A13.] 
 The adoption of internationally accepted accounting rules is moving toward reality after years of talk. [D1.]
 
INTERNATIONAL
Taiwan Aerospace's bid to buy a large chunk of McDonnell Douglas for as much as $2 billion is a sign that the Taiwanese economy is coming of age and entering the world of international partnerships and investments. [D1.]

Penthouse magazine's future may be in electronic publishing, if the new president of General Media Publishing succeeds in her latest project. Kathy Keeton learned early on not to flinch at taking risks, and now she is pushing aggressively to make all her company's publications available via computer. [D1.]
The movie-theater business is in a recession, with box-office receipts falling more than 4 percent from a year earlier. Some theater operators do not see a recovery coming soon. [D7.]
