HEADLINE: Black-White Marriages Rise, But Couples Still Face Scorn

BYLINE: By ISABEL WILKERSON

 BODY:
In another era, Tom and Yvette Weatherly might never have known each other. They grew up in opposite worlds in Atlanta, his white and affluent, hers black and working-class. But as the children of integration, they met when she was bused to his virtually all-white high school and sat behind him in English class. They helped each other with class work and goaded each other to raise their hands.
Eight years ago they were married. They have survived their families' shock and disapproval and the stares and unwelcome comments of strangers. They know not to stop in small towns or rural areas when they travel. 
 They are part of a small but rapidly growing corps of interracial couples who, wittingly or not, have put themselves on the front lines of American race relations, staring into the face of age-old stereotypes and painfully aware that their public embraces can unsettle all but the most tolerant Americans.
 
Nightmare, and Role Model
 The number of black-white marriages has more than tripled since 1970, according to the Census Bureau. And while interracial marriage is far more common between whites and members of other minorities, no pairing hits as raw a nerve as unions between blacks and whites. "We are a segregationist's worst nightmare," said Mr. Weatherly, a 30-year-old systems analyst. "But to other people, we're the perfect example."
As the nation confronts persistent racial bigotry, fanned by a stagnant economy and politicians like David Duke, these couples are quietly trying to bridge two increasingly alienated worlds.
Many manage a veneer of civility with once hostile in-laws. Others find acceptance from more tolerant families, particularly with the arrival of the firstborn.
But a few have not even told their parents that they are married and have children. Some say that even after decades of marriage, they are made to feel as if their relationships are illicit or unseemly. Many suffer indignities like being spat upon or refused services. And most say they want the one thing society seems not quite ready to give them: acceptance as ordinary couples.
"It has not passed the 'no blink' test," said Dr. Tom W. Smith, a researcher on social issues at the National Opinion Research Center at the University of Chicago. "It's clear that the majority of whites are not prepared to accept this as just another couple. The minimum you get is a look and a stare."
According to the General Social Survey, an annual polling of 1,500 American adults of all races directed by Dr. Smith, a significant proportion of whites -- 1 in 5 -- still believe interracial marriage should be illegal, as against 2 in 5 whites asked the question in 1972. "They feel so strongly about it that they don't even want to leave it up to the individual," said Dr. Smith, who has conducted the survey for 19 years.
Further, 66 percent of whites said they would oppose a close relative's marrying a black person. Only 4 percent said they would favor it; the remainder said race was not a factor one way or the other. The margin of sampling error in the poll was plus or minus four percentage points, and seven percentage points for blacks.
No other ethnic or racial group engenders as intense a response from whites. About 45 percent of whites said they would oppose a close relative's marriage to an Asian or Hispanic person and 15 percent said they would oppose a marriage between a close relative and a Jew, according to the survey.
Blacks, on the other hand, exhibited indifference to intermarriage, with nearly two-thirds saying they would neither favor nor oppose a relative's marrying someone from another race.
To be sure, some white opposition has melted. The beaming faces of interracial couples appear with little protest on the wedding pages of Southern newspapers like The Augusta Chronicle in Georgia, a state where such unions were illegal until the 1970's. Television shows like "The Days and Nights of Molly Dodd" and movies like "Jungle Fever" have brought interracial relationships to living rooms and theaters, usually in a more realistic fashion than in the 1967 film "Guess Who's Coming to Dinner?"
And in the contentious confirmation hearings of Clarence Thomas to be Supreme Court Justice, his marriage to Virginia Lamp, a white woman from Nebraska, drew little comment. The two were seen every morning of the hearings holding hands and giving each other good-luck kisses on national television.
But these new signs of openness do not necessarily translate into approval for most of these couples.
Teresa Johnson, a white social worker, has been married to Ralph Johnson, a black actor, for 17 years. They have two teen-age children and a house in the Hyde Park section of Chicago. Her relatives are miles away in Cleveland, and all but the very closest of them know her by her maiden name; they think she is single and childless.
To protect this secret, she has not been to a family wedding or funeral since she married, for fear that the topic might come up. For years, only her parents knew. But they were horrified at the news and dared not let it slip. She did not even bother to tell them she was pregnant the last time.
"They were so upset about the first one," said Mrs. Johnson, 40 years old, "because that meant I wasn't turning back."
 
'I Can't Go to Their House'
 For years her parents would not let her children enter their house, preferring instead to meet them at the airport or at a pizza parlor in some other neighborhood. Now her parents let the children visit -- but only at night so the neighbors won't see.
"To this day" said Mr. Johnson, "I can't go to their house because of the neighbors."
Mrs. Johnson said she felt caught in a cruel paradox because people cannot get beyond the color of her husband's skin. "Here we are, a typical middle-class family," she said. "Ralph's a Little League coach. He's on the local school council. I have cousins who have kids out the wedlock, who are juvenile delinquents and in the Hell's Angels. But I'm the one on the outs. If my husband was white and beat me, that would be O.K."
Marriages between blacks and whites make up a tiny fraction of all married couples in the country -- about 4 of every 1,000. But the numbers are rising, as well as the ratio, which was 1.5 out of 1,000 in 1970. There were 65,000 black-white marriages in 1970 and 211,000 in 1990, according to Census figures. While these figures are not broken down by state or region, researchers say such marriages are more common on the East and West Coasts than elsewhere, and far more common in cities than in suburbs or rural areas.
 
Threshold for Integration
 The rise in intermarriage and whites' feelings against it are an important measure of the threshold for integration, social scientists say.
"Intermarriage is like the tip of the iceberg," said Dr. Richard D. Alba, chairman of the sociology department at the State University of New York at Albany, who is a specialist in ethnic intermarriage and race relations. "It is the visible expression of a host of attitudes and informal contacts that are otherwise hard to measure. Whites have difficulty accepting blacks as neighbors and co-workers, and all the more as members of the family."
Still, things are far different from in 1958, when Richard Loving and Mildred Jeter were married in Washington and promptly arrested back home in Virginia. The white groom and the black bride were accused of violating the state's anti-miscegenation law, a felony, and faced up to five years in prison. In exchange for a suspended sentence, they were forbidden to set foot in Virginia for 25 years.
Their case, Loving v. Virginia, went to the Supreme Court, which in 1967 overturned miscegenation laws in Virginia and 15 other states, most of them Southern. Some states kept the laws on the books well into the 1970's, however, and only in recent years have some interracial couples there felt safe.
Indeed, a black woman in Georgia gave her son a gun when he married a white woman in the early 1970's. The son, Nathaniel Brown, now a doctor's assistant, never had to use the gun, but he and his wife were stopped by state troopers on a quiet stretch of rural Georgia road.
"They thought my husband had abducted me," said his wife, Brenda Brown.
Mr. Brown thinks life is easier for the couple now, but not by much. "People now say, 'Maybe I can't shoot this person like I could before,' " Mr. Brown said. "Now that you see pictures of interracial couples in the newspaper and on television, you can feel free to walk in the malls and out in the street, doing what other people do and enjoying each other."
Last August, a Methodist minister in Pennsylvania refused to marry a white beautician to a black army private after meeting the groom-to-be. It was four days before the wedding. "The pastor said I didn't tell him about the situation," said Angela Harms, who managed to find a new church and minister. "Well, I didn't know there was a situation."
Douglas and Marcia Drumright of San Pablo, Calif., were terrorized for four years by a neighbor who was infuriated by the sight of them, a black man and white woman, together. The Drumrights are now suing the neighbor.
In court papers, they say the neighbor, a professed member of the white supremacy group Aryan Brotherhood, cursed at their children, threatened to kill the husband, poured motor oil in their swimming pool and spat on their car as Mrs. Drumright drove her daughter to school. "I'm going to get you," they say the neighbor told them. "I'm going to get your whole family."
 
A Pioneering Way
 It would seem to take extraordinary strength of will to bear that kind of stress, and sociologists say that people who enter into these kinds of marriages tend to have an open, pioneering way about them.
Some say the most common black-white pairing -- a black man married to a white woman -- may be more frequent because of shared feelings of powerlessness. "They both occupy an incongruent status in society," said Prof. Charles Willie, a black sociologist at Harvard University, who is himself married to a white woman. "They both should be dominant, he because he is male, she because she is white. But because of racism and sexism, they are not respected as dominant."
Others say that some black men gain a sense of membership in a white-dominated culture through such marriages. "The white woman becomes the supreme symbol of acceptability," said Dr. Naim Akbar, a psychologist at Florida State University, who has counseled black men in interracial relationships. "It speaks to the serious assault on the person that racism inflicts on us."
For the white spouses, the marriages often become a crash course in what it is like to be black in America. They begin to measure their movements and be alert to discrimination in much the same way blacks do.
MargrietDaniels, a white bookstore owner in Evanston, Ill., who is married to a retired black chemist, worries about their two grown sons simply because of the disproportionate danger faced by young black men. "I hear police sirens, and I immediately think, Where are the boys?" she said. "This is something you don't learn growing up white."
The couples are often reminded that they are the cutting edge of integration. Once a puzzled schoolmate asked the Johnsons' son, Jamarr, about his ethnic origin. Told that Jamarr was half white and half black, the schoolmate was only more confused and asked, "Then who do you guys talk about at home?"

HEADLINE: UKRAINIAN VOTERS CROWD THE POLLS TO CREATE NATION

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KIEV, U.S.S.R., Dec. 1

 BODY:
Voters in the Ukraine were reported today to be registering overwhelming approval of an independence declaration to take the republic out of the Soviet Union to create a nation of 52 million people.
"This is a great day -- it is the flowering of our soul," exulted Olga Ovsiyenko, an election worker tending some of the millions of Ukrainians who went in a holiday mood to the ballot boxes to affirm the long-sought cause of Ukrainian statehood. 
 While the first official results were not promised until Monday, election district managers were unofficially estimating a conclusive, enthusiastic majority favoring independence.
 
Aftermath of Failed Coup
 A full-fledged nation of the Ukraine, a fragile dream across centuries of alien oppression and warfare, abruptly came within reach with the collapse of central authority after the failed coup by Communist hard-liners in August.
The vote for the republic's departure quickens the collapse of the Soviet Union's central structure and has already prompted repeated warnings and complaints from the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, who is struggling to preserve some form of national union.
Nevertheless, Bush Administration officials said last week that the United States was preparing to grant recognition to the Ukraine "expeditiously" should the referendum pass and once the republic meets a series of conditions. The White House thus signaled a shift in American policy toward the separate Soviet republics and away from what remains of Mr. Gorbachev's enfeebled union.
 
Voting for President
 Less certain in today's voting was the outcome of the race for President of the Ukraine. Leonid M. Kravchuk, the Communist Party chief who converted to nationalist politics and survived as the republic's leader, was expected to come in first, but it was not clear whether he would gain the majority needed to avoid a runoff.
Of the original 15 Soviet republics, only the three Baltic republics -- Lithuania, Estonia and Latvia -- have gained wide international recognition of their independence since the August putsch. Most of the remaining 12 republics have declared independence in some form while still forging new economic and political links with Moscow and among themselves.
But today's voting could be a watershed. A ringing electoral endorsement of independence in the economically vital Ukraine, the most populous Soviet republic after Russia, would mark an important psychological milestone and could change perceptions among the republics about whether a union can be preserved. Still, even though the Ukraine has so far declined to participate in any of the talks on political union, it remains uncertain whether today's vote will inevitably lead to a clean break with the other republics.
After a preamble about "the mortal danger" of the attempted coup and its prompting this all-out dedication to independence, the ballot asked in reference to an earlier resolution by the Ukrainian Parliament: "Do you support the declaration of independence of the Ukraine?" Voters crossed out either "yes" or "no," and the uncrossed answer was their choice.
Apart from self-pride and a sense of fresh opportunity, independence would leave Ukrainians with the same daunting problem of how to engineer economic resurrection from the ashes of Communist dictatorship.
 
'Hard Times Are Coming'
 "What else can we do but vote for independence?" asked Aleksandr Yastchenko, a 27-year-old driver. He grimly estimated that it would take 10 years even in an independent Ukraine before the economy improved significantly for his daughter, now 2 years old. "Hard times are coming, no doubt, but we'll get through better this way."
The Ukrainian television news said in a summary that there were high turnouts in most regions and that a positive referendum result was not in doubt. "A majority are for independence from their heart and soul," one newscaster reported.
The first sketchy result came from Odessa, where Ukrainian television reported that Black Sea merchant sailors were favoring independence by about a 90 percent margin. Earlier opinion polls were predicting a favorable endorsement of about 75 percent across the republic.
No clear results were available on the second ballot question, the election of a President. Election district managers said it was unclear whether Mr. Kravchuk was polling more than 50 percent of the vote needed in the six-candidate field to take the election on the first ballot. If not, a Dec. 15 runoff would be needed between the top two finishers.
 
Challenger to President
 Most estimates were that the runner-up challenger would most likely be Vyacheslav Chornovil, a leading Ukrainian nationalist who was imprisoned as an anti-Communist dissident.
"Even here in the old Bolsheviks' neighborhood, the vote is probably better than 50 percent for independence," said Ivan Seryak, manager of the Fourth Kiev Election District in the fashionable hilltop center of Kiev where Communist apparatchiks and widows have long lived.
When he counted the vote after the polls closed, Mr. Seryak was delighted that a booming 85 percent were in favor of independence, and only 12 percent opposed. Mr. Kravchuk received 61 percent of the presidential ballot in this old party district, while Mr. Chornovil drew 19 percent.
 
Absence of Ethnic Strife
 The voter turnout was heaviest in the western Ukraine, where nationalism is most fervent because of the region's history in having been taken into the Soviet Union mainly from Poland in World War II. The vote was lightest in ethnic Russian areas in the east and south, but even there officials were estimating that majorities would be registered for independence. The republic has thus far been devoid of the inter-ethnic clashes that plague other parts of the fallen Soviet empire.
With the continuing downward spiral of the union, the course to independence has grown easier. Mr. Kravchuk, who serves as republic leader through choice of the Parliament, fairly dared Mr. Gorbachev to try to stop the republic's departure. Asked whether he was concerned that the Ukraine might face "measures" from the union, he noted that earlier threats had proved hollow in the case of the now fully independent Baltic states.
"To take 'measures' against the movement of millions is absurd," Mr. Kravchuk said at his voting booth.
"Even the President of the former Soviet Union has no right to interfere," Mr. Kravchuk said of Mr. Gorbachev, whose favor the Ukrainian leader once courted as a careerist in the party. Mr. Kravchuk quit the Communist Party in August when the party's doom was sealed in the failed Kremlin coup.
In solidifying his own transition to the nationalist banner and bolstering his election image, Mr. Kravchuk spoke only Ukrainian in public. He also ordered the appropriation of 25 million rubles of impounded Communist funds to restore various neighborhood churches desecrated under Communism.
More closely noted than Mr. Gorbachev's complaint about an independent Ukraine is the view of President Boris N. Yeltsin of the Russian republic, who has succeeded Mr. Gorbachev as the disjointed nation's dominant leader. Mr. Yeltsin has already conceded that the proposal to seek a new political union from the now highly sovereign republics cannot succeed without the Ukraine.
 
Issuing Currency
 On Saturday he said plans by an independent Ukraine to issue its own currency would affect his own sweeping plans for Russia, the largest and richest republic, to take the lead in reforming the economy and stabilizing the ruble.
Mr. Kravchuk has stressed that the agriculture-rich Ukraine, dependent on Russia's oil and other goods, intends to pursue close economic ties with Russia, which recently signed a commerce treaty with the Ukraine. But the Ukrainian leader, reflecting nationalist pressures and shifting views, has lately rejected a proposal to create an economic community of 10 sovereign republics, saying it was useless.
Last month, the Ukraine Government reluctantly initialed this proposal to pursue a common course on banking and currency, trade and customs. But now the Kiev Parliament is expected to reject that compact as early as next week in the heady aftermath of the independence vote.

Voting for Kazakhstan Leader
 ALMA-ATA, U.S.S.R., Dec. 1 (Reuters) -- President Nursultan A. Nazarbayev of Kazakhstan appeared to be heading for a majority today in the Soviet Central Asian republic's first presidential election, the head of the central electoral commission said.
Four hours before the polls were scheduled to close, almost 10 million people, or 79 percent of registered voters, had cast their ballots in this republic of 16 million said the commission head, Kapar Bukenov.

HEADLINE: The Soviet Shell;
Yeltsin's Assumption of National Finances Suggests an End to the Kremlin's Authority

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Dec. 1

 BODY:
Assuming control over the Kremlin's purse strings this weekend, Boris N. Yeltsin has moved to make the vestiges of central Soviet authority an extension of his Russian government.
His agreement to finance the Soviet payroll and guarantee Soviet state bank credits may have seemed a little routine after the high drama of events beginning with the attempted Kremlin coup and its collapse 14 weeks ago. The move was announced in the form of a brief communique after a "working meeting" between Mr. Yeltsin, the Russian republic's President, and the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev. 
 Yet the surrender of financial control to Russia suggested the end of what autonomy and authority Mr. Gorbachev's battered Government still has.
 
A Label of Convenience
 That, coinciding with what today was shaping up as an overwhelming vote in the Ukraine for independence, confirmed what had seemed increasingly clear throughout November: that the Soviet Union Mr. Gorbachev has struggled so hard to maintain was little more than a label of convenience until Russia, the Ukraine and their neighbors sorted out their increasingly separate fates.
The developments seemed to open a new chapter in the extraordinary story of the disintegration of the Soviet Union. It was a measure of the unforeseeable directions things seemed to take that an event that would have roused anxiety and consternation only a month ago, the transfer of budget control to Russia, now came almost as a relief.
Somewhere in the chaotic events of the last month -- the growing awareness that the Ukraine seemed headed for independence, the bankruptcy of the central Government, Mr. Yeltsin's increasing readiness to assume the debts and responsibilities of the old "center" and the Russian leader's impatience to initiate reforms -- it became evident that the center was failing to hold, but that this might not be the catastrophe Mr. Gorbachev made it out to be.
Whether Mr. Yeltsin planned this is moot. But by waiting until the central Government was on the brink of default in its foreign debts and unable to meet its domestic payroll, he insured that his assumption of these responsibilities would be applauded abroad, at home and among the Soviet republics that still have sizable all-union institutions.
The catalyst, however, was less Mr. Yeltsin's ambition than the Ukraine, the important republic whose national aspirations have figured as a threat to the Kremlin's central authority. Both Mr. Gorbachev and Mr. Yeltsin last week reiterated a truth long familiar in Moscow, that there can be no Soviet Union without the Ukraine and its 52 million people.
Mr. Gorbachev tried to convince President Bush that the exit of the Ukraine was a "catastrophe for the Union, for the Ukraine itself, and for Russia, Europe and the world."
The argument, however, seemed to sound increasingly hollow the closer the Ukraine approached independence. Mr. Bush signaled that the United States was prepared to work toward political recognition if the Ukraine proved responsible in financial, military, human-rights and regional matters.
 
The Ruble Problem
 For Mr. Yeltsin, the real issue was not whether to try to stop the Ukrainians, but to prepare for the prospect that they were determined to go it alone. The immediate concern was that if the Ukraine introduced its own currency, other republics would quickly follow suit and Russia would be overwhelmed with a hyper-inflationary mass of rubles.
That would destroy any chance of stabilizing the ruble and going through with the moves toward a free market devised by Mr. Yeltsin's new government team. One reason for taking hold of the financial levers, then, was to prepare for the possibility that Russia might also be compelled to issue its own currency.
Another reason was an urgent need to curb the flow of paper money at a time the central Government had run out of other means to meet its finances. Mr. Gorbachev and the unwieldy State Council of republic presidents seemed incapable of reaching or carrying out any political or economic decision that might impose fiscal order, and Mr. Yeltsin finally seemed to decide that Russia could wait no more.
In the end, Mr. Yeltsin's assumption of Kremlin finances was widely welcomed. Foreign governments and investors saw a new chance for financial stability, and therefore for repayment of debts and potential new investment. Smaller republics would likewise benefit by the stability at the center and the escape from economic collapse.
Even Mr. Gorbachev gained, since the arrangement won him time to continue the search for an economic and political agreement among the republics.
 
A Curious Symbiosis
 In fact, the two leaders, who once were feuding rivals, now seemed to act in curious symbiosis. Mr. Yeltsin still needed some form of central government if he was to persuade other republics to foot their share of Soviet debts and bills, and to deflect the impression that he was trying to build a Russian empire. Mr. Gorbachev, for his part, seemed to recognize that his office and his dream of a future union could survive only with Mr. Yeltsin's help.
But if the two men once again found a way to step back from the abyss, it was only to face a host of new unknowns.
In Russia, the greatest unknown was how the diverse population of the huge republic would react to the shock of enormous price rises once prices are freed and the ruble is floated. Prices are expected to at least quadruple, and there is the chance of hyper-inflation.
Many officials expected an outbreak of social unrest. Some old supporters began to abandon Mr. Yeltsin, most notably his Vice President, Aleksandr Rutskoi, who declared that he would resign if the economic reforms went ahead.
 
Ukraine's Question Mark
 Another huge question mark hung over the Ukraine. Politicians competing for the Ukrainian presidency all promised that independence would bring quick prosperity, but the reality was likely to be far different as the republic confronted economic reality, including dependence on Russian oil.
Ukrainian politicians seemed likely to find that uniting the republic in opposition to Moscow was far easier than the task ahead -- uniting several sharply differing regions, ranging from the Greek Catholic and passionately nationalist western Ukraine to the Russified and Orthodox eastern region.
There was also the question of how Ukrainian nationalism would affect other republics. There was the chance that the Ukrainian precedent would prompt others to start printing their own money. And if the Russian economy began to founder, it was always possible that Central Asian republics with large Muslim populations might gravitate toward their Islamic southern neighbors.
But for the moment at least, an increasing number of people seemed to find comfort in an aphorism attributed to the 19th century anarchist Mikhail Bakunin: "Anarchy is the mother of order."

HEADLINE: 2 Who Lost Their Way in Urban Wilds

BYLINE: By MARIA NEWMAN

 BODY:
Darrell Sharpe and Jason Bentley lived within a mile of each other amid the threadbare streets and bricked-up buildings of East New York, but had never met.
In a neighborhood where gunfire is common, fear pervaded their young lives, and each chose to deal with it in his own way. Darrell turned inward and chose his friends carefully, so as to stay out of harm's way. The police say Jason apparently armed himself, as many teen-agers there say they do to protect themselves from one another. 
 Their paths crossed last Monday when a fight began over a book bag. It ended when gunshots exploded in a crowded third-floor hallway at Thomas Jefferson High School. In an instant, Darrell, 16, was dead, and a teacher lay wounded. A few hours later, 14-year-old Jason, a baby-faced youth who people say is small for his age, was accused of pulling the trigger.
Darrell's family is inconsolable, unable to comprehend why their son, who had tried his best to resist the allure of the streets, was gunned down during a fight that had nothing to do with him.
Jason's family is despondent, their friends say, that their hard work to build a good life for their two sons could not keep one of them from pulling a gun to defend the other in a petty fight, as witnesses have told the police.
And the neighborhood they shared has been left to wonder how two boys who seemed to be going so right could go so wrong.
A few hours after the shooting, 18 of the 35 boys and girls who graduated from the eighth grade at St. John Neumann Roman Catholic School with Jason last May gathered together to try to understand what happened.
"They were angry at him because he had the same background they had, and he made this decision, if indeed he made it," said Sister Margaret A. Merritt, principal of the school. "They knew where to come for support. Why didn't he? They were also very scared for themselves: If he could make that kind of decision, what's to say they couldn't?"
In interviews with dozens of friends, family members and schoolmates, a picture emerges of two youths who had much in common, but whose paths through the urban wilderness were beginning to diverge.
Both boys were handsome. In school pictures, Jason is always smiling. Darrell was said to love school, although he had to repeat the ninth grade. The principal of St. John Neumann School, where Jason attended since he was 4, said he was so smart, he easily qualified to attend a Catholic high school.
Both have roots in the South. Darrell's father's family is from North Carolina. Jason's parents are also from North Carolina. But in many ways, Jason's background presented fewer hardships. Darrell lived with his mother, who is unemployed, and two brothers in an apartment on Sutter Avenue, in a modern, squat red-brick public housing project five blocks northwest of the high school. Their building is surrounded by open rubble-filled lots and decaying houses, many with bricked-up windows.
In all, Darrell had 13 brothers and two sisters, some of whom live elsewhere. His father died years ago. Chris Sharpe, 18, talked quietly about his brother in the dim hallway of the apartment building. Darrell liked school and attended regularly, and encouraged others to do so, his brother and friends said.
He spent his free time hanging out with his friends on the stoop outside their building or on the streets close to home.
"He just wanted to be alive, I guess," Mr. Sharpe said of his brother. "He just didn't bother nobody. Around here everybody's got to stay out of everybody's way."
 
An Oasis
 Jason lives on Bradford Street, seven blocks southeast of the school. It is an oasis of neatly tended private homes with red and white aluminum awnings. A block or two beyond, the blight of East New York again reclaims its turf.
His lawyer, Harold Levy, said the family did not want to be interviewed for this article. "They are decent, hardworking people" distraught over reports that their son had killed another boy and injured a teacher with a gun purchased on the street for $50, Mr. Levy said.
The father, Rudolph, is a porter at a synagogue in Queens, and before that worked as a security guard. Their mother, Sally, works at the school as a librarian, a job she got to be near her children. They have three children, Jermaine, 17, and Jason and Carrie.
"He's a good kid," Mr. Levy said about Jason. "Unfortunately that's how many kids chose to resolve their problems, by carrying guns. It's a sign of the times."
The police said the shooting grew out of a fight between Jermaine, the older brother Jason adored, and another boy named Jesse Thompson, 17. The dispute apparently had begun months ago over a book bag.
Capt. John J. Finn said Jason drew his gun to help his brother. When the Thompson youth retreated, Jason fired three shots at him, but hit Darrell and a teacher, Robert Anderson, 48. As of yesterday, Mr. Anderson was in stable condition at Brookdale Hospital in Brooklyn.
Except for an accidental shooting in 1989, this was the first killing of a student in a school in more than a decade.
 
Homicides Are Frequent
 In East New York this year there have been 104 homicides, a disproportionately high figure for the city. Police at the 75th Precinct say they confiscate about four weapons a day, most of them guns, and made 158 arrests for weapons possession between July and mid-November.
Several students interviewed during the last week said they carry knives or guns or know someone who does. While some of those statements may be bravado, it is clear that school officials anticipate serious discipline problems. Students must carry ID cards to be scanned by an electronic device to enter the building, and 13 school security guards regularly patrolled the campus.
A sophomore who said his name was Willie said he knew both Darrell and Jason. Willie said many youths carried guns for the same reason that he does: protection in a rough neighborhood.
"I'm not scared to go to school," Willie said. "I come here with a weapon, a 9-millimeter automatic. So it don't make no difference. I'd rather use my fists, but if it came down to that, I'm going to use it."
Almost everyone who talked about Darrell mentioned his earnestness and how he had talked about becoming a policeman or a lawyer or a rap musician. His dreams and goals had not yet crystallized, but one desire had: he wanted to get out, perhaps to North Carolina where some of his family members live.
"He wanted to go back down South," recalled a youth outside the Sharpes' apartment who said he was Darrell's best friend, but who would not give his name. "He always talked about it. But he can never make it now."
 
Basketball and Video Games
 The friend said they would play basketball in the lot behind the apartment building, play video games at Joel's Food Center or look for girls or go shopping along Pitkin Avenue.
"He had so many friends," he said. "He wasn't a fighting kid."
Darrell told Jennifer Cusaac, 15, a classmate and close friend, that he wanted to become a policeman. She lives above a pharmacy on Darrell's street, Sutter Avenue.
"He was a nice guy," she said. "He stayed to himself. He went to all of his classes. He wanted to be a cop. He was going to be educated, and I'm sorry it happened to him."
At a barbershop near the Bentleys' home, the owner and some of the patrons remembered Jason as well behaved.
"He was a nice, cool young guy," said a barber who declined to give his name. "Every time I seen him, he was with a couple of friends. He was never into mischievous behavior, just chillin' with his friends. When I first heard about the story, I was surprised. The family was real close."
Jason came in for haircuts every other week, the barber said. He walked past the shop every day on his way to school.
His half-mile walk took him under the tracks of an elevated train, past run-down corner groceries and empty lots.
Those at St. Michael's Roman Catholic Church, which the Bentleys attended, and the Catholic school say the two boys, who both graduated from St. John Neumann, were inseparable. Jason chose to go to Jefferson because his brother had done so, even though Jason had the qualifications to attend a parochial high school.
Jason began going to the school when he was 4, because his mother didn't want to leave him at home when she walked Jermaine to school. Because she didn't want to walk all the way home twice, she spent most of her day at the school, along with her two boys, and she eventually became a school aide who runs the library.
In the school yearbook the year he graduated from eighth grade, Jermaine said his ambition was to be a cartoonist. Jason said the same when his turn came at the end of last year.
 
Milk Crates for Hoops
 On weekends, he could be found at a cement lot adjacent to the high school playing basketball with a half-dozen other youths in the neighborhood. The backboard is a 15-foot-high chain-link fence surrounding the lot, and the hoops are black plastic milk crates attached to the fence with wire.
On Monday, another neighborhood friend said Jason had stopped by the barbershop window looking distraught.
"He looked very nervous," the friend said. "But he was on his way home. That shows you what kind of kid he was. He went straight home. If he was a kid who was used to doing that kind of thing, he wouldn't have gone home. All I know is that his brother wanted to take the rap for him. They were close like that."
The Bentleys and their children celebrated Mass at St. Michael's Catholic Church on Thanksgiving, and received sympathy and support from other members. Many stayed long after the service ended.
"They have not tried to run and hide," said the Rev. Robert Abbatiello. "I think that says a lot about their character, that they're here as a family."
Still, said the Rev. Brendan P. Buckley, everyone in their community is seeking to understand why what happened happened.
"If I knew that Jason came from a family that wasn't a support structure like his is, then I would say, 'Ah,' " he said. "But that's not the case. What is the lesson here? I don't know.
"I would hope that the pain itself would be part of the process of learning," he said. "We must pray for an end to the violence."

HEADLINE: Scientists Suggest Dumping Sludge On Vast, Barren Deep Sea Floor

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WOODS HOLE, Mass.

 BODY:
Black as a cave, devoid of plants and home to worms and other low forms of life, the thick sediments at the bottom of the deepest oceans are described by marine scientists as immense and empty plains undisturbed by earthquakes or volcanoes.
Now scientists at the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution, one of the nation's most respected marine research centers, believe they have found a use for what they call the planet's most useless real estate. 
 Hoping to disprove conventional wisdom about the ocean's fragility and show that the nation is not turning its back on what they say is the potential for a vast, safe and relatively inexpensive disposal area, the scientists are pushing ahead with an unpopular proposal to investigate the use of the deep sea floor for dumping sewage sludge.
 
No Help for Sloppiness
 "The idea isn't to make it easier for industries or cities to be sloppy with their wastes," said Dr. Charles D. Hollister, a marine geologist and senior scientist at Woods Hole. "But at the same time, no matter how much we recycle and conserve and reduce waste, we're still going to have some.
"Does it make sense to close off 70 percent of the earth's surface without at least studying the idea of using it for waste disposal?"
The idea has roiled environmental groups in the United States and abroad who campaigned for years to end the deep sea disposal of human and industrial wastes and considered the matter closed when Congress enacted the ban on it three years ago. To carry out their study, the Woods Hole scientists are asking the Government to amend the anti-dumping law in a way that would allow ocean dumping of sewage sludge, the byproduct of human waste from sewer systems after it has been treated.
 
Open Ocean 'More Vulnerable'
 Dr. Elliott A. Norse, a marine ecologist and chief scientist of the Center for Marine Conservation, an environmental group in Washington that opposes the proposal, said: "Large amounts of nutrient loading in an ecosystem will bring about profound changes. The open ocean systems, although much larger than the coastal systems, also are more vulnerable because the organisms in them are adapted to cope with low levels of nutrients and have no experience with toxic materials in sewage sludge."
But the scientists at the Woods Hole center argue that the ban on the deep sea disposal of sewage sludge ignores new knowledge about the ability of the ocean to absorb such waste and closes off possibilities for getting rid of sewage in a way that could be safer and less expensive than dumping it in harbors and landfills or burning it in incinerators.
 
House Hearing Planned
 The House Merchant Marine and Fisheries Committee agreed in November to hold hearings early next year to consider allowing deep sea dumping for research purposes only. Congressional permission would allow the Woods Hole scientists to go ahead with the third phase of their study, intended to find out if deep sea disposal makes economic sense and to see how well the idea stands up to critiques by environmental leaders. The hearings could also lead to a lifting of prohibitions against using Federal money to pay for such research.
The Woods Hole proposal for dumping the waste, made public at a conference here in January, would involve shipping one million tons of sewage sludge to one of two sites in the Atlantic about 300 miles off shore, roughly halfway between the East Coast and Bermuda.
The sludge would be lowered through 16,000 feet of water on powerful hoists with leak-proof buckets larger than a house, then dumped on the ocean bottom, where scientists say it would be decomposed by bacteria.
The second phase of the project was completed in November when marine engineers here and at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology introduced concepts for self-propelled, unmanned undersea vehicles that would monitor the safety of a deep sea dumping site. The first phase involved preliminary designs for ships needed to haul the sewage sludge to sea and for the mechanisms for taking it to the bottom.
The not-for-profit Woods Hole institution, whose research is supported by grants from private and public agencies, has been conducting the disposal study with a $250,000 grant from the Sloan Foundation. The institute plans to spend the last of that money in January by holding a colloquium here with environmentalists, who have promised a lively confrontation.
 
'Fight to the Bitter End'
 "The ocean should not be the garbage can for dumping human wastes," said Sarah L. Clark, a staff scientist at the Environmental Defense Fund in New York. "Using the oceans amounts to an 'out-of-sight-out-of-mind solution' and we will fight this to the bitter end."
The notion that the deepest ocean depths might prove suitable for disposing of human wastes has proved to be the most politically ticklish idea put forward by the Woods Hole Institution since the early 1970's, when its scientists proposed disposing of high-level radioactive wastes deep in the ocean bottom. That research, which cost the Department of Energy about $100 million, ended in 1986 when President Ronald Reagan decided to use a barren mountain in Nevada as the site for the nation's repository the waste.
But results of those studies left marine scientists with a new view of the deep ocean environment. They found that currents three to four miles below the surface are generally slower than a sea snail's pace. They learned that the saltier, colder water at such crushing depths takes centuries to mix with less salty, lighter water above.
 
Knowledge Now Useful
 And through countless samples collected from the thick sediments, which are called sea ooze and have the color and consistency of peanut butter, the Woods Hole scientists say they discovered that the deep ocean bottom was probably the most geologically stable land on the planet.
Such characteristics, the scientists say, mean that anything put on the bottom of huge expanses of the northern and southern Pacific Ocean, much of the Atlantic Ocean, and most of the Indian Ocean, would stay put.
Still, to satisfy regulators that the risks were minimal, the scientists need a method for monitoring the dump site. One of the engineers put to the task of developing a remote deep sea inspector was Dr. Albert M. Bradley, a marine engineer in whose tangled laboratory here hangs a red plastic and glass model of a small submersible vehicle that resembles the Starship Enterprise from "Star Trek."
This vehicle, called an autonomous benthic explorer, would be powered by batteries, propelled by electric motors, and could carry cameras and other monitoring equipment back and forth from Bermuda to the disposal area 300 miles away.
No unmanned underwater vehicle capable of such range and intelligence has ever been built, but Dr. Bradley says the technology is readily available. "They build toys now that can do some of this stuff," he said.
The newfound knowledge from the deep had little use until the last couple of years when American cities suddenly found themselves facing large increases in waste disposal costs as landfills filled with sludge and garbage, and efforts to build more landfills met immense public resistance.
The United States produces 300 million tons of sewage sludge annually, and almost all of it is burned in incinerators, applied to the land or put in landfills. Because of much stricter state and Federal environmental laws, more than two-thirds of the nation's landfills have closed since the 1970's, and about 2,000 of the remaining 6,500 will close by 1996, the Environmental Protection Agency says.
 
New York's Dumping Deadline
 New York, the last city to dump its sewage sludge at sea, has to end the dumping by June 1992. But other coastal cities legally dispose of sewage sludge in rivers and harbors, contributing to to the fecal and toxic coastal pollution. Turning sludge into a useful nutrient is difficult and costly because of the enormous volume and the expense of the process.
Scientists who support the Woods Hole research say that, in addition to providing answers about sewage sludge disposal, it is also intended to expand man's knowledge of the deep ocean environment and explore whether the untouched undersea plains are a resource worth exploiting. Coming up with the answers could cost $100 million, the scientists say. They hope to get most of that money from the Federal Government.
The scientists also acknowledge that the study has another goal: persuading lawmakers to consider hard scientific evidence more carefully when weighing political decisions about environmental risks.
"There is too much reaction in Washington to anecdotal and unsubstantiated evidence," said Dr. Judith E. McDowell Capuzzo a biologist at Woods Hole. "If you are going to make decisions and weigh options, part of the criteria will be esthetic perceptions. But science should be at least as important, and too often now it's not."
Lawmakers may be more ready to listen to to both sides of the debate. "We need to keep an open mind," said Representative William J. Hughes, a New Jersey Democrat and a member of the House Merchant Marine and Fisheries Committee. "We're concerned that research projects end up becoming the springboard for commercial ocean dumping. But I don't think we should ever foreclose research, nor the opportunity to look at other options for disposal that are safe and would serve the public interest."

HEADLINE: PRAYERS ANSWERED FOR EMIGRES IN U.S.

 BODY:
In the grimmest days of World War II, when he was a starving Ukrainian partisan besieged by German forces on one side and Soviet troops on the other, Stephen Maksymiw said he endured by whispering to himself over and over that one day the Ukraine would be free.
Nearly 50 years later, as he prayed yesterday morning in St. George's Ukrainian Catholic Church in Manhattan, Mr. Maksymiw said he felt that his dream had finally come true. 
 As a chorus sang hymns in Ukrainian, he kneeled in the Byzantine-style church at 33 East 7th Street in the East Village with hundreds of Ukrainians who came to give thanks for what many called the stunning events in their homeland, which held a referendum on independence yesterday.
"To get freedom for our people, it is beautiful," said the 66-year-old Mr. Maksymiw, who came to the United States in 1949. "When I was freezing to death in World War II, I always told myself: 'One day, we will be a free people.' "
 
Celebrating Their Culture
 Many of the thousands of people of Ukrainian descent in the New York area spent yesterday reveling in a culture that they said had been suppressed by Moscow for decades; the pressures were particularly severe during World War II, when Ukrainian partisans fought against both Soviet and German troops.
Yesterday, Ukrainian-Americans attended services at Ukrainian Catholic and Orthodox churches, sat down to meals of borscht and dumplings, and telephoned relatives in the Ukraine for news of the voting, in which the republic's voters were reportedly favoring independence by a large margin.
Many gravitated to the East Village, long the center of Ukrainian emigres in New York City, where some greeted one another with the traditional welcome of "Slawa Isusu Khrystu!" ("Praise be Jesus Christ!")
St. George's, an onion-domed building decorated with gold mosaics, is at the heart of an area that also features a Ukrainian Baptist church, museum, community center and youth center, as well as Kiev, perhaps one of the few 24-hour Ukrainian restaurants in the world. St. George's, which conducts services only in Ukrainian, abuts Taras Shevchenko Place, named after the Ukrainian nationalist poet.
 
'The News Is Incredible'
 "The dominant spirit is the people can hardly believe this is happening in their lifetime," said the Rev. Patrick Paschak of St. George's, whose parents are from the western Ukraine. "Many of these people are refugees. All they have known is 70 years of Communism. So the news is incredible for them. It suddenly happened out of nowhere."
The Ukrainian Central Information Service, an independent news organization, says 1.75 million Ukrainian-Americans live in the United States; the largest concentrations are in the metropolitan areas of New York, with 200,000 people, Chicago and Philadelphia.
The Ukrainian Mission to the United Nations, whose existence is a legacy of maneuvering by Stalin in negotiations over the organization's charter, was flooded with calls last week from Ukrainian-Americans who wanted to vote in the referendum. But it was open only to Ukrainian citizens, said the republic's chief delegate at the United Nations, Gennadi I. Udovenko.
"Everyone is so highly emotional here," Mr. Udovenko said. "Everyone wants to do something for the Ukraine."
Ukrainian citizens in the United States were able to vote at the Ukrainian Mission, Soviet missions and the Soviet Embassy.
At St. George's, parishioners leaving the 10 A.M. service gathered in front of the church, speaking in Ukrainian and English as they discussed the election and the republic's future.
"I cry all the time about it, from happiness," said Malyniak Miroslawa, 50, of Ridgewood, Queens, who came to the United States in 1979. "I am very nervous. Everything is so good. Today, everything is exciting."
Others feared that as the Soviet Union crumbled, the Ukraine would be left with a ruined economy.
"We are worried about a lot of problems," said Ihor Vitkovitsky, 59, who drove from Silver Spring, Md., for the service. "They can come from economic issues or from the historic aggressiveness of Russia."
But the overwhelming emotion was joy.
"We are going to be free," Mr. Maksymiw said. "Free!"

HEADLINE: MANDELA DEPARTS ON A VISIT TO U.S.

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG, Dec. 1

 BODY:
When Nelson Mandela first visited the United States a year and a half ago, he was greeted with a curiosity verging on adulation because of a stature attained over 27 1/2 years as the world's most admired political prisoner.
Tonight Mr. Mandela left for the United States on a less dramatic working visit, carrying a more complex message as the leader of the African National Congress. 
 At a news conference in his house in Soweto before departing for the airport, he emphasized that South Africa would need international assistance to recover from apartheid -- but that the aid should not be granted until the African National Congress says so.
"Without investment, our economy cannot grow," he said. "But we will be talking about investment in a post-apartheid South Africa, not now."
 
Opposes Rewards to Rulers
 Mr. Mandela does not want the white minority Government of President F. W. de Klerk to receive international rewards for the political reforms it has introduced over the last two years. Mr. Mandela has said that foreign Governments must instead let his nationalist movement decide when and how remaining sanctions against South Africa should be lifted.
He has much to accomplish in a single week. At the United Nations, Mr. Mandela is to address the General Assembly during its annual debate on South Africa and apartheid. He said he would appeal for contributions to subsidize the "safe and dignified return" of South Africa's political exiles, adding that the Government had refused to pay for their trips home and their resettlement.
In New York, Mr. Mandela plans to meet with more than 30 American foundations interested in helping in South Africa. He would not confirm reports that they were considering assistance channeled through a new development bank with the approval of the African National Congress.
' Mr. Mandela is to meet President Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d on Thursday. Again, he refused to say what he would tell them.
 
Stops in Pittsburgh and Houston
 After the Washington meeting, he will go to Pittsburgh to address a group of about 200 chief executives of major American corporations. He winds up his American visit in Houston at the invitation of Texas's Governor, Ann Richards, and will mix with a cross-section of Texas legislators, businessmen and African-American leaders.
Mr. Mandela said he still opposed any further lifting of sanctions against South Africa for now. He said no move should be made to remove sanctions until a constituent assembly is elected to draft a new constitution for South Africa. He had previously said sanctions should be lifted once an interim government is in place. Mr. de Klerk has rejected both demands but has suggested that other transitional arrangements might be possible.
On Saturday, the Pretoria Government, the African National Congress and other political parties completed preparations for a convention on Dec. 20 and 21 that will effectively launch negotiations on the country's future.
The Pan-Africanist Congress walked out of the preparatory talks on Saturday after accusing the African National Congress of colluding with the Government. Mr. Mandela called the walkout "a classic storm in a teacup" today and predicted that the Pan-Africanists would return. Mr. Mandela said the congress was eager to strengthen Mr. de Klerk's position because "he is the only person we can negotiate with."

HEADLINE: Asylum Policy for Haitian Refugees Stirs Debate on Fairness by the U.S.

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1

 BODY:
The Bush Administration's response to an unanticipated flood of Haitian refugees in recent weeks has opened a new debate over whether Washington has a consistent policy on political asylum, particularly in the Caribbean and Central America.
As the Administration looks for ways to undo a court order temporarily barring the forced return of Haitians to a country run by a military Government that Washington does not recognize, critics have charged that damage is being done to America's image and reputation as a nation of safe haven. They contrast the treatment of the Haitians with the Administration's opposition to the forced repatriation of Vietnamese boat people from the British colony of Hong Kong, and with the welcome the United States has extended to to Cuban refugees over the years. 
 Hearings resume Monday in a Federal court in Miami on whether the state order will be lifted and the United States will be allowed to resume the repatriations.
 
'Migration Emergency' Asked
 Beyond the court case, there are demands in Congress and across a spectrum of religious, professional, human rights and refugee groups that the Administration declare a "migration emergency" for Haitians and abandon its forced repatriation policy in favor of more humanitarian measures until democracy is restored in Haiti and the American-led embargo against the poorest nation in the hemisphere can be lifted.
The Administration contends that because the large majority of Haitians are not victims of political persecution, they do not qualify for political asylum, even though many of them are now fleeing a general climate of political turmoil as well as economic deprivation. It says its repatriation policy saves lives by deterring many more Haitians from leaving aboard unseaworthy vessels.
The Coast Guard has picked up 5,914 Haitians in the Caribbean since Oct. 29, more than 2,000 in the last week. Of those, 2,753 are now on Coast Guard cutters, 1,019 are on Navy vessels and the rest have been taken either to a tent city being set up for them at the United States Navy base at Guantanamo, Cuba, or to temporary shelters in Honduras, Venezuela and Belize.
Fewer than 200 Haitians have been allowed to apply for asylum, even though many of the refugees say their reason for leaving Haiti is its climate of growing repression, violence and fear in the aftermath of the military coup that ousted the democratically elected President, Jean-Bertrand Aristide, on Sept. 30.
 
'Temporary Status' Urged
 A consensus is growing that Haitians should as a class be considered for "temporary protected status" under a 1990 amendment to the Immigration and Nationality Act. A full review of immigration and asylum policies could then follow. In the last year this provision has benefited groups of Salvadorans, Palestinians driven from Kuwait, Liberians, Lebanese and Somalis.
"There has been a controversy for 10 years as to whether the Haitians are refugees or not, and it is not going to get resolved in the midst of this crisis," said Dennis Gallagher, executive director of the independent Refugee Policy Group in Washington. "This in an emergency, and it would be wrong to send these people back."
He and other experts in refugee policy see a political aspect to the Administration's policy as an election year approaches. President Jimmy Carter was thought to have been hurt by the arrival of thousands of Haitians in Florida during a relaxation in policy. President Ronald Reagan tightened the policy in his first year in office, and signed the 1981 agreement with Haiti establishing the policy of forced repatriation.
The United States forcibly returned 538 Haitians on Nov. 18 and 19, under a decision that members of Congress and refugee advocates say was made in the National Security Council at the urging of Brent Scowcroft, President Bush's national security adviser. The State Department will say only that the plan was approved "at Cabinet level."
In keeping the Haitians at sea or in accommodations off the mainland, the Administration's intent apparently is to deny them the automatic right to apply for asylum or to seek legal counsel, as many Haitians who arrive in the United States by air now do. But in the court hearing in Miami on Monday, refugee organizations will argue that once in the custody of the Coast Guard or other American services, the Haitians should be considered in American jurisdiction if not actually on American territory.
Arthur C. Helton of the Lawyers Committee for Human Rights and others take the position that whether or not they are on American territory, the Haitians cannot be returned under international obligations and laws.
The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees has asked all countries in the Caribbean basin where Haitian refugees have landed not to return them.
Critics say the treatment of the Haitians is unfair especially in light Washington's treatment of Cuban refugees. Cubans have benefited from the Cuban Adjustment Act of 1966, which made qualifying for asylum easier because they are fleeing the Communist Government of President Fidel Castro. Haitians have traditionally found it very difficult to qualify as refugees and apply formally for asylum. The anomaly has provoked charges of racism from Representative Charles B. Rangel, a Manhattan Democrat, and other members of Congress.
Gene McNary, Commissioner of the Immigration and Naturalization Service, whose interviewers ride Coast Guard cutters to interview Haitians picked up at sea, told a Congressional subcommittee on Nov. 20 that the agency was being unfairly blamed for treating Cubans better.
"The simple fact is that because of the Cuban Adjustment Act, Cuban nationals are treated differently under the law," he said. He added that this law, plus the near impossibility of returning Cubans to Cuba -- except for some criminal and other special cases arising from the Mariel boatlift of 1980 -- accounted for the high percentage of Cubans allowed to remain in the United States.
Mr. Helton says an Immigration and Naturalization Service internal memorandum of Nov. 12 now in the hands of refugee advocates argues that interviews with fleeing Haitians -- conducted aboard cutters under new rules and procedures introduced eight months ago by Mr. McNary -- are proving increasingly inconclusive and of rapidly decreasing validity.
 
15,000 Came in 1980
 After a Federal judge ordered a halt to the return of Haitians on Nov. 19, the Administration has made repeated attempts to reverse the order in court so that repatriations could resume. Administration officials say any blanket change in policy would open the gates to an unknown number of Haitians trying to reach the United States for economic reasons. In 1980, 15,000 came in boats when there was no political crisis in Haiti. The Administration argues that the repatriation of Haitians under the 1981 treaty deters others from risking their lives at sea, and that no Haitian returned has suffered persecution.
On Tuesday, however, the Inter-American Commission on Human Rights estimated that at least 1,500 lives have been lost in Haiti since the Sept. 30 coup. The commission, part of the Organization of American States, met on Thursday to consider reports of detention, torture and harassment of Haitians opposed to military rule. The commission announced, without naming sources of evidence, that two burial pits had been found on Nov. 12 containing the bodies of 60 people, some of them children.
After an emergency session of the O.A.S last week, , it was announced that the human rights commission would send a team to Haiti this week to investigate these and other allegations.
The House of Representatives Select Committee on Hunger believes that the embargo has been so successful that food and other crucial humanitarian aid to Haitian children and other vulnerable people is in jeopardy. The committee, in a letter to the O.A.S., said a shortage of fuel and the general security situation was severely hampering distribution of relief supplies.

HEADLINE: Town Learns Indians Are Taking Most of It Back

BYLINE: By LINDSEY GRUSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CARROLLTON, N.Y.

 BODY:
Dayrll Wetherby drove every nail in his house here.
A Vietnam veteran, he spent a decade building the split-level home: He hauled the stone for the foundation from a creek, felled and milled oaks for the three-inch-thick stairs, laid the floor joints, and hoisted the roof's center beam on his back. 
 But now the Seneca Indians are claiming the ownership of not just the Wetherbys' land, but their house and the homes of about 6,600 other residents of this village and the nearby town of Salamanca, a once bustling railway hub that is the only town in the country built almost entirely on an Indian reservation.
When the Wetherbys moved their house a mile to get it off the reservation, the tribe's leader said the Senecas still owned it. And in an explosive war of nerves, about 50 families have obtained permits to dynamite their homes rather than to turn them over to the Senecas.
 
Residents Increasingly Militant
 "They say, 'If I can't have it, nobody is going to have it,' " said Joseph Fluent, president of the Salamanca Coalition of United Taxpayers or Scout, a group of 1,200 increasingly militant residents who captured every municipal office in recent elections. "I don't think they're going to accept the situation."
The residents have demanded a Congressional hearing that could reopen a wound bandaged over last month when President Bush signed an agreement to pay the Indians a total of $60 million to make up for decades of exploitation.
The battle has already exposed long-simmering tensions between the Indians and the non-Indian residents, many of whom built homes, businesses and factories on land leased 99 years ago for as little as $1 a year.
Both sides see themselves as victims fighting to preserve their heritage and to correct wrongs forced on them by outsiders. The Senecas say that residents are merely trying to continue a tradition of taking advantage of the Indians.
"This is just a sheep in wolf's clothing," said Calvin John, the Seneca President. "Their real beef is the rental payment. They've become accustomed to cheap rent. All we're interested in is getting our land back. We need it because we're running out of land for our own people."
 
Leases and Liquor
 The dispute's roots stretch back centuries to when the area was a speck in a vast Seneca territory. When the first railroad companies began to lay tracks through the Allegheny River Valley in the mid-1800's, white settlers started making deals with the Senecas. Many were illegal, but by the time they were questioned, the city was thriving. Bowing to intense lobbying, Congress validated the leases in 1875.
Then in 1892 tribal leaders were reportedly plied with liquor and coerced into signing a 99-year-agreement that all sides now agree was unjust. Negotiations to renew the lease, which expired Feb. 19, sputtered for a decade, creating uncertainty that accelerated the town's decline.
Driving through Salamanca now is like moving into America's Depression past: one low-slung, boarded-up building after another. Industrial skeletons sit vacant on shadowy side streets, ghosts of an era when the city was alive with a promising future and when freight cars, filled with logs, rattled dishes in dining rooms on the way to eastern markets.
The poverty becomes even more desperate outside of town, where most of the reservation's 3,500 Senecas live in ramshackle huts without plumbing.
 
A Sovereign Nation
 The tension was only aggravated by last year's announcement of the new lease. It raised some rents to $2,000 a year, from as little as $1, as part of a 40-year lease worth a total of $800,000 annually, and called on the state and Federal governments to pay the Senecas $60 million.
The deal outraged many residents. And since 90 percent of Salamanca is on the Allegany Reservation, a sovereign nation nestled against the Pennsylvania border 60 miles south of Buffalo, they cannot sue the Senecas for contract violations.
"I'm a World War II veteran and lost a boy in Vietnam and I don't have any rights," protested Ronald Havers, a 67-year-old resident.
Members of Scout were also infuriated by the failure to address the question of who owns the homes, which under New York State law are assumed to belong to the landlord, the Indians. Both sides said the issue would have complicated the already intractable negotiations.
Jennifer Coleman, a lawyer for Scout who unsuccessfully challenged the deal, said she was rebuffed when she tried to raise the question. "We were told we're crazy," she said. "We were told the nation would never assert their ownership."
 
'It Was the American Dream'
 But the residents worried.
When Mr. Wetherby moved into his house with his wife, Gail, there was little more a frame covered by black plastic. The bitter winter wind, sweeping off Lake Erie nearby, whistled through the home. To keep warm, the couple huddled around a wood stove in the basement.
"Our house: it was the American dream," Mrs. Wetherby said. She said she was so upset about the prospect of losing it that she couldn't sleep. "I wanted peace, just peace," she said.
Her husband added: "This house is where my kids were born. Knowing that this situation is only going to get worse, I felt no one is going to take my home from me. No one."
Two months ago, the Wetherbys tried to make sure. They jacked up the house and moved it to a plot of family land a mile off the reservation. In a carefully worded letter, Mr. John, the Seneca leader, responded by laying claim to the home and demanding that the Wetherbys restore the property to its "original condition, usefulness and value."
Representative Amory Houghton Jr., the Corning Republican who represents the area and helped broker the lease, dismissed the residents' fears and said they should refocus their energies on rebuilding the town's economic base.
"There are many uncertainties in life," he said. "Can a problem be made out of it? Absolutely, as there can be out of anything. But the whole tone has to be moved from the past to the future. We're asking the community to concentrate on building what could be a very exciting place. The Indians own the land. Period. Paragraph. End of story."
But Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, while advising residents to make another effort to work out a compromise with the Senecas, said he expected that Congress would have to enter the dispute.
"These people shouldn't be abandoned," he said. "Do you just allow people to be dumped? No."

HEADLINE: Jobless Man's Plight Typifies Neediest

BYLINE: By J. PEDER ZANE

 BODY:
Two years ago, David Gonzalez and his family had a six-room home. A year later, he, his wife and their three children were living in a station wagon.
"My kids became quiet and withdrawn -- they held everything in," the 32-year-old Harlem native said last week. "But sometimes they'd ask me, 'Daddy, how come no one will hire you?' 
 "I ask myself the same question all the time."
Mr. Gonzalez is among the thousands of New Yorkers who have been transformed by the recession from hard-working breadwinners to bewildered dependents on public assistance. For many, the decline has been marked by hunger, by homelessness and, most damaging, by relentless self-reproach.
 
80th Annual Appeal
 And like Mr. Gonzalez, many of them have turned reluctantly but ineluctably to the seven charities supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.
The fund, which began its 80th annual appeal yesterday, has provided Mr. Gonzalez and his family with food when they were hungry and clothes when they were cold.
Mr. Gonzalez said he "entered the twilight zone" in February 1989, when he was laid off from his $45,000-a-year job in Seattle, where he worked as an aviation mechanic for the Lockheed Corporation.
 
Slept in Parked Car
 For the first six months he supported his family with unemployment benefits and his savings while searching for a job. He started with the airlines and aircraft manufacturers, then security concerns, mail rooms and dozens of other companies. "No one was hiring," he said. "They were all firing."
When relatives told him there were plenty of jobs back in New York, he sold his furniture for $1,500, loaded his family into a station wagon given him by a church, and headed East.
He came home to nothing.
"All the people that told us to come back, when we got here they were like, 'What are you doing here?' " he said. "We had no place to live, so we parked the car on nice streets in Brooklyn and slept there."
At night, Mr. Gonzalez said, he would sit awake in the front seat of the car and try to figure out "what I had done wrong."
Sometimes he would walk off to a field or a playground and "scream, yell, say all the things I couldn't in front of my wife and the kids."
 
Swallowed His Pride
 By day he would job-hunt. He drove out to the aeronautical companies on Long Island and took the subway into Manhattan to interview for positions he saw in the want ads. "No one would hire me because times were tight and I wasn't really looking very good, living in a car and all."
After three weeks, he said, he swallowed his pride and took his family to the Cumberland shelter in Brooklyn. They shared a common space with dozens of other families, thousands of roaches and packs of mice and rats. It was difficult for everyone, especially his children, Christine, 10; David, 8, and Stephanie, 4.
"They didn't say much, but I could hear them crying at night," Mr. Gonzalez said.
He took four exams for city jobs, and applied for security-guard and janitor positions. He tried to enlist in the Army, the Navy and the Air Force, but they turned him down, he said, because it would have been a hardship on his three children. When the Persian Gulf War broke out, he reapplied, but to no avail.
The Gonzalezes' luck started to turn earlier this year, when they were given their own small apartment in a housing project on Staten Island and Mr. Gonzalez's wife, Lourdes, found work as a medical assistant.
She had never worked before, he said, and it was difficult to accept that she was supporting the family.
"I know it's hard for him," Mrs. Gonzalez said.
Today, she brings home $350 a week while Mr. Gonzalez cares for the children, cleans the apartment and continues his job hunt.
"Times are tough," he said, shaking his head.

HEADLINE: METRO MATTERS;
Deciding on Sites for Shelters: A Faceless Numbers-Cruncher

BYLINE: By Sam Roberts

 BODY:
IN a nondescript, windowless office two miles from City Hall, an unelected, unfeeling and faceless numbers-cruncher with more personality than some public officials and more power than most quietly decided earlier this year whether a shelter for homeless people might be built in your backyard.
This high-priced bureaucrat derives power from Chapter 8, Section 203a of the revised city charter. Also from an electrical outlet. Meet the 1990's incarnation of the political machine: an I.B.M. 3090 computer. It was enlisted by the city to help formulate its proposed dispersal of the homeless from barracks-style dormitories to two dozen smaller shelters scattered in every borough. 
 The shelter plan represents the first test of the charter's idealistic framework for injecting fairness into the process of choosing sites for largely undesirable city projects. The charter actually refers to the fair distribution of "burdens and benefits associated with city facilities." These days, though, even parks and school projects can generate local resistance. And it is questionable whether people afraid for their safety or property values will be comforted by being told that their share of the burden is not disproportionate.
The doctrine raises some fundamental questions: Do statistically correct quotas always represent the most proper and practical solution? Are patients better served in remote self-contained shelters or in stable communities that are not conducive to antisocial behavior? Where is land cheapest? Should sites for shelters be debated separately? Or should officials consider the cumulative impact of all existing and proposed projects in a community? If so, how do they assess the relative burden of a homeless shelter and of an incinerator?
Will the impact on middle-class communities provoke lawsuits, like one against a proposed Volunteers of America residence by the West 97-98th Streets Block Association, and another in which a court found that Federal officials had inadequately weighed the Atlantic Terminal renewal project's potential for displacing poor people who live in nearby Brooklyn neighborhoods?
An analysis by the Citizens Housing and Planning Council, a nonprofit monitor, asks: Should the location of a branch library, a presumed benefit, be determined by which community includes branches with the most books, the most books per resident or the number of books circulated compared with the size of the collection? Should the location of a shelter that meets citywide needs be calculated according to the ratio of residential social service beds to the total population or to the welfare population?
"Unfortunately," said Joseph B. Rose, the planning council's executive director, "the desire to impose a greater degree of 'fairness' in the locating of various city facilities is more easily articulated as a political aspiration than codified as a set of regulations governing the placement of facilities as diverse as libraries and sewage treatment plants."
The Department of City Planning incorporated the advice of Mr. Rose and others in drafting, if not necessarily in following, its broad guidelines. Then, the computer was fed the precise location of 66,206 residential beds in shelters, foster group homes, and other city centers, except nursing homes and jails; and the inventory of vacant sites of more than 35,000 square feet.
The computer spewed out 490 locations after exempting 20 community districts deemed to be oversaturated. Its human handlers ruled out 252 and visited the remaining 238, eventually culling 35 -- a third of them in commercial or industrial settings -- from which 24 are to be selected.
From the beginning, the Dinkins administration sought to enlist other elected officials in the process and is doing so again. Except for Ruth W. Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President, many preferred the political cover of the computer.
Richard L. Schaffer, the planning department's director, and Rosina K. Abramson, the executive director, maintain that fair share is not a mechanistic formula. Rather, they say, the computer-generated suggested sites and the eight criteria for alternatives represent just the first phase of the process. Moreover, the charter also requires that sites be "consistent with community needs and efficient and cost-effective delivery of services."
Fair share, said Frederick A. O. Schwarz Jr., chairman of the Charter Revision Commission, "forces politicians and the public, including the affluent communities, to think about the fundamental social pathologies causing the problems and not, like Pontius Pilate, to wash their hands of these problems by hiding them."
In Jim Menick's novel, "Lingo," a computer gets to be president, but makes a fatal miscalculation: by becoming too accessible to the public, he is no longer feared or respected. When the public demands, Are you a man or a mouse?, a politician has more discretion than a computer. Artificial intelligence is no substitute for common sense.
