HEADLINE: New Clue in Mystery of Nature's Forces

BYLINE: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD

 BODY:
Measurements of a rare form of radioactive decay have produced what scientists say is new evidence that subatomic particles called neutrinos could hold the key to fundamental forces of nature and one of the most daunting questions of cosmology: what is the mass -- and fate -- of the universe?
Among the most elusive particles known to science, neutrinos can emerge from radioactive decay of atomic nuclei -- indeed their existence was first theorized to explain a deficit of energy during such decay -- and they are everywhere, traveling close to the speed of light. Yet they interact with ordinary matter only very rarely, so that swarms of them are always passing through earth unimpeded and virtually undetected. Neutrinos have no electric charge and, it had been thought, no mass. 
 Now, scientists at the University of Chicago and the Los Alamos National Laboratory say they have observed an unusual natural process in which uranium atoms were transformed into plutonium-238 at a rate 100 times faster than predicted by current theory. They interpreted the phenomenon to mean that neutrinos do have mass, perhaps more than indicated by recent experiments.
The research is being reported today in the Physical Review Letters by Dr. Anthony Turkevich and Dr. Thanasis Economou, both of the University of Chicago, and Dr. George Cowan of Los Alamos.
Dr. Turkevich, professor emeritus of chemistry, said in a telephone interview that the findings constituted "another, independent line of evidence pointing toward neutrinos' having mass."
 
Far-Reaching Implications
 If neutrinos with mass exist, it could have far-reaching implications for theories of particle physics and cosmology. The ghostly neutrinos could be a major component of the hypothesized "missing mass" of the universe, mass whose gravitational effects have been observed though the source has never been identified. The gravitational influence of the missing mass is considered a major factor in the evolution of galaxies and perhaps the entire universe.
According to calculations of the probable average density of matter in the universe, no more than 10 percent of its predicted mass has actually been detected by direct or even indirect observations.
If it turns out that the universe has less than the predicted mass, it would then lack the gravity sufficient to halt its expansion. It would go on forever, stretched thinner and bleaker. If the universe has more than what is considered the probable amount of mass, in the form of neutrinos or some other unseen matter, its gravity would eventually rein in the expansion, causing it to collapse in what cosmologists call the Big Crunch.
Scientists hailed the Chicago-Los Alamos research as a potentially significant addition to the growing evidence for the existence of neutrinos with mass. But they cautioned that this might not be accepted as the definitive solution to the mystery.
 
'Tantalizing Hints'
 Dr. David N. Schramm, an astrophysicist at the University of Chicago, said that confirming the mass of neutrinos "would be tremendously important for particle physics, cosmology and astrophysics," but "we're not at that point yet, though there are a lot of tantalizing hints around the edges."
Dr. John N. Bahcall, an authority on neutrinos at the Institute for Advanced Study at Princeton, N.J., said, "The evidence is becoming increasingly clear that neutrinos have a small but finite mass."
But he said scientists were reserving judgment on the validity of the new findings. They were concerned, he said, by the possibility of contamination mimicking the observed radioactive decay and the extreme difficulty in interpreting the energies produced by the process.
But Dr. Turkevich said the measurements, first made a year ago, were not reported until the researchers could rule out to their satisfaction any contamination or other explanation.
"Either the standard model is wrong and neutrinos have mass, or we don't know how to calculate the decay rates of such heavy nuclei," Dr. Turkevich said.
 
Testing a Pure Substance
 Dr. Wick Haxton, a professor of physics at the University of Washington at Seattle, was especially skeptical. "It's almost certainly the second explanation," he said, when told of Dr. Turkevich's statement.
But Dr. Haxton praised the research as "a beautiful and very important experiment."
For the experiment, Dr. Turkevich's team used a sample of pure uranium salt that had been stored at the Chicago campus for 33 years. It had been purified in 1956, before nuclear-powered spacecraft and atmospheric tests of atomic weapons had spread some plutonium fallout.
The scientists analyzed the sample for signs of the rare form of radioactive decay known as double beta decay. In normal beta decay, a neutron in the center of an atom changes to a proton, creating an electron and a neutrino in the process. In double beta decay, two neutrons decay simultaneously to produce a daughter nucleus that is heavier than the parent. In uranium-238, this turns the uranium atoms into atoms of plutonium-238.
In their measurement of plutonium extracted from the sample, the scientists reported that one part in 100 million trillion of the original uranium had decayed to plutonium-238. They said this provided the first direct evidence that plutonium-238 occurs in nature.
This double beta decay rate is exceedingly slow, the slowest ever observed in nature, millions of trillions of years, Still, Dr. Turkevich said it was 100 times faster than foreseen by the most recent theoretical estimates. These estimates were based on the standard model of the behavior of elementary particles and the fundamental forces of nature based, among other things, on the premise that neutrinos lack mass.
 
Results of Other Research
 Dr. Turkevich said the faster decay observed could be explained if neutrinos had a mass of about 14 electron volts, a measure of energy related to a particle's mass.
Other research in the laboratory and with underground detectors, searching for neutrinos from the sun and in cosmic rays, has produced preliminary results suggesting that some neutrinos have mass. But their masses are apparently no greater than one ten-thousandth to one one-hundredth of an electron volt, in which case they would have less effect on cosmic evolution. Measurements of double beta decay in germanium indicate that neutrinos can have a mass no greater than 1.6 electron volts.
The most puzzling and controversial finding raises the possibility that some neutrinos may have a mass as great as 17,000 electron volts. The difference between this and other estimates of mass, Dr. Bahcall said, is "like the difference between a huge truck and a tiny pea."
The evidence for the neutrino with extreme mass was found in 1985 by Dr. J. J. Simpson of the University of Guelph in Canada, who was studying single beta decay in tritium, a form of hydrogen. Efforts to duplicate and confirm the results have produced mixed results, and much consternation.
"Such a massive neutrino doesn't fit with anything theoretically," Dr. Bahcall said. "If it's correct, we will have a real mess in astronomy and a real mess in physics."
Recent experiments with underground detectors in Japan, Ohio and the Soviet Union have encouraged scientists to believe that answers to the question of neutrinos with mass may be within their reach. They said new results on neutrinos from the sun were expected to be reported soon from the Soviet-American detector operating deep in a mine in the Caucasus.
Dr. David Caldwell, a physicist at the University of California at Santa Barbara, said that the "theoretical prejudice" now was that neutrinos have mass, but that it was by no means certain that any of the current experiments will provide unambiguous proof.

HEADLINE: Economics '92-Style;
Thus Far, All the Talk by Politicians About What Can Be Done Is Just That

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1

 BODY:
Deep down, most of the senior Republicans and Democrats in Washington, including President Bush and much of the leadership in the Senate and House of Representatives, doubt that there is much they can do in the next few months to boost the economy to any significant degree.
Even a pre-Christmas tax cut, the subject of so much wrangling last week, would probably not have any significant impact until well into 1992. 
 But you would never know it to listen to the politicians because they have decided that the political mood forbids inaction. They rant and rave, Democrats hurling thunderbolts at Republicans and vice versa, hoping the voters will not notice how perilously little scope for real action they have.
 
To Cut or Not to Cut?
 So desperate is the search for symbols of commitment and compassion, two of the code words in this enterprise, that Mr. Bush found himself backing last week, at first reluctantly and then with as much conviction as he could summon, a tax-cut proposal by a group of mavericks in the House, while the Democratic leadership, without much more enthusiasm, discussed the possibility of a special session on tax-cutting next month. Neither side, truth to tell, had any clear idea of where "growth promotion" measures might lead them or the country.
The day after Thanksgiving, the President went shopping at a J. C. Penney store near Camp David in a bit of symbol-mongering as transparent as Michael S. Dukakis's much-derided ride in a tank in the last Presidential race.
"This is about politics, not about economics," a senior Democratic senator said over the weekend. "It's about the politics of 1992."
On the evidence of recent weeks, those politics are not going to be much more substantive than those of the 1988 campaign, in which symbols of race and patriotism -- Willie Horton and the flag factory -- scarcely veiled the failure of the candidates to discuss the momentous changes that were even then foretelling the end of the Cold War, with all of the promise and peril that implied.
Mr. Bush has tried one gambit after another to suggest that he understood the pain felt by the unemployed and millions of other Americans. He postponed a trip to Asia, scheduled to start this week, to work on the economy, when he, in fact, had no plans. He impulsively suggested a cap on credit-card interest rates and that rattled the stock market. He challenged and ridiculed the Democrats on Capitol Hill in one breath and called for an end to partisan conflict, especially where the economy was concerned, with the next.
Sometimes he seems ready to take the advice of conservatives and other combative elements in his party who say the most important thing is to portray the Democrats as impeding progress. Sometimes not.
Already, the President has gone back on his pledge of no new taxes that many backers considered his single strongest campaign card in 1988. They fear that he will be pushed by the Democrats, and indeed by some within his own party, into a position in which he has a most unpalatable choice: either to sign a tax cut for the middle class and make the budget deficit even larger in the hope of stimulating the economy, or to veto it and thus reinforce the idea that Republicans are the party of the fat cats.
Faced with a campaign in which a David Duke candidacy might make it hard for Mr. Bush to exploit racial fears without seeming racist himself and in which there is likely to be little mileage in the old Republican tactic of accusing the Democrats of being soft on Communism, the President and his advisers are fully aware of the importance of the economy in the election. But they have given the impression of hand-wringing rudderlessness. This week's Economist magazine overstates the case, perhaps, but catches the mood with its front-page headline: "President Panic."
Curiously, there was another President Bush also on display last week -- the one who made the bold decision that the United States would have to hold out the promise of early recognition to the Ukraine, if it voted for independence, in the hope that such a prospect would prompt the Ukrainian leaders to make concessions on such important questions as foreign loans and nuclear arms.
That is the ahead-of-the-curve George Bush, the foreign-policy George Bush, the George Bush who built and maintained the coalition that won the war in the Persian Gulf. But that George Bush seems absent from the White House's search for an answer to the nation's economic problems; settle down, the President said in his Thanksgiving broadcast, and I'll tell you what I think in January. This is very different from the President who vowed from Day One that he would not permit Saddam Hussein of Iraq to retain his conquest of Kuwait.
Despite a good deal of fumbling and mindless partisanship, which has helped to drive Congress's standing in the polls to all-time lows, the Democrats have managed to resist Mr. Bush's proposals for cuts in the capital gains taxes by describing them as giveaways to the rich. They want to substitute help for the lower middle classes, especially the white urban voters whom Presidents Richard M. Nixon and Ronald Reagan convinced, at least temporarily, to leave the Democratic party.
But all of that is short-term, largely symbolic stuff.
 
A Real Test, a Real Plan
 Much of the politics of the moment revolves around Mr. Bush, because for now, his foils are the Democratic leaders of Congress, whom relatively few voters see as authentic alternative voices to that of the President. The focus will change in the weeks ahead as George Bush the candidate for re-election finds himself pitted not against Thomas S. Foley or George J. Mitchell or even against a generic Candidate X, but against Tom Harkin and Bill Clinton and the other Democratic hopefuls.
As that happens, the focus may also gradually shift from what will alleviate short-term economic woes to ways to rebuild the economy for the longer term. Then the Democratic candidates will have to move beyond populist slogans to programs, especially if Mr. Bush makes good on his pledge to propose a domestic economic program in his State of the Union Message in January.

HEADLINE: Dubrovnik, Cultural Hostage in Yugoslav Turmoil

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN

 BODY:
The threat to cultural monuments posed by the fighting in Yugoslavia has caused anguish and division among American specialists in Serbo-Croatian culture, many of whom trace their ancestry to that part of the world.
Of particular concern to scholars are reports of damage to the ancient walled city of Dubrovnik on the Adriatic Sea. The city's massive limestone walls -- up to 82 feet high, 19 feet thick and dating to the 13th century -- and many medieval buildings and artworks have earned Dubrovnik a place alongside Venice, Florence and Angkor Wat on the United Nations World Heritage List of monuments of "universal value." 
 Slobodan Curcic, a professor of art and archeology at Princeton who specializes in medieval architecture in the Balkans, said Dubrovnik was important because of its unusual state of preservation, its many important churches, monasteries and palaces, and the medieval artworks in church treasuries and museums.
"The city was badly damaged by an earthquake in the 17th century," Professor Curcic said, "but it was rebuilt in the medieval style. Afterward, its basic character was preserved because its location on a peninsula acted to prevent the Old City from becoming a modern city."
Among the notable buildings in Dubrovnik, which George Bernard Shaw once called an earthly paradise, are the 16th-century Sponza Palace, which combines Gothic and Renaissance architectural styles, as many of the city's oldest structures do; the 15th-century Rector's Palace, which has city records going back 1,000 years, and the Rupe Museum, which was built in 1590 as a granary.
 
The Human Cost
 The Serbo-Croatian civil war broke out after Croatia declared itself independent from Yugoslavia in June. Since then, the fighting has taken at least 3,000 lives, wounded thousands of soldiers and civilians and driven about 500,000 people from their homes. A precarious cease-fire has been in effect since Nov. 23, although sporadic fighting continues.
Dubrovnik's population of 58,000 is almost entirely Croatian. The Yugoslav Army and Navy, shelling the city from land and sea, have damaged the Stradun Promenade or main street, the Rupe Museum, the Minceta Tower, the Revelin Fortress and the top floor of Dubrovnik's synagogue, which was built in 1352.
Since then, damage to cultural monuments has been reported elsewhere in Croatia, notably the destruction of the dome of St. Jacob's Cathedral in the port city of Sibenik and extensive damage to the 18th-century Eltz Castle in Vukovar, a Baroque complex on the scale of Versailles. The World Monuments Fund, an international preservation organization, reports damage to 161 churches and monasteries, 129 palaces, 13 libraries and 3 archeological sites.
But there is no agreement among specialists in the United States on whether the damage has been intentional or accidental and on whether armed Croats have used cultural sites as sanctuaries.
 
An Appeal to Bush
 One of the more outspoken scholars is Ivo N. Banac, a professor of Balkan history at Yale University and a native of Dubrovnik. Professor Banac said in an interview that he had been receiving almost daily reports of destruction in Dubrovnik from colleagues in the city, including a British professor of philosophy at the Inter-University Center there.
Professor Banac said that he and colleagues in the United States had urged President Bush to protest what they regarded as the "systematic cultural vandalism" by the Yugoslav Army.
Professor Curcic, who is of Serbian ancestry and grew up in Belgrade, the capital of Yugoslavia, said he feared that any reports emanating from Dubrovnik would be propagandistic.
"Unequivocally, I would oppose any destruction of cultural monuments," he said, "but I have seen no photographs of actual destruction in Dubrovnik. It is inconceivable to me that in all of Dubrovnik there is not one camera. Until I see authentic photographs, I do not wish to be used to promote the propaganda of either side."
Alex Dragnich, an emeritus professor of social sciences at Vanderbilt University in Nashville, who is of Serbian descent and worked in the American Embassy in Belgrade from 1947 to 1950, said that although he considered himself impartial in the civil war, he had been told by friends in Yugoslavia that Croatian forces had sought shelter by establishing their bases in or near architectural monuments.
 
Many Are Bewildered
 Professor Dragnich pointed to a report in The Economist in Britain that such military installations were set up in the cities of Zadar and Sibenik. "That's a violation of the 1954 Hague Convention for the Protection of Cultural Property," he said.
Many American scholars of Serbian or Croatian ancestry confess their bewilderment with the many petitions and letters they are being asked to sign. "I am seven-eighths a Serb and one-eighth a Croat, and I feel the tragedy within my own body," said George Tomashevich, a professor of anthropology at the State University at Buffalo. "It is an immense tragedy. I won't sign any one-sided documents.
"Cultural monuments, even the most precious, can be restored, but a human life that is lost cannot be. I am not saying we should neglect cultural monuments, but what is more important is the brutalization of human life."
Professor Tomashevich said he and several colleagues had sent letters and telegrams to news organizations and public officials throughout the world urging a cease-fire under United Nations supervision, fearing that the present cease-fire would not hold.
"The Serbs and the Croats are like Siamese twins," he said. "They are joined at the hip with intertwined intestines but unfortunately also with two heads."

SECTION: Section A; Page 16; Column 1; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: Coming Back;
Tax Breaks: Stale Seduction

 BODY:
New York City's economy is in trouble. Unemployment is up 25 percent this year; nearly a million New Yorkers are now on welfare, the most in 15 years. Financial firms, including Morgan Stanley, an industry leader, are pondering leaving. And many other employers express revulsion over filthy streets, crime, aggressive panhandling and soaring drug use.
The common impulse is to demand remedies from City Hall. But even if City Hall were responding brilliantly to the gloom, there are no quick fixes. The city's maladies arise from fundamental forces over which government has little leverage. 
 City policies didn't bring on the telecommunications and computer revolutions, which have freed many businesses from having to locate in an urban core. Neither are any city policies responsible for the loss of U.S. competitiveness in textiles and other manufacturing. Neither is New York responsible for the Federal Government's abandoning responsibility for the poor, imposing an impossible burden on city taxpayers.
Just as city policies didn't create the economic mess, neither will they eradicate it. The forces driving companies out of central business districts to the suburbs and beyond may subside, even reverse. If so, the city government will be a spectator to these trends, not a prime mover.
Yet the city need not wait passively for unknown tidal forces. Intelligent development policies can't turn an economy right side up but they can improve the lives of millions. Long-term investment for the future might well spell the difference between prosperity and decay.
Economic development policies in New York, and other cities, frequently degenerate into quick-hitting tax breaks for businesses willing to locate in targeted neighborhoods and to placate big employers who threaten to move. But studies repeatedly fail to show a net benefit. Corporate location decisions turn more on labor costs and skills, services, transportation and suppliers than on taxes. Yet city after city waves tax breaks at corporate managers in a desperate attempt to keep them from moving.
The problem with targeted tax breaks is their invisible costs. Lower taxes for targeted companies mean higher taxes for everyone else, unless services are allowed to suffer. And those higher taxes will, in turn, drive some other companies to leave. There's also evidence that corporate managers negotiate circles around public officials -- wangling tax breaks for location decisions they would have made anyway.
Jawboning and peer pressure to keep a prominent company are always worth trying. Tax breaks carefully tailored to specific opportunities can make sense. But when holding a company costs a lot of city money, it's probably not worth it.
Indeed, that's the conclusion of a recent report issued by New York City's Office of Economic Development, led by Deputy Mayor Sally Hernandez-Pinero. It calls for a change in policy that would downplay attempts to discourage companies from moving in favor of policies designed to encourage start-up businesses.
Like what? A careful study recently completed by two economists at the University of Pennsylvania, Anita Summers and Peter Linneman, provides important clues. After examining the 60 largest metropolitan areas, they identified two factors that powerfully influence location decisions: the quality of a city's infrastructure and the educational attainment of its labor force.
The lessons are clear, and sobering. To attract new business, New York needs to keep its streets clean and well paved. It needs to maintain its transportation system, upgrade its telecommunications network and, above all, educate its youngsters. Carefully targeted tax breaks can help; but a policy of tax breaks is no answer.
This is not an easy lesson for politicians. Giving away tax breaks sounds good and looks easy because the lost revenues won't show up for years. Investing in public education and public facilities is costly now, and the dividends won't show up for years. Yet that is the only policy economists know can work, and it's the policy that will do the most to hasten New York City's climb back to strength.

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
More Free Lunch

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS

DATELINE: DALLAS

 BODY:
Suddenly politicians of every stripe are demanding a tax cut to "fight the recession." President Bush turned from opponent to enthusiast overnight. Democratic Congressional leaders called hearings for this week to explore their ideas and the President's.
The stampede tells us something about this country. It shows how addicted we are to fulfilling immediate desires, how unable to focus on long-term needs. It shows that we are still gripped by the faith of the Reagan years, though its ruinous effects are all about us: We believe that somewhere there is a free lunch. 
 Cutting taxes now is a bad idea on every count. Because the Federal deficit is so high, everyone proposing a cut promises that his plan will produce no net loss to the Treasury. If that is so, there will be no stimulus to the economy. Some other interest may be served -- undoing the Reagan tax law's tilt toward the rich, for example -- but not fighting the recession.
Some of the tax-cut plans would in fact have a contrary effect. One would pay for the cuts by a big reduction in defense spending, for example. But those paying lower taxes would save at least a little of the money, and spend some of it on imported goods. Result: Less spending in the U.S.
The idea of a tax cut is naturally enticing to Americans as a way of making up for what they have lost economically in recent years. Real wages have fallen in this country over the last two decades. Recession aside, middle-class people feel increasingly that their dream of a rising standard of living is gone.
But what is causing the economic pain -- what is impoverishing the United States in comparison with its international competitors -- is not high taxes. Our taxes are lower than those of any other major industrial country.
The reason for the deteriorating American position is lack of human and material investment. Over many years we have saved less and invested less than our competitors, and the problem is getting worse.
Reaganomics was supposed to cure all that -- induce Americans to save more from higher after-tax incomes. But it didn't work. We saved less. The Reagan economic shamans produced speculation, vast indebtedness, boom -- and now, inevitably, bust.
It is hardly surprising today if banks, burned by all those inflated real estate loans, are reluctant to lend -- whatever interest rates may be. So that hangover of the Reagan era deepens the recession. And so do the massive cuts that state and local governments are now making in their expenditure, in good part because they have lost so much Federal aid under Reagan-Bush policies.
There is a striking consensus among serious analysts that more than anything the United States needs to think of its long-term needs. Failure to do that means falling further behind Japan and Germany and the rest in technology and education.
Herbert Stein, the conservative economist, wrote recently in The Wall Street Journal that his answer to recession "would not be to increase the consumption of Middle America, which would be the main consequence of cutting taxes. I would rather fund Head Start fully, make sure that states have the money to provide the training, social services and jobs called for by the new welfare program, beef up the struggle against crime and keep the libraries and schools open."
Felix Rohatyn, the New York financial expert, called in The New York Review of Books for "a vast national public investment program." He pointed to what other countries are doing -- France, for instance, investing $100 billion in a new national high-speed rail system.
To say these things is to recognize that what the United States lacks is not resources. It is leadership.
For 10 years now we have had Presidents who told us that less would be more -- that the answer to our economic problems was to reduce taxes. We have had Presidents who through ignorance or political calculation would not talk economic sense to the American people.
Talking sense will not be easy for any leader. We are used to fantasy, and we do not want to hear hard truths about sacrificing and investing for the future. But someday someone will make us understand that there really is no such thing as a free lunch.

HEADLINE: Essay;
Bringing The 'Dead Cat' to Life

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
What do you do when the right thing to do is not enough?
That's the Bush dilemma on the economy. The recovery that began this summer from the too-mild, too-short recession turned out to be a "dead cat bounce" -- a brief turn-up before a further sinking sensation. Because the consensus economic forecast turned out to be mistaken, public hand-wringing is rising as consumer confidence is sinking. 
 What's the right thing for the Federal Government to do? If the goal is another long period of prosperous, non-inflationary growth, the answer is no mystery: tough it out.
Monetary and fiscal stimulation are already in place. Interest rates are low and getting lower, the best incentive to borrow and to invest. On the budget side, the Government is pumping in deficit spending of $350 billion a year; the fiscal accelerator is already pressed to the floor.
The wrong thing to do would be to cut taxes or increase spending. That would dismay bond vigilantes and drive up interest rates, inviting recession to stick around another year, harming those most needing help.
At such a moment, a secure President with a passion for prudence would come before the people with a simple message:
The free-enterprise system includes this thing called the business cycle, which includes a downturn every 5 or 10 years. We all know what to do to help keep recessions short, and we've been doing it. The trick now is to suffer awhile, helping the worst hit along, but to avoid panicking and making a big mistake that would plunge us into the double-digit inflation and interest rates of the late 70's, which were followed by the worst bust of postwar times.
Unfortunately, our President, having lost 40 percentage points of light, is feeling insecure. The political opposition, along with the jobless and careerless, has been joined by the Chicken Little media in urging him to do something now, quick, to stop the pain -- to be the nation's daddy -- and he feels forced to respond lest he seem unresponsive, uncaring or unleaderly.
His own party piles on; House Republicans urge a tax cut because they believe there is never a bad time for a tax cut, and taxes as a percent of G.N.P. have never been higher; the Senate minority leader, Bob Dole, ever the stalwart when least needed, declares the President must come up with a plan of action in the next six weeks or the game is up.
This is when the right thing to do -- to take the heat and stay the course, to refuse to make Jimmy Carter's economic mistakes -- needs a little something extra. Not action to "take command" -- ask the Soviets about command economies -- but enough visible activity to create confidence by giving the illusion of solving the problem.
The appearance of action is comforting, and the confidence it builds is necessary -- provided the soothing activity does not become genuine large-scale action (which is the wrong thing except in emergencies).
Now is the time for making a big deal out of relatively minor adjustments -- a challenge to raisin-pickers and a paradise for packagers.
To spur productive investment and break the ideological logjam over capital gains, change the name to "targeted job-creation deductions," which picks up Cuomo and Tsongas support and shifts the focus from fat-cat stock traders.
To raise investment savings and shore up banks, make I.R.A.'s deductible again except for cash-carrying richies.
To show an interest in kick-starting technical advances, start a pilot W.P.A. for a fiber-optic superhighway, offer workers job-training credits and bring back a small investment tax credit for businesses.
This sort of inspired tinkering cannot hurt; to the extent it calms fears by seeming like a bold program to save us from misperceived disaster, it can help. And everyone is already into the act; every candidate can take up a part of the President's scheme and claim it was stolen from him.
The point is to dazzle each other with economic footwork while not doing the wrong thing -- not overstimulating in political panic now at a cost to be paid by the job-entering generation.
Those of us not running for office can say: Fiddle around with creative ideas at the periphery, Mr. President and Congress, to show you're awake to the pain -- but don't mess with a system that is slowly getting itself well.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

SECTION: Section A; Page 16; Column 6; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 598 words

HEADLINE: Historical Forces Drove U.S. and Japan to War;
A New McCarthyism

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The last decade of Reagan-Bush politics and economics have torn American society and unraveled United States-Japanese relations. Middle-class America is rapidly disappearing. The American economy is stuck in a debilitating recession with mounting unemployment. 
 Official unemployment figures mask heavy human casualties among middle- to upper-middle-income households that have eluded past recessions. We must count those involuntary part-time workers who cannot find full-time jobs and those dropouts who are too demoralized to continue seeking nonexistent jobs. I have recently estimated the effective unemployment rate in the United States at a whopping 14 percent, almost double the official number. If we count those who lost high-income jobs and are now driving taxis or bagging groceries at supermarkets, the truer number is nearly 18 percent.
In today's boundaryless world, lowered costs of borrowing capital in the United States prompt many American companies to take their borrowed money out of the country, close their United States operations and invest in places like Malaysia for their captive imports to the United States. The slogan "lean and mean for international competitiveness" has given many American executives an easy excuse to discard their workers, engineers and middle-level managers, the core of the American middle class.
Many companies have certainly become mean, but their failure to invest in human resources and manufacturing facilities in the United States has gutted the industrial fabric of American society and handicapped their international competitiveness. The trickle-down effects of President Bush's voodoo economics, like lowering interest rates, restricting Japanese imports and supporting tax cuts for the capital gains of rich Americans, will never materialize unless they are linked to non-money game investments by American corporations in the United States.
Many Americans are scared for their economic future. In 1988, they were attracted to President Bush for his race-baiting message. Once aroused and legitimized, however, their racial prejudice against nonwhite minorities is easily exploited by the likes of David Duke. They are being easily seduced to blame established politicians, big corporations and especially Japan and Japanese companies for their problems. A recent opinion poll showed that more than two-thirds of Californians support outright restrictions on Japanese imports and investments in the United States. To them, Japanese corporations appear as hostile, suspiciously nonwhite institutions.
Whenever disgruntled American employees of Japanese companies file a job discrimination complaint with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, commission officials are so eager to please Representative Tom Lantos of California that they punish Japanese companies regardless of the merits of the complaints. This is McCarthyism.
I recently learned that the E.E.O.C. has pressured Recruit (U.S.A.) to deny me management consulting work to develop an E.E.O.C.-supervised seminar for Japanese executives in Japan. Pressing E.E.O.C. for an explanation, I was told that my public criticism of Mr. Lantos's witch hunting of Japanese companies angered him. If this happens to an individual, what chance do Japanese companies have from E.E.O.C.?
Fifty years have passed since Japan's attack on Pearl Harbor. United States-Japanese relations are rapidly sliding once again into a hostile phase.
 
YOSHI TSURUMI
Prof. of International Business
Baruch College, CUNY
New York, Nov. 20, 1991

HEADLINE: PRESIDENT REJECTS APOLOGY TO JAPAN

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1

 BODY:
President Bush today rejected any suggestion that the United States owed Japan an apology for dropping atomic bombs on Hiroshima and Nagasaki in 1945, saying that the bombings might have saved millions of American lives and that Americans helped rebuild Japan after World War II.
"No apology is required, and it will not be asked of this President, I can guarantee you," Mr. Bush said, adding that he felt strongly about the matter. "War is hell, and it's a terrible thing. But there should be no apology requested. And that, in my view, is rank revisionism." 
 Mr. Bush's remarks, in a taped interview broadcast on the ABC News program "This Week," came six days before he is to attend a ceremony in Hawaii marking the 50th anniversary of Japan's surprise attack on Pearl Harbor, and one month before he begins a wide-ranging tour of Asia that will include a four-day stop in Japan.
The trip to Asia was rescheduled last week. The President postponed the trip on Election Night after some election returns suggested voter resentment over what some Democrats said was Mr. Bush's lack of attention to domestic issues. The White House said at the time that the trip would be rescheduled.
 
Japan Debating Apology
 The Pearl Harbor anniversary has stirred political and emotional passions both here and in Japan, where the parliament has been debating a resolution that would apologize to Japan's former enemies for its role in World War II. Such a move would mark a departure for the Japanese, who have been slow to acknowledge, even in school textbooks and other public documents, that they were the aggressor in the war.
But as Japan has become a world economic power, sentiment among its citizens has grown that the United States also should apologize for the two atomic bombings, on Aug. 6 and 9, 1945. The bombs killed at least 200,000 civilians and left a scar on Japan's national psyche.
After the attack on Pearl Harbor, Mr. Bush became a Navy aviator. His fighter plane was shot down by the Japanese in the South Pacific in 1943 and after hours in the water he was rescued by an American submarine.
In the ABC interview, which was taped earlier but broadcast today, Mr. Bush said he no longer felt a "personal sense" of anger toward the Japanese for their role in World War II. He said he believed that the Japanese had also put aside many of their animosities over the war, partly because "what we have done with Japan, helping restore that country, is appreciated by Japan."
"And so I don't think there's anybody looking for apologies one way or another," he said. "What we're saying is, 'Hey, let's forget that, let's go forward now together.' And if you see some ugliness in our country about the Japanese, I'll be out front saying, 'Hey, knock that off.' "
But by his language, which included graphic descriptions of horrors he witnessed in the war, the President made it apparent that he believed that the atomic bombings were a justifiable response to Japan's conduct in the war and, he said, an important means by which Japan's surrender was hastened.
Asked directly whether Japan should get an apology for the bombings, Mr. Bush responded quickly, "Not from this President.
"I was fighting over there," he added. "I had my orders to go back there when the war ended, and American lives were saved" by the bombings.
"Now, do we mourn the loss of innocent civilians? Yes. Can I empathize with a family whose child was victimized by these attacks? Absolutely. But I can also empathize with my roommate's mother, my roommate having been killed in action. I think out of our squadron, I don't know whether it was 6 of our 15 were killed."
In saying that the bombings saved American lives by hastening the war's end, Mr. Bush adhered to what has long been the unofficial explanation of American officials for the world's only use of atomic weapons in wartime.

CORRECTION-DATE: December 4, 1991, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Monday about President Bush's rejection of any suggestion that the United States owed Japan an apology for the dropping of atomic bombs in World War II misstated the type of plane he was flying when he was shot down in the South Pacific in 1943. A Navy aviator during the war, Mr. Bush was piloting a torpedo bomber, not a fighter.

HEADLINE: Slow Death On Campus

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 30

 BODY:
Should the University of Bridgeport soon end the long fall from its heyday in 1970 by closing its half-empty campus and going out of business, it would leave two legacies to the world of higher education.
Its increasingly painful struggle to stay alive during the last two decades will have shown, first of all, how very hard it is to kill an American university. Yet it will also have demonstrated just how to do that, step by step. 
 Death, if it comes, will have been helped along by the shrinking pool of college-age students and the financial pressures of the recession that challenge all colleges and universities. But its root cause will be a poisonous conflict between the administration and the faculty over academic ambition: what the university should be, and whom it should serve.
That conflict, which erupted in a faculty strike in 1990, scared away students and created a large group of professors who, locked out of their jobs, hoped for the university's death. It also set trustees on a desperate search for financial salvation that led this fall to the doorway of the Unification Church, further damaging the private university's wounded reputation.
 
Demography Changed
 "Bridgeport is suffering for the situation in its city and the state and in the region all compounded," said Stephen J. Trachtenberg, president of the University of Hartford from 1977 to 1988 who now heads George Washington University in Washington. "Demography changed on them. The economy went south. And then they fell to fighting among themselves rather than dealing with the enemy that they shared."
Many administrators at other colleges and universities, watching uneasily as Bridgeport, almost out of cash, lops off departments and colleges, take its crisis as a warning of what can happen when financial pressures divide a university.
In Connecticut, those pressures have recently caused Yale to cut some sports and close its main dining hall, Wesleyan to stop admitting students without regard to financial need, Post College to affiliate with a Japanese university and Hartford College for Women to merge with the University of Hartford.
At Columbia University in New York City, in a dispute echoing a major point of conflict at far less prestigious Bridgeport, 26 departmental chairmen threatened this week to quit if the College of Arts and Sciences, the center of undergraduate education, takes the brunt of cutbacks threatened by a projected deficit.
"Bridgeport is a sufficiently plausible scenario, it is not so sui generis that it can't happen again," said Sheldon Steinbach, general counsel of the American Council on Education in Washington, which lobbies for the nation's colleges and universities.
For many years, the University of Bridgeport was a success story. Founded as a junior college in 1927, incorporated as a university in 1947, it grew rapidly in the 1960's as members of the baby-boom generation went to college in unprecedented numbers.
Construction was constant on its 86-acre campus, across a city park from Long Island Sound. Departments and colleges were added and expanded; as late as 1977, the university acquired a law school.
But despite the university's growth, its status was insecure. As early as the late 1960's when enrollment peaked at 9,100, there was talk that it would someday be taken over by the state. As construction continued in the 70's, trustees accepted demographic projections that showed enrollment inevitably shrinking.
 
The Critical 1970's
 Bridgeport took few steps in the critical years of the early 1970's to focus its identity. Instead, the most significant development was the formation of a faculty union, a chapter of the American Association of University Professors, in 1974.
The union was born out of longstanding frustration with administrators and newly found pride in the university, say professors who remain loyal to it now that it has been broken and driven off campus.
Pay raises and promotions had been handled arbitrarily for years. Some professors tolerated these practices because they saw Bridgeport as a stop along the way to careers at major research universities. Then the academic job market dried up.
"A lot of us found that we were going to stay here," Ms. Reinhart said, "so then we had a real reason to get this place regulated." As a new president, Leland Miles, took office in 1974, the administration and faculty were forming conflicting visions of the university.
Dr. Miles moved to strengthen business and engineering programs, the main interest of many trustees. The demand for liberal arts studies was falling, he said, and the humanities "should enter into a service relationship with technology."
But liberal arts professors saw the arts and sciences as the foundation of any serious academic enterprise. Every move toward the professions, they said, undermined the university's real strength.
 
Long Strike in 1978
 In 1978, after a long strike, the union had won a new contract under which tenured professors could be laid off, but only if administrators declared a financial emergency or reduced or eliminated a department or college.
"They always refer to '78 as the year the administration lost control of the school," said Gordon Haas, a striking English professor.
But other forces were in motion. Tuition was raised to make up for a shrinking enrollment, making Bridgeport less competitive with its main rival for local students, the University of Connecticut, a state school.
The city was in decline, the campus neighborhood was growing threatening, and dormitories turned shabby as maintenance was postponed. The university began losing a major source of revenue, well-off students from Long Island and New Jersey whose parents could pay tuition, which is slightly less than Ivy League schools. Tuition, room and board is currently $18,000.
When Dr. Miles retired in 1987, the new president, Janet Greenwood, was greeted by a one-day faculty strike over salaries. After learning of a $2.7 million budget deficit, she ordered a financial review and in 1988 presented the results to the university.
 
$12.7 Million in Loans
 In 1989 Dr. Greenwood arranged $12.7 million in loans from a group of Connecticut banks to cover the university's accumulated deficit. She had asked for $16 million.
In March 1990 the administration declared a financial emergency and a plan to lay off 50 professors. As negotiations began on a new contract, the administration told the union it had to save $3 million in faculty salaries. It proposed a 30 percent pay cut.
The administration also wanted back all of the authority it held before the union's formation in 1974, including the right to lay off tenured professors with 30 days' notice.
The union saw the proposals as an attack on academic freedom and an effort to break the union at any cost. That September, 120 of the union's 170 members struck, as did dining hall and maintenance workers.
A few weeks later, the university began hiring permanent replacements. The union was in shock. Within a few weeks, enough strikers returned and enrollment had dropped so much that the university needed to hire only 40 outside instructors. Student support was lost once instructors were holding class. The academic year was under way.
A year later, 64 professors and 4 librarians remain on strike. Enrollment has fallen to 3,850 students. Only 1,200 are full-time, and 93 percent of freshmen receive Federal financial aid.
This week the university won permission to cash $1.3 million in restricted scholarship funds to meet its payroll the next two weeks, leaving $700,000 in its endowment.
 
Eliminating Degrees
 This week the university announced it would eliminate degrees in 30 undergraduate and graduate subjects, including all liberal arts offerings, after spring semester. As many as 300 students will have to transfer from what is becoming, almost by default, a business and engineering institute.
Many professors and students are angry at the strikers for carrying on a campaign against the university, and at the administration for its flailing efforts to retrieve the situation.
The strikers say the university, with unqualified instructors in its classrooms, is a charade of higher education. Their goal is to shut it down for good, in the hope -- however vain -- that the state will step in and resurrect it with a new board.
What has been lost is a vision of what the university should be. The trustees have considered everything from closing down, to moving out of Bridgeport, to mergers, to bankruptcy.
Asked if the trustees have a clear idea of the university the hoped to sustain, the board's chairman, Colin Gunn, said this week: "You want an honest answer? No. We're too busy trying to save it."

 CORRECTION:
A news analysis article on Monday about Bridgeport University misstated the admissions policy of another Connecticut university. Wesleyan, in Middletown, continues to admit students without regard to financial need.

HEADLINE: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
$700 Million in Debentures Set Today by Fannie Mae

 BODY:
The Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, said yesterday that it planned to offer $700 million of seven-year debentures today priced at 99.90625 to yield 7.067 percent with a 7.05 percent coupon rate.
Proceeds will be used to redeem $550 million of series 1991 debentures carrying 11.75 percent interest and due Dec. 10. 
 At the same time, the Government-sponsored mortgage association said it planned to broaden the market for another type of its securities -- those backed by mortgages -- by adding coupon offerings in quarter-percentage-point increments.
"Mortgage securities typically are issued only in one-half percent increments," the association said, adding that those issued with an additional increment of one-quarter percentage point on coupons have generally not received the full value of that increment because of a lack of liquidity.
Debbie L. Cohen, vice president for mortgage-backed securities capital markets at Fannie Mae, said, "It will benefit lenders by allowing them to receive full value of the securities."
She said that the first such issue was a Remic, or real estate mortgage investment conduit, backed in part by $167 million of 8.75 percent Fannie Mae mortgage-backed securities. These 8.75 percent securities are based on a portfolio of 30-year fixed-rate mortgage loans bearing interest ranging from 9 percent to 10.65 percent, mostly coming from the Source One Mortgage Services Corporation, Farmington Hills, Mich., formerly the Fireman's Fund Mortgage Corporation.

HEADLINE: New Measure For Economy

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2

 BODY:
The Government this week will no longer emphasize figures for the gross national product, favoring instead numbers on gross domestic product.
What's the difference? 
 The gross national product measures all the goods and services produced by workers and capital supplied by United States residents or corporations, regardless of location. The gross domestic product measures all the goods and services produced by workers and capital in the United States.
Profits that a United States company receives from its overseas operations are included in the G.N.P. while profits foreign-owned businesses made in the United States are excluded.
The profits on the overseas operations of United States companies are excluded from the G.D.P. while the earnings of foreign companies in the United States are included.
Private economists support the change, saying it will make America's most important economic yardstick compatible with how most other countries measure their own economies.
"No one measure is perfect," said Michael Evans, head of a Washington forecasting firm. "but a far better measure of how the U.S. economy is doing is what is produced inside our borders rather than what is produced all around the world."
The Commerce Department will still publish the G.N.P. figure, but the first look at G.N.P. will come a month after the comparable G.D.P. report.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
The Dollar Is Mostly Lower; Gold Up Abroad, Off in U.S.

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar ended mostly lower yesterday against key foreign currencies, weakened at first by anxiety over an early drop in United States stock prices and later from pessimism over the American economic outlook.
Gold prices fell domestically after rising overseas. At the Republic National Bank of New York, gold was quoted at $366.05 an ounce as of 4 P.M., down $1.45 from Friday's level. At the New York Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery fell 90 cents an ounce, to $367. 
 Foreign exchange traders said the dollar declined early in the day on news of a big drop in the Tokyo stock market. Traders reasoned that the Tokyo decline would spill over into the United States market, weakening the value of American stocks and lessening foreign appetite for dollar-denominated investments.
The Dow Jones industrial average dropped initially but rebounded to a 40.70-point gain. The stock market turnaround helped the dollar recover somewhat, but it still finished mostly lower.
"The Dow average dropped so early that people just started selling the dollar in case," said David Ogg, the foreign exchange manager at the New York branch of Credit Suisse, a Switzerland-based investment banking company.
Charles Cossentino, an assistant vice president at the New York office of Germany's Deutsche Genossenschaftsbank, said the foreign exchange market's initial fixation on United States stock-price movements stemmed largely from the dearth of other economic news.
In addition, traders said the dollar's value was undermined slightly by a report from the National Association of Purchasing Management showing a stagnant United States manufacturing economy in November.
In Tokyo, the dollar fell 0.09 yen to close at 129.98 yen. Later in London the dollar fetched 129.75 yen. By the time trading concluded in New York the dollar fetched 130.15 yen, higher than its 129.93 closing on Friday.
The dollar fetched 1.6100 German marks in European trading, down from 1.6275. In New York the dollar fetched 1.6150 marks, a bit higher than its close in Europe but still down from the 1.6243 level in New York late on Friday.
The British pound rose to $1.7760 in London, from $1.7655 late Friday. In New York, the pound fetched $1.7725, up from $1.7670 late on Friday.

HEADLINE: A Deep Split In Attitudes Is Developing

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Dec. 2

 BODY:
Despite increasing disagreements between Japan and the United States, most people in the two countries say relations between them are friendly, and that their alliance is dependable, according to a poll by The New York Times, CBS News and the Tokyo Broadcasting System.
But the opinion poll also shows a deep cleavage between fundamental attitudes of the two countries, with Americans pessimistic about competing with Japan, and Japanese seeing America as a nation that is declining as a world power and blaming Japan for its own economic problems. 
 The results appear to reflect the economic distress in the United States and the growing economic power of Japan. Both factors appear to be exerting a powerful and perhaps emotional effect on people's outlooks, which may well translate into greater resentments in the future, and perhaps affect the 1992 Presidential campaign.
The findings are drawn from a random sample of 1,106 Americans surveyed by telephone Nov. 18 to 22, and 1,446 Japanese surveyed in person Nov. 7 to 13. The American survey was conducted throughout the United States, excluding Alaska and Hawaii. The Japanese survey was conducted throughout Japan. The margin of sampling error was plus or minus three percentage points.
Some of the most striking results had to do with a tough Japanese approach toward the United States, with 63 percent agreeing that the United States is in decline as a world power, compared with 44 percent of Americans who expressed this view in a Times/ CBS News Poll taken in October.
A majority of both Americans (52 percent) and Japanese (53 percent) agree that Japan will be the No. 1 economic power in the next century. Only 3 in 10 in each country say the United States will be No. 1.
When this question was last asked in both countries in June 1990, the Japanese were more divided, with 42 percent saying the United States would be the top economic power and 39 percent selecting their own country.
The poll showed that all the recent disputes between the countries over trade and economic issues and the gulf war had not affected basic Japanese and American views on the sound and friendly basis of their relations.
For example, 80 percent of the Americans described relations between the countries as friendly, and only 15 percent said they were unfriendly, virtually unchanged from figures recorded in June 1990. Japanese views also remained about the same, with 60 percent saying relations are friendly and 39 percent saying they are unfriendly.
An almost identical majority in both countries (58 percent in the United States and 57 percent in Japan) said they could depend on the other country as a future ally.
In terms of personal attitudes, 77 percent of Americans said they personally had friendly feelings toward Japan and only 17 percent unfriendly. Among Japanese, 65 percent reported friendly feelings toward the United States and 33 percent unfriendly feelings. These were also comparable to the 1990 results.
But questions about attitudes about each other elicited more negative feelings. Many Japanese (70 percent) said they felt that Americans "look down" on them, while only 43 percent of the American respondents said they felt the Japanese looked down on them.
On another emotional issue, United States economic problems, a majority in both countries agreed with the statement that "the increase in Japanese investment in the United States poses a threat to American economic independence." Among Japanese, 76 percent said "the United States is blaming Japan for its own economic problems" compared with 47 percent of Americans.
Much publicity has swirled in recent years about Japanese economic activity in the United States, but the poll showed that Japanese had concerns similar to or even greater than those of Americans.
Most Japanese (52 percent) agreed with Americans (62 percent) who said Japanese investment in the United States jeopardized American economic independence.
And a plurality of Japanese (38 percent) agreed with a plurality of Americans (43 percent) that "the future generation of Americans will be worse off."
Perhaps most striking were disagreements about the war in the Persian Gulf and about issues of war and peace, reflecting the continuing strength of Japanese pacifism and adherence to a constitution that bans the use or threat of force.
The findings echoed the criticisms leveled against Japan when it delayed its response to the war and then declined to send personnel to the Persian Gulf even though it eventually contributed $13 billion in financial aid. Although 61 percent of the Japanese said their country's response was appropriate, 65 percent of Americans said Japan should have done more.
More generally, the results reflected Japanese uneasiness about the use of force at the same time that the United States sees itself as a military guardian of the world, which could have wide ramifications with the ending of the cold war.
Japanese were nearly equally divided over the United States sending troops to fight in the gulf, with 50 percent in support and 47 percent disapproving. Among Americans, support for sending the troops was much higher, with 74 percent in favor and 22 disapproving.
But when asked whether the United States has a responsibility to take military action in trouble spots if asked by its allies, 52 percent of Japanese said no, compared with 63 percent of Americans who said yes.
In addition, 72 percent of Americans said it was appropriate to use force, including military force, to maintain international justice and order, while almost the same proportion (70 percent) of Japanese said it was not appropriate.

Based on nationwide telephone interviews with 1,106 adults in the United States conducted Nov. 18-22 and on personal interviews in Japan with 1,446 adults conducted Nov. 7-13
 
How the Two Polls Were Conducted
The New York Times/CBS News/Tokyo Broadcasting System Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Nov. 18 to 22 with 1,106 adults throughout the United States, excluding Alaska and Hawaii, and on in-person interviews conducted Nov. 7 to 13 with 1,446 adults throughout Japan.
In the United States the sample of telephone exchanges called was selected by a computer from a complete list of exchanges in the country. The exchanges were chosen so as to insure that each region of the country was represented in proportion to its population. For each exchange, the telephone numbers were formed by random digits, thus permitting access to both listed and unlisted telephone numbers. Within each household one adult was designated by a random procedure to be the respondent for the poll. The results have been weighted to take account of household size and the number of telephone lines into the residence and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to region, race, sex, age and education.
In Japan, the survey was conducted by the Nihon Research Center under the supervision of the Tokyo Broadcasting System. Interviews were conducted throughout the country to yield a statistically representative sample. In theory, in 19 cases out of 20, the results based on such samples will differ by no more than three percentage points from what would have been obtained from all adults. In addition, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of opinion may introduce other sources of error.

HEADLINE: Careers;
A College's Intense Push To Find Jobs

BYLINE: By Elizabeth M. Fowler

 BODY:
CAMPUS recruiting is down at many colleges, and the job outlook for seniors next spring is not very good, says Vicki Lynn, director of the career development center at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute in Troy, N.Y. Still, she said Rensselaer's graduates, most of them engineers and scientists, were faring better than those of other colleges.
"We have seen the number of companies sending corporate recruiters decline in recent years," she said last week. She forecast that recruiting this school year would be down by about 10 percent from last year's level. 
 Recruiting activity was plentiful last year, she said, but even so, 37 percent of the 435 companies that came to campus did not make a job offer.
The situation is a sharp contrast to the mid-1980's when most students had job offers well before graduation.
In those years before the recession, some unlikely employers -- like Wall Street investment firms and major accounting firms -- hired engineers, either to turn them into stock market analysts or to work on computer systems. Such job openings have dwindled now as these firms cut back because of hard times.
Mrs. Lynn decided something had to be done this year to help graduates find work, and she came up with the idea of a "jobathon." It resembles the fund-raising telethons in which students spend several evenings telephoning parents and alumni to raise money for their colleges.
Rensselaer's jobathon, scheduled for Jan. 19 to 21, will have a different focus -- jobs, not money. Twenty-six students have agreed to telephone alumni from 6 P.M. to 9 P.M. and ask them about job openings in their companies, most of them small to mid-sized enterprises. The students will urge the alumni to have their companies interview Rensselaer students or at least send in job notices for posting on campus.
She said she thought this was the first such effort by any college in the country. It resembles a procedure followed by the Forty Plus clubs organized for people over age 40 who have lost their jobs. The club members telephone companies to ask about job openings not just for themselves but for all the club's members.
Mrs. Lynn said the students conducting the jobathon at Rensselaer would be given a script, and would fill out a response form for each call.
She said the students would also inquire about summer jobs or co-op positions, which are jobs that permit a student to work and attend classes.
"We are not approaching companies that regularly recruit and hire our students, like General Electric and International Business Machines," she explained. "We're looking at corporations that don't have much of a relationship with R.P.I."
The College Placement Council of Bethlehem, Pa., recently reported that "employers are exhibiting cautious optimism in their 1991-1992 hiring plans." It said that 61 percent of the 342 employers surveyed indicated that they planned to hire more graduates, on average about 8.5 percent more, than in 1990-91.
Mrs. Lynn said she had serious doubts that the situation would improve so much, even though she is optimistic that her jobathon will help increase the percentage of hiring from Rensselaer.
"We will tackle about 750 companies," she said. "and if we get a 10 percent response in some way, I will consider that a success -- and I think we will equal that."
This year's promising fields for engineering jobs, she said, include environmental and chemical engineering, technical writing and management systems engineering.
Students participating in the jobathon include some with interesting affiliations. Anne Williams, a biology major from Delta Junction, Alaska, runs Bagels on the Run, which delivers on campus. Reginaldo Montague, from Brooklyn, a chemical engineering major, is vice president of the campus Society of Black Engineers. Mary Robbins, a management major from Victoria, Ill., heads Winning Attitudes, an organization that campaigns among schoolchildren against drunken driving.
Mrs. Lynn does not worry about other colleges copying her jobathon. "That would be fine." she said. "We have to reverse this trend and help seniors now."

HEADLINE: World Bank to Let Salomon Handle Its Business Again

BYLINE: By KURT EICHENWALD

 BODY:
In one of the firm's first signs of recovery from the Treasuries market scandal, Salomon Brothers Inc. has won back the business of the World Bank after three months of suspension, the firm announced yesterday.
The World Bank was one of the first and most prestigious clients to suspend its dealing with Salomon after the bond trading house disclosed in August that it had submitted a number of illegal bids in Treasury market auctions. The loss of business with the World Bank, whose global bond issues Salomon helped manage for the last several years, was the most stinging client rebuke Salomon suffered. 
 The decision by the World Bank to resume its business dealings comes as a vote of confidence in the sweeping changes made under Warren E. Buffett, the firm's interim chairman. Since taking the post from John H. Gutfreund in August, Mr. Buffett has overseen the establishment of comprehensive rules governing trading, the cutbacks of bonuses and the installation of a new management team led by Deryck Maughan, chief operating officer.
The World Bank's decision was widely seen on Wall Street as an indication that the bank believed Salomon would continue as a primary dealer, a status that allows the firm to deal directly with the Federal Reserve. Salomon's continued status as a primary dealer has been under review by the Government since the scandal began to unfold.
A spokesman for Salomon declined to provide details beyond the firm's one-sentence announcement of the re-established ties. Peter Riddleberger, a spokesman for the World Bank, said of the Salomon statement, "We have no comment, but we are not denying it."
The move by the World Bank, which is the largest borrower of dollars outside of the United States Government, could help Salomon as it tries to recapture business from other large clients. Indeed, some clients who suspended their business with Salomon were also said yesterday to be continuing examinations of their decisions and would soon discuss whether to revise them.
DeWitt Bowman, chief investment officer of the California Public Employee Retirement System, said the giant pension fund was continuing its review of its decision to suspend all trading of Government securities with Salomon. "We have not yet made a decision to rescind that action, but I suspect that we may shortly," he said.
The staff of the California pension fund will likely finish its review before its next board meeting, scheduled for Dec. 18, and make its recommendation then, Mr. Bowman said.
The decisions by clients to suspend their business with Salomon has hurt the firm's prestige as well as costing it business. Because of its suspension, Salomon was barred from a global bond offering by the World Bank and received none of the international lending institution's huge fixed-income business.
The decision by the World Bank to return to doing business with the firm came after months of indecision. When it first suspended business with Salomon, the World Bank said the punishment would last until the end of September, when it would be reviewed.
When a final decision was expected, however, the World Bank announced that it was continuing its suspension indefinitely, leaving another cloud hanging over the troubled firm.

HEADLINE: Construction Spending Up 1% in October

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2

 BODY:
Construction spending, helped by government outlays, rose 1 percent in October, the Government said today. It was the fourth consecutive monthly gain, the longest stretch of increases in five years.
The Commerce Department said residential, nonresidential and government spending totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $411.5 billion, from $407.5 billion in September. 
 The four-month stretch of increases was the longest since spending rose for five months from December 1986 through April 1987.
The revised 1.3 percent advance in September was even larger than the 1.1 percent gain first reported.
 
One Measurement Is Down
 Still, the value of construction put in place in October was 5.3 percent below that of the same month in 1990.
Despite budgetary restraints, government spending jumped 3.8 percent after rising 1.1 percent in September.
"We're seeing state and local governments hesitate to cut back on capital spending plans," said David Berson, an economist with the Federal National Mortgage Association. "They have been more prone to cut salaries and personnel."
Mr. Berson said government spending should get additional stimulus from the $151 billion in transportation spending approved by Congress last week. President Bush said today that he would sign the legislation next week.
Residential spending slowed to a gain of eight-tenths of 1 percent in October from a 2.5 percent jump a month earlier. Mr. Berson said this category would continue to rise at a modest pace.
Spending for single-family housing rose 1.6 percent, after a 2.9 percent gain in September. But apartment outlays fell 4.1 percent, after soaring 7.4 percent in the preceding month.
While housing should continue to move up, there will be no sharp increase in nonresidential spending, Mr. Berson said. Nonresidential spending fell 2.3 percent in October, continuing a six-month slide that included a loss of two-tenths of 1 percent in September.
"Nonresidential building will remain fairly weak because of the glut of office buildings," Mr. Berson said.

HEADLINE: Business Scene;
The Good News That Fails to Cure

BYLINE: By Louis Uchitelle

 BODY:
ALMOST every day brings another gloomy statistic about the economy. The flow of data, however, also includes a number of good news items; in fact, a relatively long list for an economy popularly characterized as dead in the water. But is there enough good news to generate a recovery? Increasingly the answer among economists, in Congress and even at the White House is veering from "yes" to "no."
The problem is that among the eight or so good news entries, only two qualify as engines of economic growth potentially powerful enough to lift the economy from its stagnation. One is home construction, which has risen but not nearly enough to bring the huge construction industry to life. The other is falling interest rates, which should be low enough to lure people into buying on credit. Somehow, the shopping splurges are not happening. 
 The resulting inertia prompts Robert Hall, a Stanford University economist, to declare, "The best news of all is that this stagnant economy is not contracting; it is at least not moving downward."
Like many other economists, Mr. Hall is losing confidence that the current recession, the ninth since World War II, will behave like the others and give way to recovery in some standard fashion. That concern is prodding Congress into a debate over various tax cuts that might, in effect, induce a recovery by funneling money to consumers and to companies. Even the White House, which officially sees an unaided recovery by spring, is showing signs of losing faith in this hands-off approach.
Reflecting the doubts, Michael J. Boskin, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, invited eight economists to a rare White House meeting with President Bush 10 days ago. While the President took notes, the economists told him that low interest rates might not be enough to generate a recovery -- even if the Federal Reserve lowers rates more than it already has.
"No one assured the President that the Federal Reserve alone could guarantee him a boom," said David Hale, chief economist at Kemper Financial Services, who was at the meeting. But when the assembled economists came to consider what steps Mr. Bush should take, there was disagreement.
Neither the Bush Administration nor the group of conservative economists with whom he met has much faith in fiscal stimulus; that is, tax cuts or tax credits or public works spending to increase economic activity. Such measures would raise the deficit, temporarily at least, and also undo the agreement negotiated last year to eliminate the deficit. "There is not enough scope to cut taxes or spend enough to get the economy going," said Mr. Hall, who was at the meeting.
The fallback position is faith in the restorative powers of the various items on the good news list, all of them measuring progress since last spring, 10 months after the recession's start. Aside from the rise in home construction and home sales, more people are refinancing mortgages at lower interest rates, which lowers installment payments and thus frees cash for other uses. Exports are strong, and manufacturing output has risen. Business spending on new equipment is also up slightly. Inflation is low. Profit margins are a bit higher as companies cut costs, partly through layoffs and lower materials prices. And many companies and individuals have reduced their debts.
"If you look back to early spring, you can see the recovery, but if you look back to the summer of 1990, when the recession started, you can't," said Geoffrey Moore, director of Columbia University's Center for Business Cycle Research. Put another way, the gross national product, the total value of the goods and services produced in a given year, shrank by $52 billion between July 1990 and last spring. Since spring the G.N.P. has recovered $24 billion of the lost ground, reaching by October an annual rate of $4.143 trillion, adjusted for inflation. There it has nearly stopped. (A recession officially ends when all of the lost ground is recovered.)
Apart from the recession, Mr. Bush has to consider the economy from a longer perspective, one that started in January 1989, when he took office. The G.N.P., adjusted for inflation, has expanded by only $47 billion since then, a meager 1 percent rise in nearly three years. Perhaps more important, in the 1988 campaign, Mr. Bush spoke of an economy robust enough to create 30 million jobs during eight years of a Bush Presidency, or twice the job growth in President Ronald Reagan's two terms.
So far, the sluggish economy has generated only 1.6 million new jobs since January 1989, and even that small number might be cut to less than one million, if the Labor Department adopts revisions now under consideration. "Bush's timing was bad," Mr. Hale said. "He came to office at the end of a long, excessive business cycle, and his Presidency has become a cleanup job."
