HEADLINE: U.N. Report Warns of Crisis in Eastern Europe

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Dec. 2

 BODY:
A United Nations commission warned today that the shattered economies of Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union could soon reach the breaking point, saying that their economic output had declined to the point that their slide should be called a depression.
The Geneva-based United Nations Economic Commission on Europe said economic output in Eastern Europe would plunge by almost 15 percent this year, which it said would bring the decline in production over three years to almost 25 percent. It said that in the United States Depression, output from 1929 to 1933 fell by 29 percent. 
 As for the Soviet Union, the commission predicted that economic output would fall by almost 15 percent this year. It forecast a drop next year of about 6 percent, but it said that if the republics failed to agree on a viable economic policy, the decline could be much larger.
The commission's report said it was uncertain how much longer Eastern Europeans would peacefully tolerate these huge declines in output as their nations made the harrowing transition from Communism to a market economy.
It seems likely that social unrest will increase in 1992, and that in some countries there will be increasing pressure to dilute or abandon the reform process, the report said.
Nonetheless, the commission added that all the nations undertaking economic transitions were faced with the necessity of persevering with tough measures to reorganize their economies, bring down inflation and reduce their budget deficits.
To help the region's transition to a market economy, the commission urgently called on the West to step up economic aid and do more to open its markets to the former Communist bloc. With 24 nations and 7 international institutions providing aid to the region, it called for stepped-up efforts to draft and carry out a coordinated program.
The transition process is going to be a lengthy one, extending in some cases over several decades, the commission said. "It is therefore going to require a sustained commitment to coordinated action on the part of all governments with an interest in its success," it said.
The commission said that industrial output in eastern Germany would plunge by 50 percent this year. But in one of the report's bright spots, it forecast that eastern Germany's economy would finally rebound next year, predicting growth of 10 percent thanks to the strength of public invesment.
"It is too early to say whether this is the start of a self-sustained recovery in economic activity, but clearly it is a hopeful sign of improvement," the report said.
The report predicted that Hungary's economy would grow by 1 to 2 percent next year, after sliding since 1989. It forecast that Polish output would fall again in 1992, for the fourth year in a row, although it said there were some hopes that an upturn would begin in late 1992.
The commission was of two minds on whether the Soviet republics should have a monetary union. Arguing on behalf of such a union, the report said it would help Western governments conduct business with the republics and would mean closer cooperation among republics -- and thus less of a chance of friction and violence among them.
But, arguing for several currencies, the report said that taxation and spending were already at the republic level and that fiscal discipline could be established only if republic politicians were faced with the consequences of budgetary extravagance.
One problem of a central bank with a single currency, it said, is that officials from the republics might run up huge deficits and demand that the central bank issue money to cover the debt.
The existence of a central bank and a nominally single currency has not prevented inflation from rising to an annual rate of around 360 percent in September, the report said.
Although the commission did not say whether the Soviet Union should remain intact as a single political entity, it said that "coherence in the structure of political authority" was among conditions for continued foreign assistance.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Knoxville Paper to End Daily Publication

BYLINE: By ALEX S. JONES

 BODY:
The Knoxville (Tenn.) Journal, an evening paper long dominated by its morning rival, The Knoxville News-Sentinel, said yesterday that it would stop publishing as a daily on Dec. 31.
Knoxville will then join a host of other mid-sized cities that have lost their second-ranked newspaper during the newspaper recession. These cities include San Diego, Little Rock, Ark., and Roanoke, Va. 
 Gerald Garcia, the editor and publisher, said in an article in yesterday's issue that there were plans to publish a weekend paper, to be called The Weekend Journal, that would focus on local news, entertainment and University of Tennessee sports.
 
Workers to Be Dismissed
 But Mr. Garcia said that all 69 of the daily's employees would be dismissed and that The Weekend Journal would be published with employees from a sister paper, The Daily Times, in Maryville, Tenn., a about 20 miles from Knoxville. Mr. Garcia, who is also the editor and publisher of The Daily Times, said he did not know if any Journal employees would be hired for the weekend paper.
The Knoxville Journal and The Daily Times are owned by the Persis Corporation, which also owns The Honolulu Advertiser.
The Journal, which was founded in 1838, has a daily circulation of about 40,000, according to the Audit Bureau of Circulations. The News-Sentinel, which is owned by the E. W. Scripps Company, has a daily circulation of about 104,000 and Sunday sales of about 175,000.
Neither The Journal nor The Daily Times, with a circulation of about 21,000, publishes a Sunday issue.
For most of the century, The Journal was the voice of East Tennessee's Republican Party. Perhaps The Journal's last grand campaign was a long-running expose in the late 1970's of the banking practices of Jake Butcher, a developer and Democratic gubernatorial candidate who eventually went to jail.
In the mid-1980's, the Gannett Company, The Journal's owner at the time, and Scripps renegotiated a joint operating arrangement in force at the time, under which the papers shared advertising, circulation and printing functions, along with profits.
 
Moves to Mornings
 As a result, The Journal was forced to shift from morning publication to evening. The News-Sentinel, then an afternoon paper, was dominant, but moving to the morning gave The News-Sentinel an added lift and virtually insured that The Journal would eventually fail.
Gannett then sold The Journal to a group of investors that included Howard H. Baker Jr., the powerful Tennessee Republican and former United States Senator. The Baker group, in turn, sold the paper to Persis, which is owned by Thurston Twigg Smith, an entrepreneur based in Honolulu.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Ray of Optimism From Dividends

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
EVEN as pressure grows in Washington to do something to help the economy, the pace of dividend declarations by American companies is starting to improve slightly.
The Standard & Poor's Corporation reported yesterday that 105 companies announced increased dividends in November, slightly more than the 100 companies that made similar declarations in November 1990. It was the second time in three months that the figure showed a year-over-year improvement, but the increases are not nearly enough to prevent 1991 from being the worst year, in that regard, since 1972. 
 The slight improvement in the pace of dividend increases may represent only that in late 1990 a recession was taking hold and there was widespread pessimism brought on by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. Those factors persuaded many companies to hold back on dividend increases, making this year's comparisons relatively easy.
While there has been an increase in the number of companies announcing higher dividends, the list of such companies has had a disproportionate representation of small companies. Among the large companies that make up the Standard & Poor's 500 index, the dividend outlook has continued to erode this fall, which has helped to arouse concern over whether the recession really ended last spring, as many economists have assumed.
At the end of 1990, the S.& P. 500 was paying dividends at a rate of $12.25 for the index, meaning that a basket of fractional shares of stocks in the S.& P. 500, bought at the then-current S.& P. index value of 330.33, would have paid dividends of $12.25 in 1991, if none of the companies either raised or lowered their payouts.
That figure has fallen in spurts all year. It seemed to stabilize at about $12.17 in the summer, but this fall dipped to $12.11.
For all of 1990, the S.& P. 500 paid $12.10 in dividends, but the rate of payout was rising for much of the year, leading to the $12.25 figure at the end of the year. The falling rate this year means that the total actually paid will be up only a small amount from last year, perhaps less than 1 percent. By contrast, in the 1974-75 and 1981-82 recessions, the payout on the S.& P. 500 went up more than 2 percent in each year. In 1990, despite the onset of the recession, the figure rose 9.5 percent.
There is considerable optimism among Wall Street analysts that the dividend picture will improve in 1992, although it may be noted that few analysts had expected the drop in the S.& P. 500 payout rate this year.
"We are looking for about a 15 to 20 percent increase in corporate profits next year, so we expect that dividends will start to trend upward," said Joseph Tigue, the managing editor of S.& P.'s Outlook newsletter. "We look for a brighter picture for next year. Of course that is compared to this year, which was a disaster."
Many companies announce their dividend increases in the months around the end of a year, either anticipating or reacting to annual profit figures. Over the last 20 years, November ranked second to February in the number of dividend increases announced.
For the first 11 months of 1991, S.& P. said, 984 companies announced increases in dividends. That is the lowest number for any comparable period in two decades, and in reality presents the weakest dividend picture in nearly 30 years. There were fewer increases in both 1970 and 1971, but that reflected Federal inflation controls, which barred many companies from raising payouts to shareholders. The last time fewer companies raised their payouts in a similar period, absent government restrictions, was in 1962, when 960 increases were announced.
Mr. Tigue noted that one encouraging sign came in the figures on the number of companies resuming dividends after omitting them. In November, five companies did that, up from one in November of last year. For the first 11 months of 1991, the figure is 44, up from 35 in 1990.

HEADLINE: Dow Up 40.70 as Late Rally Erases Losses

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
The stock market closed sharply higher yesterday, bouncing back briskly late in the day after a steep decline earlier. The Dow Jones industrial average, which at mid-morning was down nearly 30 points from Friday's close, finished 40.70 higher at 2,935.38.
Various forces converged to drag prices down in the morning: weakness in the Japanese and London markets, a lower-than-expected November index from the nation's purchasing managers that the market took as further evidence of a weak economy, and poor showings by I.B.M. and Digital. 
 Volume on the New York Stock Exchange totaled 188.3 million shares, yesterday, up from 76.8 million on Friday, as gainers outpaced losers, 927 to 781.
 
Bush Move a Factor
 Anthony Ludovici, the senior vice president and senior investment analyst at Tucker, Anthony, said the market's comeback was timed to a White House announcement around noon that Predsident Bush would discuss the economy in a speech tomorrow at an American Enterprise Institute conference.
The White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said it would be an important speech on the economy, but did not suggest the President would introduce any new proposals.
Mr. Ludovici said the market had interpreted the news as meaning that the President would be looking at the economy sooner rather than later.
"At the time of the announcement, there was a spread between the futures market and the cash market," he said. "Almost immediately, futures-related program trading kicked in and established the trend for the balance of the day, and reinforcing confidence for the moment."
 
Tangible Evidence Needed
 Edwin Walczak, the first vice president of Vontobel U.S.A., said yesterday's market still "needs tangible evidence that either the economy is doing something good, or that Washington will do something smart."
He added, "And until either happens, I can't see why the market should do terribly well."
Stocks in Tokyo took a beating before the opening in New York, with the Nikkei index losing 695.06 points, or more than 3 percent, to 21,992.29. The Nikkei regained some ground in early trading today, rising 265.82, to 22,258.11, by midday.
The Big Board's composite index rose 2.90 points, to 210.65, while the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose 6.18 points, to 381.40.
Trading on the American Stock Exchange was active, as the index closed 1.21 points higher at 371.89.
On the Nasdaq, the composite index rose 7.01 points, to 530.91, as the Russell 2,000, a barometer of small companies, rose 0.28 point, to 176.65.
I.B.M., which is still reeling from its announcement last week of its fourth-quarter charge and additional layoffs, weighed heavy on the Dow in early trading, as the stock touched a nine-year low of 90 5/8, before closing down 1/4, to 92 1/4.
Traders said the stock might have reacted to an announcement planned by McCaw Cellular Communications on the details of a deal with Oracle Systems to create a data broadcasting system, which analysts said could compete with a satellite-data network developed by Motorola and I.B.M.
McCaw's stock rose 1 1/2, to 27 3/4, while Oracle's gained 7/8, to 14 3/8, and Motorola's rose 3/4, to 60 3/8.

HEADLINE: McDonnell and I.R.S. Settle

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

 BODY:
The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said yesterday that it had put another of its financial problems behind it by settling a tax dispute with the Internal Revenue Service.
McDonnell Douglas said it had already paid the Government the additional $150 million called for in the settlement. Because the company had set up financial reserves in excess of that amount to cover any settlement, McDonnell Douglas executives said they expected to record a one-time gain to earnings of about $50 million in the fourth quarter. 
 As part of the settlement, the I.R.S. returned to McDonnell Douglas the stock of the McDonnell Douglas Helicopter Company, a wholly owned subsidiary that the Government had held title to pending a resolution.
The agreement comes as McDonnell Douglas, the nation's largest military contractor and its second-largest maker of commercial jetliners, is rebounding from a financial crisis that early this year threatened the company's viability. McDonnell Douglas, which is based in St. Louis, has restored its commercial aircraft business to profitability and substantially reduced its debt.
The company remains intent on cost-cutting, however, and yesterday said it expected to cut between 1,800 and 3,800 jobs out of a work force of 41,000 at its Douglas Aircraft subsidiary in the next 18 months.
A spokesman said the cuts would come from a combination of layoffs and attrition, and would affect both the commercial aircraft production lines and Douglas's one big military program, the C-17 transport plane. Most of the job cuts are expected to come from Douglas's main plant in Long Beach, Calif. The company previously warned that declining orders for jetliners would lead to further layoffs.
McDonnell Douglas share price closed yesterday at $69.875, unchanged, on the Big Board.
The settlement ends a dispute over the company's taxes from 1977 to 1985. The dispute centered on the timing of the completion of the company's Government contracts, an issue that has led to similar tax problems for other aerospace companies.
McDonnell Douglas said it still must pay the Government more than $500 million in deferred taxes and interest by the end of 1994 to cover the years 1986 through 1989.

HEADLINE: Purchasers Index Fell Last Month

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
The nation's manufacturing economy, hurt by lower production and new orders, grew far more slowly in November than October, according to a monthly survey of the nation's purchasing managers. Economists saw the figures as an indication that the overall economy was recovering more slowly than they had expected.
The National Association of Purchasing Management said yesterday that its monthly index fell to 50.1 percent in November from 53.3 percent in October. The November reading was lower than many economists had predicted. 
 A reading below 50 percent indicates that the manufacturing economy is declining; a reading above 50 percent indicates an expansion.
In the stock market, the report helped depress stocks initially, but the market bounced back, with the Dow Jones industrial average soaring nearly 70 points from the day's low to close at 2,935.38, up 40.70. [Page D8.]
 
'Virtually Stopped Growth'
 "The economic recovery grew perceptively weaker in November," said Robert J. Bretz, chairman of the association's survey committee and director of corporate purchasing at Pitney Bowes Inc. "Although the overall economy continued with unpretentious growth, the manufacturing sector of the economy virtually stopped growing."
Mr. Bretz added that the decline "suggests continued anemic economic overall growth for the immediate future." He also said the association's index -- which has averaged 47.3 percent for the year's first 11 months -- translates into real economic growth of about 1.1 percent for all of the economy so far this year.
The November index was the lowest reading since May, when it was 45.4 percent. The index had risen in the succeeding four months, causing economists to conclude that the manufacturing economy was expanding.
The purchasing managers' report is considered an important economic indicator because it is based on a survey of managers working in a wide range of industrial companies. Also, it is the first important indicator each month of how the economy has performed in the previous month. The survey is compiled from interviews with purchasing managers at more than 300 industrial companies across the country.
"The data indicate that the pace of economic activity has slowed sub-
stantially in the last few months," said Andrew Brimmer, a former governor of the Federal Reserve and president of Brimmer & Associates, an economic consulting firm in Washington. "It seems that we are on the edge of a declining economy, although the economy is still growing, but barely."
As for the future, Mr. Brimmer said "I see nothing to indicate that the pace of economic activity will pick up any time soon."
The pace of new orders slowed sharply in November, with the new-order index falling to 53.4 percent, from 58.9 percent in October. The new-order figures are considered a signal of the level of production in the coming months. The new-order index had been as high as 63 percent toward the end of the summer, but has fallen each month since.
Production, too, slowed significantly in November, with the production index dropping to 53.7 percent,from 60.3 percent in October. The reading was the lowest since May, when the index stood at 48.8 percent. The association said production would probably fall in the coming months as a result of a decline in the index of new orders.
 
Price Index Declines
 The association's price index fell slightly in November, to 51.4 percent, from 52.6 percent in October. Several items were reported by association members to have fallen in price, including aluminum, steel scrap, sulfur and nickel. Some of those surveyed attributed the decline in the price index to the rescinding of price increases that had been announced recently.
Employment declined in November, with the employment index dropping to 44.4 percent, from 45.1 percent in October. Economists said the drop in employment was largely the result of layoffs in the manufacturing sector that resulted from the lower production levels.
Imports declined in November, in keeping with their general trend for the last 18 months. The association's index of imports fell to 45 percent, from 47.5 percent in October. The figure was the lowest reading since January.
Orders for export slipped slightly, to 55 percent in November, from 55.5 percent in October.

HEADLINE: Japan and U.S. Struggle With Resentment

SERIES: Fifty Years Later -- First of three articles: An Edgy Alliance

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Dec. 2

 BODY:
Japan and the United States are struggling to prevent their successful alliance from being engulfed by a rising tide of frustrations, resentments and recriminations.
Solid majorities of both countries say they feel that relations between them are friendly and that the alliance between Japan and the United States is dependable, according to an opinion survey in late November by The New York Times, CBS News and the Tokyo Broadcasting System. 
 But reflecting the strains in their official relations, the poll shows that Americans voice a deeply pessimistic view about competing with Japan and that the Japanese increasingly see Americans as living in a nation in decline and inclined to blame Japan for its own economic problems. [Page A16.]
The war in the Persian Gulf and the collapse of Communism are forcing Tokyo and Washington to redefine their relationship -- especially the tradition of Washington providing security and foreign policy guidelines while Japan tended to business.
It has proved difficult to rally the Japanese and Americans to new kinds of cooperation -- to defend democracy, combat poverty, help the environment and other activities consistent with President Bush's new world order -- particularly because of emotions unleashed by the gulf war.
"The gulf war was a trigger to submerged feelings in Japan," said Terumasa Nakanishi, professor of international relations at Shizuoka University. "The Japanese were exposed to a typically American self-righteous justification of resorting to war. It helped convince Japanese that they are culturally different."
For many Japanese and Americans, this is a time of reflection on their relationship. While the 50th anniversary of Pearl Harbor brings reminders of the unpleasant past, the visit of President Bush in January to meet the newly elected Prime Minister, Kiichi Miyazawa, is turning everyone's attention to current problems.
The current strains are exacerbated by what Japanese see as the spectacle of a once all-powerful United States struggling with debt, deficits, weak financial institu- tions, and mounting social problems, making them wonder about America's ability to maintain its world leadership.
Leaders of both the United States and Japan, which together account for 40 percent of the world's economic output and 40 percent of aid to poor countries, defend their record and say cooperation is better than is often perceived.
"The basic trend is very satisfactory," said Koichiro Matsuura, director general of the North American bureau at the Foreign Ministry. "Nobody can disagree that the ties between Japan and the United States have become much better. It's the perceptions that have deteriorated."
But other recent events -- particularly the American decision to withdraw 15,000 of the 135,000 troops stationed in Japan, South Korea and the Philippines -- have made Japanese leaders nervous about the future reliability of the United States.
The United States' recent failure to win agreement in the Philippines for renewal of American bases there, which has accelerated the pullout from Asia, has shaken Japan. Indeed, Tokyo agreed to give the Philippines $1 billion in aid at the Americans' urging, hoping to persuade Manila to keep American troops.
 
Fear of Creating A Power Vacuum
 Now there is widespread nervousness in Japan and Asia that an American withdrawal could leave a vacuum and stimulate an arms race among Asian nations. Asians are nervous that Japan is slightly modifying its long-held pacifism and preparing to send troops abroad for the first time since World War II, as part of United Nations peacekeeping forces.
"A power vacuum in Asia is something we must prevent," said Makoto Sakuma, chairman of the joint staff council of the Defense Agency. "If the American military presence in Asia is withdrawn, not only Japan but Asia as a whole will suffer instability."
Because of American economic weakness, Washington has put pressure on Tokyo to increase its share of the burden of 56,000 troops in Japan. Japan now pays about half the cost, or about $3 billion a year, to support the American naval and ground forces, making it cheaper to station troops in Japan than in the United States.
The problem is that after the collapse of Communism, Japan and the United States may no longer see eye to eye on security.
As The Times/CBS News/Tokyo Broadcasting System poll showed, many Japanese opposed the gulf war and generally are more opposed than Americans to using American military force in the world. This contradiction could become a crisis in a future conflict requiring American troops based in Japan.
"Americans would be wise to abandon the term 'burden sharing' because it both reeks of American self-righteousness and amounts to a self-advertisement of America's declining ability to carry out an independent foreign policy," Chalmers Johnson, Rohr professor of Pacific international relations at the University of California at San Diego, wrote recently.
Moreover, many Japanese feel that the concentration of 29,000 marines in Okinawa cannot last. The new governor of that island has for the first time demanded an American withdrawal, a step that would eliminate a base from which the first marines traveled to the gulf last year.
At the heart of the Japanese-American relationship have been efforts on myriad fronts to reduce the trade deficit, which has in fact fallen in recent years. But all the negotiations, even those that have yielded results, have taken their toll in a subtle way.
"The Japanese find it hard to make concessions, only to be faced with new demands," said Michael C. Armacost, the United States Ambassador, in explaining the Japanese inflexibiity. "We find it frustrating to have to demand that Japan market access that we extend in our own country. I wish there was another way of doing these things."
American leaders are nettled by the refusal of Japan to lift its ban on rice imports or take other steps to break the deadlock in the current Uruguay Round of trade talks. In Washington's view, Tokyo is not protecting and defending the world trading system from which it benefits more than any other nation.
The United States trade deficit with Japan has narrowed to $41 billion last year from a peak of $56 billion in 1987, and there have been agreements on supercomputers, semiconductors, construction contracts and many other sectors. Japan's imports from the United States have doubled in five years. But both sides agree that the long-term trends are disturbing. The deficit is bound to go back up as the United States recovers from its recession and the demand for imports surges. Japan is also exporting more to the United States indirectly, from factories in other parts of Asia and is commanding a larger share of the American market through goods produced in its own American factories, too.
Moreover, Japan has spent five years mobilizing its resources -- investing two and a half times as much as the United States in new plants, equipment and research -- to produce new products.
While Japan has prepared in this fashion, the United States has begun lodging more fundamental criticisms of Japan's cozy business relationships, and its whole policy of submerging consumer interests to those of business, the very things that Japanese feel have been secrets to their success.
 
An Outpouring By Critics in Japan

Japan has responded with an outpouring of critical comments among scholars, businessmen and politicians, many disdainful of the United States, suggesting that the United States is blaming Japan for its problems.
One economist, Seiichiro Saito, a professor at Rikkyo University, said that the United States was becoming a "vegetable nation" suffering from a kind of degenerative disease which makes it unconscious of its problems and able only to demand to borrow money from Japan and other countries.
Japanese do not like to express their feelings openly, but it is almost impossible to speak with anyone in a position of responsibility and not pick up an undercurrent of criticism, friendly and not so friendly.
"The whole U.S. society seems to be deteriorating," a senior Japanese diplomat said. "Americans are losing their ability to communicate among themselves. Everyone is either fighting or hiring lawyers, and America's ability to integrate different elements into a melting pot is weakening. So Americans are looking for scapegoats and blaming Japan."
Many diplomats and negotiators also feel that having tried to resolve their differences on a number of trade issues, they are down to the fact that Japanese and Americans are simply different culturally, and that America should stop lecturing Japan to change.
"Americans ought to learn to respect the differences among people who live outside the United States," said Kazuo Ogura, director of cultural affairs at the Foreign Ministry. "Americans simply don't want to recognize that Japan has won the economic race against the West."
Japanese and Americans agree that in the environment after the cold war, where both countries no longer fear a Soviet military threat, the staggering economic interdependence of Japan and the United States is the glue that binds the two nations together.
Japan now has an estimated $83 billion in direct American investments, although the rate of growth dropped sharply in the last year. But Japanese-owned factories and other interests employ many Americans and have become a crucial part of the economy.
Meanwhile, Japan counts on American markets for a third of its global exports, and Tokyo carefully monitors every bill in Congress that would restrict the flow. Japanese officials, knowing that President Bush has opposed such measures, mask some of their disappointments with his Administration.
His support will be critical as it carves out a broader role in world affairs. It is seeking upgraded status at the Interntional Monetary Fund and permanent membership in the United Nations Security Council. It also wants removal of clauses in the United Nations charter referring to Japan as a former enemy state. American support for these steps is seen in Japan as lukewarm.
Japan and the United States maintain that they have achieved impressive cooperation in the areas of foreign aid, environment, narcotics, refugees and debt relief for developing nations. But the record is mixed.
Japan this year doubled its contribution to the United Nations High Commission for Refugees, for example, and for the first time a Japanese, Sadako Ogata, a respected scholar on international relations, has been chosen to that agency or indeed any other international agency.
But on foreign aid to poor countries, Japan has been struggling to fulfill its promises to provide help commensurate with its status as an economic superpower. In 1989, Japan achieved the position of the largest donor of foreign aid in the world, but in 1990 the United States regained the title.
International organizations want Japan to do more because it spends only 1 percent of its gross national product on its military, as opposed to 6 percent by the United States. Many have asked Japan raise its foreign aid spending also to 1 percent, but it has remained at less than four-tenths of 1 percent, making it only the eighth biggest giver in terms of economic capacity.
 
The Japanese Way Of Giving Out Aid
 The way Japan has given out aid has also remained controversial. Tokyo continues emphasize big industrial projects that help its own companies.
After war broke out in the gulf, for instance, Japan announced a $2 billion economic package for the region, largely for projects like the Beniseuf cement factory in Egypt, being built by the Mitsubishi Corporation and Kobe Steel, and the Golden Horn Bridge in Turkey, being built by IHI, a Japanese construction company.
Nor has Japan succeeded in developing a consistent philosophy for its foreign aid program. Last year, Tokyo announced that it would not give aid to countries that exported weapons, and would use its aid to promote democracy and human rights. But Japan has persisted in giving aid to China, a leading arms exporter, and has refused to cut off aid to Burma.
"Japan lacks a focus on what it is actually trying to achieve with its foreign aid," said Robert M. Orr, director of the Kyoto Center for Japanese Studies, and author of the book "The Emergence of Japan's Foreign Aid Power." He added, "It doesn't fit into any coherent world vision."
In the environmental area, the global partnership appears mostly to be a slogan masking continuing disagreements on matters like global warming, destruction of tropical forests by Japanese companies and protection of endangered species.
All the difficulties and differences of perspective between Japan and the United States have caused some to predict much greater conflict ahead, especially who fear Japanese intentions over the long term, although they concede that the alliance is strong for now.
Professor Johnson, at the University of California at San Diego, has warned that Japan's American investments amount to an attempt to colonize the United States, that Japan could move away from Washington's orbit and try to create a a yen-based regional trading bloc.
"In the case of Japan," he wrote recently, "past behavior and current capabilities are so extraordinary and so formidable as to cause any other nation or people to be concerned about its future intentions."
Such talk is dismissed by most Americans and Japanese. Those Japanese who argue that Japan should indeed assert its interests, even if they are antithetical to those of the United States, take the most pains to tell Americans that they should not worry that there are conflicts.
"Japan has learned the lessons of war, and we are determined never to go beyond these four islands anywhere in the world," said Jun Eto, a conservative-oriented visiting professor at Keio University. "But the United States and Japan will have to learn to live with constant conflict. We are both competitive, jealous and powerful nations, after all."
"Conflict doesn't mean war," he added. "The greatest lesson of World War II, is that we in Japan have to live with Americans whether we like it or not. But I don't know whether that's a lesson learned in America."

HEADLINE: Sugar Growers Seek Cleaner Image

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CLEWISTON, Fla.

 BODY:
The annual harvest of sugar cane from South Florida's mucky flatlands is in full swing. The horizon is flecked with smoke from fields being torched to clear leaves, and by steam from the mills that grind endlessly. The grunts and sullen chatter of cane cutters who sever the singed stalks inches from the ground vie with the whining of mechanical harvesters.
There is one surprising difference this year: the cane growers, long envied for their Government subsidies and vilified for their labor and environmental practices, aim to shed their image as an industry that fears publicity. That image, the industry has concluded, has undermined its clout in Washington and Florida and made it hard to attract public sympathy on issues like water management that threaten the growers' future. 
 "The idea is to get everything on the table," said J. Nelson Fairbanks, president of the United States Sugar Company, which began the public effort to win friends. "We haven't been confronting allegations and misperceptions."
[Yesterday, U. S. Sugar announced that it would plead guilty to eight counts of violating Federal hazardous waste disposal laws at one of its mills and pay a $3.75 million fine. The violations, which took place between 1986 and 1989, caused no measurable harm to the environment, the company said, adding that the mill passed two subsequent state investigations with no further violations.]
The industry's most infamous sore point over the years has been its reliance on some 10,000 seasonal workers, mostly Jamaican, who are imported each year for the five-month harvest. Persistent charges of worker mistreatment are costly to fight -- so costly, the growers say, that the companies are being herded toward the use of expensive harvesting machinery that sometimes cuts cane inefficiently and damages the fragile soil.
The growers, like other farmers, are also worried about the future of Government subsidies. Sugar price supports cost the Government nothing in most years because they are linked to import quotas set at levels calculated to push domestic prices higher than the guaranteed support level. But the price supports are increasingly unpopular in Washington because they drive up the cost of consumer products -- by $3 billion annually according to critics -- and undermine the Bush Administration's credibility when it pushes other Governments to support freer trade.
 
An Environmental Showdown
 The problem that drove home the need for the growers to improve their image, though, is a three-year-old confrontation with Federal and state environmental regulators over how to improve the quality of the water flowing into the Everglades.
The regulators agreed last summer on a proposed settlement that could saddle the growers with a large chunk of an estimated $440 million cost to create a new marshland for filtering water reaching the Everglades. The proposal would also force growers to make sure that water leaving their property is cleaner than the rain that falls on it.
The growers say the settlement, now before a Federal judge in Miami, could wipe out cane production and most other forms of agriculture in southern Florida, which provides a large portion of winter vegetables and citrus for the eastern United States.
The growers hope their arguments will appeal to residents in the booming cities on Florida's Atlantic coast if the settlement is subjected to a public review process. They say, for instance, that a threat to the cane industry is a threat to urban water supplies because water flowing from their irrigation systems acts as a reservoir for the cities' wells.
State officials say the cane growers are exaggerating their potential liability, particularly if the industry can demonstrate that it contributes as little to pollution as it claims. And they say the growers remain more confrontational than open.
"They have launched the most concerted attack ever by anyone against the state agencies," said Daniel Thompson, general counsel to the Florida Department of Environmental Resources. "They have 17 different proceedings of various sorts going against the settlement."
 
Disproportionate Clout
 Until the water battle arose, the publicity-shy Florida cane growers often seemed to pack clout far out of proportion to their economic importance. The 430,000 acres of cane land in this region account for over half the nation's sugar cane production, which besides in Florida can be found in Louisiana, Texas and Hawaii. But the acreage adds up to only 20 percent of the nation's total sugar output, once beet sugar production and imports are included.
The growers, though, are big landowners -- a plantation of several hundred acres would be scarcely large enough to support the equipment needed -- and most also grow fruit, vegetables or rice. More important, they have powerful allies on price-support and quota issues: the corn farmers across the nation who peg the price of their high-fructose syrup at a level just under sugar.
The cane growers tell visitors that sugar is a bargain, one of the few products that does not cost more in 1991 than it did a decade earlier.
The growers also tell visitors how the industry was repeatedly blamed for environmental problems like pollution of Lake Okeechobee that later proved to be primarily the fault of others, notably dairy farms to the north. They say they are unfairly tarred by the corrupt handling of worker savings by the Jamaican Government. And they offer mounds of documents suggesting that many of the labor complaints result from regulators and courts applying new interpretations to contracts that have existed for years.
 
A Differing Assessment
 None of these issues is so simple in the eyes of critics.
"It's not a question of new interpretations," scoffs Bruce Goldstein, a lawyer in Washington with the Farmworker Justice Fund, when asked about the contract disputes. "They hide from the Department of Labor what they are doing, while the department engages in ostrichism and acts surprised when we reveal what is going on."
United States Sugar's new policy of welcoming inquiries from outsiders has been followed by the Sugar Cane Growers Cooperative in nearby Belle Glade, which represents 54 smaller growers, and, with little enthusiasm, by Flo-Sun Inc,, the holding company of the Cuban-born Fanjul brothers. The Fanjuls, who have overtaken United States Sugar as the biggest local grower, have attracted the strongest criticism in recent years.
 
Continuing Labor Criticism
 The longest-running problem of the growers is their labor-relations record.
In 1942, United States Sugar was indicted for conspiring to enslave workers brought from Georgia and other states after an investigation by the Federal Bureau of Investigation. That case was dropped, as the sugar companies turned to Jamaica and other Caribbean islands for workers. But the improvements in pay and working conditions have been too gradual and grudging to ever put the labor troubles completely to rest.
In a village owned by United States Sugar in the cane fields some five miles from Clewiston there are ranks of small houses crammed with bunk beds and packages of electronic goods that cane cutters have accumulated to send home. Small palms and flowering bushes planted by company-hired landscapers add a touch of beauty.
But no one pretends that the work itself is not boring, dangerous and difficult. Typically, about one-third of the workers will incur some kind of injury.
While some may average $10 an hour or more with bonus, the average worker at a top-paying company like United States Sugar will end up with about $1.25 an hour more than the guaranteed minimum of $5.38 an hour, according to company accountants. But lawyers representing farm workers say that workers are often paid below guaranteed minimums because the industry's system of paying by the row.
The cane cutters are expected to work a six-day week but those who want to can work seven, which many do for several weeks in a row to earn extra money.
 
Ruled by the Dollar
 Workers gratefully grasp the chance to accumulate cash that would be impossible to come by in their poverty-stricken homeland, but they also talk of feeling powerless and exploited.
"In the old days of slavery, they ruled us with a whip," said Warren Francis, a cane cutter back for his second harvest. "Now they do it with the dollar."
A growing number of companies, starting with the Talisman Sugar Company in 1962, have abandoned the labor battle by switching to fully mechanized harvesting. The machines have been gradually upgraded, but they are no match for the most skilled human cutters.
And in the muckier fields, usually the most valuable, the big machines easily damage the soil, often forcing growers to replant cane every three years instead of on a four- or five-year cycle.
Nevertheless, most growers are now following Talisman's lead.
"Florida will go to close to 100 percent mechanized in the next five years," said George Wedgworth, president of the cooperative.
No one foresees such a clear-cut resolution to the environmental and subsidy questions.

HEADLINE: Jan Papanek, 95, Czechoslovak Who Stood Up to Communism

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON

 BODY:
Jan Papanek, a prominent member of the democratic postwar Government of Czechoslovakia who made a dramatic exit as his country's United Nations delegate in 1948 and then devoted his efforts to the refugees from its Stalinist regime, died on Saturday at his home in Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 95 years old.
His family said he died after a prolonged illness. 
 Mr. Papanek's role was acknowledged only last month by the reborn democracy in Prague when President Vaclav Havel honored him with the Thomas G. Masaryk Order, first class. The order was created by the Czechoslovak Republic after the fall of Communism to reward distinguished service to democracy.
Mr. Papanek was an associate of President Eduard Benes and his Foreign Minister, Jan Masaryk, serving as the personal representative of President Benes in this country during World War II. He first came to the United States in 1936 as a member of the Czechoslovak Legation in Washington.
 
Denouncer of Communism
 Mr. Papanek always took pride in being remembered for denouncing the Soviet-engineered Communist takeover of his country before the United Nations Security Council in 1948. The new authorities promptly branded him a traitor and cashiered him as Prague's representative to the United Nations, with which he had been associated since the organization's birth.
But the coup led a spate of people to flee Czechoslovakia as the Communists tightened their grip. In response, Mr. Papanek founded the American Fund for Czechoslovak Refugees, which helped many thousands of them to find a new home.
In more recent years, the agency assisted not only those of his countrymen who managed to slip out illegally, but Southeast Asian and Chinese refugees as well.
 
Czechoslovak Legion
 Mr. Papanek's purpose was to get the new arrivals on the road to self-support as quickly as possible. He remained president of the humanitarian fund until five years ago, driving daily to his Manhattan office from his home.
Mr. Papanek was born in Brezova in western Slovakia, then part of the Austro-Hungarian Empire. In World War I, he helped Gen. Milan Stefanik organize the Czechoslovak Legion, which fought the Austrians with the Allies on the Italian front.
Mr. Papanek then completed his education, taking law degrees at the Sorbonne and in Prague. He entered the Prague Foreign Ministry in 1922.
 
Role in Government-in-Exile
 After various assignments in and out of Prague, he was sent to Chicago by President Benes in 1939 to work toward the liberation of Czechoslovakia from its Nazi German occupiers. Two years later, he was named Minister Plenipotentiary in charge of the Czechoslovak Government-in-Exile Information Service in New York.
He accompanied Mr. Masaryk to the San Francisco Conference that adopted the United Nations Charter in 1945 and became his country's representative at the United Nations the year after. During his tenure he also served as a member and acting president of the organization's Economic and Social Council.
Mr. Papanek is survived by his wife of nearly 66 years, Betka, and a brother, Stefan, of Chicago.

HEADLINE: Europeans Warn Libya of Possible Sanctions

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Dec. 2

 BODY:
The European Community today raised the possibility of imposing sanctions on Libya if it did not extradite several senior Libyan Government officials accused of planting bombs that destroyed an American and a French airliner in 1988 and 1989.
France, the United States and Britain had demanded that six senior Libyan officials be handed over for questioning on the accusations. 
 The statement issued in Brussels today said the community took "a most serious view of the accusations against officials of the Libyan Government." It went on to say the community "calls upon the Libyan authorities to comply promptly and in full" with the demands of the three countries.
European officials in Brussels said the community's statement indicated that a strong likelihood that severe economic sanctions would be imposed on the Government of Col. Muammar al-Qaddafi should it refuse to comply.
They said Libya should comply with the request in a matter of weeks.
The officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said sanctions might include a ban on the daily sale of one million barrels of Libyan oil in Europe and, possibly, a ban on civilian airliners' landing in Libya.
Libya has so far refused to extradite the Libya suspects, but it has invited British, French and United States investigators to question them in Libya.
Britain and the United States have demanded the extradition of two senior Libyan officials for the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, in December 1988, that killed 270 people, while France indicted four more and asked Libya to hand them over to French judicial investigators for questioning on the bombing of a French U.T.A. airliner over Niger in 1989 that killed 170. None of these countries have indicated their willingness to conduct investigations in Libya as the Libyans have suggested.
While the warning today stopped short of promising retaliatory measures if Libya continues to reject the demands, a community official said, "We are certainly talking about sanctions in case Libya does not comply."
Oil industry officials as well as European and Arab diplomats said all indications pointed to the fact that the West was indeed heading toward imposing a ban on the sale of Libyan oil in Europe, a move that could deprive Libya of access to its most lucrative oil market.
Italy is by far Libya's biggest customer, buying as much as 450,000 barrels of Libya oil daily. Germany imports some 230,000 barrels a day from Libya, which is its third largest source of imported crude oil and oil products. Other European customers include Spain, Greece, Turkey and Austria.
European officials acknowledge that an oil boycott would present several European countries, particularly Italy and Germany, with great difficulties in replacing the Libyan oil. Besides being from a nearby source, the Libyan crude has very low sulfur content, making it attractive for refining into oil products, especially gasoline.
The officials said that in addition to selling oil in Europe, Libya has acquired a number of refineries and a network of gasoline and service stations in several European countries as well as other properties, all of them valued at several billion dollars. Libya owns the Tamoil refinery in Cremona, Italy, which processes as much as 200,000 barrels of Libyan oil a day into products marketed throughout Europe.
European and United States officials said economic sanctions could also include the seizure of Libyan assets and their eventual use to generate funds for compensating relatives of the victims of the two bombings.
An Arab diplomat said he expected sanctions to be adopted sometime after the peak period of winter demand for oil was over around February.
Libya would then have great difficulties selling its oil, which would have to travel to distant markets in Asia and cost a great deal more in transportation fees. Libya would lose about $1.50 for every barrel it transports to Asia, which would cost the Libya treasury a yearly loss of $1 billion, representing more than 15 percent of its oil income.
Since the United States banned all imports of Libyan oil several years ago, the Libyans have routed their light variety of oil toward Europe.

HEADLINE: George Joseph Stigler Dies at 80; Nobel Prize Winner in Economics

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
George Joseph Stigler, a Nobel Prize winner and intellectual anchor of the movement known as the Chicago school of economics, died at the University of Chicago's Bernard Mitchell Hospital on Sunday. He was 80 years old and lived in Chicago.
Mr. Stigler died of heart failure, said the university, where he taught economics for the last 32 years. 
 Mr. Stigler is probably best known to undergraduates as the author of "The Theory of Price," the coolly analytical textbook on free market economics that set the standard for a generation. Perhaps its most striking feature, and a trademark of Professor Stigler's writing, is that it sets economics in historical context.
"Few other economists around remembered where the ideas came from," said Robert Solow, an economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and a fellow Nobel Prize winner. Gary Becker, a colleague at the University of Chicago, went further, calling Mr. Stigler "our modern interpreter of classical economics."
 
Analyzed Everything
 As a practitioner and historian of economics, Mr. Stigler analyzed everything from the optimal size of corporations to rates of return in manufacturing to the demand for scientists.
A conservative, he argued skillfully that the first priority for ending poverty was to make it possible for poor people to get jobs. Proposals to cut the minimum wage "will not please some people," he wrote in the mid-1960's. "A fine thing, they will say, to raise the economic status of the Negro boy by lowering his wage rate to a dollar an hour. A fine thing, indeed, I reply, to raise it from zero to a dollar."
But from the perspective of professional economists, Mr. Stigler's most important contributions are in the theories of information and regulation.
Before the 1961 publication of his article, "The Economics of Information," in the University of Chicago's Journal of Political Economy, economists had simply assumed that everyone shared the same knowledge of how markets worked -- say, the durability of an automobile for sale or the skills of a surgeon to be hired. Mr. Stigler argued that it costs money to acquire knowledge, and that consumers and businesses would therefore choose to buy limited quantities, much the way they choose to buy goods and services.
This seemingly commonplace point created a whole field in economics, one that seeks to answer questions ranging from why the same product can be sold at different prices in different places to why some businesses lay off employees in hard times and some do not.
The impact of Mr. Stigler's analysis of the political economy of regulation is less obvious, but perhaps more profound. Instead of taking the logic of government regulation at the word of legislators and regulators, Mr. Becker said, "he studied the actual effects of regulation -- why we get the regulation we get."
Mr. Stigler's most famous conclusion, that price controls of electric utilities do not actually reduce the price of electricity, did not convince many analysts when it was published in 1962. But most economists today would put the burden of proof on those who support regulation.
Mr. Stigler grew up in Seattle, the only child of the Austrian-born Elizabeth Hungler and the German-born Joseph Stigler. He studied economics at the University of Washington in Seattle, graduating in 1931.
"It was the middle of the Depression and it seemed better to go to school than look for work," he told a biographer. The next year he moved to Northwestern University for a master's degree in business administration, and then enrolled in the doctoral program at the University of Chicago.
Mr. Stigler's teachers included giants of the field like Frank Knight, Jacob Viner and Henry Simons.
Dr. Stigler received his Ph.D. from Chicago in 1938, two years later he joined the faculty of the University of Iowa. Then it was on to the University of Minnesota, Columbia University, Brown University and back to Columbia before returning to the University of Chicago in 1958.
The Nobel Prize in 1982 for his work culminated a career in which he raised the prestige and political influence of conservative economics. But, as Mr. Solow noted, "He was never an ideologue."
 
Intellectual Independence
 He was pro-business, but never gave up his intellectual independence in pursuit of business's approval. Indeed, in the 1950's he wrote scathingly about the inefficiency of the largest American corporations and even advocated the use of antitrust laws to cut them down to size. Later, he refused to serve in a prominent position in Richard M. Nixon's Administration and embarrassed Ronald Reagan's Administration by labeling supply-side economics "a gimmick."
Mr. Stigler's wife, the former Margaret Mack, died in 1970. He is survived by three sons, Steven, a statistician in Chicago; David, a lawyer in Hartford, and Joseph, a social worker in Toronto, and 11 grandchildren.

HEADLINE: In California, New Talk Of Limits on Immigrants

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 2

 BODY:
When times were good in the 1980's, California largely welcomed the millions of domestic and foreign immigrants who flooded into the state. But now that times have turned tough, a cry has risen to narrow the gates to the Golden State.
The cry has been led by Gov. Pete Wilson, a Republican, who has been saying that immigrants, foreign and domestic, are putting the state in a fiscal squeeze by using more in services than they pay in taxes. Critics say it is nothing more than an racist attempt to find a scapegoat for the intractable social problems that have been building in California for two decades. 
 Almost from the Gold Rush days, California has vacillated between welcoming immigrants and resenting them. Thousands of Chinese laborers were brought in to build the railroads before the turn of the century, and then were excluded in a wave of anti-Chinese hysteria. During the Depression, waves of Okies migrated in search of opportunity and found hostility.
The latest great wave of immigration during the 1980's, when millions of immigrants from other states and from Asia and Latin America poured into California, added to the state's political power and wealth. Although a few environmentalists raised doubts about how many more people the state could absorb, the subject of controlling population was taboo in polite circles, where people feared being accused of racism.
 
Breaking the Taboo
 But suddenly that taboo has been broken. The state is mired deep in recession, and Governor Wilson says there are no longer enough taxpayers to support the growing ranks of tax receivers, many of them immigrants. He visited Washington on Nov. 25 to ask for more Federal help for California, which absorbed 35 percent of all the legal foreign immigrants to the United States during the last decade.
And in an interview in the Nov. 18 issue of Time magazine, the Governor argued that the state must reduce the "magnetic effect" of its generosity. While he does not claim that immigration is the central reason for California's fiscal troubles, he has said welfare payments that average $660 a month, nearly double the national average, are attracting immigrants here.
Governor Wilson's comments have set off a spirited debate, with some critics drawing parallels to the recent campaign for governor in Louisiana, where David Duke, a former Ku Klux Klan leader, ran as a Republican on a platform that some saw as racist and anti-immigrant.
State Senator David Torres, a Los Angeles Democrat who was chairman of a special Joint Legislative Committee on Refugee Resettlement, said Mr. Wilson "ought not to use the immigrants as the scapegoat for failed economic policies."
Governor Wilson has denied any racist intent. The state's dominant newspaper, The Los Angeles Times, agreed but editorialized Wednesday that the Governor's words could be misinterpreted as "the search not for answers but for scapegoats, political or otherwise."
 
Staggering Growth
 The debate has underscored the fragility of the social compact of California, the most ethnically diverse state in the nation. According to the Census Bureau, the state gained a staggering 6.1 million in population over the last decade and now is home to 29.8 million. Of that increase, a little more than half came from migration, about evenly divided between migrants from other states and from foreign countries, not counting illegal immigration.
By most analyses, this immigration played a major role in the California boom by providing a cheap labor force and large numbers of entrepreneurs starting up businesses who added to the demand for housing and services. As recently as 1988, the state returned $1 billion in rebates to taxpayers.
But this year, the state was forced to bridge a $14.3 billion budget gap, a gap that is still growing. According to a recent analysis by the state's Department of Finance, this is largely because of a rapid population shift in which the number of young people, who need schooling and other services, has exploded and economically productive people between the ages of 45 and 64 have moved out of state.
Should these demographic changes persist, the report stated, this "imbalance between taxpayers and tax receivers" could cause a $20 billion budget gap by the year 2000. By that time, it estimated, the state's dependency rate -- that is, the proportion of people under 18 and over 64 years old, who tend to need social services -- would rise from 58 percent today to 68 percent.
 
Immigrants on Welfare
 The department attributed the fiscal troubles in part to immigrants. It said that in 1990, foreign immigrants accounted for 4.5 percent of the caseload of Medi-Cal, the state's medical aid program for low-income persons, as against 1.3 percent in 1980. The caseload will increase to nearly 13 percent by the year 2000, it projected.
Experts link the reason for the demand on social services to several factors, including new laws and the change in the type of migrants from other states. Kassy Perry, spokeswoman for the state's Health and Welfare Agency, cited the Federal Immigration Reform Act passed by Congress in 1986 that granted amnesty to millions of illegal immigrants and other Federal laws that made about 300,000 additional persons eligible for Medi-Cal in 1988.
And while illegal aliens are ineligible for welfare, their American-born children are not, and the Supreme Court has ruled that local schools must accept such children. Caseloads forAid to Families with Dependent Children, the state's main welfare program, have tripled to two million over three years.
And refugees, mainly from Vietnam, Cambodia and other Southeast Asian countries, who have settled in California in recent years have been a particular burden. Forty percent of the refugees go on welfare in their first year, Ms. Perry said. About 7 percent of the general population is on welfare.
But it is not just foreign immigrants who are burdening California services. Seven percent, or more than 140,000 people, of the Aid to Families with Dependent Children caseload is accounted for by persons who moved to California from other states in the last 12 months.
 
Avoiding the Question
 The issue of controlling population has long been a delicate one, tinged as it is with racial and ethnic overtones. The question was avoided in a recent report by a panel at the Sacramento campus of the California State University, which was trying to achieve some consensus on growth management among interest groups.
Environmentalists tried to get a discussion going on the subject, but their attempt was rejected by Hispanics on the panel. "That was a sign of how difficult the issue is, especially if your parents were illegal," Larry Orman, executive director of the Greenbelt Alliance, a nonprofit group that promotes the preservation of undeveloped land around San Francisco, said last week in an interview. "How long can California maintain an open-door policy for immigrants who require services? Even if they climb out over time, California has only so much resources financially."
Another member of the panel, Fernando J. Guerra, chairman of the Chicano Studies Department at Loyola Marymount University, whose parents came from Mexico, said in an interview that the focus on immigrants was "classic scapegoating." He argued that the critics of immigration fail to take into account the role immigrants have had in fueling the economy.
But George J. Borjas, an economist at the University of California at San Diego, author of "Friends or Strangers" (Basic Books), a 1990 book on the economic effects of immigration, maintained that there is some validity to Governor Wilson's statements.
"The new immigrants are joining the welfare system at a much higher rate than the older immigrants," he said. "It's a net loss for the country. They're taking more out than they're putting in. They seem to be more unskilled and they have less education."
Another expert on immigration, Julian L. Simon, a professor of business administration at the University of Maryland and author of the 1989 book "The Economic Consequences of Immigration" (Basil Blackwell), agreed that in the short run new immigrants may represent a burden to the state.
"But in the long run, California is definitely helped by immigration," he said. "It's important to focus on the long-run situation rather than the little blips."

HEADLINE: Clinton's Campaign Signs On Strategists Who Aided Wofford

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2

 BODY:
The Presidential campaign of Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas has signed on the two men who masterminded Senator Harris Wofford's upset victory in Pennsylvania last month, an event that has already acquired mythic status in Democratic Party circles.
Mr. Clinton announced today that the men, James Carville and Paul Begala, would serve as general campaign consultants. "James and Paul will help us build on the tremendous progress the campaign is making around the country," he said. 
 The Governor has ridden a wave of good reviews in recent days, mostly resulting from his performance two weeks ago at a gathering of Democratic Party leaders in Chicago. In a field still struggling for recognition and still shadowed by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's indecision on entering the race, Mr. Clinton was widely seen as a standout.
The hiring of Mr. Carville and Mr. Begala is likely to feed the perception that Mr. Clinton's campaign is building momentum.
Mr. Wofford's defeat of former Attorney General Dick Thornburgh had a significant effect on Democratic thinking about what was possible next year and the issues that would make it so.
Senator Wofford, who had been appointed to fill the unexpired term of the late John Heinz until an election could be held, ran hard on the plight of the middle class, including the threat of unemployment and the need for a national health-care plan. Mr. Clinton has already built his campaign around the "forgotten middle class," with a host of domestic policy prescriptions on issues like the rising cost of a college education and economic competitiveness.
One top Democratic strategist, who spoke on condition of anonymity, suggested that Mr. Carville and Mr. Begala would add more of a populist touch -- "a lot more of the pickup truck" -- to Mr. Clinton's policy-oriented campaign.

HEADLINE: Wales Journal;
Big Classes and Little Hope at School

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WALES, Mass., Dec. 2

 BODY:
Lisa Valle looked in the school room, saw her daughter and about 70 other small children sitting row after row, coloring their work sheets, and seethed. "This is disgusting," she said. "My blood is boiling just standing here."
Ms. Valle and other parents hovered in the hallways today, watching anxiously as 199 children were prompted, cajoled and herded by only three teachers into classes considered to be the largest in the state, if not the country. 
 The defeat of a referendum on Nov. 12 to raise $160,000 in additional property taxes to cover a shortage of about 25 percent in the school budget touched off the layoffs of five of seven teachers at Wales Elementary School last Wednesday. On Monday, with the principal serving as an instructor, three new classes were formed, each with one teacher: fifth and sixth graders merged into one class; third and fourth graders in another, and 75 kindergartners, first and second graders made up the largest class. The school's open classroom design meant that only partitions and desks had to be moved.
Although a second attempt to pass the referendum is scheduled for Jan. 3, Wales has become the latest and perhaps most striking example so far of financial disarray and parental disappointment in Massachusetts' public schools.
"This is just one big baby-sitting hall right now," said Tony Guglielmo, the parent of a Wales sixth grader. "There's no education going on."
Some parent volunteers roamed the classrooms as aides today, trying to keep children quiet and busy and giving the teachers a chance to work with small reading or math groups.
The school's principal, Joseph DiFabio, conceded the situation was not good. "We don't pretend there will be good education going on at Wales Elementary for the next month."
School officials and educators blame the state's reliance on local property taxes for the teacher layoffs that have become common in Massachusetts over the last three years. State law limits increases in the annual property tax to 2.5 percent without a special referendum.
In the boom years of the 1980's, schools did not feel the pinch because the state could afford to offer more help, at levels approaching 42 percent of the cost of primary and secondary education in peak years. But with the recession, the state estimates it now contributes only about 25 percent of those costs.
Rural communities like Wales cannot keep filling the gap, said officials in this town of 1,500 people, perched on hilly ground 20 miles east of Springfield, Mass. Unemployment is high, and there is no commercial tax base and little hope of more residential growth because of the town's remote location, town officials say.
Instead, they are counting on state legislators to settle on one of several new school finance proposals to funnel more state money to local schools that need it most. Otherwise, they say, what is happening to Wales will repeat itself all over the state.
"Clearly educationally, this is an indefensible situation, and we have to correct it," said David Roach, the Superintendent of Schools for Wales and four neighboring towns. Middle school and high school students in the five towns attend a regional high school. Because voters in Wales approved the regional school budget earlier in the year, the elementary school has suffered the most.
Some teachers blame parents and other residents for being out of touch and not recognizing that layoffs would happen if the referendum failed.
Parents who are worried that their children will fall behind without more individual attention say they do not know what to believe. Ms. Valle, who has two other children besides her Wales second grader, said she and her husband, a blacksmith, cannot afford to pay their $2,000 property tax bill this year. She also questioned whether the school needs the additional money. "I want the books in this town checked," she said.
It is hard to believe what property taxes the town collects will not go far enough to hire at least one teacher for each grade, Ms. Valle said. "What the hell is my daughter going to learn coloring?" she demanded. "I could send her to the store to buy a quart of milk and she could learn to count the change. I have a 12th-grade education but I could do a better job than this."

HEADLINE: OUR TOWNS;
A Greenwich Quandary: Reining In Philanthropy

BYLINE: By Andrew H. Malcolm

DATELINE: GREENWICH, Conn.

 BODY:
THE public school system here has a problem with gifts. The problem is not with finding rich people to give the gifts. It's handling all the offers of gifts that drift its way.
And so the eight-member Board of Education of one of the nation's most affluent communities, here on the tree-pocked shoreline border of New York and Connecticut, has just completed a rigorous debate on the philosophical issue of private gifts to public bodies. It is a question that thousands of other districts would love to have the luxury of tackling. One thousand points of lights or not, the board decided unanimously that it must crack down. "At some point," said Thomas Heagney, a lawyer and outspoken board member, "we need to draw the line." The line, it turns out, is not necessarily a straight one. 
 In fact, no one knows how many gifts roll into the community's 13 schools every year from civic-minded corporate officers, who wouldn't mind earning a little goodwill; from the well-meaning wealthy, who wouldn't mind a tax deduction; from the relocating businessman, who doesn't want to move old equipment, or from the hard-working P.T.A. Finance Committee, which might need a fund-raising project.
Nor has anyone ever tracked the value of such gifts within Greenwich's $55 million schools budget. Since the landscaping largesse of one wealthy man, Rene Anselmo, has already passed the $350,000 mark at the Hamilton Avenue Elementary School this year, the assumption is that the charity total for the 6,600-student system is substantial.
This was a delicate debate. "Listen," said Jim Cuminale, the board's new president, "we wouldn't want to send a message of ungratefulness to anyone. But we must insure that private gifts do not disrupt or undermine the basic requirements that public money supports public education."
The newly passed policy requires advance board approval for any gift worth more than $5,000. It welcomes money, goods or services that expand existing programs such as scholarships, library books, field trips, playground equipment or musical instruments. But it forbids gifts that might dictate the direction of a particular program. It also prohibits door-to-door solicitations by students. And it warns that gifts, such as the fervent fund-raising by one Greenwich school's P.T.A. for an ambitious computer system, may be rejected because other town schools cannot match them.
Explained Stacy Orphanos, a longtime board member: "We'd hate to see one part of town that isn't well-off feeling pressured to go out and raise money to match one affluent neighborhood's effort."
"It is," admitted Mr. Cuminale, "a delicate balance. On one hand, we're constrained financially from doing all we'd like. But we shouldn't expect public education to be funded through the charity of some citizens."
Mr. Heagney sees private charity as a potential addiction of public education. "It's very tempting," he says. "It seems to be free. But public education should be publicly funded." That is why he voted against the board's recent decision to seek corporate donations to finance a winter session of English-as-a-second-language classes. The board majority reasoned that outside charity was acceptable in this case because it expanded an existing fall class.
"I have a real problem," Mr. Heagney added, "with Japanese corporations paying teacher salaries. What's more basic to American public education than English instruction?"
Mr. Anselmo, the multimillionaire benefactor at Hamilton Avenue and several other schools, is so bothered by the gift policy that he has withdrawn his plans to beautify another Greenwich school. "This is really all about power," he says. "Who needs the hassle just to do something good?"
Mr. Cuminale stresses that the board's vote last month merely formalizes and tightens longstanding procedures to prevent conflicts, miscommunication, wasted efforts and the appearance of schools sticking out their institutional hands. "As always," he said, "we'll still decide each gift on a case-by-case basis."
The problems of generosity have increased despite recent tough times, though the phenomenon of giving predates the current recession. In fact, 99 years and 11 months before the Greenwich Board of Education met in its Havermeyer Building to formalize the gift-receiving policy, the school system accepted the construction of that very building as a gift from a local wealthy family. (You'll never guess what their name was.)
But because the gift of a three-story Havermeyer Building threatened the view of Long Island Sound for another wealthy family, the Benedicts, that family offered to give the town another gift if the building's height were curtailed. All of which explains how the Benedict Building of Greenwich Hospital came to be, why the Havermeyer Building has only two floors and how, historically, a case-by-case gift policy really works.
