HEADLINE: Patterns

BYLINE: By Woody Hochswender

 BODY:

The Fear of Shoppers
The consumer has come under a microscope this season. Judging by the nonstop coverage on television and in newspapers, going to a store to buy something for Christmas is some sort of major event. 
 The President of the United States was filmed at a J. C. Penney over the weekend buying socks, reinforcing the impression that we have become a nation of skinflints. (Couldn't he at least have sprung for a sweater? How much are we paying him?)
"Lower consumer confidence has itself become news, adding to the general malaise," observed the Nov. 20 issue of a fashion newsletter published by Kurt Salmon Associates, a consulting firm. It added that such coverage was inducing retailers and shoppers "to write off this year's Christmas season in advance."
The images coming out of the malls seem to undercut the traditional American idea of keeping up with the Joneses; the Joneses, one gathers, are "just looking." Whatever happened to remembering people you care about on an annual basis?
You begin to feel embarrassed about sitting on Santa's lap and telling him you want Chanel.
 
See the Bear Ride the Pony
 One apparel notion that has been selling, retail executives said, is the new Ralph Lauren Polo Bear clothing. Instead of his famous polo pony, Mr. Lauren has been putting the image of a cuddly bear onto things like T-shirts and dress shirts.
Bears can also be found screened onto the back of a jean jacket, handknit on the front of a sweater or embroidered as a jacquard down the front of a tie. There are also stuffed teddy bears, at $450. The Polo/Ralph Lauren store at 72d Street and Madison Avenue sold out its stock of 200 bears over the weekend.
The Polo Bear idea was inspired by the teddy bears Mr. Lauren got as Christmas gifts last years from his design staff. They were dressed, naturally, in miniature Polo clothing.
 
Mizrahi and More
 Isaac Mizrahi has been named women's wear designer of the year by the Council of Fashion Designers of America, much to the relief of the designer and his staff, who had been a bit down about his recent spring show. (The lights went out in the middle of the show, and a richly detailed group of evening clothes had to be shown in half darkness.) Mr. Mizrahi also won the award in 1989.
Other 1991 council awards will go to Todd Oldham, as best new fashion talent; Karl Lagerfeld, for his Chanel fashion accessories, and the late Roger Forsythe of Perry Ellis, for his men's wear. The winners were chosen by a group of about 50 fashion editors and retail executives.
The awards will be presented on Feb. 3 at the New York State Theater at Lincoln Center, a new venue that should attract a broader spectrum of the garment industry. Past award dinners, held at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, have been limited to about 600 or 700 people, each paying $850 a ticket, because of tight space.
Dinner tickets will still be $850, but about 1,500 additional tickets for the awards ceremony, dessert and dancing will be sold for $250, said Stan Herman, the president of the council. Some student tickets will also be available.
"It's sort of taking the C.F.D.A. into a different place," Mr. Herman said. "The 90's are different. I think we have to open it up to the world."
Additional special awards, voted on by the council's board of directors, will go to Marvin S. Traub, the former Bloomingdale's chairman, and Harley-Davidson, which has helped inspire a wave of motorcycle chic. There will also be three "women of the arts" awards, honoring Angelica Huston, the actress; Jessye Norman, the soprano, and Judith Jamison, the artistic director and former principal dancer of the Alvin Ailey Dance Theater.

HEADLINE: TV SPORTS: SOCCER;
World Cup Officials Set Out To Buy Time With Networks

BYLINE: By Richard Sandomir

 BODY:
World Cup soccer officials are in town this week to attend the qualifying draw Sunday for the sports spectacle to be played in the United States in 1994. But of greater importance than who plays whom is who will televise it.
That issue was thought to be settled two years ago when the United States Soccer Federation agreed to an unusual partnership equity deal with NBC Sports in which the network would put up $11.5 million in return for a cut of certain sponsorship, advertising and ticket revenues. 
 But the governing body of international soccer, FIFA, nixed the deal. In a stunning misjudgment of a market ready to start tumbling, FIFA thought it could get more money elsewhere without becoming an equity partner with NBC.
So now, in a lousy market -- one in which the National Hockey League saw its new rights deal with SportsChannel America shrink by 68 percent -- soccer wants network money.
It won't happen so quickly. And the World Cuppers know it. That's why they are now willing to buy time on the networks rather than have a network buy the event outright. Buying time is a growing niche in sports television, in which organizers pay the networks for their time, then produce the event and sell all the commercial time.
"Buying time is a potential option," said Jim Trecker, a spokesman for World Cup USA 1994, the organizing committee for the 52-game tournament. "It may be better for us to package it and present it to a network."
What would such a deal cost for the 11 games that World Cup USA 1994 is offering to the networks? On NBC, where an hour a weekend afternoon costs about $300,000, 22 hours of coverage would cost about $6.6 million. On ABC, the cost would probably be less than $2 million.
Network figures who asked for anonymity say that NBC will make a time-buy proposal that it expects to be rejected, and that ABC and CBS will present similar plans as well as conventional proposals in which the networks would pay for the rights. Cheap rights fee proposals.
"It would not be a large commitment," said Jay Rosenstein, a vice president of CBS. "There is a possibility of succeeding economically."
 
Battle for Rights in Knick Territory
 There isn't a sports league in existence that likes to hear the word "antitrust" uttered in a negative light. As in "antitrust violations" or "antitrust questions." But those are the words the National Basketball Association is hearing from the Attorney General of Connecticut.
At issue is an N.B.A. policy that keeps blacks out a portion of the state west of Hartford hooked up to the United Artists Cable system from watching New York Knicks games on the MSG Network. The policy is absurd when you consider that the N.B.A. itself designated the area as Knicks territory.
Steve Toretto, a West Hartford lawyer who grew up in Corona and is an avid Knicks fan, noticed this anomaly two years ago when UA Cable added MSG to its channel menu. He could watch New York Yankees games and New York Rangers games on MSG. He could even watch Boston Celtics games on SportsChannel New England.
But no Knicks games. Each criterion for the blackout that the N.B.A. proferred in explanation to Toretto, he says, actually would have made his area exempt from the blackout. The true untold reason for the blackout remains a mystery to Toretto and 97,887 subscribers who can't watch the Knicks, although it's conceivable that the league considers the region Boston Celtics territory.
"I want to watch Patrick Ewing before I die," Toretto said.
Toretto's frustration was seconded in complaints by other subscribers to Richard Blumenthal, the Attorney General of Connecticut. Blumenthal's office recently served the N.B.A. with a subpoena demanding a raft of information that would somehow explain the policy. The N.B.A. has ignored the request, indicating its policy is none of Connecticut's business.
"It's disappointing that a sports league that depends so heavily on fan support is refusing to provide information on a matter that involves so many fans," says Blumenthal.
The N.B.A. will make its case for keeping the rationale for its policy a secret when it files a motion in Hartford Superior Court, due Dec. 13, to dismiss the subpoena. "I don't think the state of Connecticut understands the issue," said Gary Bettman, the N.B.A.'s general counsel. "Nobody's blacked out."
Well, 97,887 subscribers, are, even if they can watch Celtics games. Whether many of them are Knicks fans is irrelevant if the area is Knicks territory.
How the N.B.A. draws its territories is of great interest to Blumenthal as is the argument that blacking out home games is a way to shore up home attendance. But it's ridiculous to think that hordes of Knicks fans are trekking down 150 miles from Farmington to Madison Square Garden.
If the case gets far, it could go to the heart of how leagues protect themselves economically. David Stern, who as N.B.A. commissioner, knows a thing about economics, could resolve the situation by ordaining that this kind of blackout protects no one's interests and lets UA Cable carry Knicks and Celtics games throughout its system, regardless of territories.
Toretto suggests that a blackout be imposed when both teams are playing at home. The Celtics game would then be shown only in the designated Celtics territory and the Knicks game only in Knicks territory.
Territories. Dividing up markets. That's antitrust talk. Just the kind a league like the N.B.A. hates to hear.

HEADLINE: SPORTS BUSINESS;
Gutkowski Is Named to Run Garden

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR

 BODY:
Robert Gutkowski, who as president of the Madison Square Garden Network engineered the landmark $500 million cable deal with the New York Yankees, was named president and chief executive of the Garden yesterday. He replaces Richard H. Evans, who resigned under pressure in August.
Gutkowski, 43 years old, who Garden insiders say navigated smoothly through a testy relationship with Evans, has been running the entertainment group of the Garden since his predecessor's departure. 
 In his new post, the management of the New York Knicks, the New York Rangers, the MSG Network, the Garden arena, the boxing operations and the newly-opened Paramount Theater will report to him.
Gutkowski's appointment comes shortly after the re-opening of the Garden, which has undergone a $200 million renovation begun by Evans. In a statement, Stanley Jaffe, the president of Paramount Communications, the Garden's parent company, called Gutkowski's appointment "the final element in the launching of a new era for Madison Square Garden."
One of Gutkowski's goals now is to prevent the kind of turmoil that has roiled the Garden in recent years, primarily in the management of the Knicks and the Rangers. But Gutkowski is also the fifth Garden chief executive in the 14 years Paramount has owned the facility, coming in a line after Evans, Jack Krumpe, Sonny Werblin and Alan Cohen.
"It's hard to guarantee anything," Gutkowski said. "But the only thing I can say is I've been involved in the network for six years and turnover has been nonexistent. My people stay around for a long time. But any organization is impacted by turmoil, the Garden no more or less than any company."
He said his immediate goals are to "take a look at the sports franchises where the product has gotten a lot better."
He added: "Continue the momentum we've got in booking acts into the Garden and the Paramount and make sure the facility is working in a good way."
 
Subscribers Grow
 During Gutkowski's six years as president of the MSG Network, the number of subscribers climbed from 1.7 million to 4.6 million, the bulk of whom came on after the 12-year deal with the Yankees was signed.
Gutkowski was criticized for lavishing $500 million on the Yankees, but he said the deal transformed the cable network into a 52-week enterprise.
"It was the only deal we could make," he said. "The Mets weren't in the market. If we cared about the longevity of the network, we had to do it."
Gutkowski is viewed as a tough but fair negotiator with a sharp eye for programming and personnel. People who work for him at the network say that he inspires considerable personal loyalty.
Bob Page, anchorman of the nightly "MSG Sportsdesk," said of his boss: "In more than three years here, I've said a lot of controversial things. While Bob objected a few times, he never called me on the carpet -- and I've criticized the Rangers and the Knicks."
 
Achieved Goals
 Chet Simmons, who as president of ESPN hired Gutkowski in 1981 as vice president of programming, and who is now co-executive producer of MSG's "Around the NFL" program, said: "Bob did what he set out to do at MSG. He wanted to upgrade the quality of the network by putting on baseball, by creating a sports news operation and covering high school sports. He's done all that."
Now Gutkowski takes his skills to the broader tableau of the entire Garden, at a time when the economic recession is continuing unabated.
"We've been impacted by it," he said. "We've been hurt. So we wonder if we can market better. Control costs better. Sign additional product. Upgrade facilities."

HEADLINE: Better Discipline? Train Parents, Then Children

BYLINE: By JANE E. BRODY

 BODY:
FEW chores of child-rearing are more frustrating or fraught with emotional conflict than discipline. Now some researchers believe they know why: discipline is being applied to children when it should first be applied to their parents.
"Most parents lack a good grasp of what to do when there's a problem," said James Windell, a clinical psychologist in Waterford, Mich. "Their instincts aren't always useful, and when they rely on their emotions they often end up feeling guilty." 
 But new findings suggest that it may be surprisingly easy for parents to get out of ineffective disciplinary ruts. Researchers caution that beyond the importance of combining love with limits, there is no one approach that every parent should adopt. Not only do disciplinary occasions differ, but all children are different and parents cannot be convincing disciplinarians when they are using a tactic that makes them uncomfortable.
"One size doesn't fit all," said Dr. Carolyn Webster-Stratton, a nurse-practitioner and child psychologist at the University of Washington in Seattle. "Basic disciplinary principles must be tailored to each child and family."
Before parents can become effective disciplinarians, she said, they must first learn how to manage their own anger, solve problem situations and give and get support from others.
These are among recent findings suggesting that most parents can, with a little help, improve the behavior even of difficult children:
*Simple self-help techniques, with or without professional support, can help parents sharply reduce discipline problems.
*Parents who are sensitive to their children's needs have more obedient children.
*Praise and love alone are not enough to instill good behavior. Too much permissiveness hurts a child's efforts to develop self-control.
*Behavior problems should be reversed early; waiting until the preteen-age years diminishes chances for success and puts children at higher risk for drug use and other problems.
*Spanking is not only ineffective, it may erode the child's self-esteem and the parent-child relationship, leading to more problems later.
 
Learning Parental Tricks
 Studies among hundreds of families at the University of Washington School of Nursing have shown that "parents need to learn as many tricks of the trade as possible, including how to play with their children, communicate with them, praise and reward them and set limits for them, as well as how to handle misbehavior using a variety of techniques," according to Dr. Webster-Stratton, director of the Parenting Clinic there. Since 1979, she has worked with about 700 families struggling to cope with children between the ages of 4 and 8 years old who are so aggressive and disobedient that they may be unable to go to school.
In the Seattle studies, instructional videotapes showing right and wrong ways of handling behavior problems helped parents induce major improvements in their children's behavior. She said the tapes were effective regardless of parents' economic, marital or educational circumstances. Further, she said, they were a low-cost way to reach parents who might not otherwise seek professional help.
Studies of babies and toddlers directed by Dr. Everett Waters, a psychology professor at the State University of New York at Stony Brook, showed that young children were much more responsive to parental discipline if the child perceived the parent as "available, responsive, sensitive -- sensitive to the baby's signals and able to respond appropriately and in a timely manner," he explained.
 
Permissiveness as a 'Disaster'
 But the so-called permissive approach, in which parents are unconditionally warm and accepting regardless of what the child does, is "a disaster in the hands of most parents," said Dr. Gerald Patterson of Eugene, Ore. Follow-up studies of permissive parenting conducted by Dr. Diana Baumrind of the University of California at Berkeley found that the children lacked self-confidence and faced a high risk of developing antisocial behavior.
"Permissiveness alone doesn't work well because the parents, while warm and loving, do not provide enough structure or monitoring of their child's behavior," explained Dr. James H. Bray, a psychologist at the Baylor College of Medicine in Houston. In his eight-year study of 200 families, he found that when parents failed to set limits, "the child doesn't know when to stop and acts out more."
Dr. Susan O'Leary, a Stony Brook psychologist, has found that lax parenting is as bad as harsh parenting. Both for teachers in the classroom and for parents of 2-year-olds, the "timing, tone of voice and length of the reprimand determine its effectiveness," she said. When a child misbehaves, the reprimand should be immediate, brief and delivered firmly without yelling or pleading. "Don't touch" is better than a 60-word explanation, she said.
If maladaptive behavior is not reversed early in a child's life, studies have shown that highly aggressive and noncompliant children are at high risk for delinquent or socially deviant behavior like drug abuse when they reach their teen-age years. Dr. Patterson, an eminent researcher in the field, said intervention before the children are 9 years old "can bring the majority back into the normal range of behavior, but if you wait until ages 9 to 12, the success rate is only half as good."
Dr. Patterson and his colleagues at the Oregon Social Learning Center in Eugene found through observations of hundreds of families in their homes that "the core issue in socializing children is to teach a reasonable level of compliance between the ages of 18 months and 3 years."
He said parents were not solely to blame for their difficult children. Rather, he said, "children who fail to learn the necessary level of compliance may be temperamentally difficult to begin with and they may also have parents who lack the needed skills to cope with them or who are under a lot of stress themselves."
Classroom studies by Dr. Irwin A. Hyman, a school psychologist at Temple University in Philadelphia, strongly suggest that a more rational, democratic approach that teaches children to behave in certain ways because it is the right thing to do is more effective at instilling internal controls than is an authoritarian approach based on fear of retribution. In his studies, he said, "when the teacher left the room, the kids with the authoritarian teachers went crazy, but the kids with the more democratic teachers were as good as when the teachers were present."
Dr. Robert Wahler, a psychologist at the University of Tennessee in Knoxville who works with children aged 2 to 11, said a "subdued" approach to discipline was crucial. "Good discipline is not effective because it hurts but because it transfers control from the child to the parent," he said. "High-intensity discipline promotes a counterresponse from the child. Discipline should be administered in as businesslike a manner as possible."
 
Importance of Consistency
 All researchers who study discipline seem to agree, as Dr. Rex Forehand put it, that "consistency is key" to effective discipline. Dr. Forehand, a psychologist at the University of Georgia in Athens who has studied working-class families with noncompliant young children, said: "Parents must have rules and limits and the children must know the consequences for breaking them. If the rules are not clear or consistently enforced, the child feels the need to test them, to find out what the limits are today."
Dr. Mark W. Roberts, supervisor of the psychology clinic at Idaho State University, agrees that consistent discipline is the most important element in promoting behavioral improvements in disobedient children. But in his studies of about 300 disobedient children over the last 15 years, he also found that "discipline alone is not a sufficient treatment for disruptive children." He said parents must also learn to become more responsive to their child's questions and requests and must give the child more unconditional praise.
 
Harmful Effects of Spanking
 The new research also demonstrates that spanking, which remains parents' main disciplinary weapon, is not only useless in the long run but also potentially hurtful to the child's emerging personality. In experimental studies with toddlers placed in a room with their mothers and breakable objects they were told not to touch, the children who were frequently spanked were less obedient than the children who were disciplined in nonphysical ways.
As adults, Dr. Hyman said, those who were frequently harshly punished as children were more likely to be depressed and suffer from low self-esteem.
"All the evidence suggests that frequent spanking is the cause, not the result, of disobedience and mental illness, said Dr. Hyman, who builds a case against corporal punishment in schools in his book, "Reading, Writing and the Hickory Stick" (Lexington Books, $18.95). "The problem starts early with parents who fail to understand normal child development and spank infants and toddlers when they act naturally, for example, when they grab things off the table."
It has long been known that frequent spanking, yelling or threatening noncompliant children with harsh punishments can foster misbehavior. Mr. Windell, who works with children whose parents consider them out of control, said even negative consequences like getting spanked can reinforce a child's bad behavior because someone is reacting to it in a highly dramatic way.
In some families misbehaving is the only way the child gets his parents' undivided attention. But by pitting parent against child, harsh punishments often accentuate the battle of wills and prompt the child to see how far he can go before his parents will react, said Mr. Windell, who wrote "Discipline, A Sourcebook of 50 Failsafe Techniques for Parents," just published by Collier($9.95).
In addition to teaching children that physical aggression is an acceptable response when a person is angry or frustrated, "corporal punishment doesn't show the child an effective alternative way to behave," said Dr. Darwin Dorr, a psychologist at Highland Hospital in Asheville, N.C., who conducts workshops on discipline.

HEADLINE: Sea Floor Holds Story Of Hawaiian Isles' Doom

BYLINE: By WALTER SULLIVAN

DATELINE: HONOLULU

 BODY:
OCEANOGRAPHIC surveys are throwing dramatic new light on the cataclysmic landslides that lopped off a large part of the Hawaiian island of Oahu and may one day strike the chain's big island, Hawaii.
Oahu's lost half has been missing for some time, probably a million years or more, but only recently have the missing pieces been located. The new oceanographic surveys have mapped in greater detail the massive fields of avalanche debris. Some of the fragments are gigantic blocks measuring 10 miles on a side. 
 New land observations also suggest that as a large part of the island plunged into the sea, a titanic ocean wave swelled up against the neighboring island of Lanai, reaching a height of 2,300 feet.
The new findings paint a more detailed picture of the process in which the lava that built the islands fell away in cataclysmic avalanches even as the islands themselves were on the rise. The result of this process is Hawaii's remarkably beautiful steep-cliffed landscape.
The islands of the Hawaiian chain are the tops of great mountains that rise as much as 29,000 feet from the sea floor.
Oahu was born four million years ago as two giant volcanoes. The remnants of one form the Waianae Range at the island's west end. Remnants of the other, the Koolau Range, rise gently behind Honolulu and Waikiki. They end in a mighty cliff, the Nuuanu Pali. The cliff, now a major tourist attraction, marks where much of the island fell away.
The Pali is the remaining edge of the giant basin, or caldera, formed by the volcano. At its base is the town of Kaneohe, and beyond that, open ocean. The other half of the caldera, an area the size of Brooklyn, tor away and tumbled into the ocean abyss. In that event, according to measurements taken by a new survey, it appears that 1,800 cubic miles of rock cascaded into the sea. The underwater debris field left by the avalanche reaches more than 140 miles from the island and covers more than 9,000 square miles. Over all, sea-floor debris from avalanches and slumps in the Hawaiian islands covers more than five times the area of the islands themselves.
The Oahu landslide happened a million or more years ago, but the forces of change are still at work in the Hawaiian island chain. Earthquake analysis indicates that Hawaii, the largest and only volcanically active island in the chain, is gradually splitting apart along a rift extending east from Kilauea volcano.
Geologists believe the cause of the splitting is lava that pushes into the rift and spurts onto the surface. Hawaii, at the southeast end of the chain, was formed by huge volcanic eruptions fueled by a "hot spot" in the earth's deep interior from which molten magma penetrates the ocean floor. The older islands in the chain were formed by the same hot spot, but have been carried past it by the motion of the Pacific sea floor, which creeps northwest across the hot spot at the rate of a few centimeters a year.
The island of Hawaii began to form some 800,000 years ago from the eruptions of giant volcanoes, of which Kilauea is the most active. Flows of lava from the volcanoes have heaped atop sediments that built up ages before on the sea bottom. Analysis of an earthquake that occurred in June 1989 indicates that the east side of Kilauea is slipping seaward, lubricated by the buried sediments, six miles below, on which the bottom of the volcano rests.
Studies of the underwater debris fields tell much about the islands' geological past and future. The current surveys are being carried out as part of the effort by the United States to map its entire exclusive economic zone, extending 200 nautical miles off all its shores. Recent findings, analyzed by Dr. James G. Moore, a specialist in Hawaiian volcanism, and five colleagues at the United States Geological Survey, have been published in The Journal of Geophysical Research.
Preliminary results have come from a British sonar system known as Gloria, and surveys now under way by American researchers. Gloria can map a 60-mile-wide swath of sea floor on a single pass. It was towed behind the British research vessel Farnella, which docked a few weeks ago in Honolulu. The survey was jointly sponsored by the Institute of Oceanographic Sciences in Britain and the United States Geological Survey.
 
A 2,300-Foot Wave
 The Americans are concentrating on recent landslides from the island of Hawaii, using multibeam sonars that can map the bottom more precisely than the Gloria system. This has produced a perspective diagram of one slide from the west coast of Hawaii and a survey of another that has slipped into the sea from Kilauea.
Geologists have identified two distinct processes whereby the Hawaiian Islands have shed land: slow slumping and catastrophic landslides. The Nuuanu landslide that swept away the northeast side of Oahu is thought to have been of the later type.
So great was its momentum that it crossed the Hawaiian Deep, 15,000 feet below sea level and moved up the slope beyond to 1,000 feet above the deep. The Hawaiian Deep is sea floor depressed by the enormous weight of the volcanoes.
Nearer shore is a giant amphitheater, now submerged, but presumably above water when the slide occurred. The island, as it aged and moved away from the "hot spot," has sunk 1,000 feet.
That the avalanche was sudden and swift has been inferred from the immense blocks of debris showing in the sonar. According to Dr. Barry Raleigh, dean of the School of Ocean and Earth Science Technology at the University of Hawaii, the resulting wave swept to an elevation of 2,300 feet on nearby Lanai island, swamping 95 percent of its surface and depositing coral high on its slopes.
He and Dr. Moore hope that, by dating this coral and by drilling down to coral beneath the debris slide, it should be possible to learn when the avalanche occurred.
Traces of great avalanches have been found on both sides of Oahu as well as alongside all the other islands. Avalanches are at present prone to occur along the steep sides of Loihi, the submerged volcano southeast of Hawaii that should eventually form a new island.
 
Critical but Irregular Events
 Debate about the possibility of large Hawaiian landslides dates at least from 1890, when James Dwight Dana, a leading 19th century geologist, proposed that such immense cliffs as the Nuuanu Pali of Oahu, the Napali Coast of Kauai and northern Molokai were produced by fracturing and "downdrop" of the seaward side beneath the sea.
But Dr. Moore and his colleagues said that only now has the extent of such processes been shown.
Discovery of evidence for such dramatic events further discredits doctrinaire uniformitarianism -- the belief that all phenomena that have shaped the earth are currently active. Other examples of critical but irregular events include asteroid impacts such as the one that probably created the moon, or the periodic shedding of Mount Rainier's ice into Puget Sound.
As each island of the Hawaiian chain is pared down by landslides and sinks deeper into the sea, new islands should arise to the southeast, as is the case now with Loihi. That this process has been going on for tens of millions of years is evident from the islands and atolls that extend far to the northwest. Because motion of the Pacific floor changed direction some 30 million years ago, the chain then bends north, becoming the Emperor Seamounts that extend almost to the northwest corner of the ocean.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Hawaiian island of Oahu was born four million years ago as two giant volcanoes. The remnants of one is this cliff, the Nuuanu Pali, now a major tourist attraction. The rest of the caldera of the volcano, an area the size of Brooklyn, has torn away and tumbled into the ocean abyss. (Photo Resource Hawaii/Marc Schechter) (pg. C10)
 
Diagram: "Oahu Shaped By Giant Slide"
 About a million years ago, long before Polynesians arrived, the northern side of Oahu's giant Koolau volcano slid to sea, spreading debris as much as 140 miles offshore. A great cliff, the Nuuano Pali, is all that remains of the volcano. The south-facing slope in back of the cliff is the site of Honolulu suburbs.
 
Giant Blocks of Evidence
 Mapping by sonar has shown blocks of debris 10 miles on a side. The total volume is estimated at 1,800 cubic miles, covering 9,000 square miles of ocean floor. Another great landslide slid southwest into the sea from the Waianae Volcano on Oahu's west side.
 
Enormous Ocean Wave
 So swift and massive was the avalanche as it plunged into the sea that it caused a wave that deposited coral 2,3oo feet above sea level on the nearby island of Lanai.
 Lava eruption helped split the island.

HEADLINE: WASHINGTON WAITS FOR BUSH DECISION ON CHIEF OF STAFF

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2

 BODY:
President Bush met with John H. Sununu on Sunday to discuss the chief of staff's future and other issues as the President edged closer to decisions on his 1992 campaign staff and a possible shake-up of White House aides, White House advisers said today.
The meeting heightened the sense of expectation today among Washington Republicans. It was one of several gatherings over the weekend, including a discussion on Saturday at Camp David between Mr. Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, his closest friend, and a session at the White House on Sunday night between the President and Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner, a longtime associate of Mr. Bush who is widely regarded as the leading candidate to replace Mr. Sununu. 
 Republican strategists and Administration officials said none of these sessions were conclusive, in the sense that Mr. Bush did not tell Mr. Sununu, Mr. Baker or Mr. Skinner his final decision. Several Republican strategists, a ranking Republican Senator and a member of the Bush Cabinet said Mr. Bush had not made a decision, but they said they expected him to do so this week.
 
'Wobbling' on Sununu
 The Senator said Mr. Bush was "wobbling all over the place" about Mr. Sununu. But after weeks of pressure on the chief of staff, his position was insecure enough that the Senator said there was a "serious" possibility Mr. Sununu would lose his job. "His chances of survival are not better than 50-50," he said.
Mr. Bush has been under pressure from some of his Cabinet members and political associates to remove Mr. Sununu, because of several missteps on domestic policy that have contributed to Mr. Bush's current slump in public opinion polls and because of an abrasive style that many Republicans say makes it difficult to assemble a campaign staff around Mr. Sununu.
During the weekend, Mr. Bush and his son, George W. Bush, who has been a political adviser to his father for years, "talked to everybody" in the President's political circles, a senior official said.
The Washington Post reported in Tuesday's issue that the younger Mr. Bush had told Mr. Sununu on Wednesday that he had alienated members of the Cabinet and White House staff, hurting his effectiveness. A source was reported as saying that the message was meant to be taken as a suggestion that Mr. Sununu offer to resign.
Mr. Bush talked to Mr. Baker at Camp David on Saturday after the Secretary, who has been the President's primary political counselor, brought his grandchildren to the Maryland retreat for a weekend visit.
After meeting with Mr. Sununu in Washington on Sunday, Mr. Bush dined in his private residence with Mr. Skinner, who has made no secret of his desire to serve as chief of staff and is a favorite among many Republicans. A senior official said today that Mr. Bush did not offer the White House post to Mr. Skinner, who has been involved in Mr. Bush's campaigns since 1980 and has become a troubleshooter for the President as a member of the Cabinet.
Few details of the President's discussions were known, and each of the three officials could have had routine reasons for meeting with Mr. Bush related to their Government posts.
 
A Charged Atmosphere
 But the sessions took on new significance in the highly charged atmosphere of the White House as Mr. Bush returned from the holiday to prepare for the second in a series of domestic damage-control trips, this one to Mississippi and Florida on Tuesday.
The weekend sessions suggested that the pace of the President's decision-making had accelerated, and that, in turn, heightened the sense of expectation and urgency among Republican professionals and Administration officials who were searching for the slightest harbingers of Mr. Bush's thinking.
The President made no public statements about the campaign team today and White House advisers said the President had not notified any of the half-dozen associates waiting for word on their 1992 jobs. These include Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher, who is widely expected to be named campaign chairman; Robert Teeter, Mr. Bush's poll taker; Frederic V. Malek, a longtime political adviser, and Charles Black, a Republican political consultant.
"The whole town is waiting for the other shoe to drop," said a White House adviser.
 
'Nothing's Changed'
 Asked at the daily White House briefing about Mr. Sununu, Marlin Fitzwater, Mr. Bush's spokesman, answered almost as if by rote: "Sununu is chief of staff. He's been on the job for three and a half years. We expect him to stay. The President has full confidence in him. Nothing's changed."
In another sign that Mr. Bush is moving to establish his campaign organization, even though he has yet to announce his candidacy for re-election, Mr. Fitzwater acknowledged that Mr. Bush had asked Gov. Judd Gregg of New Hampshire to oversee his campaign efforts in that state's primary next February, which is the first of the election season.
That seemed to rule out one theory popular among Administration officials and party strategists: that Mr. Bush could ease Mr. Sununu out of the White House by sending him to his home state, where he was credited with helping Mr. Bush win the 1988 Republican Presidential primary, to prepare for the 1992 primary.
In the view of many Repubican leaders, the possibility of right-wing challenges in New Hampshire from Patrick J. Buchanan, the conservative commentator, and from State Representative David Duke, a former Ku Klux Klan leader who lost a race for Governor of Louisiana last month, have increased the urgency for Mr. Bush to assemble his campaign team.
Apart from removing Mr. Sununu outright, some Republican strategists have suggested that Mr. Bush could reduce his influence over the campaign by naming a strong re-election team with direct access to the Oval Office.
 
Blaming the Chief of Staff
 As his political problems have multiplied, Mr. Sununu has become the focus of criticism of Mr. Bush's domestic policies, particularly his refusal to take drastic action that might spur economic growth or, at least, persuade voters that the President is trying to do something.
Mr. Bush acknowledged these pressures today during a picture-taking session. "Many Americans want to know what their Government is doing right now to get the economy moving again," he said, adding that he was "directing the Cabinet to assure the most effective implementation of existing programs: job placement, job training, unemployment benefits programs, safety net programs, small business loans."
But Mr. Bush's order seemed largely a public relations gesture. Mr. Fitzwater later said there would be no additional expenditures on any programs the President mentioned.

HEADLINE: BAKER WILL VISIT UKRAINE TO DISCUSS NUCLEAR QUESTION

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2

 BODY:
On the heels of Ukraine's landslide vote for independence, President Bush ordered Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d today to visit Kiev this month to discuss American concerns about the control of nuclear weapons on Ukrainian territory.
The announcement came as the White House officially welcomed the Sunday vote as "a striking testimony to the will for liberty" and indicated again that it would grant full diplomatic recognition to the new nation in due course. 
 The White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said that Mr. Bush had discussed Mr. Baker's visit, which will include a stop in Moscow, with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, and that the Presidents agreed on the need for a practical approach to Ukraine's action, which Mr. Gorbachev has opposed.
 
Whittling Gorbachev's Power
 But today's White House actions seemed only to underscore Mr. Gorbachev's diminishing importance in an American policy on the Soviet Union, which has shifted in recent weeks away from the Kremlin and toward the fractious republics. The decision to send Mr. Baker to Kiev to talk about nuclear weapons undercuts Mr. Gorbachev's role as the primary Soviet leader responsible for arms issues, one of the few clear responsibilities he has maintained since the failed coup in August.
Mr. Baker will be preceded to Kiev by an Assistant Secretary of State, Thomas M. T. Niles, who will travel there for meetings this week. Both envoys will discuss the nuclear issue, Ukraine's obligation to honor international treaties signed by Moscow, and its role in salvaging the crumbling Soviet economy, the White House said in a prepared statement.
Of the three, the question of who will control nuclear weapons is by far the most urgent. It has driven an effective reversal of American policy since the summer, when President Bush urged Ukrainians, in a major speech in Kiev on Aug. 1, to retain their political and military ties to the old Soviet center.
 
Road to Nuclear-Free Ukraine
 Mr. Fitzwater said Mr. Baker would discuss with Leonid M. Kravchuk, the Ukrainian leader, "how we might help in terms of eliminating nuclear weapons" on Ukrainian soil.
Ukraine's leaders have pledged to create a nuclear-free state. But they simultaneously laid claim this summer to the estimated 176 ballistic missiles and 1,000 or so Soviet nuclear warheads still on their soil, arguing that their control cannot be left solely to a Moscow Government that they despise and mistrust.
When Ukraine said this summer that it planned to create its own 450,000-man military, supplanting the Soviet Army controlled by Moscow, President Boris N. Yeltsin of the Russian federated republic confronted President Kravchuk, demanding that all nuclear weapons be returned to Russian soil.
Mr. Kravchuk refused, and the two nations later signed a temporary military and economic agreement that put off the question of nuclear control.
In Kiev today, Mr. Kravchuk said he hoped to create a collective military command of nuclear weapons with Russia, Byelorussia and Kazakhstan, the other three former Soviet republics with nuclear forces.
Mr. Fitzwater said today that Mr. Baker and Mr. Niles would raise with Ukrainian leaders their obligation to adhere to arms-control accords and their need to control the spread of "dangerous military-related technology" to developing nations.
An Administration Soviet expert characterized Ukraine today as sharing Washington's desire to control nuclear arms, adding: "I think all the parties -- Gorbachev, Yeltsin, Kravchuk, the allies -- are agreed that we have to work this one out."
 
Cashing in Chips
 Some outside analysts have speculated that Kiev wants to use nuclear weapons as a bargaining chip in negotiating the terms of its relations with Moscow and the West.
With Ukrainian sovereignty a foregone conclusion, "we're trying to be both constructive and practical," said an Administration Soviet expert, "constructive in that we don't want to accelerate the decentralization process, and practical in that we have to keep talking to the republics on these issues."
While questions of economic integration and treaty obligations are important indicators of future American relations with the republics, "the nuclear issue, for Ukraine, is obviously of critical importance."
The United States is also concerned about the security of Soviet nuclear reactors, which contain nuclear materials that could be stolen or sold to terrorists or developing nations, and also pose potential environmental threats.
 
Recognition Not Immediate
 The 1985 nuclear accident at Chernobyl, which many analysts say played a role in the chain of events that led to the Soviet breakup, occurred in Ukraine, not far from Kiev, the capital.
Mr. Baker will discuss that and other Ukrainian matters with the governments of Mr. Yeltsin and Mr. Gorbachev during a stop in Moscow. Mr. Niles will go immediately to Kiev for talks with Mr. Kravchuk about future relations with Washington..
The United States is unlikely to recognize Ukrainian sovereignty until after Mr. Baker's trip, Mr. Fitzwater said, but he left little doubt that full recognition will eventually take place.
"The United States welcomes this expression of democracy which is a tribute to the spirit of the Ukrainian people," Mr. Fitzwater said in a prepared statement. "Ukraine's aspiration to join the Euroatlantic community is striking testimony to the will for liberty in a nation which has persisted and survived despite the terrible calamities of the 20th century."
In a single phrase in his four-page statement, Mr. Fitzwater said that the White House remains committed to dealing with Mr. Gorbachev, on unspecified matters. They include the Soviet military, the disposition of the Soviet foreign debt and Mr. Gorbachev's dimming hopes that the remaining 12 republics will join in a single economic union.
 
Another Policy Shift
 But by sending Mr. Baker to talk directly to Mr. Kravchuk about nuclear weapons, the White House has moved from the Kremlin to the republics another critical item on the foreign-policy agenda.
Mr. Fitzwater acknowledged that the United States has no choice now but to adapt its own policies to the rising independence movement in the Soviet republics, a movement Mr. Bush personally sought to dampen in his much-noted speech on Aug. 1, less than three weeks before the coup that speeded the disintegration of the Soviet Union.
"One cannot deny the changes that have already taken place and the process of transformation that's under way," he said.
Mr. Fitzwater said that President Bush discussed American policy toward Ukraine in telephone calls on Saturday with Mr. Gorbachev and Canada's prime minister, Brian Mulroney. "All three leaders view this matter much as the United States does, which is to say they want to provide constructive and realistic approaches to the changes going on there," he said.
Soviet news services reported that Mr. Gorbachev told Mr. Bush that while Ukrainian independence may be unavoidable, Kiev's refusal to join an alliance of the former Soviet states would be a "catastrophe."
Mr. Fitzwater and other officials today stressed the United States' interest in promoting friendly relations between the Ukrainian leadership and Mr. Yeltsin's Russian government, which are divided by nationalistic impulses, but still lashed together by economic and military ties.
Beyond their disputes over military matters, Russia and Ukraine have argued lately over their shared borders and over Ukraine's determination to create a separate monetary system.
The ability of Russia and Ukraine to work together in openness and mutual respect "will be a test of whether they are capable of making the transition to democratic societies which respect the rights of individuals," Mr. Fitzwater said. "We hope and believe that the leaders in Moscow and Kiev will establish such a relationship."

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
A Haitian Father

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
Almost always now, when I read about Haitians who risk the seas to get to this country but wind up on distant shores behind barbed wire, I think of an illegal immigrant I happened to know myself, and of his daughters and his son.
Then a shiver of shame and embarrassment goes through me, for a particular and large group of Americans. 
 This fellow I am talking about needed work to help support his wife and six children. He was living at the time in Canada, where he had once found the outdoor work he loved -- farming, laying track, traveling to the far country to trade. But work dried up in Canada, so he took the night train from Toronto to New York.
There he found employment as a house painter, which he hated. But he was an excellent painter as he had been an excellent farmer and fur trader. One day he fell off the scaffold; he died.
This man, who was known as Harry, never told his children exactly how he managed to cross the border. After Harry died, immigration authorities could never discover any record of his entry, or of his son's, who was also on that train from Toronto. They both were declared illegals -- night-train wetbacks.
But in the meantime Harry's daughters and son had grown up in the United States. Always Harry, his wife and his children blessed America. Many years later, when his children told the story of their father and his determination to find work in America, to hell with borders, people smiled in admiration of this man. And always, his children were filled with pride about him, and gratitude.
So of course when I read about the Haitians I think of my father, Harry, the illegal who came in search of work. Of course, Harry never went through the hells of the Haitians. He had left Russia for Canada, sick of the stench of czarism and longing for the clean air of political and religious liberty. But when he left Canada he was not in fear of being shot in the streets, as are the Haitians. He was just looking for work, which means not only bread but self-respect. But I know that if he had been born in Haiti or lived there, he would have broken every law that stood between him and work in the U.S. But where are Harry's children now?
Where are all the American Jews, and Poles, and Irish, and Balts, and Italians who can remember a parent or a grandparent who came to this country looking for work, when visas were bought by steamship agents, or who borrowed a cousin's papers, or who just took a night train from someplace to someplace?
Don't they ever feel like getting on their knees and thanking God that at least their folks never had to crawl into stinking, pitching boats out of fear and hunger?
American Jewish organizations are proud that their money helped Ethiopian Jews get to Israel, and Irish-American groups rally round the thousands of illegal Irish immigrants. The Eastern Europeans of America struggled to get to America's grace, and for their parents' homelands to be free of Communism. Does not one of these organizations understand their causes would be stronger and cleaner if they could manage, in their sympathy for refugees and work-hunters, to cross religious, national and color lines?
Forget about blaming the White House and the bureaucrats. Blame ourselves, children of Harry. Imagine what a quick pickup lobby, or parade, demanding succor for Haitians could do if it were headed by a few Irish-American Cardinals, a batch of rabbis and the presidents of Eastern European, Greek, Italian, Arab and Turkish organizations. American blacks and wasps welcome, too!
We are told, be reasonable, America can't open its doors to economic refugees. Pull up the gangplank, Jack, I'm aboard. Maybe, but the Pakistanis, who have barely a half-penny to our dollar, give refuge to millions of Afghans and Washington scolds Hong Kong and Britain for not accepting the Vietnamese refugees.
But even reluctantly recognizing some economic limitations, this country should have the moral elegance to accept neighbors who flee countries where life is terror and hunger, and are run by murderous gangs left over from dictatorships we ourselves maintained and cosseted.
If that were a qualification for entry into our golden land, the Haitians should be welcomed with song, embrace and memories.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: MARKET PLACE;
A Likely Tax Bill Provision That Would Aid Takeovers

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
The tax fight of 1992 in Congress is likely to focus on whose taxes should be cut to spur the economy. But if any tax bill passes, it appears likely that it will include an obscure provision that would greatly improve the tax advantages of many corporate takeovers.
"It would be a huge boon," said Bob Chapman, a vice president of arbitrage at County NatWest Securities. "I would say you would see a billion-dollar deal announced in weeks if it goes through." 
 The proposal would for the first time allow companies to amortize, and therefore take deductions on their tax returns, for good will stemming from an acquisition of another company. That good will can amount to billions of dollars in some deals.
In recent years, the trend of tax legislation has been against corporate takeovers. But this proposal -- made by Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democrat who is chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, and endorsed by the Bush Administration -- is being pushed not as a way to promote takeovers but as a way of simplifying the tax code and reducing litigation.
But to many on Wall Street, it is being viewed as a way to increase takeover activity, especially in the food industry. "The takeover values of food companies would go up 20 percent overnight," Mr. Chapman said.
Some are more cautious, however. Robert Willens, an accounting analyst at Lehman Brothers, said the change, if it took effect, was more likely to spur purchases of subsidiaries than of whole companies, because of differing tax treatments that would not be changed. He added that while it would make companies in some industries more attractive as acquisition candidates, others would be less attractive, among them cable television and computer software.
So great is the potential impact that Mr. Rostenkowski said last week that he had heard that some transactions were being delayed in hopes of better tax treatment. He pushed through the House a resolution saying that if the proposal was passed, it would be made retroactive to July 25, the day it was introduced.
Under current tax law, the tax advantages of tangible assets, like buildings and machines, are clear and easily ascertained. But the status of intangible assets is much less clear, and subject to what sometimes seems like endless litigation. Mr. Rostenkowski's proposal, H.R. 3035, would go a long way toward simplifying the law by making most intangible assets subject to common treatment.
In assessing the tax treatment of a takeover, the acquiring company first values the tangible assets being acquired. That can be a contentious issue, but it is relatively straightforward. The tangible assets will be depreciated over a set number of years, providing tax deductions for the company. If the purchase price of the company is no more than the net value of the tangible assets, then there is nothing more to do.
But that is rarely the case. Normally, the price paid in a takeover is much higher than that amount, meaning that intangible assets have also been acquired. The Internal Revenue Service will normally claim that as much of those intangible assets as possible are good will, or the going concern value of the company. Such assets can never be depreciated and thus provide no tax benefits.
As a result, companies spend huge sums trying to persuade the I.R.S. and the courts that the intangible assets fall into a category that can be depreciated, and over as short a period as possible. Fred T. Goldberg Jr., the I.R.S. Commissioner, said that the I.R.S. had counted 159 different types of intangible assets that companies had identified and that the list was probably not complete. The list includes everything from non-union status to trade names to recipes.
"Millions of hours and dollars are consumed each year by the American public analyzing hopelessly conflicting case law, performing intricate valuations and defending challenges to their conclusions," he said in endorsing H.R. 3035.
That bill would provide that nearly all intangible assets, including good will, could be written off over 14 years after the acquisition. The principal exclusion would be government contracts that are expected to be renewed in perpetuity, thus providing bad news for cable television companies.
Another exclusion would be professional sports franchises, a move that would likely depress valuations of teams that already seem to have peaked and headed lower. The 14-year period was chosen in an effort to assure that the net effect is not to raise or lower tax receipts.
If the bill passes, the winners will be those companies that have done poorly under the current law in persuading the courts that they have depreciable intangible assets. Food companies are high on that list, which is why Mr. Chapman is especially enthusiastic about that industry. The losers will be industries like computer software that have established tax treatment of intangible assets allowing write-offs over shorter periods.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Goodrich Is Shutting 3 Vinyl Resin Plants

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
The B. F. Goodrich Company, citing adverse economic conditions, said yesterday that it planned to shut three plants that make vinyl resin, resulting in the layoffs of about 225 workers and a $117.8 million pretax charge against fourth-quarter earnings.
Goodrich, a leading producer of plastics and specialty chemicals, said the shutdowns would occur over the next two years. 
 The charge in the current quarter would reduce earnings after taxes by $77.9 million, or $3.07 a share, the company said. Goodrich earned $14.1 million, or 47 cents a share, in the fourth quarter a year ago.
Goodrich, based in Akron, Ohio, has been hurt this year because of declining sales of its vinyl products, which are used in manufacturing everything from construction materials to appliances. The layoffs and closings will affect operations in Ohio, Illinois and Louisiana. The company will continue to operate five other vinyl resin plants.
In a statement, Goodrich said the closings were necessary because the cost of operating the plants was too high. At the same time, demand for resin fell because of the slowdown in the economy.
"This is a key step in implementing our strategy of making the Goen Vinyl division a more stable and consistent source of earnings," said John D. Ong, the company's chairman. "By focusing on our most competetive vinyl resin operations and eliminating the ongoing expense of maintaining our high-cost facilities, we will increase the return on investment in this business."
Analysts praised the company's decision, saying that it would enable the company's financial performance to improve. They also said that other producers of vinyl resins were taking similar actions.
On the New York Stock Exchange, Goodrich's shares rose 62.5 cents yesterday, closing at $39.25.
The company said that the vinyl resin production lines being shut represented about 25 percent of Goodrich's resin manufacturing capacity in North America. Goodrich added that production costs at the three plants was about 40 percent higher than at the remaining operations.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
NCNB Plans a Quick Sale of Bad Loans

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
The NCNB Corporation is planning for rapid sales of bad loans after its year-end merger with the C&S/Sovran Corporation, and has promised to concentrate on improving profits of its existing businesses rather than continuing the rapid expansion of the last decade.
"Our growth goals have been achieved," said Hugh L. McColl Jr., NCNB's chairman, who will be chairman of the merged bank, to be called Nationsbank. "Now is the time for running what we have built." 
 Besides the $450 million of savings he expects from the merger -- up from $350 million predicted earlier this year -- Mr. McColl said profits would grow as the economy improved and the company began investing deposits in high-rate consumer loans rather than low-yielding government securities.
Because of the leading position Nationsbank will have in Virginia, North Carolina, South Carolina, Georgia and Tennessee, Mr. McColl said "we are going to be the damn elephant" and raise prices for loans and services. He said employee incentive programs had already been changed to encourage improving the profitability of each loan, with less emphasis on growth.
Quick sales of bad real estate loans, mostly in the Washington area, will be possible without big losses next year because Nationsbank will have already set aside reserves to cover losses, Mr. McColl said. He noted that land loans might sell at only 40 cents on the dollar, with most commercial real estate loans fetching between 60 and 67 cents.
While Nationsbank quickly disposes of its own bad loans, Mr. McColl foresees another 10 years of good business opportunities for the Asset Management Resolution Company, a NCNB subsidiary specializing in managing bad loans that the Federal Government acquired from failed banks and savings institutions.
Mr. McColl said Asset Management planned to increase its business from $17 billion in loans to more than $25 billion by winning more Federal contracts and by purchasing up to $4 billion of weak loans from Nationsbank. At that point, he said Asset Management could be earning $100 million annually and could operate independently.
A sale of Asset Management, either to outside investors or Nationsbank shareholders is desirable, Mr. McColl said "because it would eliminate the negative good will" incurred by a company whose business is to dun delinquent borrowers.

HEADLINE: I.B.M., Bull Reported In Talks

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Dec. 3

 BODY:
I.B.M. is negotiating with Bull, France's largest computer maker, about possible cooperation in advanced microprocessor technology, a French business newspaper reported today.
According to the newspaper, La Tribune de l'Expansion, the talks might lead to an agreement by the end of the year that would give Bull access to the International Business Machines Corporation's fast RISC microprocessor technology. 
 In a statement today, Bull said that no agreement had been reached with any company because discussions involving several options were still under consideration. Bull said that it had held discussions with several large companies in the last few months to explore cooperation in open systems.
 
Other U.S. Companies Mentioned
 The statement said Bull was talking to members of the Open Software Foundation, a group that promotes open systems and includes I.B.M., the Hewlett-Packard Company and the Digital Equipment Corporation. "Open systems" refers to computers and computer networks that allow various manufacturers' equipment to work interchangeably.
The newspaper article said Bull had held talks with Hewlett-Packard and Digital Equipment, but officials knowledgeable about the negotiations confirmed that the discussions were most advanced with I.B.M. and Hewlett-Packard.
An I.B.M. spokesman would not confirm that his company had negotiated with Bull. But he said I.B.M. often talked with computer manufacturers around the world to discuss many subjects, ranging from cooperation in specific areas to licensing its RISC -- reduced instruction set computer -- technology. I.B.M. has already agreed to share its highly praised RISC technology with Apple Computer and Motorola Inc.
I.B.M. now produces some disk drives for Bull.
 
A Japanese Presence
 Bull has suffered huge losses in recent months as European computer makers struggle to compete against their larger American and Japanese rivals. Bull already has a cooperation agreement with the NEC Corporation of Japan, which holds a 4.7 percent stake in Bull and supplies Bull's largest mainframes. The French Government owns 93 percent of Bull's shares.
Electronics analysts say the French Government, which is worried about Japan's increasing economic strength, might be happy to see an American company enter into a cooperation pact with Bull to counterbalance NEC.
These analysts said it was possible that an American partner might someday acquire a stake in Bull. The French Government recently announced that it would allow foreign companies that form strategic alliances with state-owned companies to buy into their equity.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Mixed in Slow Day As Gold Posts Broad Decline

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar settled mixed on world markets yesterday in slow trading.
Gold prices fell worldwide. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $363.50 an ounce, off $3.50 from Monday. The Republic National Bank of New York said gold had fallen $2.55 an ounce, to a late bid of $363.50. 
 The dollar held to a relatively narrow range and settled mostly higher in Europe, but when trading shifted to domestic markets, the currency mostly lost ground.
Analysts said the dollar received some support from the continuing political unrest in the Soviet Union. Dealers typically buy the dollar during times of world turmoil because it is perceived as a safe investment.
But the boost appeared short-lived. Speculation that German interest rates would rise held the dollar back. Investors seeking to capture higher returns on German investments would have to buy the mark, presumably at the expense of the dollar.
"Trading was caught between concerns over Soviet unrest and the possibility of a German rate hike," said Mike Malpede, a senior analyst with Refco Inc. in Chicago.
In Tokyo, the dollar fell 0.68 yen, to 129.30 yen. Later in London, it was quoted at 129.43 yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 129.30 yen, down from 130.15 yen on Monday.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.7715, from $1.7760 late on Monday. In New York, it cost $1.7755 to buy a pound, more than $1.7725 on Monday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with those of late Monday, included: 1.6080 German marks, down from 1.6150; 1.4230 Swiss francs, down from 1.4285; 5.4980 French francs, down from 5.5170; 1,213.80 Italian lire, down from 1,218.00, and 1.1342 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1336.
Gold fell in London to a late bid of $363.80 an ounce, from $368 late Monday. In Zurich, it fell to $363.35 an ounce from $368.20. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold fell $1.08 an ounce to close at $366.60.
Silver prices also declined. On the Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $4.006 an ounce, down from $4.050 on Monday. In London, it slipped to a late bid of $4.05 an ounce from $4.08.

HEADLINE: Bank Funds, C.D.'s Lower

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH M. FOWLER

 BODY:
Yields on certificates of deposit and bank money market accounts dropped steadily through the week, according to The Bank Rate Monitor, the publication that specializes in covering interest rates.
"Because of the certainty of even lower savings yields ahead, Citibank and other large institutions are positioning themselves by cutting passbook rates now," said Robert K. Heady, The Monitor's publisher. "Although that account is not so rate sensitive, it represents a significant percentage of total core deposits in the banking industry. 
 "Hence," he added, "these reductions are bellwethers of what is to come."
Mr. Heady noted that a large bank in Chicago had cut its passbook rate to 3.15 percent, from 4.34 percent, effective Dec. 19.
 
Banco Popular at 4.34%
 In the case of yields on money market accounts, the largest cut for the week among New York banks was made by Banco Popular, which lowered its rate by 26 basis points, to 4.34 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
"The speed of the decline continues unabated, despite the fact that it has been four weeks since the banks' prime rate last fell," Mr. Heady said. "That can be chalked up to a weakening economy."
He noted that the First Nationwide Bank made the biggest cuts in its yields among savings banks in the New York area on its three-month and six-month certificates of deposit -- 25 basis points and 45 basis points, respectively. The three-month C.D. now carries a rate of 4.25 percent, while the six-month carries 4.30 percent.
For the New York commercial banks, the average yield on money market accounts was 4.24 percent, down 5 basis points, while the average yield on three-month certificates were 4.30 percent, down 6 basis points. On six-month certificates, the average yield was 4.37 percent, down 7 basis points.
At savings institutions in the New York area, yields were cut to 4.92 percent, down 7 basis points, for money market accounts; to 4.93, down 9 basis points, for three-month certificates, and to 5.10 percent, down 10 basis points, for six-month certificates.
The Monitor said the average yields at 20 leading banks outside the New York area had been cut 4 basis points, to 4.55 percent, on money market accounts, and 5 basis points, to 4.69 percent, for six-month certificates.
By comparison, at the Treasury Department's weekly bill auction on Monday, the three-month bill was auctioned at an average discount rate of 4.39 percent, compared with 4.44 percent a week earlier; the six-month bill also averaged 4.39 percent, down from 4.50 percent the previous week.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Move to Longer Issues Lifts Prices

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities moved modestly higher in light trading yesterday, as the economy's poor performance and lackluster prospects began to lure traders and investors into longer-term notes and bonds.
For the last several weeks, credit market participants have largely ignored reports of how weak the economy has become, preferring instead to worry about what policy makers in Washington might do to reinvigorate it. But with Congress in recess until next year, the focus is shifting, analysts said. 
 The reports of a meager one-tenth of 1 percent rise in the index of leading economic indicators during October and a modest rise in new-home sales did little to excite traders yesterday.
"Rates are low, and I guess they are going to stay that way for a while unless we get a surprise from the numbers," one government-securities trader said.
 
Seeking Higher Yields
 Mitchell Held, chief financial economist at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, suggested that some of yesterday's buying was by investors seeking the higher yields of long-term issues.
"The spread between 10-year notes and 30-year bonds is more than 60 basis points, and that is attractive," Mr. Held said. Moreover, he added, "the economy is weak, and bond yields of around 7.9 probably don't reflect that weakness."
The gap between yields on five-year maturities and 10-year notes is also extremely wide, and yesterday investors began to commit funds into long-term notes.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 7.5 percent 10-year notes were offered at a price of 101 5/8, up 7/32, to yield 7.26 percent.
Meanwhile, the Treasury's benchmark issue, the 8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021, were offered at 101 5/32 late yesterday, up 1/32, to yield 7.89 percent, compared with 7.90 percent late Monday.
Normally, the yield spread between 10-year notes and 30-year bonds is closer to between 25 and 30 basis points, Mr. Held said.
 
5-Year Note Rises
 Elsewhere in the secondary market for Treasury notes, the 6.5 percent five-year notes were offered at 100 17/32, up 5/32, to yield 6.37 percent. And the 5.5 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 14/32, up 3/ 32, to yield 5.26 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates moved lower. In late trading, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 4.34 percent, down three basis points, or three one-hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates fell four basis points, to a late offered rate of 4.33 percent.
Participants in the tax-exempt municipal bond market had an exceptionally busy day, as roughly $1.4 billion worth of new issues were priced.
The largest deal was the negotiated sale of $300 million worth of securities for the New York Power Authority. The issue consisted of revenue bonds maturing in 2019, serial bonds with maturities from 1992 to 2007 and term bonds maturing in 2012 and 2020.
The securities were initially priced with a maximum yield of 6.803 percent on the bonds maturing in 2019.
A group led by the First Boston Corporation acted as lead managers for the underwriting. The securities are rated AA by both Moody's Investors Service and by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
 
Corporate Issues Priced
 A number of new debt issues were also priced in the investment-grade corporate bond market, including $150 million worth of seven-year notes for the Morgan Stanley Group.
The 7 7/8 percent notes were priced at $99.92 to yield 7.89 percent, 1.05 percentage points more than the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7 1/8 percent seven-year notes at the time of pricing.
Morgan Stanley acted as lead manager on the transaction. The securities are rated A-1 by Moody's and A+ by Standard & Poor's.
Salomon Brothers acted as lead manager on a $150 million offering of 10-year subordinated notes for Fleet/ Norstar Financial Group.
The 9 percent notes were priced at $100, or par, 1.68 percentage points more than the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7.5 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing.
The securities, which are noncallable for life, are rated Baa-3 by Moody's and BBB by Standard & Poor's.
