HEADLINE: Intractable Trade Issues With Japan

SERIES: 50 Years Later -- The Sticky Differences: Second of three articles

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Dec. 3

 BODY:
For nearly a decade, Japan and the United States have labored to bridge their economic differences through a series of unusually intense trade negotiations. Despite occasional bitterness on both sides, they shared a belief that only a few barriers stood in the way of an even deeper economic alliance from which the whole world would benefit.
Now, however, there is a growing belief that some of those differences may be irreconcilable. For the first time since these former enemies bound their destinies together after World War II, there is a sense that the world's two largest economies are drifting apart. 
 "The process has simply not gone as well as we had hoped," said J. Michael Farren, Under Secretary of Commerce for International Trade. "It will not get us where we want to go. We'll make incremental progress, but it's not going to put us in the position where the trade frictions are eliminated."
Ironically, many Government officials, business leaders and trade experts say that it was the effort to come closer together that accentuated the fundamentally different approaches to economic policy, bringing the two nations to this point of departure.
The American economy is managed to benefit the consumer, who is given access to cheap imports and protected from overly great concentrations of corporate power. The Japanese model, on the other hand, is run to maximize the strength of producers, which means its consumers pay some of the highest prices in the world and exercise the least control over corporate behavior.
It is not just a clash of cultures but a clash of economic strategies, a competition of ideas. American officials argue that because of this orientation the Japanese economy remains frustratingly closed, in spite of the easing of barriers to some markets, like beef, citrus, semiconductors and wood products.
"It's hard to show that any of these individual breakthroughs have altered the fundamental system," said David C. Mulford, Under Secretary of the Treasury for International Af fairs. "Every time we think we've made some progress, we keep finding ourselves back at the structural issues."
Nobody is seriously predicting an outright break in this powerful Pacific alliance and trade is expected to grow. But there are suggestions that each will play less of a role in the other's future.
The Japanese will place more of their emphasis on investment in Asia, leaving less capital to finance United States budget deficits or to buy up American companies or open new factories. Japanese electronic goods and automobiles will not disappear from American shelves or showrooms, but increasingly they will come from factories in Asia, rather than in Japan or the United States. That will mean less job creation in Ohio or Tennessee, as the Japanese start up fewer new ventures in the United States.
Of course, none of this will happen overnight. It will take many years to redirect even a portion of what is now a substantial interdependence. The United States and Japan together account for about 40 percent of the world economy, and much of the business they do is with each other. About $140 billion worth of goods will flow between Japan and the United States this year, as well as billions of dollars in investments. Canada remains America's largest trading partner, but Japan and the United States are each other's largest overseas trading partners.
Nor will the two sides give up entirely on trying to facilitate the trade that does continue. But trade negotiations may face some chages.
Some key Government officials also say that the unending marathon of trade confrontations, which has involved meetings almost monthly for several years running, has created a sense of "burnout."
"Frankly, some of the talks on opening specific sectors have borne fruit," Mr. Farren said. "They have also persuaded us that the problems are much more fundamental than trade impediments."
 
Trying to Ease Off One-on-One Focus
 Mr. Farren said there was some interest in both Washington and Tokyo to try to ease away from the head-to-head focus and turn to international bodies to resolve some disputes. This approach was resisted for decades because of the special postwar security relationship between the two countries. The United States did not want to apply too much pressure on Japan or isolate it in opposition to both the United States and Europe because of its role as an ally in the battle against Communism in Asia.
There is also concern that the bargaining process may be taken out of the hands of the trade negotiators and enter the political arena. Some members of Congress are threatening to raise barriers against the import of some Japanese goods as a form of retaliation. This prospect is considered even more likely if the large American deficit in autos and auto parts worsens further.
And there are concerns here that the formation of the North American free-trade zone by the United States, Canada and Mexico may redirect America's trade strategy toward the Americas rather than Asia.
Japanese officials still try to put the best face on the situation. They generally emphasize the progress that has been made and say the trade negotiations have been necessary to open their economy.
But they, too, admit to nagging frustrations over the failure of the United States to live up to some of the promises it made at the negotiating table. These include the reduction of the yawning Federal budget deficit and an increase in America's modest savings and investment rates. The Japanese also criticize what they say is an American tendency to blame others for these problems.
Many Japanese officials have also grown more open in describing the American economic system as a relic of the cold war, while saying Japan's system is better suited to the competitive era that lies ahead.
"The Japanese way of doing things seems to fit this stage of history better," said Koji Watanabe, Deputy Foreign Minister for Economic Affairs. "The Japanese system puts emphasis on stability and teamwork and has distinct advantages. It fits the requirements of the times, particularly at this stage of technological development."
Many here are questioning not just America's commitment to Japan, but to Asia, as diminishing financial resources leave Washington less able to sustain its military dominance of both the Atlantic and the Pacific. Although American leaders from President Bush down have expressed an unwavering interest in Asia and Japan, some say there is unmistakable evidence -- such as the shrinking military presence of the United States in Asia and the downturn in Japan's economic investment in the United States -- that the links are loosening.
"There's no doubt we are drifting apart," said Glen Fukushima, a former American trade official who is an executive in Japan for A.T.&T. "But it is being papered over by the rhetoric."
 
Japan Steps Up Trade With Asia
 Indeed, Japan is contributing to the sense of drift by increasing its economic focus on Asia and methodically lessening its dependence on the American market. This year, for the first time in the postwar era, Japan will conduct significantly more trade with its Asian neighbors than with the United States. And that trend is believed certain to continue.
Yotaro Kobayashi, president of Fuji Xerox, a venture half-controlled by the American office-equipment concern, is an articulate business leader who at one time advocated the primacy of the Japan-United States relationship. He holds degrees from American and Japanese universities and sits on several high-level commissions promoting the relationship. But he is speaking out now for what he calls the "re-Asianization" of Japan.
"There has been a feeling that our trade may have been too skewed toward the bilateral relationship," Mr. Kobayashi commented. "The point is not to disassociate Japan from the United States, but to point out that it is natural for us to strengthen our ties with Asian countries."
He added: "Americans' domestic situation is so bad that this may make them feel uneasy, that Asia is drifting away. The difficulty will be in carefully handling that situation to stop the United States from becoming defensive."
There are other signs, too, of a slow disengagement. Despite high-profile investments like the purchase of MCA and the Pebble Beach golf course in recent years, Japan's direct investment in the United States -- which includes real estate, joint ventures and factories rather than just portfolio investments in securities -- has plummeted. It will have invested barely $2 billion in the weak American economy this year, down from $26 billion last year.
Over all, from 1985 to 1989, Japan invested a staggering $235 billion in the United States. But since then it has actually withdrawn slightly more than $50 billion if all kinds of investments are included. Where Japanese bidders once snapped up 40 percent and more of the bonds auctioned by the Treasury, it now buys 10 percent or less.
The basic rules of the United States-Japan relationship were established in response to the cold war. The United States agreed to defend Japan and the Japanese agreed to support and follow America's lead on political and security issues. The United States also granted Japan free access to the American market and permitted the Japanese to protect their home industries to insure their recovery, making the country a bulwark against Communism.
The lack of balance in that bargain became strikingly evident in the last decade, as the flow of trade and investment soared. While Japanese corporations snapped up everything from Columbia Pictures to a significant interest in Rockefeller Center, foreigners found it almost impossible to invest in Japan, either because companies were too deeply entwined in keiretsu -- interlocking corporate groupings -- or because prices in Japan's overheated markets were prohibitive.
From 1985 through 1990, Japan made direct investments abroad of $239.4 billion, of which $110 billion went to the United States; during the same period just $5.3 billion of direct investment entered Japan from all sources. In those same years, Japan sold $403 billion more worth of goods to its trading partners than it bought from them.
"The Japanese have built a structure that is completely different from ours," said Arnold Brenner, an executive vice president in charge of the Japan operations of Motorola, an electronics manufacturer that is regarded as one of the more successful American companies in Japan. "For an American company it is always going to be especially tough to break in. It has nothing to do with the government. It has to do with a structure and a philosophy."
Mr. Brenner is one of many who has thus concluded that the intensive trade negotiation process has not eliminated the economic differences.
"Are we getting closer? I'd have to say that on the broad, structural issues neither country feels closer than we did 5 or 10 years ago," he said.
Compounding the concern is the steep rise in Japan's trade surplus again this year. Japan's overall surplus is expected to hit $70 billion or more this year and perhaps $100 billion next year, compared with $52 billion in 1990. Japan's surplus with the United States is expected to rise above the current level of $40 billion when the American recession ends.
 
Search for Solutions: First Steps in 1978
 The first steps toward the experiment in managing trade problems came in 1978, when the United States insisted that Japan's protectionist economy be opened. The United States prodded Japan to raise its stingy level of imports.
The efforts intensified in 1981, when President Ronald Reagan abandoned his free-market rhetoric and persuaded Japan to accept voluntary restraints on its auto exports to America. Japan then acceded to American demands in 1983 that it loosen quotas on the import of beef and citrus fruits.
Another key phase in the efforts to redress the trade problems began in September 1985 with what was called the Plaza Accord. At a meeting at the Plaza Hotel in New York, the United States, Japan and five other leading industrialized countries agreed to devalue the dollar against the yen and other currencies to tame America's widening trade deficit. The weaker dollar made it cheaper for foreigners to purchase American goods, increasing exports, while crimping imports by making them more expensive.
In addition, American negotiators attacked an array of trade barriers in Japan, involving everything from supercomputers to cigarettes to the construction market.
The weaker dollar reduced America's once-large trade deficit with the European Community; this year, in fact, it is expected to become a surplus. But the deficit with Japan remains high, at more than $40 billion.
That means that Japan now accounts for about two-thirds of America's overall trade deficit, and $30 billion, or three-fourths of the deficit with Japan, is accounted for by autos and auto parts, which is regarded as a politically dangerous problem.
Something else happened during these critical years. Faced with a much stronger yen, Japanese corporations embarked on a crash program to enhance their efficiency. They poured tens of billions of dollars into new technologies and research, far outspending their American counterparts. They turned the country's greatest postwar economic boom into a period of restructuring that has left Japan more competitive than ever.
During those same years, the United States Federal budget deficit soared to new highs. Its personal savings rate never rose above 7.5 percent, compared with more than 14 percent in Japan. American investment bankers grew rich from a flurry of takeovers and buyouts, but many industrial concerns found themselves overwhelmed with debt as a result.
"We had always assumed that in the process of adjusting you would be moving more or less in the same direction," Mr. Watanabe, the Deputy Foreign Minister, said. "But our efforts have not been matched yet."
The United States has also found itself unprepared for the new assertiveness on Japan's part. Tadao Chino, Deputy Finance Minister for International Affairs, counts himself an optimist on the future of the relationship, but he said it was time for the United States to listen to Japan for a change.
"Now we expect the United States will be more active in cooperating with us in this region," Mr. Chino said. "After all, the United States and Japan are global partners."
In the United States, meanwhile, the answer for many Government officials and businessmen is to expect less of Japan and more from the United States. Few want to halt the trade-negotiating sessions, since they have achieved some successes. But neither do they want to rest all of their hopes for trade balance on changes in Japan, as they once did.
Perhaps the most sobering realization is how wide the gap of understanding remains.
"Frankly, we don't know each other so well," said Makoto Utsumi, who retired this summer as the Finance Ministry's top trade official. "The problem comes from the fact that Japanese believe they know the United States and Americans think they know Japan, but the facts suggest otherwise."
NEXT: Japan is pouring billions of dollars and enormous energy into Asia.

HEADLINE: United Expects Record Loss

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Dec. 3

 BODY:
United Airlines said today that it expected to post record losses for the fourth quarter and the year because of the weak economy and discount pricing in the airline industry.
United also said American Airlines had dropped its bid to block a Dec. 30 vote by Air Wisconsin shareholders on United's $70 million acquisition of the commuter airline. 
 A Federal judge set a trial date of Feb. 10, though, for American's antitrust lawsuit challenging the deal.
Last month, Air Wisconsin rejected American's offer to buy 50 landing slots at Chicago's O'Hare International Airport for $100 million.
United's parent company, the Chicago-based UAL Corporation, will record a fourth-quarter net loss steeper than its record $123.5 million loss in the fourth quarter of 1990, said a spokeswoman, Lynn Martenstein.
Together with the cumulative loss of $79.3 million already posted for the first nine months of 1991, the fourth-quarter results would bring UAL's loss for the year to more than $202.8 million. The airline's previous record annual loss was $112.8 million in 1986, Ms. Martenstein said.
United reported a 5.3 percent increase in passenger traffic in November over the period a year earlier, but said it filled only 61 percent of its seats in the month compared with 61.4 percent last year.

HEADLINE: Into a Statistical Exile: the G.N.P.

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3

 BODY:
At a time when no morsel of fresh information on the economy seems too exotic to be gobbled up by political interpreters, the Commerce Department is about to provide a feast.
On Wednesday the Government will begin emphasizing the gross domestic product instead of the gross national product as its most widely followed measure of the economy's performance. 
 Perhaps to insure indigestion, the shift will include a comprehensive revision of the most fundamental data -- the national income and production accounts -- combined with updated statistics and definitional changes. One effect of these changes will be to make the recession appear sharper but perhaps shorter than had been thought.
All this "should be unusually messy," Fuji Securities Inc. of Chicago warned clients recently.
G.N.P. data have been published since 1941 and will continue to be reported, but typically a month later than G.D.P. The two measures gauge the total output of goods and services. The difference for the United States is relatively small, with G.N.P. covering production by American residents, regardless of location, while G.D.P. covers workers and capital employed within the nation's borders.
Economists generally support the change, agreeing with the Commerce Department that G.D.P. better reflects the economy's performance. The switch also aligns the United States with practices in most other industrialized countries, making comparisons easier. Canada adopted G.D.P. as its primary production measure in 1986.
No matter what the figures, of course, an assortment of voices will be heard declaring that the data prove things are better or worse than widely supposed or that they are inadequate or possibly "cooked."
At a briefing, Commerce Department officials declined to speculate on what political hay Democrats, say, might try to make from the new figures. They rejected any suggestion that the process itself might have been tainted by the Bush Administration or anyone else.
"The bureau makes its estimates independently of the policy makers," said Larry Moran, spokesman for the Bureau of Economic Analysis, part of the Commerce Department. "To my knowledge, there's never been any tampering."
There have, however, been occasions -- apparently rare and unsuccessful -- when politicians have tried to persuade the statisticians to combine the figures in a particular way to support a given point of view.
Some Democrats might ask about the timing of the change. Among other things, G.D.P., unlike G.N.P., is not reduced by the increasing amounts of interest foreigners collect on Treasury securities.
The department has already provided some grist for argument, publishing to little notice its calculations of what happens when the base period used to adjust economic-output figures for inflation is advanced to 1987 from 1982. In general, when output is recalculated using more recent prices, the components that have grown strongly receive less weight and total output is therefore reduced. Production of computers, for example, has risen in recent years, but because prices have fallen, their contribution to total output would be lower using 1987 instead of 1982 as a base.
On a 1987 basis, both G.D.P. and G.N.P. showed that the economy slumped more sharply in the fall of 1990 and improved more in the spring of this year than the use of 1982 prices would indicate. For G.N.P., the shift to 1987 prices converts a rate of decline of five-tenths of 1 percent in the second quarter of this year into an advance of four-tenths of 1 percent. For G.D.P., a gain of three-tenths of 1 percent for the period becomes a rise of 1.2 percent.
 
One Negative Effect
 Comparing G.N.P. on the old 1982 basis with G.D.P. on the 1987 basis, the deterioration during the fourth quarter of 1990 is even more pronounced -- a negative 3.7 percent rate instead of a negative 1.6 percent -- and the rebound comparably sharper.
Among other changes, losses from bad debts, formerly considered expenses to the lenders and income to the defaulters, will be designated as financial transactions, increasing the income of lenders and reducing the incomes of defaulters for statistical purposes.
Wednesday's flood of statistics will also include the monthly revision to quarterly output, which for the third quarter was initially reported up 2.4 percent on G.N.P. and 2.5 percent on G.D.P., though slightly less in terms of 1987 dollars. The revised gain is expected to be significantly higher.
But the new approach is unlikely to have a large enough effect "to change anybody's view about what's going on now," said Robert Ford, chief economist for the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.

HEADLINE: October New-Home Sales Up 2.2% in Year's 7th Gain

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3

 BODY:
Consumers edged back into the housing market in October, pushing new-home sales up 2.2 percent for the seventh gain since the housing recession hit bottom in January, the Government reported today.
While analysts found the report encouraging, they worried that sales could turn negative in coming months, as they did in July and September, unless the economy took a turn for the better. 
 The report said sales were mixed, rising in the Midwest and South but falling in the Northeast and West.
Mark Tipton, president of the National Association of Home Builders, said the nation "needs an economic stimulus package, and we need it now" to overcome dwindling consumer confidence.
Mr. Tipton said it was the same message that he and other real estate officials took to the White House on Monday when they met with President Bush.
The Commerce and Housing and Urban Development Departments said today that sales of single-family homes totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 513,000 in October, up from 502,000 a month earlier.
The report also showed that September sales, which had first been estimated to have plunged 12.9 percent, actually fell only 4.9 percent.
"However, the housing market, as well as the overall economy, still has not regained the momentum seen after the conclusion of the Persian Gulf war," said John A. Tuccillo, an economist with the National Association of Realtors, who also called on the Government "to stimulate our ailing economy."
Analysts attributed the October gain and the upward September revision both to lower mortgage interest rates and to lower prices.
The interest rate on the average 30-year fixed-rate mortgage slipped below 9 percent in October for the first time in more than 13 years, the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation said.
At the same time, the home-sales report said the median price of a new home fell from $123,600 in September to $122,900 in October. The median means half of the homes cost more and half less.
The lower rates also played a part in a 1 percent advance in sales of existing homes in October. The increase, the first in four months, was reported earlier.
Thomas Holloway, an economist with the Mortgage Bankers Association, also noted that inventories declined in October, providing builders with an incentive to build houses and further stimulate the economy.
Regionally, the Midwest posted the largest gain, an 8.1 percent increase, to a rate of 107,000 units. Sales in the South were up 6 percent, to 213,000.
But sales plunged 5.9 percent, to 127,000, in the West, and they slipped 1.5 percent, to 66,000, in the Northeast.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Radio Waves Can Be Solid Gold

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
WANT to earn big money in your spare time? You might take a flier on a sure-fire cold fusion stock recommended by that nice young broker on the telephone from Fort Lauderdale. Or you could really strike it rich by doing what hundreds of lucky millionaires have done: enter one of Washington's bizarre lotteries for licenses to use the airwaves.
For years, economists have gnashed their teeth over the policy of giving away stunningly valuable rights to use the radio spectrum. And for years, those who already control commercial licenses have successfully defended their sinecures by fending off attempts to end the giveaway. 
 But the stalemate is apparently on the verge of being broken. Thanks to the persistence of the revenue-hungry Bush Administration and a growing realization among Congressional Democrats that assignment by any other means has become an administrative nightmare, there's an excellent chance Uncle Sam will auction off some new licenses. The public payoff, estimates Peter Pitsch, a former Federal Communications Commission staff member who is a communications consultant in Washington, could amount to "billions and billions."
Room on the spectrum, needed for everything from broadcasting television to paging the dishwasher repairman, has generally been parceled out to the applicants who can show how they are uniquely qualified to revitalize the economy or brighten the dreary lives of their fellow Americans. But once assigned, licenses effectively became private property, to be freely sold to anyone without a felony conviction.
That makes the award equivalent to a visit from John Beresford Tipton. And as the value of the licenses has grown, so has the legion of lawyers employed to argue over their initial disposition. Polite elbowing for the juicier slices of the spectrum in the 1960's and 70's turned to outright frenzy in the 80's, once the commission started dispensing licenses for cellular phone systems in big cities, worth hundreds of millions of dollars each. In an attempt to cut through the time-consuming sham of searching for the most qualified licensees, the commission decided in the late 1980's to distribute licenses by lottery.
But the lotteries have not reduced the agency's workload. Consultants armed with laser printers and faxes now stand poised to fire off lottery entries at the first glimpse of license green. Earlier this year, a lottery for relatively low-value spectrum to be used for data transfer services drew 60,000 applications in just two days.
Nor have the lotteries satisfied critics like the former F.C.C. chairman, Mark Fowler, who asks why the Government gives away the spectrum when it sells rights to extract oil, harvest timber and graze cattle on public land. The Commerce Department estimates that the total market value of cellular phone licenses alone exceeds $50 billion. It is, in fact, the lure of this revenue that is changing the politics of spectrum policy. The Bush Administration is eager for any new source of cash that does not begin with the letter T. And it has refused to go along with a Congressional initiative to transfer a fat slab of underused spectrum from government to civilian use unless the licenses are sold to the highest bidder.
A year ago Congress would almost certainly have defended license applicants' rights to something for nothing. But a combination of disgust with the lottery follies and pressure to make room for new mobile communications technologies has weakened the opposition. "There's open-mindedness on the part of Democrats," reports Janice Obuchowski, the Assistant Secretary of Commerce in charge of telecommunications policy.
In the Senate, an auction bill is expected to breeze through next session, after broadcasters and perhaps rural telephone companies have carved exemptions in stone. It will have a tougher time in the House, where John D. Dingell, the Michigan Democrat who is the powerful chairman of the Commerce Committee and a longstanding skeptic on auctions, is sure to demand his pound of flesh. But aides to Mr. Dingell say that he will try to square the auction idea with sound public policy, not kill it altogether.
Mr. Dingell will, for example, seek to prevent the Government from enriching the Treasury at the expense of consumers who must buy services from license holders. Such ploys are not unthinkable: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, sometime champion of free markets, worked to shore up British Airways' privileged landing rights and routes before selling the airline on the stock market.
Even with Congressionally mandated restrictions, the pot of gold at the end of the auction rainbow could be enormous. A dazzling array of new technologies, ranging from low-cost pocket phones to compact-disk quality digital radio to satellite-based worldwide communications systems, lack only room on the spectrum to become a commercial reality. And this time around, Uncle Sam could share in the bounty.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Maxwell Empire Is Near Collapse As Son Discloses Far Higher Debts

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Dec. 3

 BODY:
The publishing empire of the late Robert Maxwell seemed on the brink of collapse today as one of his sons disclosed that the debts of its private family-owned businesses were far greater than previously estimated, raising the prospect that the family would lose control of its vast holdings.
The Maxwell family's holdings are clustered into three spheres, two of which are publicly traded companies that the Maxwells control. The third company is a collection of private companies and trusts controlled by the Maxwell family, and it owns, among other things, The Daily News in New York. 
 The future of The Daily News is now in the hands of bankers who might sell it or conceivably even close it. Kevin Maxwell, the 32-year-old son of Mr. Maxwell, will remain publisher of The News. He said that he would fly tonight to New York and that the Maxwell family's widening financial crisis would not immediately affect the newspaper's operations. [Page D6.]
The Maxwell family's private companies are in such dire straits that apparently without the bankers' knowledge, loans from the publicly held companies had been used to prop them up. One of the public companies, Mirror Group Newspapers P.L.C., disclosed tonight that an investigation had found that a significant amount of the assets of its pension fund had been used to shore up the family's private businesses.
Only last week, the Maxwell family said that the debt of its private companies totaled about 800 million ($1.42 billion) and that it was trying to negotiate a restructuring of the debt. But today, Kevin Maxwell said it was "in excess of 900 million." And an adviser to the Maxwells said it was "several hundred million pounds more."
Citing potential conflicts between the private and public sides of the family's businesses, Kevin Maxwell announced at a news conference here that he had resigned as chairman and chief executive of the Maxwell Communication Corporation, the publicly held but family-dominated corporate flagship. It owns a host of companies, mostly in the United States, including Macmillan Inc., the big New York publishing house. He also resigned as a board member of Mirror Group, one of Britain's largest newspaper companies.
His brother, Ian, 35, resigned as Mirror's chairman and as a member of Maxwell Communication's board.
Three executives who have been associated with the Maxwell holdings for several years will replace the Maxwell brothers.
Kevin Maxwell met with bankers this morning. Bankers said later that they had been shocked to learn of the intercompany loans. Auditors are continuing to investigate the loans, Mr. Maxwell said. Until the investigation is completed, it will not be known to what extent the loans, which apparently occurred under Robert Maxwell, were flatly illegal or merely of questionable propriety. Mirror said the use of the pension fund was "apparently without due authority."
When asked whether his father had kept his brother and him in the dark in general, he responded, "Clearly we didn't know everything," and added that Mr. Maxwell had informed them on a "need-to-know" basis "as opposed to sharing information all the time."
 
Fuel for Speculation
 The latest revelations will undoubtedly fuel more speculation that there might have been a connection between the precarious health of the Maxwell empire and the mysterious death of Mr. Maxwell on Nov. 5. His naked body was found floating off the Canary Islands after he was discovered missing from his yacht. Spanish authorities have not released the final autopsy report.
When asked whether the family still hoped to be able to retain control of the two public companies, Kevin Maxwell said it was now out of the family's hands. "I don't think it's a question of do I hope I can maintain this, do I hope I can maintain that," he said. The family has made proposals to the banks, he continued, "which we think are commercial and rational, and it will be up to the banks to decide."
He added that there are no sacred cows, including The Daily News, which the family had previously insisted that it wanted to protect.
 
Doubt on Keeping Control
 In an interview, one of the Maxwell family's advisers said the latest developments made it highly unlikely that the family would be able to retain control of the public companies.
But it is the loans to the private companies, several of which lack adequate collateral, that are the most immediate threat to the publishing empire. The banks have informally agreed to take no action until Friday, said Derrick Plummer, director of credit control at National Westminster Bank, which is heading a steering committee of banks with loans to the private companies.
At that meeting, bankers will probably decide whether the family's debt crisis can be defused by selling some major operations. If they decide it cannot, they may force the private holdings into bankruptcy proceedings in Britain.
 
Chain Reaction Possible
 But there is likely to be a chain reaction if the private companies are forced into bankruptcy. The public companies would probably have to follow because finances are intertwined and because the private companies own the family's controlling stakes in Maxwell Communication and Mirror Group -- about 68 percent and 51 percent, respectively. Much of those stakes has been pledged as collateral for the loans of the private companies. But bankers are concerned because the 71 percent plunge in the price of Maxwell Communication stock since Mr. Maxwell's death is a main reason that the collateral of some loans is now inadequate.
Mirror and Maxwell Communication requested on Monday that trading in their shares on the London International Stock Exchange be suspended indefinitely, "pending clarification of the financial position of the Maxwell family companies and its effect on them." When suspended, Maxwell's share price was 35 pence (62 cents) and Mirror's was 1.25 ($2.22).
Mr. Plummer, the National Westminster banker, indicated that the banks' agreement not to take action against the Maxwells, which was reached on Nov. 25, was fragile. "A de facto banking standstill remains in place, but this is a very complex situation," he said in a statement.
In interviews, some other bankers were pessimistic today that the bankruptcy could be avoided. They noted that they still did not have reliable financial figures.
"The question is, do the figures stack up at all?" said one banker who insisted on anonymity. "If they don't, then management has no option but to put the thing into administration."
Analysts and some bankers predicted that in the end the family would be forced to sell most or all of its stake in Mirror Group, the public company the Maxwells are believed to want to keep the most. Until the problem with the Mirror pension fund was revealed tonight, Mirror appeared to be relatively healthy financially, with a relatively low debt level.
If a buyer did not have to worry about the pension fund, Mirror Group might sell for anywhere from 721 million ($1.28 billion) to 1.2 billion ($2.1 billion), analysts said.
On the other hand, Maxwell Communication is heavily indebted. Analysts estimated that its net debt -- debts minus cash on hand -- totaled about 1.2 billion ($2.13 billion). This figure includes the proceeds from the sales of some businesses that are in the process of being sold. If it were sold piecemeal, it might fetch about 200 million ($354.4 million) more than its net debt, said Valerie Conner, an analyst at Henderson Crosthwaite Institutional Brokers Ltd.
 
Maxwell's Dizzying Pace
 Robert Maxwell had shifted businesses around his various public and private companies at such a dizzying pace that even his executives had trouble keeping track of which entity owned what. Even so, analysts were shocked today to learn of the financial dealings between the public and private companies under Mr. Maxwell.
"That was the one thing that nobody really knew about -- the extent to which they were wrapped up together," said Derek Terrington, an analyst at Kleinwort Benson Securities Ltd. "You always suspected they were linked but never knew it had reached these levels."
The Government's Serious Fraud Office said previously that it was investigating a charge that one of the Maxwell family's private companies had failed to provide the promised collateral to the Swiss Bank Corporation for a loan of 55 million ($97.5 million).
Interviewed before the Mirror disclosure on its pension fund, a spokeswoman for the Serious Fraud Office said today that the invesigation was "carrying on and hasn't widened." But she added that it could do so if auditors discovered that there had been an illegal transfer of money within the Maxwell empire. "All should become clearer later in the week," she said.
Peter Laister, who has been Maxwell Communication's deputy chairman and who had once been managing director of Thorn EMI P.L.C., the British entertainment and lighting company, succeeded Kevin Maxwell as chairman. David Shaffer, who was made the company's chief operating officer last month, was named to the additional post of managing director, which is the British equivalent of chief executive. He will continue to serve as president of Macmillan.
Ernest Burrington, who had been managing director and deputy chairman of Mirror, was named its new chairman.

PUB-DATE: December 4, 1991

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; National Desk

LENGTH: 1415 words

HEADLINE: SUNUNU RESIGNS UNDER FIRE AS CHIEF AIDE TO PRESIDENT; CITES FEAR OF HURTING BUSH

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3

 BODY:
John H. Sununu resigned today as the White House chief of staff, telling President Bush that he feared he would be "a drag" on the President's re-election campaign after months of bruising political attacks in which he had become the symbol of the increasing disarray in Mr. Bush's domestic policy team.
Mr. Sununu and the White House portrayed the departure as voluntary. But it followed meetings in which Mr. Bush listened to Mr. Sununu's arguments that he should stay on and then decided to follow the advice of top-level Republicans who urged the removal of his chief of staff.
 
Cheney a Possible Candidate
 Speculation about a successor to Mr. Sununu centered this evening on Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner, a longtime political aide to Mr. Bush who is known to want the job and has proved a popular newcomer among Washington Republicans. Some White House officials and a top Republican strategist said Mr. Skinner was Mr. Bush's choice. 
 Another possible candidate is Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, who was chief of staff under President Gerald R. Ford and is widely respected in the Republican Party and on Capitol Hill.
The removal of Mr. Sununu seemed designed to give the President a chance to dispel the aura of confusion and hesitation that has hurt his Administration in recent months. He left Mr. Sununu with a consolation prize that seemed modest in light of speculation that the chief of staff would be given a major Cabinet department to placate him and conservative Republicans who are loyal to him.
 
Letter of Tribute
 The President said he was naming Mr. Sununu a counselor to the President with Cabinet rank from the effective date of his resignation, Dec. 15, through March 1. He paid tribute to Mr. Sununu's loyalty in a letter that said he "played a major role in achieving some of our significant goals" and would continue to seek his counsel on major issues.
Mr. Sununu's resignation, which makes it simpler for Mr. Bush to name his 1992 re-election team, came after two meetings in the White House between the chief of staff and Mr. Bush.
Mr. Bush had made it clear to Mr. Sununu in the two meetings, on Sunday afternoon and again on Monday, that his position was becoming increasingly untenable and, in effect, invited the resignation, White House advisers said.
Mr. Sununu informed Mr. Bush at the Monday meeting that he intended to step down and handed in him his letter of resignation this morning as Mr. Bush flew from Washington to Florida, the White House said.
Mr. Sununu told reporters today in Mississippi, the second stop on a one-day trip, that "the President was kind enough to let me make the decision."
He continued: "I knew the rules of the game when I came to town. He's going into a campaign. He doesn't need the extra political target that folks would be shooting at."
The meetings with Mr. Bush came after shoving from lesser figures had failed to dislodge Mr. Sununu and, indeed, prompted him to appeal to conservatives on Capitol Hill to lobby the White House to keep him.
The President's son, George W. Bush, told Mr. Sununu last week that he no longer had any political support, a message that a senior Republican today called "a hint so broad that it would be hard to miss."
Mr. Bush, who was traveling in Florida and Mississippi, accepted Mr. Sununu's resignation without a grand face-saving gesture. This seemed to reflect the consensus that Mr. Sununu was responsible for several embarrassing political missteps and flip-flops and had in the final days of his tenure tried to salvage his political fortunes by turning the heat on his boss.
 
No Clear Campaign Role
 Mr. Bush passed Mr. Sununu over for a departmental Cabinet position or an ambassadorship, posts for which he was considered virtually unconfirmable because of his sour relations with Congress.
Mr. Bush also declined to guarantee Mr. Sununu even a ceremonial role in the 1992 campaign team. This omission seemed to signal the President's wish to remove the chief of staff from his inner circle entirely at a time when Mr. Bush is increasingly eager to recover from a drop in his public approval ratings.
"Thank you from the bottom of my heart for your distinguished service," Mr. Bush wrote in his letter. "I look forward to working with you in the future."
Returning to the White House, Mr. Bush praised Mr. Sununu for making his departure "a class act."
Asked whether Mr. Sununu would work in Mr. Bush's 1992 campaign effort in New Hampshire, where he was Governor in the 1980's, the President replied: "You bet."
Mr. Sununu won his White House post in no small part because of his role in engineering Mr. Bush's comeback primary campaign in New Hampshire in 1988. Mr. Sununu tried to keep his tone upbeat, signing off his letter with the words, "It really has been great!!!"
But beneath that was a subtle defiance as Mr. Sununu blamed his problems on "distorted perceptions" and seemed to make one last attempt to shed the abrasive image he had acquired as a chief of staff supervising a Presidential legislative strategy that relies primarily on partisan dueling and vetoes of bills passed by the Democratic-controlled Congress.
In doing so, Mr. Sununu, as he has done before, seemed to be trying to shift responsibility away from himself and toward Mr. Bush.
The circumstances of Mr. Sununu's resignation, which had been the subject of heated speculation for days in Washington, were as extraordinary as the public spectacle of his prolonged political death throes.
It was not clear why Mr. Bush did not name a new chief of staff today. It was also not clear whether Mr. Cheney would accept the post, if asked.
Mr. Sununu leaves a post that always has been shaped more by its occupants than by any job description, but is among the most powerful positions in Government. He was Mr. Bush's gatekeeper, controlling access to the Oval Office and reviewing all paperwork reaching and leaving Mr. Bush's desk. Mr. Sununu sat in on most major policy discussions and has been the President's top adviser on many domestic policy and political matters.
 
Actions Aboard Plane
 Mr. Sununu gave Mr. Bush his four-and-half-page resignation letter, which was handwritten on White House stationery, and Mr. Bush wrote a reply as the two huddled in Mr. Bush's stateroom aboard Air Force One on the way from Andrews Air Force Base near Washington to Bradenton, Fla.
There, Mr. Bush went about a visit to the Tropicana orange juice plant without betraying any sign of the events aboard his plane, brushing off a question about Mr. Sununu with a brusque, "I'm here to learn about oranges."
As Air Force One flew from Bradenton to Meridian, Miss., Mr. Bush's letter was typed by a secretary. But he still said nothing as he toured the Peavey Electronics guitar factory.
A few seconds after the President's motorcade sped out of the plant gates, White House staff aides rushed into a makeshift newsroom at the plant and distributed copies of the two letters.
In his letter to Mr. Bush, Mr. Sununu said he wanted to thank Mr. Bush "for the fun we have had these last three years."
Mr. Sununu continued: "And I would never want to not be contributing positively, much less be a drag on your success."
Mr. Bush credited Mr. Sununu with a major role in passing the Clean Air Act, this year's civil rights measure, a law on Americans with disabilities and the budget agreement.
Mr. Sununu's political problems began shortly after he arrived in Washington. By the time he resigned, stories were rife about the fear with which he was treated by subordinates, who often accused him in private of meeting their suggestions with scorn.
The uproar over the 1990 budget deal, in which Mr. Sununu was seen by many Republican lawmakers as a malevolent influence, exacerbated Mr. Sununu's troubles. In the same fashion, he was badly wounded by disclosures of his extensive use of military aircraft for personal and political trips.
More recently, Mr. Sununu was blamed for the lack of direction in Mr. Bush's domestic policy staff, which was unable for months to present the President with a consensus about what he should do to spur the economy.
Then Mr. Sununu committed what many in Washington considered the unpardonable sin: he made his boss look foolish by saying that Mr. Bush had "ad-libbed" a remark about lowering credit card interest rates, when in fact the comments had been written into the President's speech.

The New York Times

 

PUB-DATE: December 4, 1991

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 4; National Desk

LENGTH: 1456 words

HEADLINE: 'Pit Bull' at the White House Falls Victim to His Own Role

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3

 BODY:
No one expected John Sununu to go gently. And he didn't.
As his final act, the man hired by George Bush to be his political hatchet man took a swipe at the boss. 
 In comments with a pointed subtext in his resignation letter, Mr. Sununu conveyed a sense of betrayal because, in many ways, he was doing exactly what Mr. Bush had hired him to do. The departing chief of staff was also obliquely reminding the President that this was not a matter of principle, but of ratings; his bullying tactics had been fine as long as opinion-poll ratings did not go down.
 
A Sardonic Offer of Help
 "I assure you that in pit bull mode or pussy cat mode (your choice, as always), I am ready to help," Mr. Sununu wrote.
His reference was sardonic. He had called himself "a pussy cat" and kept what looked like a plush cat on top of the bookcase in his large West Wing office. But, at close range, it was clear that the toy animal was really a tiger, and that is how Mr. Sununu saw himself.
As he stated his credo in his first month in Washington: "I don't care if people hate me, as long as they hate me for the right reasons."
When he boarded Air Force One in Meridian, Miss., on a Presidential trip today, after his resignation was made public, Mr. Sununu was asked by reporters if he would be involved in Mr. Bush's re-election campaign. He used the question to suggest that his services were critical in turning around the 1988 election for a boss who likes to keep his hands clean.
"Maybe I'll do to whoever runs what I did to Dukakis in 1988," Mr. Sununu said, in a sharp reference to his no-holds-barred effort in the general-election campaign to destroy Michael S. Dukakis's reputation as a competent Governor of Massachusetts.
Mr. Bush and Mr. Sununu formed a close bond in the snows of New Hampshire, when Mr. Bush saw his dream to be President melting away after a humiliating showing in Iowa.
"Whatever they did in Iowa, they will not reject George Bush in New Hampshire," Mr. Sununu vowed, as he dragged Mr. Bush down from his elite perch to start what he called a "see me, touch me, feel me" campaign. He encouraged Mr. Bush to ride a snow plow and wander around Nashua, shaking hands and offering to help skeptical motorists dig out their cars.
On the surface, they seemed an odd couple -- one tall, slim and patrician, the other short, pudgy and middle class; one well-groomed, the other often slightly disheveled, with his shirttail hanging out; one polite and conciliatory, the other rude and contentious.
But on matters of politics, George Bush and John Sununu were not so oddly matched. Mr. Sununu embodied the barbed-wire side of Mr. Bush's politics; in many critical ways, he was an accurate reflection of the way Mr. Bush believed that things should work.
In the 1988 campaign, Mr. Bush conceded in interviews that he had to do some of the dirty work in attacking Mr. Dukakis. But as President, Mr. Bush preferred to farm out to aides the duties of bully and gunslinger. He was prone to play Henry II of England, going off to Camp David or staying above it all when dirty work had to be done, murmuring something to the effect of: "Who will free me from this turbulent priest?" Mr. Sununu would, just as Lee Atwater, Mr. Bush's bare-knuckles campaign manager, once would.
 
Playing the Bad Cop
 For example, Mr. Sununu, plying his own conservative agenda, was happy to play the bad cop to Mr. Bush's good cop on volatile issues like abortion and the environment. The responsibility for conservative moves was laid to Mr. Sununu, even though Mr. Bush shared those positions.
When Mr. Sununu screamed at shocked House Republicans about why they had to support the Administration's bipartisan budget agreement, including unpalatable tax increases, Mr. Bush would sit silently watching, never telling his chief of staff to stop bullying the Congressmen.
By making the abrasive former Governor of New Hampshire his chief of staff, Mr. Bush hoped that he could keep a certain balance of rough and smooth in his governing and in his politics.
In the many times over the last three years when Mr. Sununu helped land the President in the political soup, the Washington cognoscenti speculated that Mr. Bush was keeping his chief of staff out of loyalty for helping him win the New Hampshire primary, or because Mr. Bush was too nice to fire anyone, or because he was too indecisive.
The truth is more complicated, and Mr. Sununu put his finger on it today. While Mr. Sununu's lack of political skill in dealing with political Washington eventually cost him his job, and while his fatal flaw may have been in believing that he was smarter than George Bush, the chief of staff was, often in an inept way, trying to fulfill the mandate he had been given.
When Mr. Bush became President, he gave Mr. Sununu the job as chief of staff for several reasons: He wanted to repay him, he wanted to please the conservatives and he wanted to show his campaign chairman and best friend, James A. Baker 3d, that he was in charge. Mr. Baker, who had been credited with helping to save Mr. Bush's flagging campaign, had recommended a power-sharing arrangement among top White House aides that would have given some authority ultimately held by Mr. Sununu to others.
Mr. Sununu was not proclaimed a failure from the start. Indeed, in a May 1990 cover story called "Big Bad John Sununu," Time magazine said: "Sununu has emerged as Bush's most inspired choice for any senior post. His brisk certainty and willingness to take bold stands complement his risk-averse boss."
 
A Harvest of Bitterness
 But in many critical ways, Mr. Sununu exacerbated Mr. Bush's limitations, rather than making up for them, and whenever the spotlight swung away from foreign affairs, it became painfully apparent that this was a White House without a long-range agenda, without a communications strategy and without first-rate thinkers in many top jobs. "John Sununu and a thousand interns," went the joke among White House officials disgusted with the lack of exchange in ideas and with Mr. Sununu's need to surround himself with people who would not challenge his authority.
But while he accumulated more power than had any chief of staff since H. R. Haldeman in the Nixon years, Mr. Sununu started sowing the seeds of his own destruction early on by flouting Washington's tribal conventions.
Just as Sherman Adams and Donald T. Regan before him, he failed to realize that in the political capital, it is not so much what you have done wrong as whom you have offended and that it is not so much what you have accomplished as how you have operated.
Mr. Sununu went out of his way to make clear that he was not following the James Baker model for chief of staff: schmoozing and flattering.
When he bashed House Republicans at private dinner parties long after the first budget deal had been defeated, he ignored the fact that members of Congress do not think of themselves as "insignificant," to use the word that Mr. Sununu once applied to Senator Trent Lott, Republican of Mississippi.
When Mr. Sununu denied Defense Secretary Dick Cheney a Presidential helicopter for a trip to Camp David, he did not realize that he might need defenders some day on the issue of government travel.
As Mr. Bush tried to be the ultimate Washington insider, the chief of staff alienated Congress, Cabinet members, House Republicans and members of the he press, who disdained Mr. Sununu because they believed he misled them. He even tried to manipulate his boss on occasion, with the effect that Mr. Bush looked weak and waffling.
In the October 1990 budget deal negotiations, Mr. Sununu tried to sway Mr. Bush in the direction he wanted him to go, opposing any increase in the tax rate for the wealthy. He instructed Marlin Fitzwater, the Presidential spokesman, to tell reporters that Mr. Bush had acquiesced with some Senators who had suggested that there be no increase in the tax rate, even though Mr. Bush had not, and he told a group of businessmen that the President had decided this, as well.
When Mr. Bush repeated, the following day, that everything was "on the table," he looked foolish, as though he were flip-flopping. He was very angry at Mr. Sununu, one senior Bush aide said, who added that the President yelled at his chief of staff in the Oval Office and then stormed out, slamming the door.
And, in the recent fiasco about ceilings on credit card interest rates, Mr. Sununu did something that is never done in a city that operates strictly on hierarchy: He blamed the mess on his boss, going on television to say Mr. Bush had "ad libbed" the idea in a speech.
And so, finally, Mr. Bush invited Mr. Sununu to resign.

GRAPHIC: Photo: John H. Sununu boardgin Air Force One yesterday before submitting his resignation to President Bush. (Associated Press) (pg. B12)
 
Chronology: "Sununu's Troubled Tenure"
 
1988
November: President-elect Bush picks Gov. John H. Sununu of New Hampshire as his White House chief of staff against the advice of some top advisers, who critize Mr. Sununu for being arogant and abrasive and unfamiliar with key leaders of Congress. Leaders of some Jewish organizations point out that he had once been the lone opponent of a National Governors' Association resolution condemning the United Nations for equating Zionism with racism.
 
1990
 February: Leaders of eight environmental groups write to President Bush complaining that Mr. Sununu intervened to weaken Administration policies on global warming, wetlands protection and legislation to strengthen the Clean Air Act.
 October: During marathon negotiations over the deficit-reduction accord, Mr. Sununu not only manages to annoy Congressional Democrats, he also infuriates many Republican members.
 
1991
 April: The chief of staff finds himself at the center of a new political squall over his personal and political trips on military aircraft, including ski trips and trips to the dentist.
 May: President Bush orders Mr. Sununu to clear all future flights with the White House counsel in advance and bans the use of military aircraft for most of Mr. Sununu's political and personal travel.
 June: Mr. Sununu's travel practices again draw fire when he uses a Government limousine to take him to a New York stamp auction and do personal errands, and when he solicits American companies to give him use of their corporate jets for personal an dpoltical trips.
 The White House imposes new rules requiring Mr. Sununu to arrange travel for political purposes through the White House Office of Administration. Mr. Sununu acknowledges that his travel habits had created the "appearance of impropriety" and expresses regret.
 November: As President Bush's political ground becomes shakier because of a souring economy, Mr. Sununu is the center of several controversies: abrupt cancellation of the President's trip to Asia; a furor about a call for lower interest rates on credit card debts that was inserted at the last minute into a speech for the President; and concern that Mr. Sununu intends to keep tight control over the President's 1992 re-election campaign.
 Dec. 3: Mr. Sununu resigns. (pg. B12)

HEADLINE: 2 Bronx Men Are Charged With Murder In Death of 4

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI

 BODY:
Two Bronx men were arrested yesterday and charged with the execution-style murders of two children and two women in a Brooklyn apartment Saturday night, the police said.
One of the women and one of the children "just happened to be visiting," said Capt. Richard Ward, commander of Brooklyn's 12th Detective Division, when the killers forced their way into the apartment, took one woman into one bedroom, the other woman and the children into another bedroom, and then fired more than 15 shots. 
 "Apparently this was a dispute over missing money," Captain Ward said. "They were trying to find out who was responsible for the stolen money. That's as clear as we can give you as far as the motive is concerned."
On Sunday, the day after the bodies were found in the wood and stucco Tudor-style apartment building at 927 East 35th Street in Flatbush, Captain Ward had said the victims "were not bound, but they were shot in the head, which indicates that the persons who committed this crime wanted to insure that they had killed everybody."
 
Arrested at Their Homes
 The suspects were identified as Robert Dystont, 26 years old, of 2970 Laconia Avenue, and Rohan Maragh, 27, of 854 East 214th Street, both in the Williamsbridge section of the Bronx. Mr. Dystont, who described himself to the police as a self-employed music promoter, and Mr. Maragh, who is unemployed, were arrested at their homes before dawn yesterday.
They were each charged with four counts of second-degree murder in the deaths of 11-year-old Nadia Williams; her 14-year-old cousin, Damali Pournall; Sharon Robertson, 24, and Pauline Henry, 35.
Nadia, who was the daughter of Ms. Robertson's estranged boyfriend, lived with Ms. Robertson in the two-bedroom apartment where the shootings occurred. Damali lived with her mother about a dozen blocks away on Nostrand Avenue, and was visiting her cousin. Ms. Henry, a resident of the island of Jamaica, had been visiting Ms. Robertson for about a week. Ms. Robertson was a part-time waitress and a student at Baruch College.
The suspects, Captain Ward said, "were targeting Sharon Robertson; she was the person they felt knew who stole the money."
Captain Ward said "a substantial amount of money" had been stolen from Mr. Dystont several days before the murders. "We haven't identified the persons who took the money, but we believe that that's what the suspects were doing at the crime scene," he said, "trying to find out who took the money."
The captain said investigators were led to the suspects through a witness and physical evidence. He would not gave any information about the witness, but said the physical evidence included four handguns found at Mr. Maragh's apartment.

HEADLINE: NEW PLAN ORDERED ON HAITIAN EXODUS

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, Dec. 3

 BODY:
In a ruling that maintains a temporary ban on the forced repatriation of Haitians fleeing their country, a Federal District Court in Miami tonight ordered the Immigration and Naturalization Service to devise new procedures to screen refugees and assure that no Haitians with a legitimate fear of persecution are sent back.
The decision, which Justice Department and immigration officials said would immediately be taken to the United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit in Atlanta, orders the Government to submit a screening plan for Haitians in American custody within seven days. Many of those involved left their Caribbean country and ventured to the United States in small, rickety boats. 
 The ruling makes no provision for further refugees to enter the country. But it suggests that the number of Haitian refugees will continue to grow. Some of those being held are on United States Coast Guard vessels and some are at a refugee center at the American naval base at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba.
The decision was issued by Judge C. Clyde Atkins after a day of deliberation. He rejected one of the Government's central arguments -- that because Haitians were plucked from international waters, they had no right to protection under American laws. The ruling also rejected arguments that the United States could no longer shoulder the burden of the Haitian refugees.
 
Refugees at Greater Risk
 Judge Atkins wrote that the Haitian plaintiffs had shown that the "threatened injury" of their return "outweighs the potential harm an injuction would cause defendants."
The Justice Department, other than saying it would appeal, had no immediate comment on the ruling.
Expressing satisfaction over the ruling, Ira Kurzban, a lawyer with the Haitian Refugee Center in Miami, which brought the case, said he had been able to show that the Immigration and Naturalization Service and the Coast Guard had carried out a 1981 repatriation agreement with Haiti in a way that "deprives Haitians of their rights."
Mr. Kurzban said that American officials who interview the refugees to determine who is eligible to apply for political asylum should first be educated on conditions in Haiti, and that "artificial limits" on the length of the typically brief screening process should be lifted.
Besides the courts, the argument over the refugee issue is likely to be carried on in Congress, where immigration advocates are expected to press for some form of temporary protected status for Haitians, allowing those who have fled the strife in their country to remain in the United States until the situation in Haiti returns to normal.
 
Center to Be Expanded
 While the issue works its way through the legal and political system, pressure on the Coast Guard, whose ships patrol the Caribbean, and at the Guantanamo Bay base is likely to increase. More than 4,000 boat people from Haiti are now being temporarily housed at Guantanamo.
Last weekend, more than 400 Haitians heading for the United States were rescued by Coast Guard patrols, bringing the total number saved since the current refugee exodus began on Oct. 29 to more than 6,300.
Although Haitians have sought to reach the United States by boat for years, there had been a lull in recent months before the current rush, which began a month after the overthrow of the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, the elected civilian President.
To accommodate the rise in refugees, the Navy announced Monday that it was expanding the size of the Guantanamo center to accommodate as many as 10,000 more refugees.
The urgency of a solution to the refugee crisis was underscored by the Bush Administration's decision to have the Solicitor General, Kenneth W. Starr, argue the case.
 
U.S. Government's Arguments
 During a tense session of oral argument on Monday night, Mr. Starr urged that there be no extension of the restraining order. It was scheduled to expire at 5 P.M. today.
"It is 'we the people' who are protected by U.S. law," said Mr. Starr, who argued that the court had no jurisdiction in the case. "We do not see fit to protect everyone, no matter how moving their case may be, outside our territorial limits."
Mr. Starr said delaying the return of the refugees in United States custody sends a "false beacon of hope which could result in a human disaster" if yet greater numbers of Haitians are encouraged to attempt the perilous 700-mile sea journey.
The Haitian Refugee Center's lawyers argued that shipboard interview procedures used to winnow out those with a legitimate basis for seeking asylum, from those thought to be economic refugees, were deeply flawed.
Many of those who would be returned under existing procedures, they said, had a well-founded fear of persecution.
Jocelyn McCalla, director of the National Coalition for Haitian Refugees, who toured the Guantanamo Bay base over the weekend to gather depositions for the case, said, "Most of the Haitians that we interviewed said that the army had either gone on a rampage and destroyed their house, or that they had lost a brother, sister, father or mother."

HEADLINE: Fee Proposal Attacked at a Landmarks Hearing

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
Rather than cut 10 more employees from its already depleted staff, the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission has proposed raising $300,000 by imposing work-permit fees for the first time in its history.
But the plan was attacked yesterday at a commission hearing as a suicidal measure that would undermine any future regulation and designation efforts. 
 A steady stream of preservation leaders, neighborhood organizers and elected officials warned the commission that such fees would amount to a tax on the very property owners whose cooperation is essential in maintaining the 19,000 structures covered by landmark or historic district designation.
"Charging fees for the privilege of being regulated is political suicide," said Anthony C. Wood, a preservationist in Manhattan.
Permit fees would range from $25 for minor work on a protected structure to $1,500 for major work. There would be a $25 application fee in all cases.
Such fees would tempt many more landmark owners to violate the law by undertaking work without coming before the commission, opponents of the proposal said. It would also make it far more difficult to muster popular support for prospective designations.
"The imposition of fees would spell doom for our communities as it relates to historic preservation," said Councilwoman C. Virginia Fields, a Democrat from Harlem, where broad designation efforts are under way.
Jeffrey A. Kroessler of the Queensborough Preservation League said, "I'm telling you now, if these fees are adopted, you'll never see another designation in Queens."
Not one speaker among 42 favored the fees as proposed, and the commission voted to continue taking public testimony next month.
Laurie Beckelman, the chairwoman of the commission, said she shared many of the opponents' concerns. But now, she said, $300,000 must be found to satisfy the city's Office of Management and Budget.
The commission staff has been cut to 58 from 79 in the past year and a half as a result of the city's economic distress, Ms. Beckelman said. "You can't cut any more," she said. "It's below the bone. Once you cut any more, you have to evaluate whether New York can afford a landmarks commission."
In a search for more revenue, other city agencies have raised the cost of parking, ballfield permits and pool hall licenses.
 
The Highest Fees
 For landmark owners, the highest permit fees would apply to major work requiring a Certificate of No Effect (meaning that the work does not affect protected features) or a Certificate of Appropriateness (meaning that the planned changes are deemed appropriate to the landmark or historic district).
Many speakers urged that money be raised by collecting fines for violations. To do that, however, the commission must go through Criminal Court. At the most, it can collect $1,000 from an owner who has undertaken major work without approval.
"It's not expeditious to go after people in court," Ms. Beckelman said.
Charging that the fee proposal is "a violation of the public trust," Councilman Alfred C. Cerullo 3d, Republican of Staten Island, said he will introduce a bill tomorrow that would transfer the power to establish fees to the City Council, which would presumably be loathe to enact them.

HEADLINE: ABOUT NEW YORK;
For One Brooklyn Gang, Restoration Is the Cause

BYLINE: By Douglas Martin

 BODY:
PETER ROMEO took his daughter to the carousel in Prospect Park one sunny day last summer. He noticed an old building nearby. It was the Lefferts Homestead, a 200-year-old house that combines Dutch Colonial and Federal details to quite pleasing effect. Too bad the architectural treasure was falling apart.
Mr. Romeo also focused on the people pulling weeds. They looked like farmers, but said they were volunteers -- a vague concept to this energetic lighting entrepreneur who routinely puts in 17 hours a day. 
 The self-described "doctor of socketology" greeted Vivienne Shaffer, who works as the homestead's director. She offered a tour, and Mr. Romeo was mightily impressed by the antique lighting fixtures. But not their wretched condition.
He immediately offered to restore them for nothing. "You will?" Ms. Shaffer sputtered. "You mean that?"
Thus began a remarkable episode in volunteerism. Not only did Mr. Romeo refurbish exquisite chandeliers and lamps, he got some Brooklyn friends to help with other chores. Mr. Romeo has lured some two dozen businesspeople to pitch in, with more help still materializing.
"It's snowballing," exuded Tupper Thomas, the Prospect Park administrator.
Government and foundations and seemingly almost everybody who once wrote checks to make the world a better place are taking troubling steps backward in these mean and penurious times.
So enter the little guys, led by a 51-year-old scrambler who grew up playing stickball on the streets of Bensonhurst, got a tattoo on Coney Island at 18, and has been through bankruptcy and a bitter divorce without anyone much in evidence to care. Real life.
Mr. Romeo did it because real people need parks most. "We've got millions of people crammed into this city," he said. "The only relief the lower class has is a park."
He raised the donations from salt-of-the-earth types like himself. Sal Raio, for one. Talk about honesty. Mr. Romeo, over a year's time, took a Cadillac, Mustang and Lincoln to Sal's Transmission on Neptune Avenue thinking each needed a new transmission.
Mr. Raio said the Cadillac instead needed a vacuum hose; the Mustang had a slight problem with its linkage, and the Lincoln required a distributor adjustment. Mr. Romeo -- who says the price for all the repairs was, maybe, that of a nice lunch -- had expected to pay $1,500.
He returned the favor by arranging for free lighting fixtures at Mr. Raio's shop. When Ms. Thomas said she wanted a van for volunteers, Mr. Romeo turned to Mr. Raio, who had not been in the park since grade school.
"Sal, you know me, I know you, trust me, go with me on this," Mr. Romeo said.
The transmission man eased into gear, and proceeded to rebuild completely a 1983 Dodge van. A $15,000 value, easy.
"It's just something I wanted to do," he said. "I feel good about doing it."
Mr. Romeo has long believed that people must do more than the minimum, starting at home. He has personally decorated landings on each floor of his high-rise apartment building in Sheepshead Bay.
His competence comes from the school of hard knocks. He was almost killed by a runaway blimp while in the Navy, he has delivered packages, programmed computers, and watched a gift shop he owned financially disintegrate.
Perhaps most relevant to his fund-raising skill, he once collected bills for a loan company. Relentlessly. "When I think of the things I should go to hell for, that's one of them," he said. "I have this habit of overachieving."
For two decades, he has owned the Lamp Doctor, a store specializing in lamp restoration and antique shades on Coney Island Avenue. The recession's bite has had the bittersweet effect of giving him time to volunteer.
Tomorrow, Parks Department poobahs will hold a ceremony to honor him and his unlikely band of modern-day Medicis. But Mr. Romeo's sprightly mind is already on his next volunteer effort. He longs to spruce up Coney Island's defunct parachute jump. "The ultimate lamp," he calls it.
His inspiration is a vanished Coney Island, the one in a fraying photo he shyly displays. In front of a gleaming 1957 Ford and the boardwalk, a young Mr. Romeo poses with a blond woman whose name he thinks was Debbie.
"We can send men to the moon, and we can't bring back Coney Island?" he asked with refreshing incredulity.
