HEADLINE: Independent Ukraine Keeps Sight of Cooperation

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOYARKA, Ukraine, Dec. 3

 BODY:
The backyard roosters glared and crowed proud as ever this morning but seemed no match for the residents of this dirt-road hamlet as they took stock of the stirring new notion of an independent Ukraine being recognized as such by other nations.
"So, Yeltsin recognizes Ukraine as free?" said Vera Melnik, a pensioned grandmother, focusing on the really important piece of the news about recognition from abroad. 
 This was not the Polish and Canadian declaration, nor the White House plans, but the far more impressive nod here from Boris N. Yeltsin, the President of the giant neighboring Russian republic, who recognized that Russia and Ukraine, steady as the centuries, still need each other.
 
Facing Reality
 "Yeltsin pays us a compliment, perhaps, but he also admits to reality," the apple-cheeked woman said in the biting cold whipping down the mud lane called Sakhalin Street.
"We're at the very bottom now," said her friend, Antonina Khomenko. "The goods began disappearing from our stores with Gorbachev and his perestroika. So of course Russia needs Ukraine -- that's where Gorbachev has his dacha."
Both women laughed at the mild joke about Russian imperialism as they stood stoutly bundled against the first flakes of snow on an iron-gray day.
Over the centuries far too many ties have grown between the two republics to ever be sundered by the collapse of the Communist Soviet Union after a mere seven decades. The women were amused that the "catastrophe" that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev keeps warning about could ever arise in this small village cut close to the woods and farmlands that roll south of Kiev toward Odessa.
 
Family Ties
 Both Ukrainian, the two women told of complicated family ties of Ukrainian and Russian blood and marriage, of trade and education, of border traffic and intuitive tolerance. They spelled out in human terms how the two republics together accounted for about 70 percent of the economic output and population of the collapsed union, and aim to do even better under free-market independence.
"Like my sister always says, 'How can we live without the Russians?' " said Miss Khomenko. "We're not used to separation."
"It's like a big family," said Mrs. Melnik, including the full range of family animus and affection in her simile. "Smart members know it doesn't pay to cheat, but the wise course is to treat the people well."
 
Importance of Image
 A neighbor, Tatyana Kristal, walked by with her 6-year-old daughter on the way to one of the small brick houses packed together neat and close as the two-story hamlets of Queens County, New York.
"Kravchuk is a cunning person and that's a natural feature," she said. She spoke as a Russian married to a Ukrainian, one who appreciates some card-shark values in Leonid M. Kravchuk, the newly elected Ukrainian President and former Communist leader, whom the people are pleased to find vying with Mr. Yeltsin in presidential imagery and republic one-upsmanship.
"Our politician should be as cunning as theirs," said Mrs. Kristal, speaking as a Ukrainian. "Let Ukrainians and Russians sell their goods to each other and keep their profits to themselves, and not for the center."
 
Wrestling With Bureaucracy
 She touched on what so far seems an emotional point almost as moving to Ukrainians as the idea of independence -- the end of the dictate and economic parasitism long enforced by the now-dying central Government.
"Put yourself in this small town, 800 kilometers from Moscow, and having to go to them in Moscow to get a simple road built," said Anatoly Boyko, a retired schoolteacher, clearing brush from his patch of garden.
He grew angry in the cold thinking about what Ukraine inherits from the necrotic center: "They leave us with not a fork, not a pair of socks to be found in the Government shops, but with all their ministries in Kiev mimicking the center, with 17 sets of deputies and subdeputies all wanting to keep feeding off of us."
Villagers here, like city-dwellers in Kiev, dismissed speculation that, with the center gone as dictatorial referee, independence will mean economic warfare between Russia and Ukraine. Mr. Boyko focused his resentment on the "colonialists" of the center rather than on the Russian people.
"Intellectuals tried to reduce us to the level of the Russian bear versus the Ukrainian fox, but ordinary people don't talk that way here," said another Ukrainian, Anatoly Kozy. "We're well aware that our problem was the state and not the Russian people."
Still, Mr. Kozy said it would be hard for Russia in general, and perhaps the new Yeltsin Government in particular, to get rid of the ancient empire mentality in a new rage of independence. "For this, Ukrainians themselves must learn that they had a highly cultured civilization, centuries before they joined with Russia," he said.
 
Keeping Eye on Russia
 One diplomat who has been watching Ukraine engineer its independence feels the republic already showed a healthy spirit of conciliation toward Russians and every important group, during the highly successful election campaign for the referendum and presidency.
"All the politicians had a Pole, a Jew, a Russian on their staffs, and they really made a point of showing this to the public," the diplomat said.
But while talking of independence, Ukrainians keep an eye on Russia.
"Actually, this country has only started to move away from a slave mentality," said Les Tanyuk, a political intellectual in the parliamentary opposition to President Kravchuk. "Its provincialism manifests itself acutely in dealing with Russia."
Perhaps, but here in this backwater town all the talk and hope about independence focuses not so much on the psychological baggage of the past as on the shabbily stocked shops of the present. When they met in the street, Vera Melnik and Antonina Khomenko were thankful that the recent long milk lines had disappeared and that good loaves of crisp Ukrainian bread remained at hand.
 
Days of Plenty
 "In the old days there was plenty and we'd go into the woods there to eat and drink and dance," said Mrs. Khomenko, gesturing toward the soothing darkness of the pine, oak and moutain ash trees standing nearby.
"Oh, the vodka you could get then," she recalled, suddenly dropping talk of independence to recall the old Soviet center at its heights in meeting consumer cravings.
"Nowadays, when someone can get his hands on a bottle of vodka, he sneaks off deep into the forest so no one sees him and he drinks it alone, as if this were a funeral," said Mrs. Khomenko, and the laughter of the two women carried into the woods.
"But the most important thing in all this is not to hurt the people, right?" she asked her friend and Mrs. Melnik agreed as they tried to look ahead at independence.

HEADLINE: Made in Vermont: Myths You Can Eat

BYLINE: By MARIALISA CALTA

DATELINE: MONTPELIER, Vt.

 BODY:
FOR the purposes of statehood, Vermont was born on March 4, 1791, in Windsor. But for marketing purposes, Vermont was born on Nov. 11, 1984, in Manhattan, at the third annual Gourmet Products and Tabletop Show.
That's as far as Jerome Kelley is concerned, and he should know. As director for marketing with the Vermont Department of Agriculture, Mr. Kelley seven years ago shanghaied a motley assortment of specialty food producers and trekked with them to New York to help them display their wares, thus becoming midwife to the birth of a marketing concept that some artisans and specialty food producers call "Vermont Inc." 
 That's the Vermont of purity, wholesomeness, rural values, tradition, self-reliance, trustworthiness, simplicity, honesty, hard work, environmental awareness and closeness to nature, which residents and visitors alike described in interviews with the State Agency of Development and Community Affairs for a 1986 survey on the image of Vermont. For many, the report concluded, "experiencing Vermont becomes a religious experience: oneness with nature, oneness with self, oneness with the universal life force."
That's the Vermont that produces not only such native products as maple syrup, cheese and apple cider, but organic sauerkraut, ginseng honey, raspberry vinaigrette, jalapeno sauce, coffee blends, organic beef, chocolate truffles, pate, horseradish jelly, organic baby food, creme fraiche, flavored mustards, salsa, farm-raised quail and dog biscuits made with (among other things) whole wheat flour, wheat germ, brewer's yeast, honey and Brazil nuts.
The Vermont mystique has been bottled, bagged and stuffed into cute little canning jars to create a cash crop that brings in an estimated half-billion dollars to the state each year. The number of specialty food producers has grown from about 15 in 1984 to over 200 today. After the Gourmet Products and Tabletop Show of 1984 came other shows, and Vermont products soon began showing up in such New York emporiums as Dean & DeLuca, Zabar's, Balducci's and Bloomingdale's. "We were the first state to ever have a special food promotion at Bloomingdale's," Mr. Kelley said with obvious pride. "They had done France. Why not Vermont?" Why not indeed? "It's as if people are nostalgic for a past they never even had," Mr. Kelley said. "It's as if every American feels like a Vermonter at heart."
Rod Clarke, a former journalist who now runs a public relations and political consulting firm in Vermont, puts it another way. "I once heard someone suggest a T-shirt," he said. " 'Vermont: America's Pet.' "
But the image can't get too cute or too cosmic for Mr. Kelley, a native of Vermont who in 1978 took a job with its state government after retiring from a career in publishing and advertising in New York. "Vermont sells," Mr. Kelley said, "and I sell Vermont."
Tom Slayton, editor of Vermont Life (published by the state's development agency), dryly describes his job as "keeper of the sacred myths." He ascribes Vermont's cachet to the pastoral ideal, which he said has been alive since ancient times. "The Greeks called it Arcadia, and it embodied the idea of an idyllic, open farmland where man lived close to nature but still in control," Mr. Slayton said. "The bigger the city, the bigger the dream.
"Of course it's a little unreal. We have crime here, and poverty, and economic and social stress. But people still think of Vermont as a place where good people do good things in a good way."
Frank Scalzo, dairy director for Mrs. Gooch's, a chain of natural food stores in the Los Angeles area that regularly stocks about 15 Vermont-made products, said: "Vermont is perceived as clean, and natural. It's everything California wants to be and can't, because we're too smokey and crowded."
But, as the saying goes, what does that have to do with the price of eggs? Or, to be more exact, the price of goat cheese, salsa, pasta or barbecue sauce? As it turns out, just about everything.
"I'm convinced that when people go home and buy our product, they're eating their memories," said Roberta MacDonald, vice president of marketing for the Cabot Farmers' Cooperative Creamery. She said 95 percent of Cabot's customers in New England have visited Vermont. The appeal of the state, she said, is that "we're so bloody small and so ripe with history."
Alan Parker, special projects manager for Ben & Jerry's Homemade Inc., the ice cream manufacturers based in Waterbury, said: "There is an ache for our rural past that goes beyond nostalgia. I think that people feel there's something missing in general in the path their lives are taking, and images are part of the way we try to reclaim what is lost."
Artisans and, in particular, specialty food producers, are helping with the images. Herds of smiling cows, flocks of happy geese and pleased-looking pigs parade across boxes, cartons and bags along with, perhaps, a picture of the producer, or his or her grandmother, or staff. A small card displayed with jars of Green Mountain Gringo salsa, for example, announces that the product is made by "seven of the most energetic, hard-working, dedicated, fun-loving salsa makers in the world."
Vermont labels are rife with such phrases as "all-natural," "organic," "pesticide-free" and "homemade." Jams contain "100 percent pure Vermont maple syrup" or "pure Vermont honey." Flours tend toward the "stone-ground" and "whole grain." Labels are hand-lettered or, through the magic of high-tech graphics, at least look it.
"Vermont is prescriptive" Ms. MacDonald said. "It's good for you. People definitely get the feeling they are doing something good for themselves when they buy products made here."
Some of these good-for-you, made-in-Vermont products are not actually made in Vermont. Or even near Vermont. A soda manufacturer, for example, was investigated by the State Attorney General's office for representing as a "Vermont all-natural soda" a beverage manufactured and bottled in New Jersey. A salad dressing producer agreed to eliminate the word "Vermont" from her labels when it was found she was making the stuff in Maine. A third company, Vermont Maple Orchards and its parent company, Borden Inc., paid $150,000 last year in costs and restitution for selling Canadian syrup in packages that, said Elliot M. Burg, an Assistant Attorney General, a "reasonable consumer" would assume was produced in Vermont.
The reason why some producers want to use that "made in Vermont" label is because "made in Vermont" translates into higher prices at the cash register. In a specialty store, a Vermont-made product can easily retail for 15 to 20 percent more than a comparable product that is mass produced, said Nick Greene, president of Unifood Marketing of Augusta, Ga. In a grocery store, however, a Vermont-made product can only command perhaps 5 percent more to remain competitive with less expensive, brand-name labels.
"Vermont products have a value-added aspect," said Mr. Greene, who represents several Vermont food producers, placing them in specialty stores and membership clubs.
And most Vermont food producers feel that the words "Vermont" or, perhaps, "Green Mountain" do add value to their product. Brian Tyrol, of Vermont Distillers in Waterbury, for example, said he knew from the start that he wanted "Vermont" on the company's labels, even though it manufactures such un-Vermonty products as gin and vodka. "Vermont conjures up images of a pristine countryside and an honest, uncomplicated lifestyle," Mr. Tyrol said. "Never mind that I find my life about three times more complicated than it ever was when I lived in New York City."
He and the co-owner, Steve Israel, went back and forth over the names "Vermont Distillers" and "Vermont Distillery," eventually deciding on the former because they wanted the emphasis, Mr. Tyrol said, "to be on the people, not the machinery."
"Vermont is personal," he added.
Then there are Ben Cohen and Jerry Greenfield, who, with their pictures on their ice cream cartons and the slogan "Two Real Guys" are about as personal as it gets.
Of course, Ben or Jerry might be too busy these days to come to the phone. But other Vermont businesses do live up to the warm fuzzies of their packaging. If you call the number on the jar of Vermont Harvest Strawberry Amaretto Conserve, for example, you are likely to speak with company founder Patty Girouard, who began by cooking her sauces on her kitchen stove and still develops new products there. Call Brian or Steve, who put their signatures and phone number on the Vermont Distillers bottles (their motto: "Who ARE these guys?"), and you are likely to talk to Brian or Steve.
Moreover, in aligning itself with such issues as saving the rain forest and family farms, helping the homeless and promoting world peace, Ben & Jerry's has spearheaded the list of Vermont companies that have become socially active, which has the added value of making customers feel not only pure and natural, but politically correct as well.
Community Products of Montpelier, a company founded by Mr. Cohen that uses brazil nuts and cashews from the Amazon rain forest, donates 60 percent of after-tax profits to rain forest survival and other social causes. Food 2000, also in Montpelier, donates money and jars of its Chili 2000 (vegetarian and all-natural) to nearby food banks. Moon Over Vermont All-Natural Rainforest Dog Biscuits, (their motto: "Loving Our Pets and Our Community") of Westford dedicates 10 percent of company proceeds, according to the label, to "buying back the rain forest."
Next summer, at the International Fancy Food and Confection Show in Washington, Vermont producers will run a total of 42 booths. Vermont will have the largest representation of any state and more than a number of foreign countries.
"That's because we're Vermont," exulted Mr. Kelley. "And Vermont sells."

HEADLINE: As Annual Price War Begins, Caviar Business Is in Turmoil

BYLINE: By FLORENCE FABRICANT

 BODY:
THE cold war may be over but the annual caviar war is flaring up again. Macy's and Zabar's are sniping at each other's bottom lines on beluga. In the next few weeks, the price for a 14-ounce container of this most prized grade of sturgeon eggs is likely to fall well below last year's price of just under $400.
This year, there is also plenty of undercover maneuvering worthy of John le Carre. The breaking up of the Soviet Union has thrown a once orderly business into turmoil. Lack of central government control there has opened the door for all kinds of entrepreneurs: on the fishing boats, in the processing plants and in the marketplace. 
 In this country, caviar peddlers, like mercenaries in a guerrilla skirmish, are out in force, circumventing the traditional tightly controlled avenues of caviar export. These are mostly Russians who have obtained tins of caviar in the Soviet Union and have gone into business for themselves.
A number of American and European importers and dealers have been approached about entering into joint ventures to produce caviar in Russia. Mats and Dafne Engstrom, the owners of California Sunshine, a food importer and distributor in San Francisco, have already started one with a group of Russians to produce caviar in eastern Russia, not the Caspian Sea, the traditional source of sturgeon caviar.
Even the Federal Food and Drug Administration is getting into the act. The term "fresh caviar," meaning unpasteurized, may no longer be permitted under the new food-labeling proposals, said Mary Snyder, chief of policy guidance in the agency's seafood office. "Our definition would not allow caviar to be labeled fresh because it is not entirely unprocessed," she said. "It has been salted."
Since 1965 most of the Russian caviar exported to Europe, the United States, Canada and Latin America has been bought through agencies in Hamburg, Germany, and in Switzerland.
"We have been paying in Deutsche marks for caviar since 1965," said Gerald Stein, the president of Iron Gate, Macy's main supplier. "And until the Shah of Iran was overthrown, the caviar business was pretty orderly. It gradually began to break apart in the 1980's and now it has become very factionalized."
For example, Murray Klein, one of the owners of Zabar's, at 80th Street and Broadway, and that store's caviar maven, said peddlers have been showing up on his doorstep regularly for the last year. "But I won't buy from them," he said. "What they are bringing me is half the price and I don't trust it. Fresh caviar is perishable and you can't just carry it around in a suitcase."
What the peddlers often bring him is 95-gram tins (about three ounces) of caviar. These have been available fairly regularly in recent months in shops in Brighton Beach, a Brooklyn neighborhood that is home to many Soviet emigres. The writing on the tins or jars is only in Cyrillic. The F.D.A. requires that the labeling be in English.
The consumer is taking chances by buying this caviar, not only because of the conditions of transport and storage but also because it may not be of the quality reserved for export. But this "peddlers' caviar," which a number of importers say has been more available worldwide this year than ever before, amounts to a small fraction of the estimated 150 tons of caviar exported from Russia every year.
Total American consumption is estimated in the industry to be about 40 tons a year, as it has been for the last decade. About a thousand tons of Russian caviar is produced annually from the Caspian Sea.
The best caviar, usually reserved for export, is processed at sea on factory boats as soon as the fish are caught. The rest is sent to processing plants on shore to be tinned or jarred and, usually, pasteurized. Some dealers say that a small amount of Iranian caviar, which is allowed in Europe but not the United States, makes its way into the Russian caviar pipeline.
"A lot of caviar is laundered in Germany," Dafne Engstrom said. She suggested that counterfeit tins are being produced in Europe to be filled with lesser quality caviar and passed off as top quality Russian.
Obviously, you don't need Russians hiding jars of caviar under their fur hats to make this business rife with innuendo. Take the pronouncements from Caviarteria at 29 East 60th Street in Manhattan, for example. The store insists that it does not deal in "salty leftovers from previous years, substitution of lesser grade caviars, mixed or blended caviars or mislabeled Chinese caviar."
Bruce Sobol, the president of Caviarteria, is quick to suggest that some of his competitors misrepresent what they carry or sell caviar that has been sitting in warehouses for a year or more. He said that he is visited by peddlers on a fairly regular basis but that he refuses to deal with them because he believes that their goods are inferior. Other dealers, of course, insist that their businesses are above reproach.
One thing most dealers do share is concern that without Soviet Government controls on production, and with small fishermen going into business for themselves, the overall quality of caviar may suffer, as it did in Iran when the Shah fell.
Armen Petrossian, the president of Petrossian, an importer based in Paris, expects a six-month shakeout period in the caviar business in Russia. "We will undoubtedly see more profit-sharing by the producers and the republics," he said.
Everybody's main concern is for the quality. "It's an important export and they had better see that quality is maintained," said Hossein Lolavar, the president of Epicurean International, an importer in Rockville, Md.
All this means that it makes sense for consumers who can afford the indulgence of sturgeon caviar to buy with care. And there is a range of choices.
The most prized caviar is fresh Caspian Sea beluga, the variety with the largest eggs and the most delicate flavor. It is also the most expensive, adding to its cachet. In most instances, the price of beluga this year is 10 to 20 percent lower than last year. But the reduction has nothing to do with any changes in the system, increased entrepreneurship or even the recession. It simply reflects greater availability of the largest eggs compared with 1990, when there was a small catch.
Fresh osetra, the medium-size eggs that are often grayish or brownish and have a distinctively nutty or earthy flavor, now range from about $140 to just under $400 for 14 ounces. Sevruga, the smallest grade, with a firmer egg and a slightly sharper flavor, ranges from about $110 to about $260 for 14 ounces.
Prices for fresh osetra and sevruga are about the same this year as last year. Many connoisseurs prefer these grades to beluga, which they regard as overpriced and less distinctive tasting.
When buying fresh caviar, buy only the amount you will use in one sitting. An unopened tin should be kept in the coldest part of the refrigerator, preferably sitting on a frozen gel pack, and used within a month. Once opened, it should be eaten that day. But leftovers can be kept a couple of days in the refrigerator in the original tin with a piece of plastic wrap on top.
 
FROM OTHER REGIONS
 THERE are a number of other options besides unpasteurized caviar from the Caspian Sea.
Fresh Chinese caviar, with beluga-size eggs and a gray-green color, is about one-third the price of Caspian Sea beluga.
California Sunshine's Tsar Nicouli beluga, with a delicate flavor but a firmer texture than typical beluga, comes from eastern Russia. The company will not be more precise than that about its source.
American sturgeon caviar, which is similar to sevruga and has been improving in quality and consistency, now sells for about $12 to $15 an ounce, almost the same price as imported sevruga. Fresh salmon caviar, with large eggs that taste briny, is $2 to $5 an ounce.
This year several dealers, among them Caviarteria, Caviar King and the Collins Caviar Company in Chicago, have introduced trout caviar. It is the same color as salmon caviar but has a slightly smaller egg and is not as sticky. The price is about the same as salmon caviar.
Pasteurized sturgeon caviar, heated quickly to make it shelf-stable and packed in vacuum-sealed jars or tins, has a less delicate texture and flavor. It is sold in one- to four-ounce jars for about half the price of fresh caviar. It should be refrigerated upon opening.
Pasteurized American sturgeon, salmon, trout and golden whitefish caviar are also available. Collins Caviar, which specializes in caviars from the Midwest, even sells whitefish caviar spiked with chili peppers. -- FLORENCE FABRICANT

HEADLINE: Food Notes

BYLINE: By Florence Fabricant

 BODY:

Food From Afar
One of the year's more engaging cookbooks, "The Ellis Island Immigrant Cookbook," did not come off the slick presses of a big publishing house but grew from two years of loving effort by Tom Bernardin, who compiled and published it himself. 
 Mr. Bernardin, an entrepreneur and a former English teacher, worked as a guide at the Statue of Liberty and Ellis Island for several years. He decided to collect recipes by people who entered this country through Ellis Island. His search was announced two years ago in about 400 newspapers nationwide, and he is still receiving recipes in the mail.
The recipes in the spiral-bound book and the text of accompanying letters from immigrants and their descendants were left essentially unedited. Some are highly professional, like the recipes from Jim Fobel, a cookbook author and cooking teacher whose grandfather arrived at Ellis Island from Finland in 1904.
Others are sketchy, like Jacqueline A. Frost Deasy's lamb and macaroni dish from her Greek grandfather, who also arrived in 1904; it calls for a leg of lamb, any size, and a smidgen of oregano, among other ingredients. Some recipes require expertise, and others, like Deana Solomon's meatball soup from her Turkish mother, are simple and inviting.
The book also has a history of, and a guide to, Ellis Island. It can be ordered for $15.95 plus $3 for shipping ($2 per book for more than three books to the same address); New York State residents must add sales tax. The address is Ellis Island Immigrant Cookbook, Suite 2306, 175 Fifth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10010.
 
A Patisserie Spreads
 Patisserie les Friandises, 665 Amsterdam Avenue (92d Street), has just opened a second shop at 972 Lexington Avenue (70th Street). It is larger than the Amsterdam Avenue store and has a few cafe tables in addition to the bakery counter.
Jean Kahn, the owner, studied with Gaston Lenotre in France. Both shops carry her varied line, from simple, earthy bran muffins ($1 each) to fancy pastries like the luscious caramelized tarte tatin on a buttery pastry base ($9.50 for six-inch; $19 for eight-inch). Lavish seasonal items like buche de Noel and croquembouche will be available for Christmas.
 
A Hunt to the Finish
 Last week, Giovanni Piermadini's dog, Diana, lived up to her namesake, the Goddess of the Hunt. She cornered her prey in the woodlands near Asti, in northern Italy. When Mr. Piermadini captured it after an hour and a half of digging, it was indeed a prize: a white truffle that weighed 850 grams, or nearly two pounds, and was about the size of a cantaloupe.
The truffle was flown to New York and is now at Balducci's, 424 Avenue of the Americas (Ninth Street), where it is priced at a mere $5,500.
Louis Balducci, the merchandise manager of the store, estimated that the truffle could be shaved over pasta or risotto for 100 to 120 people. He added that Bruno Urbani, the store's truffle dealer in Italy, said it was enough for only 85.
The truffle's shelf life, before it begins to shrink from loss of moisture, is about 10 days.
As for Diana, she got her favorite treat: a bowl of biscotti (cookies, not dog biscotti).
 
Help by the Butter People
 Land O Lakes butter is operating a toll-free holiday baking service to answer questions and give tips about baking. Home economists from the company's test kitchen will answer the phones from 9 A.M. to 7 P.M. Eastern time every day through Dec. 22. The number is (800) 782-9606.
 
Gingerbread Architecture
 Building gingerbread houses will be the subject of a two-day workshop taught by Bianca Borges Henry, a professional baker, at Peter Kump's New York Cooking School, 307 East 92d Street, on Friday from 6 to 9 P.M. and Saturday from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M.
Participants will learn how to make a simple gingerbread house that even children can handle, and a very complicated one. The class costs $240. It will be repeated on Dec. 13 and 14. Reservations: (212) 410-4601.
The New School culinary arts program has a workshop on Saturday from 9:30 A.M. to 12:30 P.M. on making buche de Noel, the French yule log cake. The class, taught by Lisa Montenegro, costs $70 and will meet at the Culinary Center of New York, 100 Greenwich Avenue (10th Street). Registration: (212) 229-5690.
Breathtaking cake decoration is the stock in trade of Colette Peters, the author of "Colette's Cakes: The Art of Cake Decorating" (Little, Brown; 1991). She will give a three-hour class on the subject at Hay Day, 21 Governor Street, Richfield, Conn., on Dec. 12 from 7 to 10 P.M. The cost is $50. Reservations can be made through Sue Olex at (203) 221-0100.
 
A PUERTO RICAN SAMPLER
 ON Sunday from 1 to 4 P.M., the Brooklyn Historical Society, at 128 Pierrepont Street, Brooklyn Heights, will give a program on Puerto Rican food traditions. Yvonne Ortiz, a culinary historian, will explain the history of the island through its food, starting with the indigenous Taino Indians, and will also discuss Puerto Rican holiday cooking. Slides, displays and sample tastings of food will be included.
The museum opens at noon. Admission is $2.50 for adults, $1 for children under 12. There is no extra charge for the program on Puerto Rican food, but reservations are recommended. Call (718) 624-0890.

HEADLINE: HOCKEY;
Where, Oh Where, Have All the Fans Gone?

BYLINE: By JOE LAPOINTE

 BODY:
Through the 1970's and much of the 1980's, attendance figures for Ranger games at Madison Square Garden were pretty predictable: always around 17,500, a near-capacity crowd.
Every seat wasn't always sold and occupied, but most were. And the money was in the bank, often well in advance, earning interest. Then, as now, the National Hockey League was a business based on gate receipts, and business was pretty good. 
 In recent seasons, including this one, attendance figures at the Garden have not always been so healthy.
 
Charting a Falloff
 Although 17,542 attended the home opener with Boston in early October, only 13,269 came for a game against Calgary in early November and average attendance has fallen from 17,402 in 1984-85 to 15,964 last season.
The Rangers aren't the only N.H.L. team suffering a falloff in attendance. Last season, as the nation's recession deeped, the league's regular-season attendance dropped by nearly a quarter-million customers, from 12.58 million in 1989-90 to 12.34 million in 1990-91, a drop of about 2 percent. Through October of this year, attendance has fallen another 1 percent.
"When businesses are going through tough times and people are going through tough times, the entertainment dollar suffers," said John Ziegler, president of the N.H.L.
 
Northeast Hit Hardest
 The box-office problems seem worst in the Northeast, where the recession has been most persistent. The Islanders are down 25 percent, from an average of 11,789 at this time last season to 9,212 so far this year.
The Hartford Whalers' average for the first quarter of the current season is 10,925, compared with 12,014 at the same time last season. The Devils won't provide cumulative figures or comparisons. But they have announced crowds of 11,506, 10,438, 11,551, 11,813, and 10,237 in a building that seats 19,040.
Even the Stanley Cup champions, the Pittsburgh Penguins, are down about 150 fans a game after increasing by $5 the price of every ticket.
Dave Andrews, executive vice president of the Whalers, said that revenues are down substantially in Hartford and that attendance continues to drop in that arena while ticket prices remained the same.
"Over all, we are concerned," he said. "If concern is pessimism, that's a way to look at it. Hockey tickets are not a necessity of life. They are a passion."
Andrews said that two-thirds of the N.H.L. teams made money in 1989-90, the last season for which balance sheets are available. The Whalers don't expect to be profitable this season. "We could lose as much as $5 million, cash," he said.
Hockey teams are trying to adjust to this changing marketplace. For instance, the Rangers are offering partial-season ticket plans for fans who cannot afford all 40 games. They are advertising extensively. They are selling some tickets at a discount.
The Rangers say they aren't worried about selling the $65 seats near the ice or about filling the new high-level suites for the corporate clients who write them off on the expense account.
"We're concerned more with some of the lower-priced seats skewed toward the individual game buyers who reach down into their own pocket," said Kevin Kennedy, director of marketing for the Rangers, whose cheapest seats go for $16.
"You will see, this season, an overall slippage or reduction in total attendance in sports and in entertainment, period," he said.
While that may be so, hockey is unusual among the major sports in that so much of its revenue comes from gate receipts. In fact, this year the N.H.L. suffered a major blow when it signed a $5.5 million television contract with SportsChannel America. Three years ago, the league's television contract brought in more than three times that amount. But television may be causing problems in other ways.
While the other major team sports maintain a strong presence through over-the-air and major cable networks, in many cities hockey appears almost entirely on cable networks and sometimes on cable channels that charge a premium beyond the basic cable fee.
Hockey teams are also leading the major sports in the drift toward pay-per-view telecasting, an even more expensive form of cable. With pay-per-view, a household pays extra on its cable bill -- usually $10 or more -- for a single telecast.
The Minnesota North Stars and the Detroit Red Wings are selling a few games via pay-per-view this season. While this marketing technique can generate quick profits on important games that are in demand, it also eliminates the casual fan who might be browsing through channels and does little to expand the base of fans for the sport.
David Stern, the commissioner of the National Basketball Association, said recently that his sport is discouraging pay-per-view marketing because it keeps the product away from large numbers of fans who might not have access to these viewing opportunities or might not be able to afford them. By contrast, Ziegler, has said repeatedly in recent years that his vision of the future is a "menu in the sky" by which viewers order specific hockey games on pay-per-view.
 
Increase After Merger
 The 2 percent dropoff in attendance that the league suffered last season was the first decline of that magnitude since the league merged with the World Hockey Association in 1979. Since that merger, attendance had generally increased almost every year, from 10.53 million in the first season of the 21-team league to a peak of 12.58 million in 1989-90.
This season, the N.H.L. admits a drop of 1 percent in ticket sales for October, when compared with the same period last season. (November figures will not be available until December. The figures do not include the San Jose Sharks, the expansion team, which has sold out all 10,888 seats at home in the Cow Palace.)
Business remains robust in many cities, particularly in the Western half of the league, where capacity or near-capacity crowds are still the rule in Los Angeles, Calgary, Edmonton, St. Louis, Detroit and Chicago.
While falling attendance would be of concern to any sports enterprise, the trend comes at an awkward time for the N.H.L., which says that between 60 and 65 percent of its revenue comes from ticket sales.
On one hand, the league is trying to negotiate a new collective-bargaining agreement with its Players Association. One of the owners' arguments is that they can't afford the increasing salaries of players, especially if loosening restrictions on free agency causes competitive bidding for labor to further raise wages.
On the other hand, the league is expanding from 21 to 28 teams during this decade. A plea of hard times could make it difficult to entice investors to spend $50 million for an expansion franchise in a gate-receipts league that is losing gate receipts.
But is the league losing gate receipts? Bob Goodenow, the new executive director of the Players Association, said attendance figures could be misleading if the income from rising ticket prices is greater than the money lost from tickets not sold. He said it is tricky to compare different markets so early in the season.
"You can have a huge increase in Minnesota and a huge decrease with the Islanders," Goodenow said. "One reflects a revived market and one reflects a polluted market."
Goodenow said he was cautious about "buying the party line" about box-office woes.
"You keep raising prices, you're going to have a tailoff," he said. "At what point do you hold your prices and try to make up revenues through increased attendance? Are the teams getting calls from people who say they just aren't going to games because they can't afford to?
"If hockey is not an affordable type of entertainment, it's obviously something the league and the players have to be concerned about."
The league office said that the average price of an N.H.L. ticket this season is $23, up from $21 last season. A league official, speaking on the condition of anonimity, said league ticket revenues were up about 5 percent in October compared with the same point last season.
Is affordability a problem? Top ticket prices for the Rangers and for the Los Angeles Kings are $65. San Jose charges $55 and Chicago $50. The Islanders' top price is $35 and the Devils' is $30. The cheapest of the high-end ticket prices is Minnesota's, at $28.50.
Jim Johnson, director of sales for the Islanders, said his team is selling tickets to students for half price for selected games. Johnson said he worries that high ticket prices are costing the league young fans.
 
'Attendance Is Miles Up'
 "People's income has not kept up with the cost of coming to a game," Johnson said. "If you don't have kids and younger people developing an identity with your product, that is your future. When we played over in New Jersey, they had 10,000 people there and 20 percent were for the Islanders. And the Devils are an entertaining team.
"People want to support their teams, but they can't afford it. Anybody in pro sports today who isn't concerned about their attendance five years from now is naive."
Not all executives are so pessimistic. Norman Green, owner of the Minnesota North Stars, said "our attendance is miles up" after his team reached the Stanley Cup finals last spring.
"Our average is up from around 6,000 to around 12,000," he said.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
In the Salary Standings, Mets Making Big Progress

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
The Mets next season will pay Bobby Bonilla, Dwight Gooden and Eddie Murray more money than either the Houston Astros or the Cleveland Indians paid their entire teams this year.
"They'll pay Murray and Bonilla just about more than I'll pay my whole team next year," John McMullen, the Astros' owner, said yesterday, obviously disgusted with the continued escalation of player salaries as exemplifed by the free-agent contracts the Mets have given Murray (two years, $7.5 million) and Bonilla (five years, $29 million). 
 Counting salary and a prorated share of their signing bonuses, Bonilla ($5.8 million), Gooden ($4.9 million) and Murray ($4.1 million) will earn a combined $14,841,667 in their first season as teammates. Only four years ago, in 1987, the Mets' total payroll didn't reach that amount.
Neither did the 1991 payrolls of the Astros and the Indians. Based on average salaries compiled by the Players Association and the Player Relations Committee and made available yesterday, the Astros had the lowest average in the major leagues and a payroll just shy of $11.5 million while the Indians were 25th in average and had a payroll just over $13.3 million.
In 1991, the Mets had the fourth highest average salary on both lists. The labor units of the players and the clubs treat certain payments differently so they compute different averages, with the Players Association almost always slightly higher than the Player Relations Committee.
 
A's Were at Top
 The Mets' average salary was $1,113,446 (players) or $1,106,875 (clubs). It was a club record, but it fell significantly behind the highest-ever average attained, by the Oakland Athletics, $1,394,119 (players) or $1,399,684 (clubs).
The major league average salary as computed by the Players Association was $851,492, a 42.5 percent increase over the 1990 average of $597,537. The average computed by the Players Relations Committee was $845,383, a 43.4 percent increase over the 1990 figure of $589,360. The only previous increase that was bigger came in 1977, the first season that followed the creation of free agency, when the average rose 47.7 percent from $51,501 to $76,066. Bonilla will earn more than that in three days next season.
The Athletics also had the highest average salary last year, but in 1989, it was the Mets who led the salary standings with an $865,741 average. They have taken strong steps to reclaim the No. 1 spot next year.
With Bonilla the richest player in baseball and Gooden and Murray set to earn more than $4 million in 1992, a plateau no one has ever attained in the game, the Mets will have at least five players beyond $3 million, including John Franco ($3,333,333) and Vince Coleman ($3,212,500). They all figure to be joined by David Cone, maybe even Frank Viola.
 
Still Hoping to Sign Viola?
 Al Harazin, the general manager responsible for the spurt of costly economic activity, has told people privately he plans to try to sign Viola, who last April rejected a three-year, $13 million offer. But the Mets have so far taken no steps to implement whatever plan Harazin might have in mind.
Cone, the National League strikeout leader the past two years, is not a free agent but can be after the 1992 season. This would be the time for the Mets to sign him to a multiyear contract, three years most likely, and it could cost them about $4 million a year to do it.
Other players scheduled to earn more than $2 million next year are Kevin McReynolds, Howard Johnson, Hubie Brooks, Sid Fernandez and Tim Burke.
The Mets will try to trade McReynolds to get the pitching help they need. They also won't mind shedding his $3,416,667 salary,
Also on his way out is Dave Magadan, who earned $1.25 million this year. It's not known what kind of trade value Brooks has left, but the Mets will try to send him away because they won't want to pay a pinch-hitter $2,316,667.
 
'Another Level'
 Late in the season the Mets talked to Johnson's agent, Jim Krivacs, about a possible contract extension. Johnson has one guaranteed year at $2,266,667 and an option year left.
"We kind of let it go after one meeting," Krivacs said. "It was just too close to this time of year. We wanted to see what Bonilla was doing. Obviously what happened yesterday sets some market value. When we talked, they looked at some of the top players in the game, but we knew we were probably going to another level and that has happened."
The Mets signed Coleman as a free agent a year ago because they had lost Darryl Strawberry as a free agent and they felt the need to fill the offensive void somehow. Before that four-year, $11.95 million signing, they basically eschewed the free-agent market, very occasionally signing a Bill Almon or a Mike Cubbage.
Now Harazin has changed the Mets' approach, spending lots of money on free agents and even departing from so-called club policy to give Bonilla five years.
"When you set out to get Bobby Bonilla in this circumstance," Harazin explained, "it was pretty obvious early on we weren't going to be successful unless we went to a fifth year. That was wrenching for us. But to get a player we wanted badly, we had to bite the bullet on the fifth year."
It was a silver bullet Harazin hopes will turn to gold.

HEADLINE: Can Yale, With Budget Troubles, Still Be Great?

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN

 BODY:
A few days after classes started last September, hundreds of Yale University students held a rally at Beinecke Plaza and ceremonially ate cake in mocking protest of a money-saving decision to end freshman dinner in the Commons dining hall, a move they said would cheapen the quality of life at Yale.
Today, such concerns pale in light of much deeper reductions under review at Yale. The university is running an $8.8 million deficit, its first deficit in 11 years, and financial projections for the coming decade are so bleak that Yale plans to reduce the scope of its scholarly endeavors by paring, and possibly eliminating, several academic departments, including linguistics, sociology and engineering. The specific cuts, under study for months, are expected to be made public in the next few weeks. 
 Adding to the campus tension are rancorous labor negotiations with non-teaching staff and a move by graduate students to form their own union. All in all, faculty members and students say they are apprehensive about the university's ability to support the standards of excellence it has worked almost 300 years to attain.
"The greatness of this university is at risk in the decisions we are now making," said Michael Holquist, a professor of comparative literature.
 
Anxiety Reflected Elsewhere
 Yale's anxiety reflects uneasiness on most college and university campuses, where changing finances are challenging standards of excellence. In essence, most colleges and universities, even the big, powerful and well-endowed ones like Yale, are being forced by budget problems to concede that they can no longer be all things to all people, their unspoken goal for decades.
Last month, a group of 26 professors at Columbia University protested further budget cuts in the arts and sciences by threatening to resign their positions as department chairmen. Washington University in St. Louis has eliminated its sociology department and its dental school. Stanford University in Palo Alto, Calif., Howard University in Washington and Tulane University in New Orleans are among the private institutions undergoing the equivalent of an intellectual CAT scan to assess their academic health. Big publicly supported universities like the University of California at Berkeley and the University of Oregon have also begun self-examinations.
The squeeze comes from reduced income from endowment investments and cutbacks in Federal spending for research contracts, on the one side, and on the other, from increased costs for maintenance of buildings, medical benefits for employees and financial aid for students.
Tuition -- averaging around $20,000 at many elite universities -- has hit a psychological ceiling beyond which it can be raised only by small increments, not enough to cover rising costs.
 
Position to Weather Storm
 There is no need to start passing the cup for Yale just yet. With its $2.6 billion endowment, its rich alumni -- like the Bass family of Fort Worth, who in the last year have donated $80 million -- and its elevated standing in American higher education, Yale is in a strong position to weather the coming decade.
In some ways, though, Yale is in a more difficult position than other major universities and under more pressure to reconcile its spending. Yale's singular problem is its urgent need to rebuild and repair buildings that until recently had been ignored.
Yale has 197 buildings spread over New Haven. Many are old, some of their roofs leak and most are energy-inefficient. Over the years, university officials tended to keep an ivory-tower view of expenditures. They put money into academic programs and generally left mundane matters like gutters, roofs and windows for another day.
Under A. Bartlett Giamatti, who served as president of Yale from 1978-86, the university began making some repairs. But now, the university plans to spend $1 billion over the next 10 years to renovate its physical self, allocating an increasing portion of its nearly $800 million annual budget to building repairs. Student and faculty critics do not dispute the need for such work, but say the administration may have overstated the case. At a series of crowded faculty meetings this semester, professors argued that Yale is swerving too far toward repairing its offices and classrooms, at the expense of academic pursuits.
"The decision to engage in a major program of deferred maintenance and new capital investments in structures is something that can be questioned," said Willem H. Buiter, professor of international economics. "We are substituting, as people put it, bricks for bodies, but I don't think the greatness of the university is measured by the quality of the bricks in its buildings."
But administrators, led by Benno C. Schmidt Jr., the 49-year-old president of Yale, insist that history will judge them harshly if they put off the needed repairs any longer.
Mr. Schmidt, who as long as two years ago was speaking about falling masonry and leaky pipes, is intent on adopting what he calls "a disciplined vision of excellence."
The cuts made so far, like the Commons dining schedule and elimination of the varsity wrestling and water polo teams, may affect the quality of undergraduate life in New Haven but few critics argue that they cut into Yale's academic standing.
But there has also been a 5 percent to 15 percent across-the-board reduction that has forced libraries to close earlier and some classes to grow. In the English department, for instance, the average size of discussion sections has grown to 25, as against 20 in previous years.
And, most critically, a committee of faculty and administrators has been working since last February on a complete self-examination of Yale, trying to lay out in detail the university's strengths and weaknesses, identifying its essential parts and targeting those that are expendable.
When the committee releases its report sometime in the next few weeks, it is expected to recommend the reduction and possibly the elimination of entire departments. Sociology, linguistics and engineering are rumored to be on a hit list. Other departments will also be asked not to fill faculty openings, or otherwise to shrink.
After hearing the committee's recommendations, the president, the provost and the deans will decide, probably early next year, which changes will be made.
 
A Big Gamble
 Mr. Schmidt admits that Yale is taking a big gamble. "I am very much aware that, yes, there is an inescapable risk of making decisions that in the light of the evolution of knowledge in the future may be short-sighted," he said in an interview in his office just off Beinecke Plaza.
Rushing from one set of meetings to another, he looked haggard but he forcefully argued that Yale had to change. "To do nothing also is to take a great risk that could lead to creeping mediocrity," he said.
Although there are few signs of turmoil on the New Haven campus, the student paper, The Yale Daily News, is filled almost daily with the latest rumors about the restructuring committee's secret work.
"The talk at all the dining room tables is that the university is changing, and not for the better," said Michelle Maldonado, a junior from Puerto Rico who is majoring in psychology. "It's a little depressing."
Kyu B. L. Rhee, president of the Yale College Council, the undergraduate student government, is angry because students have been left off the restructuring committee and effectively closed out of that important process. Faculty, too, have been suspicious; many point out that the committee contains no representatives from the departments of sociology, linguistics or engineering.
"We're apprehensive," said Laurence Horn, chairman of the linguistics department. "We're not entirely certain that the decisions are being made with the full knowledge of what these programs contribute to the university."
Some members of the faculty are uneasy with the administration's message that Yale can no longer afford to be all things to all people and must become smaller.
"Simply being smaller," said Gaddis Smith, a professor of history and director of the Center for International and Area Studies, "in itself is not exactly a vision of greatness."
One member of the restructuring committee, Donald M. Engelman, said that all those concerned were being careful to remain objective.
"It's a very tough business," said Professor Engelman, chairman of the molecular biophysics and biochemistry department who will be filling in as dean of Yale College next year. He said the committee was considering several options, including eliminating departments when current faculty members leave or retire, which would avoid the need for layoffs, or merging two departments for greater efficiency. "The hope is that we will end up being not less excellent but less ambitious in scope," he said.
 
Protest Planned
 Yale's turmoil is further complicated by the expiration, on Jan. 17, of its contract with more than 3,500 clerical and technical employees and by attempts by graduate students to form their own union. To make their point, graduate students planned a protest for today in which about 1,000 of the 2,000 graduate students will refuse to teach their classes.
The rumors and the angry confrontations have made Yale a turbulent place this year. But there is a growing sense that this is an important moment in Yale's history and that the intensive self-examination will lead to a university that will be either stronger or weaker, but certainly different.
Perhaps no one is more aware of this than Mr. Schmidt, whose reputation as president may be determined by the outcome. He has considered the possibility that, if his calculations are wrong, and his decisions not the right ones, he could be known as the president who loosened Yale's grip on excellence.
"I'd much rather take that risk," he said, "than instead to preside over a kind of slow deterioration of the excellence of this place."

HEADLINE: In Arctic, Warm Reunion Ends Cold War Division

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KOTZEBUE, Alaska, Dec. 1

 BODY:
Last August, six wooden boats carrying residents of Uelen, at the northeastern tip of the Chukchi Peninsula in the Soviet Far East, sailed across the Bering Sea into this northwestern Alaskan port that is home to about 2,700 Eskimos.
The Chukchi passengers came to attend a trade fair and sell some of their coveted scrimshaw and other art works. But, said Yuri Tototto, a former deputy of the region, sometimes called Chukotka, to the Congress of Peoples Deputies in Moscow who is director of the Association of Chukotka Native Businesses, every third or fourth Chukchi ended up discovering an Alaskan relative. 
 "It was one big family gathering," Mr. Tototto said. He visited Kotzebue (pronounced COTS-eh-boo) again this weekend, this time to sign a formal agreement of cultural cooperation with Alaskan Eskimos that is expected to bring the long-isolated Soviet Chukchi further into the global mainstream.
"We're one people, one culture, one tradition," said Nina Vaal, the Chukotka region's minister for culture and native affairs, who also signed the documents.
The two main ethnic groups in Chukotka are the Chukchi and Eskimos, but a long history of intermarriage has blended the two.
On the Alaskan side, the chief groups are Inupiat and Yupik.
 
A Long History
 From both sides Eskimos crossed back and forth over the Bering Sea by kayak or over the ice for centuries. In the 18th and 19th centuries, activities of the Russian-American Trading Company, a czarist fur trading entity similar to the Hudson's Bay Company, further stimulated exchanges between these nomadic peoples.
Then in the late 1920's the Soviets consolidated their empire in the Far East, patrolling the international date line and creating an "ice curtain" that is only now starting to melt.
Under the new accord, the Chukotka region is joining Alaskans and other people in northern Canada, Greenland and Scandinavia in sponsoring an international exhibition that will give greater exposure to the artists from the Chukchi Peninsula and provide for even more exchanges with their counterparts in Alaska.
"It removes them from the forgotten status and helps close the circumpolar loop," said Noel J. Brown, North American regional director of the United Nations Environment Program, one of the backers of the exhibition.
The purpose is to show how the 40,000 natives of the 2.5 million square miles of Arctic Circle country harmonize life and art with the flow of nature.
The weekend developments, in which the two Chukotka officials met with leaders here and toured Alaskan Eskimo villages to examine art works, follow an agreement two years ago between President Bush and the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, to allow the native people to travel across the Bering Sea without passports and other bureaucratic formalities.
The thawing of the "ice curtain" has also meant more exchanges in the performing arts. The Kotzebue Northern Light Dancers, who swing arms and pound feet to the beat of drums made from caribou bladders, now have their ranks increased by Soviet Eskimo dancers and drummers from Uelen and Lavrentiya.
Kotzebue radio station KOTZ has become one of the main sources of news for the Soviet Chukchi. It broadcasts Russian-language current events programs twice a week, and Natalie Novik, one of the broadcasters, said the station "has gotten word that the shows are heard 700 miles up the Soviet Far East coast." She added, "There are probably more listeners to this than anything else the station does."
The international exhibition that will give the artists from the Siberian Far East greater exposure is an itinerant show called "Masters of the Arctic," first shown at the United Nations in New York in 1989, that and which heads next year for Mexico City, Rio de Janeiro and Buenos Aires. It receives its main financing unding from the Amway Environmental Foundation, created by the Amway Corporation of Ada, Mich., which sells cleansing and health-care products in more than 50 countries.
The exhibition curator, Christopher D. Stephens, who has just been appointed Lindsey Fellow of Indigenous Studies at Fitzwilliam College, Cambridge, called the Chukchi participation a "remarkable development signaling not only the cultural pride but economic aspirations of this indigenous people."
 
'Share Common Goals'
 He noted that it marked a "new indigenous world order in which governments and private corporations together with circumpolar native peoples share common goals that would have been unthinkable a few years ago."
The region of Chukotka will work closely under the accord with the Northwest Alaskan Native Association, a regional cooperative organized under the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act of 1971 to guide the economic life of this region.
The association's 4,800 members, almost all Inupiat Eskimos, share in the profits not only of village artistic creation but a wide range of other communal projects, like the Red Dog gold and zinc mine northeast of here and oilfield and food services.
Mr. Tototto said he wants to organize Chukotka along similar lines. What attracts him most about the association's structure, he said, is that "it breaks down the walls of bureaucracy and puts the people in greater control."
Although many of those who live north of the Arctic Circle are known as Eskimos, the term, which roughly means "eaters of raw meat," is considered pejorative in some regions -- though not in Alaska or Siberia.
International organizations and others are increasingly substituting the neutral word Inuit, which broadly means "people."
The meeting here brought former cold war antagonists together. John Schaeffer, a former chairman of the association, had been a major general in the Alaska National Guard. Mr. Tototto served as a commando captain in the Soviet Army Polar Brigade.
But now that is all past. Mr. Schaeffer's son Pete, a vice president of the association, said during the ceremonies that the organization "looks forward very much to cooperating with the Soviet Chukchi."
David Swan from Kivalina, a village northwest of here on the coast, said he thinks the new cooperation is great.
 
Snow-Quilted Houses
 Mr. Swan, a hunter, fisherman and local political leader whose uncle, Clinton Swan, carves ivory and weaves baleen baskets, added: "After 40 years we have relations on both sides that we would like to find out about. This will help everyone."
Kotzebue, the association's headquarters and the urban center for all the villages in the northwest region of Alaska, is a patchwork of snow-quilted wooden houses at the mouth of three rivers, the Noatak, Kobuk and Selawik that drain into Kotzebue Sound. In summer, Kotzebue is a transit point from sea to the hinterland.
In early December, the main activity is generated by snowmobiles either racing for sport on five-foot-thick sea ice or returning from inland hunting trips pulling sled loads of reindeer and caribou carcases.
Though many residents still keep dogs, the snowmobiles, which can cover larger swaths of territory faster than dog teams, have become the preferred mode of transport.
Some of the bigger buildings incorporate spiral refrigeration devices to prevent the permafrost from melting beneath the structures. In Siberia, the bigger structures sit on pilings to avoid melting the top layer of tundra.
Looking at the Alaskan Eskimo homes, Mrs. Vaal, the Chukotka minister of culture, observed: "We have problems in our villages. We need to build new houses."
Asked about the snowmobiles, she said, "Oh, yes, we could use these."

HEADLINE: Sununu as Symbol;
Departure of Embattled Chief of Staff Removes Convenient Target of Critics

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3

 BODY:
By at least indirectly soliciting and then promptly accepting John H. Sununu's resignation, President Bush sought today to halt his slide in the opinion polls, to mute criticism of his domestic and economic policies or lack thereof, and to clear the decks at last for his re-election campaign.
For all Mr. Sununu's reputed arrogance and abrasiveness, for all his carelessness about appearances, even his bitterest enemies conceded that the chief of staff was not responsible for all of the manifold ills that have plagued Mr. Bush recently. But symbols often have to suffice when substantive change is too difficult or too slow in coming, and scapegoats are useful symbols to troubled Presidents. 
 Mr. Sununu was a convenient target. His retention would have attracted continuing criticism to his boss. As he himself said, he "knew the rules of the game" when he came here: the last thing a White House chief of staff can be is "a political burden," a reverse lightning rod that exposes rather than insulates the President.
So he has gone the way of Sherman Adams and H. R. Haldeman and Donald T. Regan, all jettisoned when the Presidents whose doors they guarded got into trouble. In a nearly perfect piece of historical symmetry, Mr. Sununu's resignation was announced in Meridian, Miss.; Mr. Haldeman resigned just after Richard M. Nixon returned from a trip to the same city.
 
An Impression of Disarray
 Like Mr. Bush's hasty decision to postpone a trip to the Far East, the departure of Mr. Sununu may at first contribute to the impression of an Administration in disarray. His departure had long been rumored, but it came suddenly; the chief of staff's defenders were caught badly off balance, with Congressional backers urging that he be retained at a news conference only this morning.
But Mr. Sununu's departure is likely to lead to other changes, including the selection of leading figures in the Bush campaign, that may benefit the President. That had been complicated by Mr. Sununu's efforts to maintain at least partial control of the re-election bid and the resulting antipathy of rival party strategists.
"I'm sure the President will pick a successor shortly," said Charles Black, a Republican consultant who is expected to play a central role in the campaign. "Surely, the campaign team will not be very far behind."
Whether Mr. Bush will achieve his long-term goals by replacing Mr. Sununu will of course depend in part on whom he chooses as a successor and how well that person does.
 
Problems With Conservatives
 Clearly, the change creates some problems for Mr. Bush with the most conservative elements of his party, who looked to Mr. Sununu as their leading voice in the Administration's inner circles. They want a conservative as chief of staff, and set about immediately to let the President know it.
"As far as conservatives are concerned," said Richard Viguerie, a leading conservative fund-raiser and spokesman, "George Bush is hanging by a thread. If he makes the wrong choice at this critical time, the Bush campaign will sink like a stone."
Representative Dick Armey, a Texas Republican who has been loudly critical of Mr. Bush recently, said: President Bush needs to regain control of his Administration. The President needs sound, conservative advice on politics and economics."
Mr. Bush cannot afford at the moment to dismiss such threats out of hand. Conservatives played a leading role in his 1988 successes, and he faces a possible primary challenge next year from Patrick J. Buchanan, the conservative columnist.
 
Skinner Is the Favorite
 But within the Republican mainstream, the longing is for someone who can effectively deal with Capitol Hill, with party professionals around the country and with the Government's major departments, all of whom Mr. Sununu often irritated and in some cases alienated. Unity and effectiveness, as one strategist said, "will re-elect Bush and elect more Republicans to the Congress."
Most said they favored someone like Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner or Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, who served as the White House chief of staff under President Gerald R. Ford. Mr. Skinner was described by a senior White House official tonight as "the all-but-certain choice."
Senator Alan K. Simpson, a Wyoming Republican who has been one of the President's leading confidants in the last three years, said: "People are waiting for someone to do something. There's a whole lot that needs to be done in this country."
But that will require policy initiatives, especially to combat the persistent recession, as well as shifts in personnel and attitude. Democrats were quick to note this, and will undoubtedly hammer away at the point in the weeks and months to come.
"This move will not improve the eceonmy by one iota," said Gov. L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia, a candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination.
 
Focusing on New Hampshire
 After Mr. Bush has named his campaign team, he will have to come to grips with the question of what he is going to propose by way of economic stimulus next month in his State of the Union Message, which looks as if it may become a kind of unofficial Republican manifesto for the 1992 campaign. The new chief of staff will undoubtedly play a leading part in those deliberations, which will seek to find a way to keep the Democrats from claiming with credibility that they have become the last best hope of the hard-pressed middle class.
The President will also have to begin focusing on New Hampshire, where Mr. Buchanan apparently intends to launch his challenge. The economy in that state has been devastated by the recession, and the Republican Party there is seriously fragmented, with pro- and anti-Sununu factions dating to his years as Governor.
The hope of winning support from both factions is surely one reason that Mr. Bush said Mr. Sununu would remain as a White House adviser through March 1, nearly two weeks after the New Hampshire primary.
None of this will be made easier by the transition that now must take place at the very apex of the Administration. But the holiday season gives Mr. Bush some breathing room, and he clearly felt that he had no choice but to act.

HEADLINE: Chief U.S. Economist Forecasts a Recovery in Spring

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3

 BODY:
In what could be a preview of the Bush Administration's testimony to Congress about the economy later this week, the chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers acknowledged today that the economy was worse than he had expected early this year, but he said he foresaw improvement by spring.
Speaking at a conference here sponsored by the Agriculture Department, the official, Michael J. Boskin, offered no new proposals and suggested that President Bush would withhold initiatives on the economy until his State of the Union Message next month. 
 The general forecast, Mr. Boskin said, is that the economy will be "somewhat more sluggish this quarter and next than previously thought, and picking up thereafter."
 
3 Officials to Testify
 Mr. Boskin, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady and Richard G. Darman, the White House budget director, are scheduled to testify on Thursday before the House Ways and Means Committee about tax policy and the state of the economy.
That is the first day of a series of hearings called by Congressional Democrats to draw political attention to the weakness of the economy and to their view that the solutions put forward so far by the Administration are insufficient and would mostly help the the wealthy.
Until last week, the Administration's basic approach was to sit tight and let the recession take care of itself. But just before Congress adjourned, Mr. Bush endorsed a set of tax breaks put forward by conservative House Republicans to give the economy a jolt.
The Democrats responded immediately, brandishing tables as evidence that the main beneficiaries of the Republican measures would be taxpayers earning more than $200,000 a year. At the same time, the Democrats began pressing harder for their own proposals, which they said would provide "middle-class tax relief."
All that will be hashed out at the hearings, although no legislation is likely until next year.
 
Bush to Discuss Economy
 Mr. Bush himself is scheduled to give a speech on the economy Wednesday to the American Enterprise Institute, a research center here, but the White House advised that the speech would break little new ground, if any.
Today the President visited Mississippi and Florida in an effort to rehabilitate his standing in public opinion polls, and everything seemed designed to show that a politician who has spent years battling his prep-school-and-golf image is in touch with everyday concerns: his rolled-up blue shirt sleeves, the factory worker who introduced him to a crowd in Florida, his oft-repeated assurances that he understands the plight of the unemployed, hard-pressed small-business people and typical Americans.
Speaking of the economic troubles of many workers, he told a small crowd at a Tropicana orange and grapefruit juice plant in Bradenton, Fla.: "I do understand. And I am concerned. And I really want to help."
"Much more needs to be done," he declared, without saying exactly what he had in mind. "We can't sit back and hope for the best."
Mr. Boskin, the Administration's top professional economist, has more or less previously made the points he made in his speech today, but they took on new significance because the economy has become such a central topic politically.
His thesis is that unavoidable "external shocks" like the rise in oil prices that followed Iraq's invasion of Kuwait pushed the country into a mild recession last year. "A modest recovery began in the spring," Mr. Boskin said, but in the last two or three months, "the recovery has turned quite a bit more sluggish."
He said he thought the most recent average forecast of 50 prominent private economists collected by Blue Chip Economic Indicators, that the economy would grow by 1.9 percent in the current calendar quarter, was probably too optimistic, and he cautioned that it would be some time before the economy returned to the level of mid-1990, just before the recession began.
Furthermore, Mr. Boskin said, economic growth is being hampered by a lack of available credit, by tax increases and spending cuts by state and local governments, by the longer-than-usual lag in time before cuts in interest rates work their way through the economy and by the fact that the large budget deficit makes a fiscal stimulus inappropriate.
But he said he saw "opportunities for upside potential." Banks, he said, will someday soon begin to lend more readily, lower interest rates will begin to have a broad effect on the economy, growth abroad will lead to more exports, and the lean state of inventories will cause the economy to pick up quickly as soon as there is an increase in consumer demand. In addition, Mr. Boskin said, the current low rate of inflation is an encouraging sign.

HEADLINE: Ban on Race-Exclusive Scholarships Is Expected

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3

 BODY:
After a seven-month review, Education Secretary Lamar Alexander is expected to issue regulations on Wednesday that ban race-exclusive scholarships for college students, Administration officials said.
A similar position, taken last December by Michael L. Williams, Assistant Secretary for civil rights at the Education Department, raised a firestorm of protest by colleges and universities and civil rights groups. They argued that such a policy would undermine minority participation in higher education. 
 Under the rules to be issued Wednesday, race could still be used as one factor in awarding scholarships in order to achieve diversity on college campuses, but not the only factor, said the officials, who insisted on anonymity. Campus diversity could be achieved, they say, without considering race but by considering factors like geographic origin, cultural or economic disadvantages, or specific talents.
 
Rescinding of Ban
 Mr. Williams, who argued that race-exclusive scholarships violated Title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, would have completely banned such scholarships except those being used under court desegregation orders.
Mr. Alexander rescinded Mr. Williams's ruling in April, saying he wanted the issue to be studied further.
Different drafts of the new proposed ruling, first reported in The Washington Post today, have been circulating within the Department of Education and the Justice Department and it is still unclear how scholarships given by private donors and designated specifically for minorities would be treated.
One proposal would permit colleges to accept private donations designated for minority scholarships as long as white students would have the opportunity to compete for similar financial assistance. Another proposal would permit race-exclusive scholarships as long as they were not administered by the college or university; a student would instead apply for and receive such financial aid directly from the private donor, then use the funds to pay for college fees.
Robert Atwell, president of the American Council on Education, an association of colleges and universities, said he would withhold any reaction to the ban until he had seen the specific details.
But Representative Ted Weiss, a Manhattan Democrat who is chairman of the Subcommittee on Human Resources and Intergovernmental Relations, said, "This proposed rule is the same misguided policy the department attempted last year."
"Despite the sugar coating," he said, "the Administration continues to deny the legality of race-specific scholarships and the economic hardships faced by minority students who suffer from the remnants of discrimination. It is another example of the Administration's blind spot on civil rights."
Scholarships based on race in combination with other factors, like financial need or a student's grades or special talents, would still be permitted.
Phyllis McClure, an official of the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund, said: "Based on what we know, we believe these scholarships were legal. There is only one thing that has changed, and that is use of the race issue for political reasons."
Before Mr. Williams issued the rescinded policy last year, the Education Department permitted race-specific scholarships as a way to increase minority student participation, to remedy past discrimination and underrepresentation and to achieve Congressionally mandated goals.
Race-specific scholarships would continue to be allowed under the new policy if institutions are under court-ordered desegregation or state-mandated orders. Congressional scholarships targeted for minorities would also continue.
Mr. Alexander, who was in Louisville, Ky., today released a statement through the Education Department here reassuring the higher education officials that "no student will lose a scholarship under the principles we are about to announce."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Education Secretary Lamar Alexander is expected to issue regulations today on banning scholarships based exclusively on race. (The New York Times)
