HEADLINE: High Interest Holds Up House of Credit Cards

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "The Senate's Credit Card Blunder" (editorial, Nov. 20), you join those denouncing efforts to reduce interest rates on credit cards. Amazingly, in the public debate over whether or not to cap interest rates on bank and retail credit cards, there seems little acknowledgment that interest rates on credit cards are too high now and have been too high for a decade. 
 The banks, joined by most editorial boards, have turned the credit card debate around, to portray banks and retailers as needing sympathy, while those who have been calling for restraint on credit card interest rates are termed irresponsible.
The issue is not whether or not any particular cap should be applied to interest rates on credit cards. Instead, we need to question why those interest rates are, in many instances, triple the prime rate of most lending institutions. Indeed, as the prime rate has decreased over a decade, interest on some credit cards -- especially those of retailers -- has actually increased. A recent study by the New York State Consumer Protection Board and the New York City Department of Consumer Affairs shows that while the cost of money to most banks has dropped from a high of 15 percent in 1981 to 4 1/2 percent in November 1991, credit card interest rates have averaged approximately 19 percent without any significant reduction in the same period.
Some major retailers have increased interest rates on their store cards since last Christmas despite the decline in all other interest rates. For example, Bloomingdale's now charges 21.6 percent, up from 18 percent; Macy's increased its rate to 21.6 percent from 19.8 percent. How anyone can justify these actions is beyond comprehension.
While we can question the appropriateness of a specific cap on interest rates, most banks and retailers have failed to heed the call for a voluntary reduction of excessive interest charges on credit cards. And, while you talk about credit card competition, a majority of consumers face little choice when it comes to available credit. Most banks who have credit cards with low interest rates do not make them available to the large majority of consumers whose credit records are only satisfactory or worse. Furthermore, your attempt to blame the recession for the slow fall in credit card interest rates lacks merit, considering that these rates have not really fallen for the last 10 years.
You made one acknowledgment that most critics of cap proposals fail to make. Credit card interest rates are excessive because the profits from them are being used to offset bad loans by banks and poor business decisions by retailers. Why should middle class consumers bail out banks and retailers through their credit card purchases?
Advocates for low credit card interest rates do not contend that banks and retailers should not be able to earn a profit or cover costs through interest rates. And I have never seen it argued that credit card interest rates should equal the prime or discount rate. We ask that credit card interest rates fairly reflect economic conditions and that they be flexible and competitive. Today's rates are neither.
 
RICHARD M. KESSEL
Executive Director
State Consumer Protection Board
New York, Nov. 22, 1991

HEADLINE: High Interest Holds Up House of Credit Cards;
Curbing Usury

 BODY:
To the Editor:
A ceiling on credit card interest is a very conservative idea. The usury laws were the first consumer protection laws. New Jersey's general usury law has been in effect since English colonial times. Usury laws are a centuries-old tradition because they have always been needed to protect people from interest gouging. 
 In contrast, the last decade has seen a radical experiment in which lenders were generally free to raise their rates. That experiment proved that when a few institutions control 175 million credit cards (as the chart in your Nov. 20 editorial shows), credit card interest prices do not rise and fall with economic trends.
A floating usury ceiling embodies the same economic principle as the adjustable rate mortgage. What's fair for the banks to charge should also be the limit on what they charge.
Congress had the right idea about a floating ceiling, but caved in to bank pressure. While consumers wait for a reasonable law, they should reward the smaller banks that lend at low rates. For a free list of banks offering rates of 9.5 percent to 15 percent, consumers may send a stamped, self-addressed business envelope to the Consumers League of New Jersey (60 South Fullerton Avenue, Montclair, N.J. 07042).
 
NEIL J. FOGARTY
President, Consumers League of N.J.
Montclair, N.J., Nov. 27, 1991

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Using the Recession As a Selling Tool

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
Grace & Rothschild, New York, is using the recession as a selling pitch for its client Range Rover vehicles.
 "Buy something," is the headline of a print advertisement scheduled to appear in USA Today and other publications starting next Tuesday. The ad goes on: "Our preference, of course, would be that you buy a Range Rover. But if that's not in the cards, buy a microwave. A basset hound. Theater tickets. Because if we all wait for the recession to be officially declared over to start spending again, the problem will simply keep feeding on itself." 
The ad was not completely selfless, said Roy Grace, the agency's chairman. "It's a fresh way to reach potential buyers," he said, "by shaking them up and bringing them a little bit closer to making a purchase."

HEADLINE: Cuomo Seems Closer to Decision on Running for President

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Dec. 3

 BODY:
Although classically cryptic, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo seemed to be accelerating toward a decision today on entering the Presidential race as he backed away from the notion that he needed a state budget solution to run. He said he would like to compete in the New Hampshire primary but would not have to. And he cast himself as an underdog despite polls that show him as the front-runner among Democratic contenders.
 Mr. Cuomo, who said in October that he would have to make such a decision by the end of November, entered December by suggesting that he would announce his plans in time to meet the Dec. 20 filing deadline for the New Hampshire primary. 
If you want to run in the primary in New Hampshire, which I would want to, then that's a date," Mr. Cuomo said this morning on "Good Day New York" on WNYW-TV. At a news conference later, however, he said that while skipping the New Hampshire primary would be a "disadvantage," it would "not necessarily" preclude him from running.
 The Feb. 18 primary is the first in the nation and traditionally has served as a barometer of political strength.
 
Scoring Well in Polls
 The latest polls show that Mr. Cuomo would be a heavy favorite in the Democratic primary there, as around the country. A poll conducted from Nov. 15 to 22 by the American Research Group, for example, found that Mr. Cuomo was favored by 31 percent of the New Hampshire Democrats surveyed while his closest prospective competitor, Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa, was favored by 6 percent. The poll had a margin of error of plus or minus 5 percentage points.
 But Mr. Cuomo tried strenuously today to diminish the high expectations set by such polls. The Governor, who feels his scrappy, combative style is best suited to an underdog campaign, argued that he would be "starting from way behind" because of the organizational problems associated with a late entry.
 "I am already falling behind everybody else," Mr. Cuomo said. "They have their speeches down pat. They have their fund-raisers. They've hired their consultants. They have their line of logic. They even have their negatives in place, some of them, attacking other candidates. I haven't done any of that."
 In fact, Mr. Cuomo has done much of that. He may not have hired a staff, but the Governor has spent more than 18 months honing a critique of the Bush Administration's domestic policy and formulating his own proposals for stimulating economic growth.
 
Themes Being Tested
 He has tested his themes and strategy in recent conversations with business leaders like H. Ross Perot, Democratic Party figures like Ethel Kennedy and Gary Hart, and political consultants like John Sasso, David Garth and Ann Lewis.
 Mr. Cuomo may not have a Presidential fund-raising committee, but his campaign treasury holds close to $4 million, and his aides estimate that about $1 million of it could be used under Federal rules as seed money for a national race. "I know just from the people who have asked me to run that we could get the money," Mr. Cuomo said in an interview 10 days ago,
 And while most of the Governor's invective has been aimed at President Bush's Administration, he has also found time to criticize some of his potential Democratic opponents. He recently referred to a college-loan proposal by one of them, Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, as "a lot of baloney."
 Aides to several of the announced candidates could not stifle laughter when hearing that Mr. Cuomo was positioning himself as an underdog.
 
Name Recognition
 "Some of what he says is true," said Lorraine Voles, a spokeswoman for Mr. Harkin's campaign. "These candidates have been out there. But he does have the advantage of incredible name recognition from -- what is it -- six weeks of uninterrupted press coverage of his decision-making process."
 It actually has been seven and a half weeks since Mr. Cuomo first disclosed on Oct. 11 that he would think about the 1992 Presidential race. Since then, he has taken the position that the only obstacles to his candidacy are posed by the fiscal problems afflicting the state and New York City.
 Mr. Cuomo is negotiating with the State Legislature to close an $875 million gap in this year's $30 billion budget. A gap of nearly $4 billion is projected for the fiscal year that begins on April 1.
 At various points during the last month, Mr. Cuomo has seemed close to ruling out a Presidential campaign because of the inability to find a quick solution to the state and city budget problems. In explaining that he was feeling pressure to make a decision soon, he told reporters in Buffalo on Nov. 18: "If you have to rush your decision and I don't have a budget solution, then I would have to say, 'No.' "
 But when asked today whether he could run without resolving the state's budget problems, he said, "I never said resolve them. To say, well, you have to wait to resolve the budget means that you could never run because the budget won't be resolved until next April, if you do it on time. What I've said is I have to be sure that my running for President won't make it more difficult, won't make it worse for the state."
 
'A Great Flood'
 As he has throughout his deliberative process, Mr. Cuomo then constructed a rationale both for running and for not running. He began by saying the problems of the states and the cities have their source in Washington.
 "This is a great flood and it happened at the dam," he said. "There is no point in putting sandbags here. You've got to stop it at the dam. That's one logic.
 "The other logic is in the meantime I've got to get the sandbags up because New York City and New York State are in trouble. I don't want to bore you with how complicated it gets, but that is the essential tension."

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Tax-Exempt Funds Post A Slight Increase in Yields

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH M. FOWLER

 BODY:
Yields on tax-exempt money market funds tended to rise a little during the last week, but yields on taxable money market funds showed a moderate decline, according to IBC/ Donoghue's, which monitors the funds and issues The Money Fund Report.
"We would expect the tax-exempt yields to rise a little during the short term because of the heavy supply of municipal bond offerings coming to market," said Walter S. Frank, chief economist for IBC/Donoghue's. He said many municipalities were rushing to issue securities before the year ended. 
 The declining yields in taxable funds, he said, still partly reflected the easing of monetary policy by the Federal Reserve a month ago.
 
Economist's Expectations
 "We would expect to see a further decline in yields," Mr. Frank said, "although we are coming into the season when there are short-term rises in yields because of the squeeze on short-term funds at year-end due to window-dressing by institutions hoping to improve the look of their balance sheets."
He said total assets of the tax-exempt funds dropped by $312 million, to $91.5 billion. The average days to maturity of holdings in tax-exempt portfolios remained unchanged at 58.
The seven-day compound average yield for tax-exempt funds was 3.80 percent, up 6 basis points from the previous week. The seven-day simple yield for the tax-exempt funds rose to 3.73 percent, also up 6 basis points. A basis point is one-hundredth of 1 percent.
The 30-day compound yield did not reflect the short-term rise. It declined to 3.79 percent, from 3.83 percent the previous week. The 30-day simple yield also showed a drop, moving down to 3.72 percent from 3.76 percent.
Among tax-exempt funds investing in individual state securities, the top New York fund was once again the Salomon Brothers New York Municipal Money Market Fund, which had a seven-day compound yield of 4.44 percent, down 2 basis points from 4.46 percent last week.
In Connecticut, the leader was the Prudential Connecticut Municipal Money Market Fund, with a yield of 4.16 percent, compared with 4.10 percent last week.
 
Tops in New Jersey
 In New Jersey, the best showing was made by Calvert Tax Free Reserve New Jersey, with a seven-day compound yield of 4.35 percent, about 5 basis points higher than the top fund last week.
The highest-yielding tax-exempt fund among those with assets greater than $100 million continued to be the Strong Municipal Money Market Fund, with a seven-day compound yield of 4.83 percent, up 4 basis points from last week.
Assets of taxable funds, Mr. Frank said, dropped $1.7 billion, to $472.5 billion. "Of that, $800 million came from institutional investors," he said. "This presumably was a reflow back into the stock and bond markets." There has been a steady flow of money out of money market funds, as individual investors seek higher returns, with many of them switching to stock and bond funds.
 
Maturities Decline
 The average days to maturity of the taxable funds was 62 days, down one day.
The seven-day compound yield on taxable funds dropped 4 basis points, to 4.77 percent, while the seven-day simple yield for the taxable funds dropped to 4.66 percent, also a decline of 4 basis points.
Meanwhile, the average compound 30-day yield fell to 4.86 percent, down from 4.94 percent, and the 30-day simple yield fell to 4.75 percent, off 7 basis points.
The top-yielding fund for the week among the taxables continued to be Riverside Capital of Columbus, Ohio, with a seven-day compound yield of 5.96 percent compared with 6.00 percent last week.
By comparison, bank money market accounts, a main competitor of money funds, dropped to a yield of 4.65 percent, from 4.70 percent a week earlier, according to The Bank Rate Monitor's national index.

HEADLINE: THE LAST U.S. HOSTAGE;
From Iran to U.S., a Hint of Good Will

BYLINE: ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Dec. 4

 BODY:
The release of Terry Anderson closes a painful, eight-year chapter of America's experience with hostage taking in Lebanon and removes the most serious obstacle to an improvement in the relationship between Washington and Teheran.
Throughout the period when Americans were held hostage by Iranian-backed groups in Lebanon -- even during the ill-fated deals to exchange arms for hostages -- United States policy was to keep Iran at arms length, resolved that there could be no fundamental change in Washington's attitude until the last American went free. 
 It now seems evident that the freeing of all the American hostages in Lebanon and the reported deal to let the remaining two Germans go free soon came at the initiative of Iran, which in recent months has repeatedly stated its desire to broaden its economic and political contacts with the West.
The Iranians knew that their welcome in the West awaited the release of the remaining hostages, since it had long been established that the radical Shiite Muslim groups holding the Westerners in Lebanon were financially and spirtually linked to Iran.
 
Bush Is Cautious
 Whatever his ultimate plans for dealing with Iran, President Bush reacted cautiously today. He praised the United Nations, Syria, Iran and Lebanon for their help in freeing the hostages, but noted that the story was not over. Two German hostages are still being held in Lebanon, Arabs and Palestinians are being held by Israel, and information about hostages and prisoners who may have died in captivity has yet to be supplied.
When asked about a possible resumption in relations between the United States and Iran, Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, equivocated in statements that reflected the Administration's ambivalence toward Teheran. "It's impossible to define the future," he replied, but then cited Mr. Bush's inaugural pledge to Iran that "Good will begets good will." Then he qualified the remark, adding that the Teheran Government has not divorced itself from state-supported terrorism. "Nevertheless, they are still a terrorist state and there's still no change in that," he said.
 
U.S. Ambivalence
 This ambivalence was evident in recent American dealings with Iran. Two weeks ago, the United States paid Iran $278 million for undelivered Iranian-owned, American-made arms that had been prevented from being shipped to Iran after the fall of the Shah in 1979. But also, in recent months, the United States has blocked the sale of British-made planes built with American components to Iran and urged India not to build a nuclear plant for Iran.
Iran was allowed to sell limited amounts of its oil to American companies, but only to help fund a special escrow account at The Hague used to pay American claims stemming from Iran's seizure of the United States Embassy in Teheran in 1979. A number of European governments have declined to sign large projects with Iran, a situation that Iranian officials attributed to American spoiling.
The assassination of a former Iranian Prime Minister, Shahpur Bakhtiar, in Paris this year, the slaying of other Iranian opposition figures around the world, and the death order for the author Salman Rushdie, which Teheran has refused to lift after the death of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, all contribute to keeping Iran on the State Department's list of countries that support terrorism. But inclusion on the terrorism list does not always mean much more than a number of bothersome economic sanctions.
Syria also remains on the list, yet the Government of President Hafez al-Assad has won praise from Washington for its part in the American-organized alliance against Iraq during the Persian Gulf war and in the American-sponsored Middle East peace talks.
Iran still has "several hundred" revolutionary guards in Lebanon and still finances some of the Muslim fundamentalist groups linked to the captors, American intelligence officials say.
Amid the rejoicing, there also remains an unease that Middle Eastern terrorism is by no means over. There is no certainty that another group, at another time, will not snatch another Westerner from the Beirut streets. Assessments by counterterrorist experts in various agencies of the Bush Administration range from cautious optimism that the groups that held the hostages for so long will now turn to more productive projects to outright cynicism that the political situation in the region may unleash an even more virulent strain of freelance terrorism.
 
A Major Victory
 Nevertheless, today's release represents a major victory: for the United Nations, whose months of quiet, often daring negotiations have paid off; for Iran, whose global image as a reliable political and economic partner is improved; and for the United States, which can now craft a regional policy in the Middle East unencumbered by the wearisome hostage issue.
The negotiations, brokered by the United Nations, were made possible and eventually succeeded because of a confluence of factors that made taking hostages an unprofitable proposition.
The most important reason was that Iran, which enjoyed considerable although uneven influence over the captors of the Americans, decided that its own economic reconstruction and links to the West superseded its radical aims in Lebanon. Teheran's religious leadership, in the aftermath of the Gulf war saw Iraq's defeat as an opportunity to strengthen Iran's own regional stature via more conventional diplomacy and therefore removed its plans for exporting the Muslim revolution from the Government's agenda.
 
Lost of Soviet Aid
 Second, the collapse of the Soviet Union made it apparent that no Arab country would have a Soviet-supplied army with the latest modern technology or would benefit very much from Moscow's patronage. Syria, which for years had used Lebanon for its own terrorist aims, decided to buy into games played by American rules: the coalition in the gulf war and the Arab-Israeli peace process.
Third, a Syrian-Lebanese treaty of cooperation expanded Syria's control over Lebanese affairs, helping to restore stability to the country.
Fourth, the immediate reason for the capture of some of the Western hostages in Lebanon -- and once a non-negotiable demand for their release -- evaporated overnight when, in the confusion of the Iraqi seizure of Kuwait in August 1990, 15 prisoners who were jailed in Kuwait for terrorist activities were set free.
Finally, the relentless efforts of Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar and one of his deputies, Giandomenico Picco, to seize what they perceived as an opening in Teheran and mediate an agreement with all the parties that facilitated the breakthrough.
Still, there has been no resolution of many of the issues that led to hostage-taking in the first place: reducing the influence of the United States in the region, bridging the gap between rich and poor and creating a balance of power with Israel. That reality has led Administration specialists in counterterrorism, granted, the most pessimistic interpreters of hostage-related events, to suspect that the hostage-taking era may not be over.
In the view of the Administration, the release of the last American hostage does not make Lebanon a more benign place. A State Department advisory warning American citizens to avoid all travel to Lebanon is still in place, and United States passports are not valid for travel to, in or through Lebanon. Officials acknowledge that they can give no assurances that more Americans will not be taken hostage. Said one senior Administration official, "They could seize hostages tomorrow."

HEADLINE: Sununu Expects Skinner Will Be New Staff Chief

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4

 BODY:
John H. Sununu, the ousted White House chief of staff, said tonight that he expected his successor to be Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner.
Speaking in an interview on the Cable News Network, Mr. Sununu, who submitted his forced resignation on Tuesday, also said he expected President Bush to name the new chief of staff either Thursday or Friday and to make the long-expected announcement of the President's top 1992 campaign staff at the same time. 
 Mr. Bush remained publicly silent on his intentions but kept up a busy schedule of meetings with his closest advisers, including one with Mr. Skinner, that suggested he was moving quickly toward decisions on a leadership team for 1992 and repairing the political damage he has suffered in the last weeks of Mr. Sununu's tenure.
In the CNN interview, which took place on the "Larry King Live" program, Mr. Sununu, who will remain chief of staff until Dec. 15 and will be a Presidential adviser until next March, ll but confirmed that Mr. Bush's choice to succeed him was Mr. Skinner.
"I think he's made up his mind," Mr. Sununu said of the President.
Asked about widespread reports that Mr. Skinner would be the choice, Mr. Sununu said, "I don't think the name that comes out will be a surprise, considering what's been discussed in the press."
Mr. Skinner visited the White House late this morning, and during the day the President also met with Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, perhaps his most trusted political adviser; Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, a longtime friend, and two of the anticipated top officials of the President's re-election team: Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher, who is expected to be the campaign manager, and Robert M. Teeter, the President's poll taker.
Mr. Bush also delivered a speech to the American Enterprise Institute, a research center here, in which he tried out the latest version of his economic message, one of concern linked to the promise of "common sense" proposals for growth in his State of the Union Message next month. It was an apparent acknowledgment that his attempt to place blame for the Government's inaction on the Republican-Democratic split between the White House and Congress was not working.
Moving on another front where he has drawn much criticism for a perceived lack of leadership, Mr. Bush planned to meet on Monday with top officials of the Department of Health and Human Services and the National Commission on AIDS, which has criticized his policies on the disease.
 
Sense of Expectation
 As of this evening, associates of Mr. Skinner said he had not yet been offered Mr. Sununu's job, but the sense of expectation at the White House was heightened by the appearance of his limousine in the executive parking lot at 11 o'clock this morning. It was the third time in four days that Mr. Skinner had been to the White House.
Although Mr. Skinner has tried to avoid leaving a public impression that he wants the job, Administration officials and Republican strategists said he had been cultivating contacts both inside and outside the Administration in a manner that contrasts to Mr. Sununu's inability to play Washington politics.
Mr. Skinner, an Illinoisan whose friends describe him as a "Chicago pol" who knows how to make things work, has made a practice for some time of showing up at the White House mess on a regular basis and having lunch with White House aides, an extremely unusual habit for a Cabinet officer.
Perhaps mindful that his reputation as a pragmatic moderate could draw fire from the Republican right, Mr. Skinner has also cultivated a friendship with Vice President Dan Quayle, conservatives' best friend within the Administration. Associates say Mr. Quayle once invited Mr. Skinner to the Indianapolis 500 by calling him at work and saying into the telephone: "Vroom! Vroom!"
 
Former U.S. Attorney
 Mr. Skinner, 53 years old, is a former United States Attorney from Chicago who developed a relationship with Mr. Bush through his own mentor, former Gov. James R. Thompson Jr. of Illinois, a leading political supporter of Mr. Bush. Mr. Skinner ran Mr. Bush's primary and general election campaigns in Illinois in 1988 and also worked on Mr. Bush's 1980 primary campaign against Ronald Reagan.
Other than Mr. Skinner, people mentioned for the chief of staff's job have included Fred Malek, a longtime associate of Mr. Bush who is reported to prefer a spot in the President's re-election campaign, and Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, who has reportedly indicated that he is not interested in the job and who left today for a 10-day trip to Hawaii and Europe.
In addition, one faction of Bush advisers has been pushing Secretary of Education Lamar Alexander.
One day after Mr. Sununu handed in his resignation, Mr. Bush seemed clearly eager to begin to repair the damage caused by the disarray in his domestic policy team, much of which has been attributed to Mr. Sununu.
But the removal of the former New Hampshire Governor is unlikely to end Mr. Bush's problems by itself.
Democrats, who had used Mr. Bush's hesitation in dealing with Mr. Sununu as ammunition against a President whose leadership had suddenly been called into question by public opinion polls, are now saying that he must do more than get rid of one aide to demonstrate his concern about domestic affairs.
Removing Mr. Sununu will also leave Mr. Bush a residue of problems with his party's conservative wing, which has been increasingly critical of his economic policy and has long been suspicious of his commitment to a conservative agenda.
In his interview tonight, Mr. Sununu sought to dispel any notion that he might run for the United States Senate in New Hampshire if Senator Warren B. Rudman, a Republican whose term expires next year, decides not to seek re-election.
"Even if he doesn't run, I'm not going to run for the seat," Mr. Sununu said. "I really have to get back to the private sector, to get what my kids call a real job."

HEADLINE: White House Memo;
Sununu Downfall: He Broke 7 Cardinal Rules

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4

 BODY:
The White House is an easy place to lose perspective.
When George W. Bush, the President's oldest son, visited John H. Sununu's office in the West Wing a week ago to suggest that Mr. Sununu might want to do the President a favor and resign, the chief of staff balked. 
 Mr. Sununu rejected the younger Bush's assertion that he no longer had enough support in the Cabinet, the Bush inner circle or the Republican Party to do his job effectively, and he began telephoning Republicans to drum up support. But he soon learned that while a few Republicans were willing to speak out for him or to call the President, it was a very few. It did not break into double digits.
 
Lacking Cadre of Friends
 Only then did Mr. Sununu understand what the rest of Washington had known for weeks: He had no cadre of friends on Capitol Hill, no core of Bush loyalists and no conservative base to break his fall.
As William J. Bennett, the prominent conservative and former national drug czar who made calls on Mr. Sununu's behalf on Monday, put it: "I was trying to rally support, but it was tough. People were saying, 'Gee, I like John. He is conservative. But he was mean to me.' "
"I mean, come on, grow up, guys; some people in this town are just too delicate," continued Mr. Bennett, who knows something about the political price of operating with a blunt, combative manner. "I dealt with Sununu. We had our shouting matches on drug policies and Republican National Committee matters, but so what?"
 
Job Campaign Came Too Late
 Mr. Sununu had also alienated many conservatives when he helped hammer out a bipartisan budget deal last year that included tax increases, and, as one leading conservative put it, continued to treat any criticism or opposition to the deal as "treachery." Conservatives considered it a betrayal when Mr. Sununu did not try to persuade Mr. Bush to stick to his no-tax campaign pledge.
By the time Mr. Sununu began his campaign to save his job by asking Republicans to lobby the President, it was too late. Persuaded by the report of his son, who had made a survey of Bush loyalists; persuaded by his talks with his wife, Barbara, with Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and other trusted friends, and persuaded by the lowest popularity-poll numbers of his Administration, Mr. Bush had made up his mind over the weekend at Camp David, his advisers said today.
The campaign to lobby Mr. Bush was Mr. Sununu's final bit of political tone deafness. The Bushes did not like it, their friends said, calling it unseemly, wrong and in poor taste.
In the end, Mr. Bush told his friends, he had to ask Mr. Sununu to resign because, as a Bush intimate said, "the White House was not functioning as smoothly as George Bush likes it to."
Or, as another Republican put it less delicately: "Bush is at 48 percent in the polls. The wheels are coming off the White House. And there isn't any domestic policy."
Mr. Sununu, a former engineering professor, is proud of his I.Q., estimated at 180. But top Republicans said that once he was ensconced in the heady West Wing atmosphere, he seemed unable to grasp Washington's seven cardinal rules: 1. Don't make enemies you don't need to make.
2. Don't start believing you're indispensable.
3. Don't confuse what's good for you with what's good for the President.
4. Don't forget that you are not the elected official.
5. Don't start blaming the boss if you get into trouble.
6. Don't unilaterally announce you are going to run things, rather than letting the President announce who will run things.
7. Someone must pay the price when the polls plummet, and anyone who has maintained a high profile will be a prime target.
Mr. Sununu should have learned the lessons early.
Yet again tonight in an interview on the Cable News Network call-in program "Larry King Live," Mr. Sununu blamed others for his problems.
"I can't change my personality," he said. "Now I would say there is a perception of my personality out there" that is mistaken. Mr. Sununu said that since he had come from the academic world he liked to "argue it out" on issues. "In this city some people don't like doing that," he said.
But Mr. Sununu's critics did not object to a lively debate as much as they objected to what they called his gratuitous nastiness and belittling. As for his working relationship with Mr. Bush, he said he "never took a position or nuance different than his." He said Mr. Bush had suggested that he say he was not to blame for spontaneously mentioning a ceiling on credit card interest rates, adding that Mr. Bush said, "Hey, you tell them that I did it."'
But Republicans close to the White House said today that even if Mr. Bush had made such an offer, Mr. Sununu still should not have publicly blamed the President.
Whatever the cause for Mr. Sununu's downfall, it was a new day in the White House. One top Administration official said there was "a certain amount of relief that the ordeal is over," adding, "The last few days were like being at someone's wake before he's dead."
 
An Upbeat Parting
 Staff members around Mr. Sununu who were dependent on him for their positions were described as morose today. But many younger staff members, who felt that Mr. Sununu had stifled the flow of ideas and engaged in gratuitous belittling, were secretly celebrating.
"From talking to assistant secretaries and lower-level people in the White House, it's clear that they never forgave him for showing them the error in their memo in front of five other people," Mr. Bennett said.
But at the senior staff meeting this morning, Mr. Sununu gave a gracious summation. Appearing in an upbeat mood, he thanked his staff and paid tribute to Mr. Bush. He talked about the events in the world that had changed during his tenure, and he talked about what he felt the Administration had achieved on the clean air bill, the child care bill and the budget agreement.
He told the staff to "have fun," and added, "If you don't have fun, it's not worth doing."
Although one top aide in the meeting dryly noted that Mr. Sununu's advice to have fun was "not entirely consistent with his modus operandi when he was here," everyone seemed to appreciate the chief of staff's grace note.
Mr. Sununu jokingly apologized to Marlin Fitzwater, the President's press secretary, for stepping on Mr. Bush's message in speeches on the economy in Meridian, Miss., and Bradenton, Fla., on Tuesday.
And Mr. Sununu laughed when Bill Kristol, Vice President Dan Quayle's chief of staff, suggested that Meridian might be a dangerous place for chiefs of staff to allow Presidents to go. It was on the way home from an appearance in Meridian on April 27, 1973, that Richard M. Nixon talked to H. R. Haldeman about the possibility of having to dismiss him because of the unraveling Watergate scandal. Three days later, Mr. Nixon did.
Mr. Sununu goodnaturedly agreed that letting Mr. Bush go to Meridian had probably been a mistake.

Charles H. Keating Jr. was convicted of securities fraud in connection with the collapse of Lincoln Savings. A jury in Los Angeles found Mr. Keating guilty on 17 of 18 fraud counts after deliberating for more than two weeks. Mr. Keating faces a maximum sentence of 10 years in prison. [Page A1.]

HEADLINE: Duke Takes His Anger Into 1992 Race

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4

 BODY:
David Duke, the former grand wizard of the Ku Klux Klan who polarized Louisiana politics with his angry campaigns against welfare and affirmative action, announced today that he was entering the race for the Republican Presidential nomination.
Mr. Duke, who declared his candidacy in a packed news conference at the National Press Building here, accused President Bush of "selling out" the Republican Party by signing a new civil rights bill, by raising taxes and by failing to protect American workers from foreign competition. 
 The former Klansman and one-time neo-Nazi touched on nearly every volatile issue in American politics: immigration, taxes, crime, racial preferences, "the welfare illegitimate birth rate," the undermining of "Christian society" to the point "where we can't even sing Christmas carols in many of our public schools anymore."
 
Racial Allusions in Speech
 Despite careful security, he was interrupted several times by protesters, but rarely missed a beat. His speech was riddled with allusions to race and ethnicity. On the subject of trade, he said, "We must go to the Japanese and say, 'You no buy our rice, we no buy your cars.' " He described the Democratic Party as the party of "Jesse Jackson and Ron Brown," referring to the former Presidential candidate and the chairman of the Democratic National Committee, both of whom are black.
He also mispronounced the name of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York, pronouncing it, "Kew-mo." In every instance, when later asked, Mr. Duke replied he did not mean to make any racial or ethnic point.
Mr. Duke said he would be entering primaries around the country but suggested he saw particularly ripe opportunities in the South, where a cluster of states will hold primaries on March 10. He said he would not enter the Feb. 18 primary in New Hampshire, contending there was a lack of time. This means that Mr. Bush will now face a two-front challenge: in New Hampshire from Patrick J. Buchanan, the conservative commentator and former Nixon and Reagan White House aide who is expected to enter the race next Tuesday, and in the South from Mr. Duke.
Analysts say Mr. Duke's greatest peril to Mr. Bush could be if he uses the primaries to build a basis for an independent challenge next fall, which Mr. Duke said today he was "not ruling out." Few analysts expect Mr. Duke to pose anything like the challenge that George C. Wallace did in 1968 with his independent candidacy, when by some estimates the former Governor of Alabama captured more than 60 percent of the white vote in the Deep South states, and 14 percent of the total vote nationwide.
 
Complicating Primary Season
 But Mr. Duke could be troublesome for Mr. Bush, particularly in a close race in a bad economy, when an independent candidate getting 2 to 3 percent of the vote in a state could make a very big difference.
Republican strategists and analysts contend that neither Mr. Buchanan nor Mr. Duke poses a serious threat to Mr. Bush's renomination, although they certainly complicate a primary season that had been expected to be a mere formality for the Bush forces.
"They've got four things they never imagined would happen: Buchanan in New Hampshire, Duke in the South, the economy probably headed into a second-stage problem and the American electorate sick of Bush running around overseas," said Kevin Phillips, a conservative analyst.
The White House, which has repeatedly disavowed Mr. Duke and denied his claim to the Republican label, responded stonily to his announcement today. "We've denied him every way from Sunday," said Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman.
But the Republicans' inability to shake Mr. Duke was underscored today as the Presidential motorcade rolled back to the White House from a hotel where Mr. Bush was speaking. As the Presidential limousine turned a corner, the doors of a taxi flew open and Mr. Duke emerged to watch the procession. Mr. Bush later ignored reporters who asked if he had noticed.
 
Attacking Bush's Right Flank
 Mr. Duke clearly intends to nip at Mr. Bush's right flank. "We've had a bigger government under the Republican Administration; we've had bigger taxes, we've had affirmative action, we've had an increase in the welfare system, and we've had an increase in foreign aid," Mr. Duke said.
Mr. Duke said Mr. Bush had the opportunity even now to roll back affirmative action programs, adding, "I want to say this to George Bush -- you know, whether I run third party or not is going to depend on what he does."
The Duke Presidential candidacy has been expected almost from the moment he was defeated in last month's runoff for governor of Louisiana. Mr. Duke, a 41-year-old State Representative whose term ends on Jan. 12, was soundly defeated by former Gov. Edwin W. Edwards, a Democrat. But the former Klansman carried 55 percent of the white vote -- much of it, some analysts said, an angry protest vote against politics as usual. What is unknown, and what is sharply debated in political circles, is how transferable Mr. Duke's appeal is to other parts of the country.
It is also unclear whether Mr. Duke can sufficiently organize to compete in Republican primaries around the nation. Some Republicans said voters likely to participate in Republican Presidential primaries tended to be party regulars -- not the disaffected voters, many of them Democrats, who swelled Mr. Duke's vote in Louisiana.
 
Standard Themes
 Mr. Duke hit many of his standard themes today. For example, he argued, "We've got to reduce the welfare illegitimate birth rate," asserting that preference in housing allocations, job programs and other benefits should go to those "who go without having an illegitimate child over a certain period of time.'
He argued "whether we call affirmative action quotas or whether we simply call it racial preference," such policies discriminate against white people and were simply "wrong." Mr. Duke also denied the frequent charge that he is a racist, following his customary argument that his Klan activity was a youthful excess.
Mr. Duke said today that he believed immigration policies would be a major issue in the election, arguing that "the time has come in America to limit and stop the illegal immigration into our society." He added: "What's happening is, we are unraveling. We're losing our way. This country is overwhelmingly European descent. It's overwhelmingly Christian. And if we lose our underpinning, I think we're going to lose the foundations of America."
Mr. Duke's professed born-again Christianity came under fire toward the end of his campaign in Louisiana, when some Christian conservatives questioned his sincerity and suggested he was using religion as a political ploy.

HEADLINE: Its Cash Depleted, Pan Am Shuts

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
Pan American World Airways finally died yesterday -- broke and too weak to attempt yet another comeback -- two days after Delta Air Lines ended its financing arrangement.
The shutdown means the loss of the jobs of 7,500 Pan Am employees, thousands of whom had worked in the New York area and were in the process of moving to Miami to join the carrier at its new headquarters at Miami International Airport. 
 Economists in Dade County, Fla., said the airline's shutdown would result in the loss of about 9,000 jobs in that area when outside jobs dependent on the airline were taken into account.
Both Miami and New York had already lost many airline-industry jobs when Eastern Airlines shut downearlier this year.
"Today we see the end of an airline whose name will be forever forged in American history," said Russell L. Ray, the president and chief executive of Pan Am, which was founded in 1927 and was long a dominant carrier in global aviation.
Pan Am is the third big United States airline to stop flying this year as the industry struggles with declines in travel caused by the weak economy. Eastern Airlines ceased flying in January and Midway Airlines shut down last month.
Thousands of passengers, some on flights just preparing to take off, were stranded yesterday. Pan Am said that as a result of an earlier agreement with Delta Air Lines , its ticket holders would get comparable service on Delta or on some other airlines. A number of other airlines said they would honor Pan Am tickets, but some said they would not. [Page D6.]
Pan Am's airport gates and routes could be acquired by other carriers; among those that might be interested are Trans World Airlines, United Airlines and USAir. Indeed, Jeffrey Shane, the Assistant Secretary of Transportation, yesterday asked other carriers to apply for temporary permission to fly Pan Am's international routes.
American Airlines, a major carrier to the Caribbean and Latin America, said yesterday that it had asked the Transportation Department to allow it to add more flights to seven routes no longer served by Pan Am. John Hotard, a spokesman for American, said the airline already had authority to fly on the routes.
The routes are Miami to Buenos Aires, Grand Cayman, Rio de Janeiro and Mexico City, and New York to Rio, Buenos Aires and Mexico City.
 
An Uncertain Future
 But as of yesterday, it was unclear what would happen to Pan Am's workers and fleet of 58 planes, which is parked in Miami and John F. Kennedy International Airport in New York. Pan Am has already sold its terminal facilities at Kennedy to Delta, and still owns a maintenance area there.
After selling Delta its prime assets -- the East Coast shuttle and routes to Europe and points east -- Pan Am had hoped to emerge from bankruptcy-court protection as a smaller airline serving the Caribbean and Latin America. It had begun a small domestic system with a hub at Miami with the help of a financing package from Delta.
Under a Chapter 11 bankruptcy reorganization plan that was to be considered last Tuesday by Judge Cornelius Blackshear, the unsecured creditors would have owned 55 percent of the airline and Delta 45 percent.
 
Plan Not Considered
 But the judge did not have a chance to consider the plan, even though major obstacles had been overcome. Agreements had been negotiated with five major unions at Pan Am for concessions worth $48 million and an agreement had been reached with the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation to deal with a shortfall of $900 million in Pan Am's pension funds.
The plan was scuttled when Delta, which had offset Pan Am's huge losses for months with $115 million in cash, decided it would no longer provide more cash.
Pan Am, with the help of its investment banker, Lazard Freres & Company, yesterday was looking for buyers for its Latin American routes, which at one time had been profitable.
Carl C. Icahn, the chairman of Trans World Airlines, said yesterday that "we are studying the Latin American routes to see if we want to make a bid."
 
Wary Travelers
 Even the backing of a strong carrier like Delta -- with money, advertising, staff and marketing expertise -- was not enough to reassure travelers and travel agents, many of whom avoided booking on the airline.
Estelle Lessack, the president of Travel Trends in Fort Lee, N.J., said that she did not avoid Pan Am outright in her bookings but added, "If there was another option, I usually took the other option."
She said that many of her clients were reluctant to fly Pan Am mainly because of memories of the loss of one of its Boeing 747's in an explosion over Lockerbie, Scotland, that killed all aboard.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Hundreds of passengers were stranded yesterday at New York's Kennedy International Airport when Pan Am shut its operations. Iris Guzman, left, and Maria Rojas, who were two of 100 passengers taken off a flight to the Dominican Republic just before its takeoff, rested at a Pan Am counter. (Vic DeLucia/The New York Times) (pg. D1)
 
Chronology: "The Selloff at a Pioneering Airline"
 
1980
 July 28: Pan American World Airways reached preliminary agreement to sell the Pan Am Building to Metropolitan Life Insurance Company for about $400 million, reportedly the highest price for a single building.
 
1981
 Aug. 21: The airline announced the sale of its Intercontinental Hotels subsidiary to Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. for $500 million in cash.
 
1985
 April 22: Pan Am agreed to sell its Pacific operations to United Airlines for $750 million.
 
1990
 May 18: With cash reserves dwindling, airline put its shuttle, serving Boston, New York and Washington, on the block.
 Oct. 23: The UAL Corporation, parent of United Airlines, agreed to acquire Pan Am's London routes for $400 million.
 Nov. 11: Trans World Airlines and its chairman, Carl C. Icahn, offered to buy Pan Am, contingent on Pan Am's dropping its negotiations with United.
 Dec. 16: After T.W.A. agreed to sells its U.S.-to-London routes to American Airlines, Mr. Icahn bid $375 million for Pan Am.
 
1991
 Jan. 8: Pan Am Corporation filed for Chapter 11 protection.
 July 28: Pan Am agreed to sell its European routes, planes, Frankfurt operations and the shuttle to Delta for $460 million.
 Yesterday: Pan Am shutdown, one day after Delta refused to provide any more money for operations. (pg. D6)

HEADLINE: Old Veterans Return to Mark a Day of Infamy

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HONOLULU, Dec. 4

 BODY:
They are coming back to remember Pearl Harbor again.
Half a century after the surprise Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor, which drew the United States into World War II, the old soldiers and sailors who survived that day of infamy are returning to ponder its meaning, honor the dead and socialize with old buddies. 
 The survivors are mostly gray and wrinkled now; many walk with canes or listen with hearing aids. And they are finding a Honolulu that has also changed vastly since the war ended with Japan's defeat in 1945. Fifty years after they attacked the American forces in Hawaii, the Japanese now own 61 percent of the hotel rooms in Honolulu and Japanese tourists are a mainstay of the Hawaiian economy.
C. A. Murray was a 21-year-old corporal in the Marines that fateful Sunday. He recalled the Japanese planes flying so low over the naval base that "I could see the bastards smiling." Today he stood on the second floor of the Sheraton-Waikiki Hotel, owned by a Japanese company, and watched Japanese tourists walk by.
"I'm sorry I didn't take Japanese in school," he said sarcastically, referring to all the signs in Japanese around him. "I don't have any animosities, but it rubs me the wrong way."
The hotels and streets of Waikiki have never seemed odder. Crowds of old veterans wearing peaked caps mixed with swarms of Japanese tourists, many of them young honeymooners. They walked past each other as if the other were invisible.
Officials of the Pearl Harbor Survivors Association said they expected about 2,400 survivors, plus their families and guests, for the anniversary events. They include a parade down Kalakaua Avenue, dinners, dances and a luau, and will culminate with a Saturday morning ceremony to be attended by President Bush at the memorial over the sunken battleship Arizona, where 1,117 sailors and marines died on Dec. 7, 1941.
Honolulu has been awaiting the 50th anniversary of the attack on Pearl Harbor with no small trepidation, fearful that long-festering animosities against the Japanese would drive away free-spending Japanese tourists and bring grief to Japanese-Americans. But so far none of that has happened.
Kenji Ito, a longtime Japanese resident of Honolulu who is executive director of JTB Hawaii Inc., which brings three jumbo jets full of tourists from Japan every day, said bookings were normal for December.
"The majority of people here are playing it cool," he said. "I just hope we have a good relationship between Japan and Hawaii. We need each other."
William M. Kaneko, director of the local chapter of the Japanese American Citizens Association, a civil rights group, said there had been no untoward incidents yet. "Knock on wood," he added. "With 4,000 vets drinking beer with old Army buddies, it takes just one bad apple."
 
Reports of Remorse Doubted
 Among the returning survivors there was much talk today, as well as skepticism, about reports of official Japanese remorse over the attack. The Honolulu Advertiser this morning had a news article by The Washington Post from Tokyo quoting Foreign Minister Michio Watanabe as saying, "We feel deep remorse about the unbearable suffering and sorrow Japan inflicted on the American people and the peoples of Asia and the Pacific during the Pacific war, a war that Japan started by the surprise attack on Pearl Harbor."
All this was generally dismissed by the returning veterans as coming 50 years too late. But 50 years also appeared to have taken the edge off animosities. One survivor who returned, Victor J. Paradiss of Mankato, Minn., spent four years fighting the Japanese in the Pacific as a Navy fireman.
"I don't hold any hard feelings," said Mr. Paradis, now 72. "They were just taking orders from someone else. It's their world, too."
His wife, Lucille, agreed. "It's a new generation," she said. "They cannot help what their grandparents did. It's just that we won't buy a Japanese car."

HEADLINE: Limits Proposed for Race-Based Scholarships

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4

 BODY:
Education Secretary Lamar Alexander proposed rules today that would ban scholarships based exclusively on race except under specific circumstances.
But Mr. Alexander said race could still be used as one factor in awarding scholarships to achieve diversity on college campuses, along with other factors like geographic origin and economic background. 
 He said race-exclusive scholarships would be permitted when used to remedy proven discrimination, when Congress specifically created them or when a private donor gave the money and it did not result in the denial of aid to other students.
Colleges will have four years to implement the policy, and no current scholarships will be revoked, he said.
"What we're trying to do is create an area of certainty," Mr. Alexander said. He said the proposed regulations clarified what was permissible under Title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, which prohibits discrimination on the basis of race, color or national origin.
Many college and university officials as well as civil rights leaders said the ruling would have a chilling affect on college applications by minority students, because following financial aid regulations was already a complex process for students and their families.
Mr. Alexander's decision cames after a seven-month review of a position taken last December by Michael L. Williams, Assistant Secretary for Civil Rights at the Education Department. Mr. Williams declared illegal a $100,000 scholarship for minorities created by the backers of the Fiesta Bowl college football game.
Colleges and universities and civil rights groups protested Mr. Williams's action, arguing that it would keep minorities out of higher education. In April, Mr. Alexander delayed it for more study.
Today, Mr. Alexander said the Fiesta Bowl scholarship would be legal because it was a private scholarship.
Tim Christensen, associate director of the National Association of Student Financial Aid Administrators, said Mr. Alexander's decision varied from Mr. Williams's only "in changing a couple of details."
He added, "I think it will discourage qualified minorities."
 
Administration Pattern
 Mr. Alexander's decision fits into the Bush Administration pattern on racial and affirmative action issues of seeking to satisfy conservative philosophical concerns while also seeking not to be racist. And some observers have suggested that the issue is being brought up because of the impending Presidential campaign.
William H. Gray 3d, the former House Democratic whip from Pennsylvania who now heads the United Negro College Fund, compared the scholarship ruling to the positions against affirmative action programs taken by David Duke, the former Ku Klux Klan leader who recently lost the race for governor of Louisiana. Mr. Gray told The Associated Press: "It's beginning to smell awfully political to me. It has the stench of Louisiana politics."
There are relatively few race-exclusive scholarships, with about 35,000 students, and 3 percent of minority students, holding them. But they have become a lightning rod for those opposed to affirmative action programs.
Richard Samp, chief counsel of the Washington Legal Foundation, a conservative public interest and policy center, lauded Mr. Alexander's proposal, saying: "The cycle of racial discrimination has got to be brought to an end if we are ever going to achieve the idea of a color-blind society."
But others said today's announcement muddied a once-clear area.
"What is going to happen is that we're going to send a rather confusing and diffuse message to minority students," said Dr. Richard F. Rosser, president of the National Association of of Independent Colleges and Universities. "For a number of years, we've had minority based scholarships and now we will have to find other kinds of criteria to give them."
Today's actions focused specifically on race and left open the question of what effect it would have on scholarships for women or those designed for adherents of a particular religion.

HEADLINE: M.T.A. Is Turning to Itself on Fare Increase

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
Unusual forces are pushing transit officials toward a reluctant but inevitable conclusion: If they want to limit the size of the New York City subway and bus fare increase, they must find the money themselves, within the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.
Increasing the fare -- never a simple political decision -- is complicated this year by three unusual elements. One is that neither the city nor the state has any new money to put into the system. Another is that cooperation from suburban legislators was undercut when the M.T.A. decided in October against raising fares on commuter railroads, severing a traditional link between city and suburban fares. 
 The third -- the Presidential ambitions of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo -- also looms over the process. Can a Democrat who speaks on behalf of large cities afford blame for a large subway increase when more affluent suburbanites have been spared?
All three forces have coalesced to press M.T.A. officials to search hard in the nooks and crannies of their own agencies for creative ways to avoid a huge fare increase.
Just three weeks ago, the Transit Authority, the M.T.A. subsidiary that operates the city's subways and buses, said that it would raise the $1.15 fare to $1.40 on Jan. 1 unless the state provided additional subsidies.
But since then, transit officials have shifted gears, indicating a willingness to consider a variety of proposals to alter the way the M.T.A. does business -- provided that in return the Legislature approves the authority's stalled five-year capital plan.
Transit officials said on Tuesday that they were considering a number of ideas. Among them are shifting money from suburban commuter lines to the subways and buses, raising tolls on bridges and tunnels, or trimming further the Transit Authority's budget.
The various scenarios under consideration could limit the size of the fare increase. If the commuter railroads in essence gave $90 million to the Transit Authority, that could produce a fare of $1.30; if other proposals were also accepted, the fare might go to $1.25.
 
An Uncertain Fate
 But while transit officials are being pressed to solve their own financial problems, they say they do not even have the power to do it on their own. Many of the proposals would require the approval of the Legislature, where their fate appears uncertain.
So transit officials, desperate to stave off a $1.40 fare, are trying to broker a broader settlement. If they do their part -- by agreeing to reallocate how money is shared by the city and suburban lines or by paring further the Transit Authority budget -- will the Governor push, and state lawmakers approve, the M.T.A.'s $10.6 billion five-year capital plan?
Peter E. Stangl, the M.T.A. chairman, said in an interview on Tuesday that the plan to shift $90 million from the commuter lines to the Transit Authority was under consideration. The New York Times reported yesterday that Mr. Stangl had endorsed the idea and hoped it would induce the Legislature to approve the comprehensive five-year plan.
But Mr. Stangl said yesterday that he had been misunderstood and that he would support the shift of funds only if it was part of a more broad-based agreement on fares, tolls and operating and capital expenses.
"I'm not fixed on any one fare strategy," Mr. Stangl said. "My concern is that these ideas must be considered within the context of solving our problems over the next five years and not the next six months."
In most previous fare fights, the Legislature rode to the rescue by creating new tax revenues for additional transit operating subsidies, thereby maintaining the fare or limiting an increase.
But with legislators now debating how to close an $875 million gap in the current state budget, and the region struggling through a grueling recession, new taxes for mass transit are unlikely.
The political balance that the M.T.A. brought to Albany in past years has also been altered this year. The authority's board voted in October to hold the fare in 1992 on the Long Island and Metro-North commuter rail lines, severing a 20-year link between fares in the city and suburbs.
That makes it harder to get both city and suburban legislators to support measures to aid the M.T.A.
Further complicating the maneuvering is a larger political question: Will Mr. Cuomo run for President? Transit riders' groups traditionally try to personalize the fare debate, to force governors and mayors to risk blame for a fare increase and thus goad them into action to prevent it. This year has been no different; the groups' representatives brought life-size cardboard photos of the Governor to hearings on the fare increase.
"I think the problem the Governor has is explaining why the suburban railroads do not have a fare hike," said Gene Russianoff, staff attorney with the Straphangers Campaign.
"There is a lot of agita over this in Albany and City Hall," he said.
Mr. Cuomo has said little publicly. In a letter to Mr. Stangl last week, the Governor said he was not convinced a $1.40 fare was necessary and he suggested several small savings that, by themselves, would have limited impact on the Transit Authority's projected $263 million deficit in 1992.
The pace of private negotiations, though, has begun to pick up. "A lot of people are looking at this," Mr. Stangl said. "We've been talking and working with the Governor's staff."
No final decisions have been made, he said, and many matters remain to be resolved before the M.T.A. board votes on Dec. 20 on the subway and bus fare.

HEADLINE: 10-Day Sales Of Vehicles Up by 20.9%

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT

DATELINE: DETROIT, Dec. 4

 BODY:
Sales of domestically made cars and light trucks rose 20.9 percent in late November, auto makers reported today, but sales for the full month were down 6.7 percent from last year's level.
Analysts said the low annual selling rate of six million for the full month provided a more accurate reflection of the depressed auto industry in recent months. 
 Although industry executives saw the 10-day figures as a glimmer of hope, analysts said several factors had artificially inflated the numbers, and that underlying retail demand remained weak.
Analysts noted that auto makers reported dismal sales for the late November period last year, making a year-to-year gain easily attainable. Sales to rental fleets and corporate customers skewed the figures somewhat, analysts said. "There is some smoke and mirrors," said Jack V. Kirnan, an automotive analyst with Kidder, Peabody & Company in New York.
 
Selling Rate of Cars
 The seasonally adjusted annual selling rate for American-built cars was 6.3 million for the late November period, compared with 5.3 million cars for the year-earlier period.
Still, industry executives seized upon the year-to-year gains. Robert L. Rewey, vice president of sales operations for the Ford Motor Company's North American automotive operations, said Ford's late November sales gains "provide evidence that the U.S. economy is stronger than surveys of consumer sentiment suggest."
And Tom Webb, chief economist for the National Automobile Dealers Association, was optimistic that the auto industry may be turning the corner. He said the Big Three had managed to revive sales with attractive lease and finance packages that are overcoming consumers' lack of confidence in the future of the economy.
Other indicators suggest that the auto makers are not optimistic about the short-term future of the auto industry. The Big Three recently slashed 243,000 vehicles from their production plans for December through March.
Several dealers also said they did not expect to see sales pick up until the second quarter of 1992, when they believe the Presidential campaign will prompt Washington to try to encourage spending and lead consumers to dealer showrooms. "I have never not made good money during election year," said Scott Reas of Reas Chevrolet Oldsmobile Geo in Richmond, Mich.
 
Hope Lies With Politicians
 Mike Shad, who owns a Ford dealership in Jacksonville, Fla., agreed that the slumping market will likely last until spring. "Something is going to happen in politics" to spur the economy, he said.
For the 10 days that ended on Nov. 30, domestic car sales totaled 180,084, up 17.5 percent from 1990. Light-truck sales rose 27.2 percent, to 104,269, from the period a year earlier.
During the month of November, American auto makers won back market share in the car market including imports, from the Japanese manufacturers, which have been scoring steady gains. The Big Three held 62.3 percent of the market, compared with 60.1 in the year-earlier period. Japanese car makers saw their share drop to 29.6 percent, from 30.9 percent in November 1990. The market share of non-Japanese importers fell to 8.1 percent in November from 9.0 percent last year.
For the entire month, sales of all cars and trucks, domestic and imported, fell 6.7 percent to 917,276 from 983,158 a year earlier. General Motors sold 214,914 North American-built cars in November, a gain of 1.7 percent from a year earlier; Ford sold 108,507, a drop of 15.5 percent, and Chrysler sold 56,071, down 9.1 percent.
G.M.'s total market share for all cars in November was 36.5 percent, compared with 33.2 percent in November 1990. Ford had a 19.2 percent share, compared with 20.2 percent a year earlier. Chrylser's total market share was 10.1 percent, down from 10.2 percent. Toyota Motor 's market share was 9.2 percent, up from 8.6 percent. Honda Motor 's share was 9.7 percent, down from 11.6 percent.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Continue to Rise

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities continued to rise and interest rates moved lower again yesterday, as investors eager to capture higher yields concentrated their purchases on longer-term notes and bonds.
A number of developments during the session seemed to reduce the risk of buying longer-term, higher-yielding securities, which because of their maturity are generally seen as speculative investments. 
 The news included more evidence that the economy remains soft, as well as comments by President Bush and Robert Parry, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, that were well received by bond traders.
The economic data included another weak report from the nation's auto makers, which reported that 6.2 million vehicles were sold during the last 10 days of November at a seasonally adjusted annual rate. The numbers were slightly better than sales during the middle 10 days of the month, but analysts said that sales for the entire period probably did not exceed six million, a very low level.
 
Other Sign of Weakness
 Revisions in the third-quarter growth rate of the gross national product, announced yesterday by the Commerce Department, also reinforced the notion that the economy was still very weak, analysts said.
The changes showed that inventory accumulation during the summer quarter was much bigger than expected, and that final demand was weaker.
"Those changes leave us vulnerable to a negative growth number in the fourth quarter and again in the first quarter," said Joseph Liro, a senior vice president and money market economist at S. G. Warburg & Company.
The revisions were announced only a few hours before Mr. Parry, who will become a voting member of the Federal Reserve's policy-making Open Market Committee next year, told an audience in Seattle that because of favorable inflation trends, the Fed has more leeway to push interest rates lower to stimulate the economy.
Meanwhile, President Bush was reported as saying yesterday that he did not want any economic stimulus package that would increase the size of the Federal budget deficit.
"Mr. Bush's comments that he won't throw in the towel in fiscal policy helped the market," said Steven A. Wood, director of financial markets research at the Bank of America.
 
Searching for Yields
 For the second straight session, most of the buying activity was concentrated among longer-term notes and bonds. "The search for yield is on," a bond trader said.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 101 3/4 late yesterday, up 18/32, to yield 7.84 percent, compared with 7.89 percent late Tuesday.
In the secondary market for Treasury notes, demand for the 7.50 percent 10-year securities remained strong. In late trading, those securities were offered at 102 7/32, up 19/32, to yield 7.18 percent.
Among other note issues, the 6.50 percent five-year notes were offered at 100 29/32, up 11/32, to yield 6.28 percent. And the 5.50 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 17/32, up 3/32, to yield 5.21 percent.
 
Lower Treasury Bill Rates
 Rates on short-term Treasury bills continued to move lower. Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 4.30 percent late yesterday, down four basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates fell by a similar amount, to a late offered rate of 4.29 percent.
New-issue activity remained strong in the municipal bond market. Among the issues priced yesterday was a negotiated sale of $337 million worth of serial and term bonds for the New York State Environmental Facilities Corporation.
Serial bonds were preliminarily priced with yields from 4.90 percent in 1993 to 6.75 percent on bonds maturing in 2005.
A term bond that matures in 2010 was priced to yield 6.996 percent. And securities maturing in 2014 were priced to yield 6.95 percent.
Goldman, Sachs & Company acted as lead manager for the underwriting. The securities are rated AA by Moody's Investors Service and A by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
 
K Mart's Securities
 In the investment-grade corporate bond market, the K Mart Corporation offered $200 million worth of 15-year securities through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.
The 8.25 percent notes were priced at $99.50 to yield 8.183 percent, 97 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7.50 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing.
The securities are noncallable for life and are rated A-1 by Moody's and A by Standard & Poor's. As a result of strong demand, the size of the issue was increased from $100 million.
The rally in the Government securities market did not provide a great deal of support in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds. Traders said that prices of most issues were up, but only by about 1/8 point to 1/4 point.
In the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds, prices of most widely quoted issues improved by about 1/4 point, dealers said.

HEADLINE: State Sues Potamkin, Citing Tactics in Car Sales

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI

 BODY:
The Potamkin group of car dealerships routinely used "bait-and-switch tactics" and other deceptive sales practices, the New York State Attorney General charged in a suit filed yesterday.
Bait-and-switch tactics involve promises made in advertisements that are not kept when the customer arrives to buy the product. Customers arriving at Potamkin dealerships, Attorney General Robert Abrams said, were told "that they don't qualify for the offer, that the company just ran 'out of stock,' or that the advertisement was a 'mistake.' " 
 A lawyer for Potamkin, Stanley S. Arkin, said yesterday in a written statement that the Attorney General's office had based its case on a "minuscule number of complaints." He also said that the suit was motivated by the political ambitions of Mr. Abrams, who is seeking the Democratic nomination to run for the United States Senate seat held by Alfonse M. D'Amato, a Republican.
Mr. Abrams denied last night that the action was linked in any way to his political ambitions and said it was based on a history of problems with Potamkin. In a phone interview, Mr. Abrams said: "In 1983, we made an agreement with the Potamkin dealerships that they would end their abusive tactics. Since then, we have received more than 400 complaints involving bait-and-switch advertising, failure to return deposits and reneging on commitments to provide low-interest rates for financing.
"This time," Mr. Abrams said, "because it was a violation of that agreement, we had to go to court to seek damages for consumers who were defrauded, to impose fines and penalties and to obtain a court injunction" to prevent future violations.
The suit, filed in State Supreme Court in Manhattan, cites 115 complaints filed with the Attorney General in the last two years, said Edward Barbini, an Abrams spokesman.
Mr. Arkin said last night that the suit involved four Potamkin dealerships, all in New York City. Mr. Barbini said it involved four umbrella corporations for the Potamkin group, which has about 50 dealerships in five states on the East Coast. Sales in 1990 totaled nearly $800 million.
In his written statement, Mr. Arkin said: "The Attorney General has alleged a minuscule number of complaints over three years that amount to about 1/25th of 1 percent of 250,000 consumer contacts at Potamkin dealerships. He has taken a few drops from the ocean and is attempting to portray a tidal wave.
"To take 40 unhappy customers out of thousands upon thousands and try to portray their problems -- real or perceived -- as typical, is totally misleading," Mr. Arkin said.
"What is even more puzzling," he said, "is that virtually all of these complaints have already been resolved. Any fair-minded person will understand the motive here is the Attorney General's quest for publicity as he seeks higher office."
Mr. Arkin said that "over half" of the 115 complaints cited were resolved "to the satisfaction of the customer."
But Mr. Barbini disputed that assertion, and added: "The overall number of complaints points to a significant problem with the sales practices of Potamkin. That's the real issue."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Plunge in Boeing's Stock

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: SEATTLE, Dec. 4

 BODY:
The stock of the Boeing Company fell today after the chief executive said Boeing would not be able to maintain planned production levels if the market for aircraft failed to improve.
"I'm disappointed the recovery of the economy hasn't occurred faster," Frank A. Shrontz said after a speech to American military officials and industry executives. "The U.S. market at the moment is very uncertain for the next year."
Boeing fell $3.125, to $41.375, on the Big Board, its lowest level in more than a year. It was the exchange's third-most-active issue, with a volume of 2.3 million shares.
"All the bad news coming out of the airlines certainly tends to support the bear case rather than the bull case," said Paul Nisbet of Prudential Securities Inc.
The latest bad news came from the Pan Am Corporation, which ceased operations after it was unable to come up with financing to get out of bankruptcy.
Pan Am had long been one of Boeing's largest commercial customers, buying 208 jets beginning in 1955, although it had no aircraft on order at the time of its demise.
Mr. Shrontz called the Pan Am shutdown "a sad state of affairs" but declined to comment further.
Mr. Shrontz said he remained confident that Boeing's commercial aircraft backlog, worth nearly $100 billion, would remain firm, noting that 60 percent of the company's sales were made outside the United States.
