HEADLINE: Added Cuts Are Planned By Du Pont

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
The Du Pont Company, hoping to make a substantial gain in profits, is planning a new round of belt tightening and productivity improvements, company officials said yesterday.
The program, which is still being prepared, will be different from a plan announced in July to cut costs by $1 billion and reduce employment by 5,500 jobs, in that the new plan does not have firm targets for cutting costs or the work force, said Edgar S. Woolard Jr., chairman of E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company. 
 "This is not a phase two of what we announced in July," he said. "It is an effort to see if we can get people to work more efficiently together. We estimate if we are successful, it has the potential to improve profits by up to $2 billion, with about half of that coming from increased production in existing plants and the other half from things like reduced cycle time and less redundancy."
 
No Involuntary Layoffs Yet
 Mr. Woolard said the program would probably reduce overall employment in the company, but said there is "no head-count reduction target for 1992."
In July the company said that because of sluggish growth in the United States, it was planning to cut costs in its chemicals businesses by $1 billion by the end of next year. Since then, various operating units have announced that a total of 5,500 jobs will be eliminated.
Du Pont has about 80,000 employees in its chemical operations and another 20,000 in oil and coal. The energy operations were not affected by the cutbacks.
Mr. Woolard said the two-year program was on track, adding, "We will get 55 to 60 percent of the savings in 1992 and the remainder in 1993." He said that more than 3,000 Du Pont employees had accepted incentives to take early retirement and that there had been no involuntary layoffs so far.
 
A Bottom-Up Plan
 Mr. Woolard said the $1 billion program had been imposed from the top down. The $2 billion plan, he said, would be more bottom up, as the company's 30 individual businesses modify their structure to operate more efficiently.
One effort will be to get workers who handle engineering, purchasing and distribution to work more closely with manufacturing. "We want to try to have the people in plants and offices to work effectively together," he said.
Du Pont's profits have slumped as a result of the recession. A consensus of analyst estimates would have the company earning about $2 billion, or about $3 a share, in 1991 before nonrecurring items. That would compare with $2.3 billion, or $3.40 a share, last year. Du Pont has said the one-time charge for its cost-cutting campaign could be as much as $500 million this year.
In trading today on the New York Stock Exchange, Du Pont shares rose 62.5 cents each to close at $45.625.

HEADLINE: On L.I., the Anti-Tax Prophets Come In From the Wilderness

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GARDEN CITY SOUTH, L.I., Dec. 4

 BODY:
At Pat Friedman's house, the green-shingled Cape Cod on Roxbury Road South, the one with the tiny lot where the trees are bedecked with blue ribbon, property taxes have been rising, but not without a fight.
For most of the last three decades -- as her property taxes have gone from $550 a year to nearly $5,500 -- Mrs. Friedman has been one of a small band of activists who have crisscrossed Long Island, railing, often in vain, against slothful government and soaring property taxes. 
 But now, as unemployment and recession continue their rampage through the region and across the country, and fear routs optimism, the anti-tax prophets have come in from the wilderness.
 
An Attitude Changed
 "Over the years they have called us gadflies and worse, but they don't view us that way now," said Mrs. Friedman as she sat on her living-room couch, holding a 100-yard reel of blue ribbon and plotting the next step in a campaign to roll back county taxes.
In Nassau County, where protests are rare and people usually prefer tending their gardens to attending public meetings, the anti-tax movement has reached the highest pitch since the late 1970's when a move to limit taxes in California sparked copycat efforts across the suburbs.
In the last few months, blue ribbons, the new symbols of the anti-tax movement, have begun appearing on lightpoles near public buildings here, a talk show host has collected 7,000 signatures on anti-tax petitions and Democrats, abetted by Rita Mezzapelle and her Tax Cut Party, made important gains in the County Legislature.
And in another sign of the times, tax foes have gained control over several school boards that had passed sharp tax increases in response to state aid cuts. Mrs. Friedman, the president of the Garden City South Civic Association, was swept into office as the president of the Franklin Square school district and immediately set about cutting spending, consolidating classes and laying off teachers.
 
Hundreds Protest
 On Tuesday night Mrs. Friedman joined with hundreds of other people, some wearing blue ribbons and carrying blue balloons, who descended on a county budget hearing to protest proposals to increase property taxes 25 percent and impose a new sales tax on home heating oil.
Outside, thousands of county workers picketed, demanding that the county rescind furloughs ordered for more than 10,000 county workers, a move that could put pressure on the county to raise taxes even further.
In a letter to Mrs. Friedman, the County Executive, Thomas S. Gulotta, declared that he "enthusiastically" supported the goals of a tax revolt rally she organized, and declared that local government, including the county he has headed for nearly five years, "must be completely overhauled."
"The time for talk is over," he wrote. "The time for action is now!"
What is going on recalls the events in 1978, when a county budget hearing overflowed with people fighting increases in property taxes and calling for the repeal of the home heating oil tax that was, in fact, swiftly repealed. That is the same tax Mr. Gulotta proposed reimposing this year, only to change his mind a few days later.
 
'A Lot of Anger Out There'
 "There is a lot of anger out there," said Richard M. Kessel, the executive director of the New York State Consumer Protection Board, who was a leader of the earlier tax protest. "It seems that all that has changed from the last tax revolt to this tax revolt is that the taxes have gone up."
But Mrs. Friedman and other longtime civic leaders say that much more has changed. In the past, they said, tax protests mainly stirred the passions and shook the pocketbooks of elderly homeowners living on fixed incomes. This time, they say, the business establishment -- in its own restrained way -- has joined in the tax revolt.
"Long Island's economy is hurting," said James L. Larocca, president of the Long Island Association, a business group, at Tuesday night's hearing. "Business and residents are suffering. The absolute last thing we need are more taxes."
Mrs. Friedman became troubled over property taxes as she watched members of her civic association struggle to pay their bills. The wife of an electrician foreman, she raised two children before going back to school in her 40's. She graduated summa cum laude from Adelphi University after serving as president of the adult student government.
For years, she said, most homeowners ignored complaints about rising taxes because home values were rising at the same time. But that changed when real estate values began to tumble.
The elderly, fed up with taxes, used to be able to sell their homes and move. Now they are stuck. One elderly woman in Hempstead, Mrs. Friedman said, continues to give piano lessons simply to pay her tax bills on a house she has been unable to sell. She said the woman, who received $5,000 in Social Security payments last year, paid $6,000 in property taxes. This year her school taxes are to go up by $786.
Mrs. Friedman sees herself as a member of the permanent loyal opposition to the party in power, especially during decades when the Republican Party dominates local government, and the Democrats are all but irrelevant. Her main goal now: replace all property taxes with a tax on income.
Other anti-tax activists have moved from civic groups to politics, out of frustration. Rita Mezzapelle, the publisher of The Elmont Herald, founded the Tax Cut Party three years ago after seeing her complaints as civic leader either ignored or studied to death.
In November the party helped a Democrat, Assemblyman Lewis J. Yevoli, defeat an incumbent Republican as Supervisor for the Town of Oyster Bay, a move that gave Democrats veto power over county spending for the first time in more than 70 years.
While the Republicans see the Tax Cut party as a tool of the Democrats, Ms. Mezzapelle said, her goal is to re-establish a balance of power between the parties as a way of controlling spending. She said her party was prepared to support right-thinking Republicans as well.
 
An Activist Radio Host
 And then there is the role played by "Good Morning, Long Island," a new talk show on two Long Island radio stations, WGSM in Huntington and WGBB in Freeport, that took the tax issue to the air for four hours a day for almost all of last week.
Paul Lyle, the show's host, brought a dozen turkeys to a meeting of the Suffolk County Legislature at which 12 legislators raised taxes by overriding the County Executive's veto. He placed a half-page ad that cost $12,000 in Newsday, asking readers to send back an anti-tax coupon. He said he received 7,000 responses.
"We found that tax increases were at the point where they were causing strangulation," he said. "I get calls from people every day saying, 'I don't know if I can keep living here, I may have to get out.' "

GRAPHIC: Photo: "Over the years they have called us gadflies and worse, but they don't view us that way now," said Pat Friedman, of Garden City, L.I., who has been one of a small band of people fighting soaring property taxes on Long Island. She posted a flier in a campaign to roll back county taxes. (Steve Berman for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: John C. Miller, 83; Writer and Professor Of American History

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:
John C. Miller, a retired professor at Stanford University who wrote several major books about early American history that won praise for their scholarship and analysis, died Sunday at Stanford University Hospital in Palo Alto, Calif. He was 83 years old and lived in Palo Alto.
He died of liver cancer, his family said. 
 Mr. Miller wrote a dozen books about the American Revolution and the early years of the nation.
Critics praised him for research and fresh insights dispelling myths. They said his work captured the color and personalities of history while plumbing political, social and economic forces.
Born in Santa Barbara, Calif., he grew up in Tacoma, Wash. He was a graduate of Harvard University, where, studying under Samuel Eliot Morison, he also earned his master's and doctoral degrees in history.
After traveling in Europe on a fellowship, he wrote his first book, "Sam Adams, Pioneer in Propaganda" (Little, Brown, 1936), which delved into the often devious methods of that founding father. It was a Book-of-the-Month Club reserve selection and was described in a review in The New York Times as a "distinguished contribution."
His next volume was "Origins of the American Revolution" (Atlantic Monthly Press, 1943). A review in The Times said the work's urbanity, scholarship and clarity deserved "a very wide public," and it became a Book-of-the-Month selection.
In all, Mr. Miller's career as a writer of history spanned more than four decades. His last book was "The Wolf by the Ears: Thomas Jefferson and Slavery" (Free Press, 1977).
In his academic career, he taught history at Bryn Mawr College from 1939 to 1949 and at Stanford from 1950 to 1973.
He is survived by his wife, the former Gladys Johnson; three sons, Jeffrey B. of Friday Harbor, Wash., Charles A. of Palo Alto and John H. of Tokyo, and three grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Economy Expands Sluggishly

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4

 BODY:
The Government reported today that the economy grew at a 1.7 percent annual rate during the quarter that ended in September, an advance considerably less than initially estimated and a disappointment to both private analysts and the Bush Administration.
The bad news, coming just before the beginning of an election year, is sure to increase the political pressure on the Bush Administration to take steps to spur the economy. In a speech today to the American Enterprise Institute, President Bush promised to offer a package of common sense economic proposals in his State of the Union Message next month. 
 Marlin Fitzwater, a White House spokesman, acknowledged increased worries. "I think everybody understands that the economy has got real problems," he stated.
 
More Chances for Downturn
 Although the statistics show two straight quarters of expansion, economists noted that most data published so far for October and November indicated that the recovery had halted. Some suggested that a jump in inventories disclosed today raised the chances of a renewed downturn, since higher inventories prompt businesses to cut back on purchases.
In a separate report, a survey conducted by the Federal Reserve found "flagging momentum in the economic recovery" for several weeks. The middle of the country continued to inch ahead while most other areas experienced "stable to slightly weaker" business activity.
The 1.7 percent growth rate for the third quarter as measured by gross domestic product compared with a previously estimated 2.5 percent pace.
 
Data Cannot Be Compared
 With the gross national product, which the Government previously stressed, the revision was somewhat less -- to 2 percent from 2.4 percent. But these two figures are not directly comparable since they use different inflation adjustments.
The most surprising revision, said Gordon Richards, an economist for the National Association of Manufacturers, was that investment in equipment rose only $5.7 billion instead of more than $15 billion, an indication that businesses do not expect a strong recovery.
This revision also partly reflects a higher estimate for the preceding quarter and an inflation readjustment based on 1987 prices instead of 1982 prices. The readjustment, among other things, lowers the prices for computers used in calculating the value of total output.
Over all, Mr. Richards said, today's figures show the economy was "a bit stronger in the second quarter than previously estimated and a bit weaker in the third, with more of the growth coming from inventory accumulation and less from equipment investment."
The mass of statistics published today included recalculations of other earlier data to substitute 1987 prices for 1982 prices, updated figures and changes in some definitions as well as a shift to the G.D.P. from the G.N.P. as the primary indicator of total output.
The G.D.P., like the G.N.P., is generally defined as the value of the economy's total output of goods and services. But the G.D.P. counts only activity taking place within the borders of the United States, excluding the effect of an American who commutes to a Canadian factory or Japanese profits from an auto plant in this country.
 
Mistakes Acknowledged
 The Commerce Department acknowledged that it had made mistakes in some of the data released today, but said that the G.D.P. totals were not affected.
Today's report also indicated that corporate profits were lackluster at best. In the Commerce Department's first compilation of the quarter's earnings, profits from current production rose $400 million, or one-tenth of 1 percent, following a five-tenths of 1 percent increase in the second quarter.
But current production cash flow -- the internal funds available for investment -- fell $2.7 billion, or six-tenths of 1 percent. In the spring there was a rise of three-tenths of 1 percent.
 
Recovery Only Partial
 The 1.7 percent rate of increase in the G.D.P. during the summer followed a 1.4 percent spring advance -- revised up from a three-tenths of 1 percent gain -- and declines for the two preceding quarters of 3.9 percent and 2.5 percent.
"It is no solace that the second-quarter figures were revised upward because that gain was more than offset by worse third-quarter performance," said Lawrence A. Hunter, acting chief economist for the United States Chamber of Commerce. "Now we see that the economy has recovered only 46.7 percent of the almost $80 billion drop in gross domestic product since the recession began, compared to 52.9 percent previously reported."
Stuart G. Hoffman, chief economist for the PNC Financial Corporation in Pittsburgh, said it appeared that imported and domestic goods increasingly piled up unsold during the third quarter, helping to create a weak footing for the start the fourth.
 
Few Signs of Growth
 "I see little or no sign of growth" for the current quarter, Mr. Hoffman added.
Without adjusting current prices for inflation, the G.D.P. rose at a 3.9 percent rate in the third quarter after rising at a 4.6 percent pace in the spring, today's report showed. The price indexes normally published with output figures will not be available until the final estimate of the third-quarter G.D.P. on Dec. 20, the Commerce Department said.
Among the results of recalculating historic data using 1987 prices was the discovery that the economy grew somewhat more slowly than had been thought during the period from 1977 to 1990. The G.D.P., adjusted for inflation, rose an average of 2.5 percent a year instead of 2.7 percent. These figures were the same for the G.N.P.

HEADLINE: LIBYAN MAINTAINS HE HOLDS SUSPECTS

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Dec. 4

 BODY:
The new chief of Libyan intelligence services asserted in an interview published today that he had ordered the detention of two Libyan officials accused by the United States and Britain of carrying out the bombing of a Pan Am airplane in 1988.
The statement appears to be an unusual Libyan attempt to diffuse growing tensions with the United States and Western Europe over the charges during what Arab and foreign diplomats say is a growing fear by Libya that it may be subject to a military attack or a stringent economic boycott. 
 In a front page interview published this morning in the Saudi daily Asharq Al-Awsat, the intelligence chief, Col. Yusef Abdelqader el-Debri asserted that he had begun an investigation of the American and British charges, but reiterated Libya's refusal to extradite the two either to the United States or Britain to face charges there.
Colonel Debri added that four other Libyan officials accused by the French authorities of bombing a French airliner in 1989 were also detained but that no investigation had started yet.
A number of Arab diplomats expressed skepticism about Libya's intentions to conduct serious investigations of those accused in the two bombings.
 
Concerned With Image
 The Libyan official conceded that "Libya's image abroad is distorted and it must be reviewed," adding that this was among his new functions as chief of Libyan security services.
Those accused of the bombings, in which 441 people died, are reportedly all members of the Libyan secret services.
Colonel Debri said Libya was prepared "to cooperate and present all necessary information" to investigators of the two bombings in the United States, Britain and France and hinted that he would cooperate with foreign security services "to preserve security in the world and in the region."
But when asked if Libya planned to end its support to armed groups around the world, like the Irish Republican Army and other terror groups whose names have been associated with Libya, he replied only that "this kind of change is premature."
Asked if Libya is contemplating a change in its conduct of foreign policy with the aim of diverting accusations that it has engaged in violent acts abroad and if he planned to purge Libyan secret services, Colonel Debri answered "definitely."
The unusually conciliatory statements by the Libyan official reflect what Arab diplomats here say is a growing fear in Libya that the United States and Britain may undertake military action against the country in a matter of weeks if it failed to comply with the extradition requests.
In the last few days Libya has multiplied its contacts with Arab and foreign countries in an attempt to rally their support for Libya. While virtually all Arab nations have said they will not support any military actions against Libya, there has been a palpable lack of enthusiasm among them to oppose further economic sanctions against Libya.
Western Europe has already signaled this week the possibility of imposing economic sanctions on Libya, including a boycott of Libyan crude oil, to force the Government of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi to comply with the extradition requests.
 
Europeans Prepare Response
 In a tough statement on Monday the European Community hinted that it might act within weeks and a senior British foreign office official who visited Algeria, Tunisia and Malta this week to urge their support for the British extradition request would not deny reports in the British press that United States airmen in England were training to bomb Libya again, as they did in 1986.
The British official, the Foreign Office minister Douglas Hogg also visited Egypt today calling upon President Hosni Mubarak who maintains a good personal relationship with Colonel Qaddafi to press Britain's request.
"There are a whole range of options which are available to us but at the moment we are concentratting on persuading Colonel Qaddafi to surrender these people," Mr. Hogg was quoted by The Associated Press as saying when asked if military actions will be taken against Libya.

HEADLINE: G.O.P. Senator Opposes Using Rail Funds to Limit Subway Fare

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Dec. 4

 BODY:
With a fight looming in the Legislature over fare increases for mass transit in New York City, a powerful Republican Senator said today that he would adamantly oppose any attempt to transfer money from construction funds used for commuter railroads to the city's subway and bus lines.
The transfer is one method being explored by Metropolitan Transportation Authority officials to limit the fare increase in the city to 15 cents, from $1.15 to $1.30, rather than the 25-cent increase to $1.40 that the M.T.A. had proposed earlier. 
 The Senator, Norman J. Levy, chairman of the Transportation Committee, said using the railroad's construction funds to cover the operating deficits in the city would be "a nightmarish leap back into the 1960's and 1970's, when the M.T.A. neglected its vital infrastructure."
The M.T.A., which oversees the city and suburban mass-transit lines, says the Senate, along with Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and the Assembly, would have to sign off on any such transfer. Thus, Mr. Levy's opposition is considered a significant obstacle to its passage. Behind his complaint is a classic battle shaping up between the Republican-led State Senate, which represents the vast majority of suburban commuters, and the Democratic-controlled Assembly, whose strength depends on votes from city residents who are sure to be unhappy about a steep fare increase.
But this division, as always, has complicating undercurrents. For example, as much as the Senate Republicans have catered to suburban interests, their majority in the chamber would crumble without the six men from their 35-member delegation who come from New York City. These six have urged colleagues to find some way to help reduce the city fare increase or avert it altogether.
Reflecting this division, Senator Roy M. Goodman, a Manhattan Republican, said today that it was an "outrage" that 25-cent increases were being considered in the city while the commuter railroads had managed to freeze current fares until at least the end of 1992.
"I personally take the view that any effort to give the commuter lines a two-year holiday while soaking New York City straphangers with such a gigantic increase would be unacceptable," he said.
Because fare increases are among the most irritating reflections of the mounting costs of public services, politicians go to considerable lengths to shun responsibility for them.
Even Mr. Levy, of Merrick, L.I., who earlier this year persuaded the M.T.A. to freeze commuter fares after he got rail officials to admit they had surplus funds to avert an increase, said he wished to avoid any increase in the city fares. He suggested that they be frozen for now, while an audit is conducted to see if the city subway and bus system has surplus funds.
But an audit completed just a few weeks ago by the Deputy State Comptroller for New York City, Elinor B. Bachrach, found that the Transit Authority's operating deficit was real and was caused mainly by "the severe downturn in the local economy."
Many lawmakers agree that something has to be done to put more money in the system.
Jerrold A. Nadler, a Manhattan Democrat who is chairman of the Assembly Committee on Corporations, Authorities and Commissions, which handles M.T.A. matters, said it was "grossly unfair" that fares on the Transit Authority, which runs the city's subway and buses, account for a higher percentage of that system's operating funds -- about 61 -- than fares on the commuter railroads. The commuter fares pay less than 50 percent of the costs of running Metro-North and Long Island Rail Road. Most of the rest of the operating costs come from various subsidies.
Equalizing the rate of subsidies by using state funds could transfer tens of millions of dollars from the suburban railroads to the city's mass transit system.
Governor Cuomo will ultimately play a major role in the dispute. But while he has said he is opposed to the $1.40 fare, he has not yet stated an opinion on transferring funds from suburban lines to the city's system. Aides said today that he was considering that option as one of many ways to pare down the fare increase.

HEADLINE: Hearings on Economy Opening Today

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4

 BODY:
The Congressional hearings on the state of the economy that begin Thursday will spotlight the fundamental difference between Republicans and Democrats over tax policy and what makes the economy tick.
The basic Republican principle of the last half-century has been that if rich people's taxes are reduced they will invest more money. That, in the Republican view, will cause the economy to grow, leading to more jobs and prosperity for all Americans. 
 The Republicans describe this as a rising tide lifting all boats. Democrats deride it as trickle-down economics.
The main tenet of the Democrats' tax policy is that the wealthy should be taxed as heavily as needed to finance Government programs that mostly benefit the poor and the middle class.
 
2 Sides of Issue
 Democrats call this fairness and say that reducing the gap between the rich and the poor leads to a more productive economy. Republicans say redistribution of income has nothing to do with improving the economy.
The hearings before the House Ways and Means Committee, to be televised on C-Span, open at 10 A.M. with testimony from the Bush Administration's top economic policy makers: Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady; Richard G. Darman, the budget director, and Michael J. Boskin, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers. On Friday, lawmakers from both parties will offer their own tax proposals.
Some of the issues that will be discussed at the hearings -- capital gains, last year's budget agreement, individual retirement accounts, real estate tax breaks, middle-class tax relief -- can be arcane, but understanding them is essential to understanding not only the hearings but also what is likely to be the central debate in next year's election Presidential campaign.
The Democratic and Republican positions on taxes are in sharpest focus on the question of capital gains, the profits from investments. The Tax Reform Act of 1986 raised the rate on capital gains to the same as that on other income like wages, interest and dividends. Before that, the rate on capital gains had been significantly lower. Last year Congress raised the maximum tax rate on ordinary income to 31 percent from 28 percent but left the top capital gains rate at 28 percent, a much smaller difference than the one that existed before 1986.
 
Dispute on Capital Gains
 President Bush has proposed lowering the capital gains tax so that the top rate would be around 21 percent, and most Republicans and some Democrats support him. They make several arguments: a lower rate would encourage investment and induce investors to take risks that could lead to innovations; it would improve real estate prices, reducing the cost of bailing out failed banks and savings institutions by bringing in more money from the sale of assets; it would redress in part the imbalance in the current system that allows companies to deduct interest payments but not dividends; it would help offset the fact that part of the increase in the value of an investment, whether in stock, real estate or some other property, is usually a result of inflation.
The Republicans also argue that a cut in the capital gains tax would actually raise revenue for the Government because more people would sell their property and thus be subject to the tax. As long as an investment is not sold, no tax is paid.
The Democrats who oppose a lower tax on capital gains maintain that Republicans vastly overstate the extent to which such a tax break would stimulate investment. They note that many of the country's biggest investors, like pension funds, foundations and universities, are not taxed anyway and so would not be affected by a lower capital gains tax. They also assert that reducing the tax would lead to the reintroduction of unproductive tax shelters, which were virtually eliminated by the 1986 law.
But the Democrats' main argument is that the bulk of the benefit from a reduced tax on capital gains would go to the wealthiest taxpayers, since they are the ones who make most of the investments. Studies show that about two-thirds of all capital gains are enjoyed by taxpayers with incomes over $200,000 a year and that more than three-quarters go to those with incomes over $100,000.
The Democrats agree that in the first year or two, the Government would get a windfall of revenue as investors sold their holdings. But over five years, the Democrats say, a lower capital gains tax would lead to less income for the Treasury.
 
Judging Who Is Right
 Economists disagree over which side is right, but they generally agree that both sides have overstated their cases. Even economists in the Bush Administration say a lower capital gains tax would increase economic growth by only a fraction of a percentage point a year. And while rich taxpayers would undoubtedly get richer, opponents of the tax break can hardly argue that other taxpayers would be much worse off.
Another issue that is likely to be debated thoroughly at the hearings is whether the Government should stick to the budget agreement that was struck last year by the President and Congress. Under that law, any tax cut must be offset by a spending reduction or a tax increase elsewhere, unless the President declares a national emergency to deal with a specific issue. And money cannot be shifted from the military to domestic programs. As long as the agreement is not broken, the Government cannot take the steps it usually takes in a recession, cutting taxes and raising spending to give the economy a jolt.
Proponents of changing the budget procedures say that the country needs a quick stimulus to climb out of recession and that it makes no sense to stick to rules about military spending that were set before the collapse of Soviet Communism.
But many economists and politicians say that relaxing the discipline of the budget law would cause the financial markets to worry about the threat of inflation, resulting in an increase in long-term interest rates that would be damaging to the economy.
In addition to the capital gains question, a number of other tax issues are expected to be explored at length in the hearings. One is whether tax breaks should be broadened for individual retirement accounts.
Before the 1986 law went into effect, taxpayers could take deductions for money placed in I.R.A.'s, and no taxes were paid on the money until it was withdrawn at retirement. The new law limited such deductions to taxpayers not covered by company pension plans unless their annual income was below $25,000 for an individual or $40,000 for a couple.
Some lawmakers want to reinstate the old system of deductions or create a new kind of I.R.A. with various tax benefits. These legislators, and some economists who have studied the matter, believe that such a policy would improve the national rate of saving, creating a new pool of money for investment. Others doubt that overall saving would increase and say taxpayers would simply shift money from where it is now to a tax-favored I.R.A.
Another tax question is whether to revive old real-estate tax breaks. Under old law, investors in real estate could write off paper losses against income earned from working. This was the basis of tax shelters enjoyed by many highly paid professionals and executives.
These kinds of shelters were abolished by the 1986 law. The result was a decrease in the value of commercial real estate, and that was one of the causes of the savings and loan disaster and of the dismal condition of the real-estate industry that exists in many parts of the country.

HEADLINE: Justices Weigh Ban on Voicing Hate

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4

 BODY:
The Supreme Court wrestled today with what steps the Constitution permits governments to take in efforts to curb speech and acts that express hostility based on race, religion or sex.
"Each generation must reaffirm the guarantees of the First Amendment with the hard cases," the Justices were told by a lawyer representing a St. Paul teen-ager who is charged with burning a cross on a black family's lawn in violation of the city's "hate crime" ordinance. 
 It was apparent throughout the hourlong argument that this was a difficult case, as likely to fuel as to resolve the debate over campus speech codes and the many recently enacted state laws that attach criminal penalties to speech or actions motivated by bias. Most states have passed such laws in the last few years.
 
Broad Terms of Law
 The two-year-old St. Paul ordinance is expressed in broader terms than most of these laws, defining as a crime the display of any symbol or label that can be expected to arouse "anger, alarm or resentment in others" on the basis of a person's race, religion or sex.
These phrases are so general as to raise serious constitutional problems under the Supreme Court's First Amendment precedents. The Minnesota Supreme Court upheld the ordinance by, in effect, judicially rewriting it to make it apply only to types of expression that the United States Supreme Court has found to be unprotected by the First Amendment.
Under the Minnesota court's opinion, the ordinance bars only "fighting words," those likely to incite violence or produce "imminent lawless action." The phrases come from two Supreme Court precedents, one from 1942 and the other from 1969. It is the state court's interpretation, rather than the ordinance as originally written, that is now before the Justices.
Several Justices made clear today that the Minnesota court did not necessarily solve the ordinance's constitutional problems by trying to make it consistent with Supreme Court precedent.
 
2 Kinds of 'Fighting Words'
 Justices Antonin Scalia and David H. Souter both questioned whether a law can constitutionally prohibit some "fighting words" -- those motivated by bias against specified groups -- while ignoring other "fighting words." The Court has generally interpreted the First Amendment as barring government from regulating speech on the basis of its content.
"If you want to prohibit fighting words, why not just prohibit fighting words?" Justice Scalia asked Thomas J. Foley, the prosecutor for Ramsey County, Minn., who was defending the ordinance. Why define some and not others as illegal, Justice Scalia asked.
Mr. Foley replied that speech and conduct motivated by racial or other bias created more harm and had a more serious effect on the community.
"That's a political judgment," Justice Scalia said. He added that some people might be more offended by provocative speech about economics "or even philosophy."
Justice Scalia also questioned the ordinance's limitation of the type of expressed bias it prohibits. "You say 'bias motivated,' but that depends on what your biases are," Justice Scalia told Mr. Foley, offering as an example a cross burning intended to deter the placement of a home for the mentally ill. Mr. Foley agreed that the ordinance would not apply to such an incident, because the ordinance is limited to bias on the basis of race, religion or sex. .
"So it's the wrong kind of bias," Justice Scalia said. "Why is that? It seems to me the rankest kind of subject-matter discrimination."
The discussion of "fighting words" led the Court to a difficult constitutional question, the answer to which could determine the outcome of the case.
Mr. Foley asserted that because "fighting words" were not worthy of First Amendment protection at all, as the Court has long held, there is no constitutional problem with a law that punishes some fighting words and not others. Because the entire category is "outside the First Amendment," he said, the Court's usual concern about government regulation based on the content of speech does not apply.
 
Making New Law
 Justice Souter commented, "If we accepted your view, we would be making new law." He did not indicate whether he or other members of the Court would welcome such a development. In fact, a number of constitutional scholars have questioned how valid the Court's 50-year-old "fighting words" doctrine remains in light of the evolution of First Amendment law in the intervening decades. Since its original ruling, Chaplinsky v. New Hampshire, the Court has never upheld a conviction based on "fighting words." In that 1942 decision, the Court upheld the conviction of a man who, in violation of a law that prohibited insults in a public place, had called a city official a "racketeer" and "a damned fascist"
Edward J. Cleary, the lawyer challenging the St. Paul ordinance, said the measure remained unconstitutional, even as interpreted by the Minnesota Supreme Court. He said the state court had not eliminated the possibility that the ordinance could be used to chill "political discourse and debate."
Although "many well-meaning groups" support ordinances of this kind, Mr. Cleary said, "this is the hour of danger for the First Amendment."
Mr. Cleary's client, Robert A. Viktora, has not yet been tried for the cross burning, which under the bias ordinance is a misdemeanor carrying a 90-day jail sentence. The lawyer described the conduct his client was charged with as "reprehensible and abhorrent." He said that cross burning or other bias-related activity could be addressed by "neutral" laws that prohibit "terrorist threats" to anyone, without reference to motivation.
The Court will decide the case, R.A.V. v. St. Paul, No. 90-7675, by early next summer.

HEADLINE: Castro, in Talk With U.S. Senator, Calls Fuel Crisis 'the Biggest Test'

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4

 BODY:
President Fidel Castro told a visiting United States Senator this week that Cuba was struggling with a fuel and energy crisis that he regarded as "the biggest test of the survival of our revolution."
The Senator, Larry Pressler, a South Dakota Republican and member of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, said Mr. Castro and his aides told him in a meeting that began Sunday night and stretched over more than five hours into Monday morning that Cuba would receive less than a third of the oil it was expecting from the Soviet Union this year. Work on a Soviet-built nuclear power plant, which Cuba planned to open in 1992, has been stalled because the Russian republic is not sending equipment, Mr. Pressler was told. 
 In Havana, bicycles appear to have replaced most cars on the streets and only about a third of the public buses are operating, Senator Pressler said. Commenting on his four days of travel in the Cuban countryside before he met with Mr. Castro, he said Soviet tractors were in disrepair or broken down for lack of spare parts.
"Havana looked like Ho Chi Minh City, with bicycles all over," the Senator said in an interview by telephone Monday from the Dominican Republic after leaving Cuba. "Castro tried to give it a positive side, saying he thinks this is good for the environment. But the Cubans are running out of fuel."
 
From Tractors to Oxen
 The Cuban President also said that Havana would replace farm machinery with oxen, a plan Mr. Pressler, a farmer as well as a lawyer, described as impractical, because there are not enough animals available for agriculture on the Cuban scale.
"I said, you're going to be the first country in the world to go from tractors back to oxen," the Senator said. "He said, if we have to do it, we're going to do it."
Mr. Pressler said Mr. Castro added that if Cuba could not overcome the crisis caused by the breakup of the Soviet Union and the loss of Soviet aid and commodities at concessionary prices, "no one in Washington would take us seriously."
In the meeting, which included a late-night dinner, President Castro spoke for the first time to a visiting American about what went on behind closed doors at a Cuban Communist Party congress in October. At that session, the Cuban President made one of his characteristically long speeches in which he called Western democracy "garbage."
The Senator, who had not previously been to Cuba, said President Castro told him that the Communist Party congress had been devoted overwhelmingly to a discussion of "where Marxism-Leninism goes from here." Moves toward democratization were apparently not considered seriously, Mr. Pressler said.
The Cuban leader, speaking in Spanish through an interpreter, argued that his brand of socialism was never imitative of any other model and that it would go on being unique. He called his new philosophy "socialism with joint ventures," Senator Pressler said. President Castro ruled out elections, saying they could not be held when there was no fuel and the country's economy was on a "war" footing.
The joint ventures Cuban officials are seeking are primarily in the tourist industry, Havana's biggest hope for earning hard currency.
 
Shortages Are Everywhere
 Everywhere there are consumer shortages, Mr. Pressler said, and some seem likely to have an effect on the health of Cubans, especially children. The country is unable to find enough dairy products, he said, because a barter agreement with the former East Germany that brought in milk and other goods in return for Cuban orange juice was lost in the collapse of the regime.
The shortages appear to have affected the Cuban President's life, too, Mr. Pressler said, noting that Mr. Castro seemed to travel with a portable generator to provide light for his late-night sessions.
A doctor was also in attendance at the meeting, in which President Castro talked at length about health and fitness. He told Senator Pressler that he did 30 minutes of exercise a day on a stationary bicycle.
Senator Pressler and his aides steered the discussion toward Cuban relations with the Soviet Union several times. The Senator said that the Cubans seemed most bitter about the Russian republic, which has cut its aid most drastically. Soviet military support is also being reduced, Mr. Castro said, telling the Americans that "a whole era of Russian soldiers and arms in Cuba is probably over."
Asked who Cuba's closest friends were now, Mr. Castro said "no one."

HEADLINE: Survey by Fed Sees More Weakness

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4

 BODY:
The nation's economy continued to weaken on the eve of the holiday shopping season and retailers struggled to lure customers with widespread discounting, the Federal Reserve said today.
The Fed said a survey by its 12 regional banks "generally suggested flagging momentum in the economic recovery in October and early November." 
 Middle America experienced "continued but slower growth," while the economy remained "stable to slightly weaker" elsewhere, it found.
The survey was completed the day before Thanksgiving and two days before the traditional start of the holiday shopping season when retailers generally make half of their annual sales and profits.
Not only does the Fed survey bode ill for merchants, but it also was bound to cause fresh concern over the nation's ability to emerge from the recession.
 
Importance of Consumers
 Consumer spending represents two-thirds of the nation's economic activity and thus is essential for any sustained recovery. Retail sales account for about half of consumer outlays.
"Retail sales generally remained sluggish," according to a summary of the survey, adding that in the Atlanta and Cleveland districts, sales gains were concentrated in non-durable goods, those not expected to last three years.
"Dallas, Boston and Kansas City each reported weakness in sales of big-ticket items," it said. "Minneapolis indicated that retail sales have generally been stagnant except for areas close to the Canadian border, which have benefited from a surge in shopping by Canadians.
"Active discounting was widely noted," the survey found, "and several reports indicated that discounting was necessary to achieve sales gains."
The Fed banks conduct the surveys eight times a year to use in considering monetary policy. The policy makers meet again on Dec. 17 amid some speculation that they will make further cuts in interest rates to help stimulate the economy and insure the recovery. The central bank has been hesitant to lower rates further, fearing that action could spur inflation.
Still, the survey found that "reports on price trends suggested steady to diminished inflation."
The central bank last eased credit conditions on Nov. 6 when it reduced the discount rate, which it charges banks for loans, to 4.5 percent, the lowest in 20 years. At the same time, it nudged the Federal funds rate, the interest banks charge each other for overnight loans, to 4.75 percent.
The survey also found new car sales were uniformly weak across the nation and said manufacturing activity had flattened in most districts.
 
In Cleveland and Chicago
 "Conditions in the auto industry contributed to some slowing in the growth expected in the Cleveland and Chicago districts," the summary said.
But the weakness was not confined to the automobile industry. The survey found manufacturing activity also fell in the Boston, Philadelphia and Richmond districts and said continued sluggishness existed in the Atlanta, Kansas City and San Francisco regions. Manufacturing was mixed in Chicago, Cleveland and St. Louis.
"Housing activity continued to expand at a slow pace," the summary said, with modest improvements in the Atlanta, Kansas City and St. Louis districts.
"Demand for existing homes picked up in the New York metropolitan area, particularly among first-time home buyers attracted by lower mortgage interest rates and lower home prices," the survey found.
 
Sales of Existing Homes
 But it said "sales of existing homes softened in parts of the Chicago district, and home remodelers in the Chicago metropolitan area reported sluggish demand."
Commercial construction, on the other hand, remained weak.

HEADLINE: Power of the Yen Winning Asia New 'Co-Prosperity' Is Displacing U.S.

SERIES: 50 Years Later -- Last of three articles: Asian Quest

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia

 BODY:
The day that most Americans remember as a day of infamy resonates very differently in Asia. Here, Pearl Harbor is regarded as a sideshow to Japan's real ambitions in World War II -- the creation of a "Greater East Asian Co-Prosperity Sphere," an economic and military empire that stretched from the coal mines of Manchuria to the oilfields of Indonesia.
Fifty years later, in radically different form and with very different purposes, the co-prosperity sphere lives on. Over the last decade, while America's attention was elsewhere, Japan has poured billions of dollars and enormous energy into the region, building car factories and electronics plants here on the edge of the Malaysian jungle, employing thousands in the Thai countryside and erecting giant shopping centers and office towers in Hong Kong and Singapore. 
 As Japan has turned Asia into its manufacturing and merchandising backyard, it has ever so gradually begun to displace the United States as the most politically influential power in the region. This time, the Japanese insist, the outcome will be real co-prosperity, with the power of the yen, not the military, bringing Asia into its own.
With surprisingly little trepidation, Southeast Asians have welcomed Japan's return, concluding that the road to industrialization, or at least to capital and technology, now starts in Tokyo. Certainly deep bitterness remains: Emperor Akihito and Japan's political leaders still cannot arrive anywhere in Asia without apologizing and promising that Japan will never again seek new territory. Tellingly, even a debate now under way in the Japanese Parliament over an apology for the suffering caused during World War II is aimed more at Asia than at the United States.
But whatever fears Asia has of a resurgent Japan are overwhelmed by a growing conviction that Japan's studiously non-ideological pragmatism should be the archetype for much of the rest of Asia.
"I think there is a sense in Southeast Asia that the Americans kicked themselves out," said Takakazu Kuriyama, who recently retired as Japan's deputy foreign minister and served in the mid-80's as ambassador to Malaysia. "In the 60's and 70's the United States understood its strategic interests in the area. But it is not clear now that it always understands its economic interests."
To travel through Southeast Asia today is to hear government officials and industrial leaders talk enthusiastically about their one-time invader as their teacher and financier. In contrast, the United States is often described as the region's absentee ally, a continuing military presence but an increasingly marginal player in the most dynamic, booming economies in the world today.
In their more candid moments, Japanese officials say that how they harness Asia's talent and energy in the next few years may ultimately determine whether, in the early part of the next century, Japan's economy overtakes that of the United States. For them, Asia is the critical cog in the machine, a cure for Japan's shortage of talented labor and inexpensive land, a way to free up Japan's resources for more profitable, research-oriented work at home.
 
Embracing Capitalism, Japanese Style
 For Japan, investing in Asia has been an enormously profitable strategy, not only by manufacturing there but by selling there. Japanese argue that their efforts have helped Asia too, fueling the double-digit growth that swept many of its hard-driving economies through much of the 80's. Only recently have those rates slowed to growth of 6 to 9 percent a year, at a time much of the rest of the world economy is stagnant.
The most remarkable change wrought by the Japanese is what they have built over the last six years -- at a cost of more than $25 billion, three times what the United States has spent in the same period. Piece by piece, corporate Japan has created a startling replica of itself, not only in look and feel but also in culture. As a result, a region that only 15 years ago was seen by the United States as on the brink of falling to Communism has instead embraced a decidedly capitalist model -- but capitalism Japanese-style.
The shift is most vivid inside the giant factories of the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company here. The company's operations account for more than 3 percent of Malaysia's gross national product. Every morning, 17,000 Malaysian workers pour through the gates wearing uniforms nearly identical to those at Matsushita's headquarters in Osaka. They start the day by singing the Matsushita song -- in Malay -- and spend 45 minutes discussing Japanese-style manufacturing techniques with their managers before heading to their posts on sparkling, highly automated production lines.
The Japanese love it. "In some ways it is better than operating in the U.S.," says Tadashi Akita, the head of Matsushita's operations here and a veteran of the company's plants in North America. "Now, we can buy most of our parts here. The quality is high."
And because the cultural gap between teacher and student seems narrower than it does when Japan builds factories in the West, "the workers are easy to train," Mr. Akita said.
Matsushita is here largely because the Prime Minister, Mahathir Mohamad, has explicitly urged his people for the last decade to "look East," and find Asia's future with other Asians, meaning the Japanese. Mr. Mahathir has spent most of the year pressing a plan for a new economic grouping that excludes non-Asians. Japan, torn between its Asian identity and its Western interests, would be the linchpin, and so far it has sided with the United States in trying to bury the idea. Like their counterparts in Singapore and Seoul, Malaysia's planners have closely copied Tokyo's strategy of "targeting" strategic industries, financing major projects in autos and electronics, exporting fiercely and protecting infant industries.
"What we most want to emulate is the Japanese work ethic, the sense of loyalty to the country and the company," said Mohamad Rusli, one of Malaysia's economic planners. "Japan's experience of rebuilding after the war, the way it got workers and management to cooperate and got the economy to grow in leaps and bounds, seems very Asian to us. It has much more relevance to our society than the experience of the West."
Without question, the new co-prosperity sphere is very different from the old. The Japanese who landed in Dutch-controlled Indonesia, the Philippines and the old British colony of Malaya 50 years ago had to fight their way off the beaches. Today they are feted the way Katsushige Mita, president of Hitachi Ltd., was a few weeks ago when he arrived here to open yet more factories. "We feel very welcome here," Mr. Mita said.
Japan's motives have also changed. Hideki Tojo, Japan's wartime prime minister, sought natural resources and military bases to keep the imperial empire afloat, and promised liberation from "ruthless exploitation by the United States and Britain."
Today Mitsubishi, Toyota and Mitsui seek liberation from the expense of doing business in Japan and promise to bring VCR's and Japanese fashions to a rising generation of Asian consumers. And this time, the Japanese have kept explicit political ideology out of the equation, substituting the highly pragmatic, pro-business formulas that implicitly promise to make other Asian countries more like Japan.
That has given Japan a political influence in the region that is hard to define, yet universally felt. In Kuala Lumpur, for example, virtually everyone acknowledges that one of the most influential behind-the-scenes power brokers is the longtime head of the Mitsui trading company office, Kazumasa Suzuki. In Thailand, the military Government has made it clear that the No. 1 concern of Japanese investors, rapidly improving a network of roads and telephones that is collapsing under the strain of development, has also become the Government's top priority.
"They have a forceful, one-dimensional approach to developing Asia's economies," Paul Cleveland, the American Ambassador to Malaysia, said of Japan's approach. "Later on, as a great nation and people, I'm sure the Japanese harbor other designs. But right now, they may not know what they are."
Other factors have paved the way for Japanese-style capitalism. For example, almost all of the countries pursuing the Japanese model are run by authoritarian-leaning governments that openly admire the 35 years of single-party rule by Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party. Many consider that stability essential to staying focused on economic development.
Wartime antagonisms do still run high in some of these countries, especially in places like Singapore, where 130,000 Chinese were killed as Japanese forces swept down the Malay peninsula and captured the city in the winter of 1941-42. In Korea, a Japanese colony for 40 years and today Japan's biggest Asian manufacturing rival, enmity for the Japanese often bubbles to the surface in conversations, especially when the subject turns to how Japan has cut South Korea off from new, Japanese-developed technology.
Elsewhere, though, a desire to build new bridges to Japan is quickly softening wartime memories. Thai officials now frequently point out that Thailand was allied with Japan during the war, something that was impolitic to mention just a few years ago. Japanese in Malaysia contend that older residents have thanked them for the Japanese invasion. "They say it triggered the postwar independence movement" from Britain, Mr. Akita noted recently.
At the same time, there is a constant worry about Japan's ultimate intentions. The Singapore Defense Minister, commenting on a plan under consideration in Japan's Parliament to allow the Japanese military to join United Nations peacekeeping forces, warned that Japan has the technology and power to "transform overnight into a military power of the highest order." Singapore has led the calls for the United States to remain a major military presence in the region.
"There is no country in Asia that would welcome us," a senior Japanese diplomat in Tokyo said the other day, "if the U.S.-Japan relationship was not maintained. With our past and our size, they would be too scared."
 
Is America's Mind Elsewhere?
 But America's presence is not solely military. Singapore, for example, remains a leading outpost of American companies, from Apple to A.T.&T., and there are American success stories in every country. Exxon and other oil companies continue to invest heavily in drilling projects; Intel and Motorola have expanded their electronics operations; Asia is one of the few bright spots for I.B.M. these days. American companies are courted because of their willingness -- in contrast to Japanese concerns -- to transfer technology and promote local executives.
Nonetheless there is a widespread sense that America's mind is elsewhere. "American executives come through here, and intellectually they understand it when I tell them that if they are not in Asia in the next century, they will probably be out of business," said Mr. Cleveland, who with other American ambassadors in the area plans to barnstorm around the United States early next year to drum up more investment.
"But it requires a lot more to invest in Asia," he added. "You have to change your character, your own practices. And in the end, many decide they don't want to do it."
Rightly or wrongly, Japanese cite America's absence as an example of the short-sightedness of American industry. "U.S. companies will change their mind in the near future," said Atsushi Oi, who overseas Japan's Asia strategies for the powerful Minister of International Trade and Industry. "And the market will still be growing. But no one can really understand why they are giving up the chance to grab leading positions."
Japan's move into Asia began in earnest in 1985, soon after the so-called Plaza currency accord with the United States strongly drove up the value of the yen and the price of Japanese exports. Desperate to cut costs, Japanese companies flocked to countries with easily trained, low-cost labor.
By all accounts, it was not a move orchestrated by the Japanese Government. Like most of Japan's industrial policy today, it did not need to be. The Keidanren, the organization that represents Japan's biggest businesses, organized "survey tours" and investing in Southeast Asia soon became a game of one-upmanship.
If the move was driven by economics, it was accelerated by Japanese-American trade politics. Goods built in Malaysia or Thailand are not included in Japan's trade accounts with the United States, even if they contain largely Japanese components. So Japan can still make television sets and VCR's and send them to American stores without further enlarging the American trade deficit with Japan because of what amounts to an accounting shell game that no one has yet been able to quantify accurately. If these goods were counted, the Japanese trade surplus would look far larger.
The development process was speeded by policy changes in some of the Asian countries. Malaysia, for example, had depended for years on its own people -- chiefly the "bumiputra," or native Malays, to industrialize the country. But it was not working. The Chinese minority in Malaysia, often at odds with the bumiputra, dominated the business world.
 
Call Goes Out For Foreign Help
 So Mr. Mahathir, a wily leader with a strong nationalistic streak, reversed course, creating huge tax incentives for foreign investment and calling in companies like Mitsubishi Motors to design and manufacture a national car. Today the streets are filled with a compact model call the Proton, complete with an illuminated Malaysian flag on the hood. Now more than 800 Japanese manufacturers are here, and their presence has transformed the economy: 59 percent of Malaysia's exports in 1990 were manufactured goods.
Matsushita led the drive. It vastly expanded its plants. Today it has one of the world's largest air-conditioner plants here -- Malaysia next year will be the world's largest producer of room air-conditioners -- and it is building 14-inch television sets on a highly automated manufacturing line that uses some equipment so advanced that it has yet to be installed in Matsushita's older plants in Japan.
Matsushita brought with it a raft of Japanese suppliers, many of whom entered joint ventures with local companies. Now roughly 80 percent of the parts used in the television sets are locally sourced -- though many of them by Japanese-based companies with long ties to the electronics giant.
Slowly Japan is moving more technology to places like the Matsushita plant, even designing television sets there. But as the investment flow slows -- it is already beginning to happen -- tensions seem bound to rise. Japan's experience in Korea and Taiwan suggests it still plans to leave the most advanced, highest-value work at home, farming out the less profitable tasks. Over time, the nations that welcome Japan today may feel increasingly exploited.
The lingering question of Japan's real motives will always push itself to the fore. For now, the Japanese seem happy to keep the new co-prosperity sphere solely economic in nature. But as Japan's interests in the region deepen, no one knows, in the words of a senior European diplomat with wide experience in the region, "how long the political presence will stay so benign."
For the United States, many believe, the time to challenge Japan in its home region is running short. "The story is like Pearl Harbor," said James Alfred, a Malaysian who has long worked for Matsushita. "I look around and I see America enjoying itself. The Japanese are busy getting ready for the next project, refueling themselves in the air. You never saw the planes coming across the Pacific, and you may not see this, either."

HEADLINE: Rebuilding the Building of Castles in the Sand in Casino Land

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTIC CITY

 BODY:
"It's the second oldest profession in Atlantic City," says Ralph Halpslader, who just a few months ago joined a new wave of sand sculptors in this storied resort city.
Mr. Halpslader, who is in his 30's and describes himself as "basically homeless," works as he talks, restoring tautness to the haunches of a 10-foot alligator tousled a bit by the wind. The alligator, which has seashells for teeth, seems to be stifling a grin that could make you look around to see if the dachshund you were walking is still safely on its leash -- a crocodile smile. 
 "Well, he could be a crocodile, if you want him to be a crocodile," said Mr. Halpslader, who is agreeable to almost anything as long as it makes you happy. "He could be Abraham Lincoln if you want him to be. This is entertainment. This is show business."
Whatever it is, sand sculpture has been around a long time in Atlantic City, though, like the city itself, it fell on hard times over the last few decades and seemed about to die out completely.
But now people like Mr. Halpslader, who sleeps under the boardwalk on starry nights when it is warm, or in his van when it's not, finds that shaping fantasy out of sand is satisfying to the soul -- and not a bad way to pick up some ready money for a fellow temporarily at liberty to pick up some ready money.
There are not many of them at work in the fall, the days being short, the sun shy and the temperatures less than balmy. But even so, a half-dozen sand artists, as they like to be called, can be found along the boardwalk on days that are not too chilly, usually in pairs, molding sand into whatever strikes their fancy -- alligators and sharks, sphinxes and pyramids, turtles and toadstools, octopuses and unicorns. Up the beach there is a 10-foot likeness of Neptune himself.
People stop on the boardwalk and look, admire the sand art or just laugh, and many throw down a coin or a bill by way of thanks.
How much can a fellow make, shaping sand?
Mr. Halpslader looked behind him, as if there was someone lurking, ready to knock on his door, even though he does not have a door.
"If I tell you that, the Internal Revenue Service will be after me," he said. "But there's rumors," he added, brightening. "People claim, let's say, people claim that they make over a thousand dollars on a weekend for their displays."
 
Art and Commerce
 A thousand dollars?
"Well," said Mr. Halpslader, at pains to dismiss the thought that sable art is abetted by green commerce, "that's over 24 hours, and you may have to split that up among 8 or 10 guys."
But even so, with times so hard, how does a sand artist keep his franchise, so to speak, his place on the beach, and the money from the milkshake cups the artists set on blankets in front of their work to catch the quarters people toss as they stroll between casinos.
"By having 8 to 10 guys on the displays, 24 hours a day, carrying a big baseball bat," Mr. Halpslader said, pulling back a forelock to display an ugly little crescent scar on his scalp.
"That was a made by a bottle of Thunderbird," he said. "Hit me there. People trying to rip my money off."
At their best, the sand fantasies are just that, "cartoons brought to life," as Mr. Halpslader put it. Down the beach are three yard-high sphinxes flanked by pyramids. But these are sphinxes that might have had Felix the Cat as an ancestor or Garfield as a sibling, grinning mightily. Beside them is a half-finished creature that looks suspiciously like a giant mouse. Its sculptors are nowhere to be found.
 
A Declining Craft
 Further up, Alan Cline, who is 33, hails from Memphis and does construction work when sand sculpting is slow, specializes in classic forms like the unicorn and the sea god Neptune (looking strangely Egyptian, it must be said). He laments the decline of the craft.
"The best don't like to do it anymore," he said. "There's too many amateurs."
City officials look at the rebirth of sand sculpture with some ambivalence, a tradition in the city but one now fraught with urban problems.
Regina Armstrong, director of economic development for Atlantic City, said sand sculpting of the more or less professional variety, as opposed to children building castles in the sand, sprang up just before the turn of the century, fell into decline after World War II and only recently underwent a rebirth -- one that is likely to be short-lived.
"We have what we think is the first recorded sand sculptor in 1897," she said, "a man named Philip McCord. The originator of sand pictures -- drawings in the sand rather than sculpture -- was James J. Taylor around 1900. This was a big business in the 1920's and 30's. People used to come and commmission a sculpture of their family, and businesses had their logos and corporate seals done."
 
'The End of an Era'
 Though artists were adamant that only sand be sculpted, Ms. Armstrong said, some sprayed the finished work with a concrete shell to make it permanent.
But then came the hurricane of 1944 -- the Great Hurricane, as it is remembered here -- which swept it all away, along with several miles of boardwalk and several piers. "It marked the end of an era," Ms. Armstrong said. "Atlantic City started downhill then. The spirit dulled, I suppose."
Last year, sand sculpture began to re-establish itself, and the city itself sponsored a family sand sculpting contest.
But the rebirth is in some peril. Within the next few years, Ms. Armstrong said, environmental regulations intended to protect the city's fragile dune structure will prohibit disturbing sand within 50 feet of the boardwalk, a prohibition that would effectively ban sand sculpture since the displays must be close to the boardwalk to draw crowds.
"Presently," she said, "we are allowing the artists along the flat areas. But that will change."
In the meantime, Mr. Halpslader said he might write a book detailing the history of the city's second-oldest profession. He said he knew nothing about the city's oldest profession -- fortunetelling.

HEADLINE: Words of Care Go With Gifts To Neediest

BYLINE: By J. PEDER ZANE

 BODY:
"This year more than last year, more than previous years, the need for your fund is apparent to any person who observes our city," Arthur Tenenholtz of Brooklyn wrote to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. "Although my employer has not granted a pay raise this year, I am increasing my donation."
Those words by Mr. Tenenholtz, who sent $50, echo the concerns of hundreds of people who have contributed to the Neediest Cases, which began its 80th appeal this week. The letters of those people reflect a mood of despair brought on by the recession. 
 "I am aware of many homeless, including whole families, many job seekers in a bad economy, many older and infirm and many people who of necessity are on welfare rolls," wrote Ruth A. Unterberg of Manhattan.
Through her $100 contribution, Ms. Unterberg wrote, she hopes that recipients will know "that they aren't forgotten."
Since it was founded in 1912 by Adolph S. Ochs, who was then publisher of The New York Times, the Neediest Cases Fund has raised money for New York's sick, poor and disabled. What began as the "Hundred Neediest Cases" has expanded to meet needs of thousands of individuals.
As in the past, The New York Times is covering all of the campaign's overhead so that every dollar collected can go directly to seven charities. Last year $4.4 million was raised from at least 15,580 individuals and organizations. The money provided many forms of relief, including food for the hungry, shelter for the homeless and clothing for those without. The seven charities also used the money to provide job training for the disabled, counseling for substance abusers and child abusers, and services that address the innumerable problems faced by victims of AIDS.
In short notes accompanying their gifts, many contributors said they were pleased that none of their money would go toward overhead or solicitation. "I like the fact that 100 percent of the donations go to people who need the money," Saul Bennett of Manhattan said in a telephone interview this week. "I also like the fact that it benefits people regardless of their race, religion or background."
Mr. Bennett, who is president of Robert Marston Marketing Communications, said the $50 his company sent in memory of the relative of a business colleague is the latest in a long line of contributions.
"I haven't missed a year since I saved a dollar from my allowance when I was 8 years old and sent it in," he said. "But I won't tell you how long that's been."

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Coffee Prices Drop Sharply On Setback for Export Plan

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Coffee futures prices fell sharply yesterday after the Brazilian Government said it would be up to the factionalized private sector to develop a price-support plan.
Coffee for March delivery tumbled 2.65 cents, to 82.55 cents a pound on New York's Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange, erasing most of the gains accumulated in the four previous sessions. The more lightly traded December contract fell 1.95 cents, to 78.80 cents a pound. 
 Coffee futures rallied recently on indications that Brazil, the world's largest coffee producer, was leaning toward a return to export quotas to raise prices.
The last such agreement among the world's largest coffee-exporting and importing countries collapsed in mid-1989. As delegates to the 73-nation International Coffee Organization gathered Tuesday in London, the presidents of Brazil and Colombia signed a statement proposing discussions among exporters on strategies for withholding coffee from the market.
But yesterday, Brazil's Deputy Economy Minister, Dorothea Werneck, said it was up to the Brazilian and Colombian private sectors to negotiate any price-support plan. The Brazilian Government's only role was to offer encouragement, she said.
The surprise announcement started heavy selling by speculators because it apparently left responsibility for both negotiating and financing a price-support plan largely up to the sharply divided segments of Brazil's coffee industry.
"The private sector already is considered to be in dire financial shape, prohibiting any outcome to the talks going on in London," said Sandra Kaul, coffee analyst with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. in New York.
Petroleum futures rallied on the New York Mercantile Exchange, partly in reaction to a weekly industry report on Tuesday showing lower-than-expected stocks of crude oil.
Crude oil for January delivery rose 25 cents, to $20.76 a barrel; January heating oil rose 0.86 cent, to 60.33 cents a gallon; January unleaded gasoline rose 0.44 cent, to 57.09 cents a gallon.
Soybean futures prices rose strongly on the Chicago Board of Trade amid indications of fresh Soviet demand. The market recovered most of the previous day's losses.
Wheat futures finished mixed while corn and oat futures ended mostly higher.
Wheat for delivery in December rose 4 cents to settle at $3.90 1/4 a bushel; December corn rose 3/4 cent, to $2.39 1/2 a bushel; December oats rose 3 cents, to $1.27 a bushel; January soybeans rose 7 1/4 cents, to $5.62 3/4 a bushel.
Near-term live cattle futures rose, reflecting perceptions that the market's recent losses were exaggerated. Other livestock futures ended lower, under pressure in in part from heavy hog slaughter levels. Pork bellies were narrowly mixed.
Live cattle for December delivery rose 0.08 cent, to 73.20 cents a pound; January feeder cattle slipped.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
Hard Times Call for the Hard Sell

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
RETAILERS are changing the face they present to shoppers during the holiday season, shifting from the warm and fuzzy image-building long popular at this time of year to hard-selling product promotions.
The changes are particularly noticeable in network television and magazines. They are beginning to seem more like radio and newspapers, filled with ads emphasizing prices, sales, limited-time offers and contests.
"Every bit of economic news is negative," said Pete Vetowich, executive vice president and director of retail at Ross Roy Group, which creates campaigns for K Mart and the K Mart Corporation's chains of office supply, sporting goods and home-improvement stores.
"You put that on top of the short selling season," Mr. Vetowich added in a telephone interview from his office in Bloomfield Hills, Mich., "and there's reason to be very promotional.
The changes are apparent in campaigns for K Mart, by Ross Roy; Sears, Roebuck & Company, by Ogilvy & Mather Chicago, and Toys "R" Us Inc., by J. Walter Thompson New York, and they echo what has been occurring in brand-name consumer products from cereal to soap. There, too, long-term image advertising has become subordinate to short-term promotional programs.
"In this tough economy, to keep the stores open, you've got to sell product," said Susan Marber, vice president and group management supervisor at Grey Advertising Inc. in New York, which creates broadcast spots for Bloomingdale's. Today and tomorrow, she added, the agency will shoot two holiday television spots for the retailer; one, called "Give Hope," will be altruistic, listing charities to which donations can be made, while the other, called "Best of Gifts," will be packed with products and prices.
When the spots start running on Dec. 13, "we'd love to do them 50-50," she continued, but in all likelihood the sales pitch will predominate.
For Toys "R" Us, Thompson New York has produced a television commercial touting the toy stores' selection of lower-priced video games, at $14.98 to $19.98, in addition to another spot, sans prices, devoted to the new Nintendo Entertainment System.
Toys "R" Us executives "wanted to make sure they were viewed as having reasonably priced video games as well as the higher-priced ones," said Marty Rose, a senior vice president and management director at Thompson New York, adding, "They know people are not as generous in spending money as in the past."
Among similar measures that Toys "R" Us is pursuing, Mr. Rose listed radio commercials centering on a guaranteed-low-price program and booklets of coupons good for discounts on purchases of Mattel Inc. toys.
At K Mart, shoppers will find they can enter a sweepstakes, called "Celebrate a Magical Disneyland Christmas," that offers more than 100,000 prizes like a $500,000 annuity and 3,000 trips to Disneyland.
While in previous, more economically robust years, it would have been unusual for retailers to sponsor such consumer-enticing contests, "when economic conditions are not really strong, anything we can do to enhance sales is our job," said Jerry Habeck, K Mart's vice president of advertising in Troy, Mich.
For all the popularity of promotional advertising, retailers and their agencies say they recognize the problems it can generate, like weakening a brand name's value and conditioning consumers to buy only when prices are marked down.
"It is inevitable that if you take the price message to its logical conclusion, you go out of business," said Tom Hall, president and chief executive at Ogilvy Chicago. That is why, he added, the agency, in creating Sears's holiday campaign, "gave consumers both kinds of messages, the price-product message and reasons why to feel smart or good about shopping at the store."
