HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Concerns on U.S. Economy Bring a Decline in the Dollar

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar ended weaker against major foreign currencies yesterday as new reports suggested problems with the United States economy.
Gold prices rose. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery rose $1.60, to $365.10 an ounce. A late bid at the Republic National Bank in New York quoted gold at $364.90, up $1.40. 
 The dollar opened higher early in the day after the Soviet Union told creditors it was halting payments on the principal portion of its foreign debt for one year.
Dan Scherman, senior trader at the Bank of Boston, said traders sought dollars as a safe haven after the Soviet announcement.
Against this backdrop, the dollar stood firm after the Commerce Department reported that gross domestic product in the third quarter was lower than had been expected. The G.D.P., the total output of goods and services produced inside the nation's borders, rose 1.7 percent from July through September. That was sharply below an earlier reported rate of 2.5 percent.
The dollar weakened, however, afterthe Federal Reserve released its so-called beige book survey of national business conditions, which suggested "flagging momentum" in October and November. Hardest hit were consumer spending, construction activity and factory production.
The dollar's losses accelerated after President Bush offered a pessimistic assessment of the economy in a speech before the American Enterprise Institute.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.7730, from $1.7715 late Tuesday. At the close in New York, a pound cost $1.7835, up from $1.7755 late Tuesday.
In Tokyo, the dollar fell 0.05 yen, to a closing 129.25 yen. Later in London it was quoted at 129.38 yen. In New York, the dollar sold for 129.10 yen at closing, down from 129.30 late Tuesday.

HEADLINE: Bagging a 10,000-Pound Twig House in the Wilds of Maine

BYLINE: By PATRICIA LEIGH BROWN

DATELINE: OLDWICK, N.J.

 BODY:
THE old adage says, "Never shop when depressed."
But Judyth van Amringe was depressed. Very depressed. 
 Business was slow. At the flea markets she frequents early on Sunday mornings, when the rest of the world is dreaming, the pickings were slim. Very slim. Like many of her cohorts in the antiques business, her spirit was being sapped by what she calls "that recession thing."
But one day last summer, as she was scanning The Newtown Bee, a Connecticut publication that is to antiques mavens what Field & Stream is to bass fishermen, fate intervened. It came in the form of an advertisement for an 8-by-20-foot house, handcrafted of logs and twigs, that was to be auctioned in Maine. That night, the 46-year-old Manhattanite tucked the now-crumpled ad under her pillow, as if she were expecting the twig fairy rather than the tooth fairy.
As the saying goes, she had to have it.
Thus began the Twig House Tale. Like the cat and dogs in "The Incredible Journey," who traipsed through the wilderness in search of their master, so the twig house began its inevitable 540-mile journey from rural Maine to Ms. van Amringe's weekend home in Hunterdon County, N.J.
For most people, life has its profound moments. Ms. van Amringe had hers while she was in her Saab at a toll booth on the New Jersey Turnpike. She suddenly caught sight of the twig house sitting on a flatbed truck in another lane, wheeling its way to her property, followed by another truck ceremoniously bearing oak logs for the foundation. It was, she said, "the perfect moment" -- and like any mother seeing her baby for the first time (hers weighed almost 10,000 pounds), she started to cry.
Ms. van Amringe's baby is approximately 95 years old and was originally a trapper's cabin, according to Charlie Melanson, a contractor in Westbrook, Me., who sold it to her and installed it.
The house came with wheels and a McMurtryesque legacy. The original owner was the town drunk, who used it both for trapping and for selling hot dogs at county fairs. He lost it in a card game. The victor willed it to his daughter, who in turn sold it to Mr. Melanson for $300 last year.
The auction was held last September in North Windham, Me., at M & S Discount, Mr. Melanson's antiques store. Ms. van Amringe wound up bidding against another antiques dealer from Manhattan and bought the house for $19,900.
"I had a gut feeling it was valuable," Mr. Melanson said. "If you want to sell anything, sell it to a New Yorker."
A month later, working 12 hours straight, Mr. Melanson and his crew trucked the house from North Windham to New Jersey and set it on its oak foundation, at a cost of $3,000. It joins a main house and three outbuildings in Ms. van Amringe's three acres of woods overlooking Mumford's Rock, a locally fabled trout pool. (Trout in the water appeal to her visually, but "once they're out of water, forget about it," she said.)
The house still conjures up images of hard drinking and tobacco, despite Ms. van Amringe's predilection for china decorated with trout flies. (She doesn't fish. She hates having to be quiet.)
Sitting now in a hollow framed by tree branches, with a tuft of smoke meandering out of its chimney, it out-Ralphs Ralph Lauren. It looks so perfectly woodsy that it could pose for a maple sugar bottle label.
It is not only an atmospheric prop but a work of folk art. The cedar log house is a miniature handmade world, with a cleverly arranged interior lined with wondrous gnarled burls. Its forgotten builder crafted shelves held up by dried fungi, a stone fireplace and a tiny closet containing a twig rod that looks like a crooked witch's finger. Etched into the beams are the names of the woods: "maple" where he used maple, "willow" where there is willow.
The fact that the house was crafted from twigs and moss, combined with the aroma of logs burnished with motor oil, appealed to Ms. van Amringe, whose own sensibility matches that of the builder (except for her knee-length black leather vest and velour leggings, a statement that springs from the wilds of SoHo).
For Ms. van Amringe, finding the twig house was the equivalent of Juliet combing the personals and finding Romeo. She has long been fascinated by little houses. A five-foot-high, six-foot-wide child's playhouse from the 1940's is one of the many objects adorning the bedroom of her duplex apartment in midtown Manhattan, an hour's drive from the twig house and her very fashionable whitewashed outhouse.
Ms. van Amringe's love of offbeat objects is exhibited in her shop on Greene Street in SoHo, which has a floor stenciled with poodles, a tribute to her two standard poodles, Bix and Ruby. Here she fashions her own versions of folk art: lamps with painted cords festooned with velvet grapes, Bakelite belt buckles, tassels and buttons. The lamps seem to be wearing hats and look as though they might drink tea and gossip.
A former fashion designer, Ms. van Amringe assembles interiors that seem to have sprouted magically from their source, as if they were divined by a Ouija board. She is adept at matching objects with places. By layering blankets, vintage fabrics, rugs and pillows, often bearing beads, buttons and other touches, she creates rooms that seem as if they have always been there.
The twig house was no exception: It took her all of one day to decorate it. Only Ms. van Amringe would just happen to have on hand a State of Maine blanket, a deer pictorial hooked rug, a copy of "Wood's Natural History," a portrait of an Indian maiden framed by birch bark, a collapsible chandelier, an ashtray made from a Maine license plate, ice-fishing decoys and a wooden box with "State of Maine" carved on it, bought at her favorite store -- a prison shop.
She knew in advance exactly where it would all go and hauled it to New Jersey in her poodle-ravaged car. "Once I set my mind to doing something, I do it -- fast," she said. She found the details of the house, like a fossil embedded in the fireplace stones, enchanting. "You sit here," she said, "and feel like you're in the middle of Maine somewhere."
But a Mainer probably would have been less likely to perch a fish weathervane in a wood pile for dramatic effect, or make an outdoor coat rack out of a tree branch plunked into an antique Christmas tree holder. Ms. van Amringe is esthetically fearless. She is the kind of person who checks into a hotel room and instantly sets about draping scarves over the lampshades and moving the furniture.
For her, there is equal beauty in a fossil and a fish hook, as well as a tiny twig house with an ever-so-picturesque sag at the bottom. Now the house, which she calls the chateau ("Isn't it adorable?"), seems as much a part of the landscape as a burl on a piece of wood. But it's doubtful a wizened trapper would recognize it, with its Beacon blanket throw pillows and artfully arranged bouquets of barbed wire.
Ms. van Amringe, who describes herself as a "three-month-a-year outdoor person," has yet to spend a night in the house. When a visitor asked how she intended to use it, she replied cheerfully, "I don't know."
But it's the thought that counts.
"Bye-bye," she said to the house, as she headed home to Manhattan. "Maybe I should have put it in a rented gallery space in SoHo. It's a work of art. Don't you think so?"

HEADLINE: 'Boys' Film Leaves Studio Wondering

BYLINE: By BERNARD WEINRAUB, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 4

 BODY:
Holiday decorations are splashed around the offices of 20th Century Fox, but the studio is probably the gloomiest in town.
After weeks of elaborate and expensive promotion of "For the Boys," the musical drama starring Bette Midler and James Caan, it has proved to be an unexpected box-office disappointment and perhaps the first major casualty of the holiday season, when moviegoing reaches a peak. The film, a sentimental and elaborately emotional story about two U.S.O. performers over 50 years, received mixed to good reviews, and in the studio and in the film industry it was seen as a potential winner. 
 But the trade newspaper Daily Variety called it "the holiday's only turkey" this week, and its dismal performance so far has unleashed a wave of anxiety and second-guessing about the future of movies aimed at audiences in their 30's, 40's and 50's. Beyond this, the fact that the industry can virtually write off a major movie after less than two weeks leaves the Fox studio despondent.
Joe Roth, the chairman of 20th Century Fox, said in an interview this week that he remained hopeful that "For the Boys" would emerge from the doldrums. "The fact is, we have terrific exit polls, as good as any movie we've released," he said. "Why haven't we made it so far? I wish I knew. If I knew I'd be able to correct it. I don't have any brilliant answers."
 
Some Hope Left
 The studio chief, whose record is largely successful, said he hoped the movie would eventually find an audience, and he cited other films appealing to adult audiences that also started slowly but eventually gathered momentum. These included the teary drama "Beaches," which starred Ms. Midler, and "The Verdict," a courtroom drama with Paul Newman.
But these films cost less than half the $40 million to $45 million that Fox paid for "For the Boys," not to mention promotion costs of probably $10 million to $15 million, making it one of the studio's most expensive and risky films. Although Fox is still basking in the financial sunshine because of the huge success of "Home Alone," the third-highest-grossing film in history, after "E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial" and "Star Wars," its recent movies have been disappointments. These include, "Dying Young," "Dutch" and "Only the Lonely."
"For the Boys" opened nationally over the weekend, and in New York and Los Angeles the weekend before. It had grossed a paltry $5.9 million as of Monday, said Exhibitor Relations Inc., which monitors film releases for theater chains. In contrast, "The Addams Family" grossed $24.2 million on its first weekend. Other holiday films that are showing signs of being major successes are "Beauty and the Beast" and "My Girl."
"Kids went out to see 'The Addams Family' the first or second weekend because moviegoing for them is like a tribal ritual," Mr. Roth said. "For people over 25, this is not the case. But all of this sounds like an excuse on my part, and I don't want to do that. I have a lot of faith in this picture."
 
Reasons for Failure
 Film executives at Fox and elsewhere attribute the apparent failure of "For the Boys" to several factors, including the World War II story line, music that has little appeal for younger audiences and the film's trailer, which does not make clear what the movie is about. They also point to the odd relationship between Mr. Caan and Ms. Midler's characters, who seem to dislike each other and have little romantic involvement. The film's mixed reviews, strong competition from other movies and economic conditions were also cited.
One executive said: "What is this film really about? If you look at it in story and structure terms, it's about two characters who don't fall in love, who don't physically relate to each other. It's the nature of the story that does this film in." The executive said that in successful films geared to older audiences, such as "Driving Miss Daisy" and "On Golden Pond," the relationships were intense and believable, while the one in this movie was not.
As conceived, the story of "For the Boys" was harder edged, industry executives said. Ms. Midler, whose company produced the film, has been fascinated for years by the entertainer Martha Raye, who performed for troops in Vietnam and was shocked to find herself booed by demonstrators when she returned to the United States. As a result, executives said, Ms. Midler began shaping a film, with Mark Rydell, the director, that was to have an antiwar message, with her character turning against the war, while her partner, played by Mr. Caan, remained a hawk. During many rewrites, the film was softened considerably and the message blurred.
One prominent executive called the fate of "For the Boys" sad. "One would like to think there's an audience out there for this kind of movie," he said. "To some extent its failure so far may be the tone of the times. People are looking for escape entertainment. There should be room for 'For the Boys' to flourish, but there just doesn't seem to be."

HEADLINE: Toward a 'Family Friendly' Work Place

BYLINE: By CAROL LAWSON

 BODY:
HER weekly calendar is a gridlock of meetings. Some are with parents who utter a familiar lament: If only they had 28 hours in a day, perhaps they might find the energy to handle jobs and raise children at the same time. Others are at corporations seeking ways to ease family stresses so employees can give their all when they are on the job.
Families and work. These are the two worlds of Ellen Galinsky, a co-president of the Families and Work Institute, a nonprofit research and advisory organization in New York. In the last decade, this 49-year-old educator and author has been a leader in efforts to bring the two together, to change corporate thinking so radically that American business might become what she calls "family friendly." 
 Progress has been slow and spotty. By Ms. Galinsky's own count, 33 percent of major American corporations have done almost nothing to help reduce employees' family pressures, and 46 percent more are just waking up to the issue. But the remaining 21 percent now offer employees an array of benefits like child-care assistance, leaves of absence to take care of infants or ill relatives, referral networks for the care of aging parents, job sharing and flexible work schedules to permit parents to spend more time with children.
"Only five years ago, work and family were seen by most corporations as very separate domains," Ms. Galinsky said. She said that while the recession may have slowed the spread of new family policies across the corporate landscape, the trend is irreversible.
Dr. T. Berry Brazelton, the Harvard pediatrician and child-rearing expert, said he was a great admirer of Ms. Galinsky.
"At first, corporations are not the least bit interested in what she has to say," Dr. Brazelton said. "But she has such drive and energy, yet her manner is so low key, that she is very convincing to high-powered people."
A preschool teacher by training, Ms. Galinsky has carved an unconventional career path. She testifies before Congress on family-related legislation, appears on television as an expert on child-rearing issues and travels around the country for speaking engagements.
But for most of her professional life Ms. Galinsky was on the faculty of Bank Street College, from which she received a master's degree in child development. She taught preschool children at Bank Street for five years, then did research and wrote books about child care and other subjects based on her own concerns as a parent and her interest in conflicts between work and family life.
The spark for Ms. Galinsky's career was struck one day when, as a sophomore at Vassar College, she walked into a child study class. Until then, she thought she was going to be a lawyer.
"The first day of the class, I said, 'Oh, wow, this is what I want to do,' " Ms. Galinsky recalled, her rapid-fire speech softened by a trace of her native West Virginia. "Vassar was very exciting at that time because it was on the cutting edge of studying how kids grow and how they learn."
Ms. Galinsky said that in the years when she was teaching, she always had a high opinion of her work, even though much of society does not regard teachers with the greatest respect.
"What happens to children is one of the most important issues this country can think about, so I never felt that I had a low-status job," she said. "I never went to cocktail parties and felt ashamed to say I was a teacher. I was always so proud."
That interest in children has inspired her books and research, as well as her newest and most ambitious venture, the Families and Work Institute. She founded it in 1989 with Dr. Dana Friedman, formerly a researcher in work-family issues at the Conference Board, a nonprofit business research organization.
After a shaky start and some sleepless nights for the two founders because of uncertain finances, the institute now has a staff of 21 and has raised $4.5 million in grants from corporations and foundations for research and consulting projects.
Ms. Galinsky is quick to concede that the name of her institute is something of a tongue twister. "Everybody gets it mixed up," she said. "We deliberately called it Families and Work, with 'families' first, because we are looking for ways to make family life better for people."
In one of its first projects, the institute helped design the $10 million family care development fund that was part of A.T.&T.'s collective bargaining agreement with its unions in 1989. The fund is to be used to increase the availability and quality of care available for employees' children and elderly family members.
Recently the institute published "The Corporate Reference Guide to Work-Family Programs," a study of 188 of the nation's largest companies. The guide, which grew out of a three-year study financed by the Ford Foundation, named four corporations as being "the most family friendly" in America: Aetna Life and Casualty, Corning, International Business Machines and Johnson & Johnson.
"These companies not only have programs like parental leave and flexible scheduling, but they encourage employees to use them without fear of jeopardizing their jobs," Ms. Galinsky said.
When she was president of the 76,000-member National Association for the Education of Young Children, Ms. Galinsky fought for the child-care bill that Congress passed in October 1990. "This bill recognizes child care as part of the social fabric of the country," she said.
Ms. Galinsky has been married for 26 years to Norman Galinsky, an artist who works at home. They have two children, a 22-year-old son and a 17-year-old daughter.
Mr. Galinsky said that he and his wife were often "looked at as sort of strange" in the suburbs where they lived. "We weren't a husband going to work and a wife staying home," said Mr. Galinsky, who has known his wife since they were in high school in Charleston, W.Va.
Ms. Galinsky said her husband, who does the grocery shopping and cooking, keeps the household going while she maintains her busy travel schedule. "I get up at 4 in the morning and go to places like Utah or Texas for the day," she said. "I try not to be away very much. And if my kids say, 'Come home,' I do."
At least two or three times a week, Ms. Galinsky meets with groups of parents as part of her research for corporations that want to develop family policies. Recently she met over lunch with mothers and fathers at a Ciba-Geigy plant in Suffern, N.Y.
She listened to familiar parental complaints: no time to themselves, no energy for their children. One mother said that with pots on the stove and both children needing help with homework, her evenings are "impossible."M
Ms. Galinsky gave a knowing nod. "With both parents working, we are a generation of pioneers," she said. "Sometimes I feel like we are assembling an airplane while we are flying it: we are inventing it as we go along."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
J. I. Case Plans to Cut Work Force by 4,000

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, Dec. 4

 BODY:
J. I. Case, the faltering maker of farm and construction equipment, will eliminate 4,000 jobs by the end of next year, paring its work force to about 21,000, its parent, Tenneco Inc., said today.
The cutbacks will be split evenly among plants in the United States and abroad, primarily in Europe, but the specific number of jobs to be eliminated at each of Case's 23 plants has not been determined, the company said. Case has more than 11,000 employees in North America, at nine plants in the Midwest and Canada. 
 Case, based in Racine, Wis., is the world's largest maker of small- and medium-sized construction equipment, like bulldozers and backhoes. It is the second-largst maker of farm equipment in North America, after John Deere Inc.
The job cuts were not a surprise. Tenneco posted a special charge against earnings of $461 million in the third quarter for expenses it projected then for shutting plants, trimming product lines, as well as for layoffs at Case. The operating loss for the quarter at Case was $169 million.
Robert J. Carlson, Case's president, said the cutbacks were forced by sliding demand for farm equipment in the last decade 10 years and "a severe economic recession" that had slashed sales of construction equipment.
"Though regrettable, these work force reductions are essential to our continued progress in very difficult market conditions," he said. Jobs of hourly and salaried workers, including managers and executives, will also be eliminated, the company said. Employees who lose their jobs will be paid severance and will receive extended benefits for a year, as well as counseling to find jobs.
The cutbacks are the latest move by Tenneco, which is based in Houston, since its new president, Michael H. Walsh, ordered a restructuring in September to stem growing losses. Other operations include packaging, shipbuilding, natural-gas pipelines, auto parts and chemicals.
The company halved its yearly dividend, to $1.60 a share, in September and has since signed agreements to raise $686 million from asset sales by the end of the year. The largest deal involves the sale of natural-gas liquid operations to the Enron Corporation, for $632 million.
Tenneco's shares rose 62.5 cents each today, to $34, on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: In the Nation;
A Predictable Demise

BYLINE: By TOM WICKER

 BODY:
John Sununu gave up the struggle to stay on as White House chief of staff more quickly than Sherman Adams did during the Eisenhower Administration. Both formerly were New Hampshire Governors, both regarded themselves as indispensable to Presidents who almost agreed, and both were disliked if not despised by the rest of Washington.
Mr. Sununu's offense was the more serious; he became a policy problem for President Bush and the Republican Party, widely regarded in and out of the White House as responsible for the Administration's lack of coherent policy on the domestic economy, its foot-dragging on environmental issues, and other political deficiencies. 
 Sherman Adams committed only the comparatively trivial political sins of accepting favors from a New England political friend, including a vicuna coat. But the Eisenhower Administration had taken a holier-than-thou stance on the supposed scandals of the Truman Administration, and Mr. Adams as White House gatekeeper -- he did not have a significant policy role -- had become known as the Abominable No-man; his firing became inevitable.
With the help of the President's dependence on him, he managed to hang on from June 1958, when his "indiscretions" became public, until September, when he finally was forced to resign. At that, a reluctant President Eisenhower had to enlist Vice President Nixon and Meade Alcorn, the Republican chairman, to do the job -- which might not have been done at all had not Mr. Adams become a party embarrassment, with the 1958 elections two months away.
How long Mr. Sununu has been under serious fire is not clear, but the heavy cannonading came in the last week or two. As in the Adams case, an election is just around the corner, this time the President's run for a second term. Mr. Bush seems to have been a little more forceful than General Eisenhower was; but again, a number of intermediaries -- including the President's son -- were enlisted to help do the deed.
Of these parallels, the most instructive is that Sherman Adams and John Sununu, undeniably able men, never seemed to understand that their abrasive style, abrupt decision-making and confidence in their own indispensability were not conducive to good White House political relations. Even a despised Congress, for example, needs to be treated with a certain deference, owing to its status and power as a coequal branch. Even a political opponent might be less hostile if treated more generously; and in politics as in real life, more flies are caught with honey than with vinegar.
Donald Regan, President Reagan's second chief of staff, also had a reputation for arrogance and abrasiveness; so did H. R. Haldeman in the Nixon Administration. The cases of Mr. Adams and Mr. Sununu are more remarkable, because both served as state Governors, and therefore came to the White House with the kind of political experience that should have warned them that the acid refusal and the cutting remark ultimately are of declining return.
It's true that any President needs someone to "take the heat" for him -- at least part of it -- as Mr. Sununu may well have been designated to do. Dwight Eisenhower and Ronald Reagan, in their different ways, are examples of Presidents who did not often appear to be deeply involved in political or policy battles, leaving that sort of thing to Mr. Adams and Mr. Regan; both Presidents left the White House still high in public esteem. President Carter, on the other hand, mixed personally but not always successfully into every controversy of his Administration -- and never quite acquired the high prestige and public popularity that are at the root of Presidential power.
Still, White House chiefs of staff can serve well without stepping on powerful toes; witness the successful tenure of James Baker 3d in the first Reagan Administration. He remained well liked personally but also served Mr. Reagan better than that particular President deserved. So as George Bush ponders a replacement for Mr. Sununu, he might look to Mr. Baker as a model. And the next chief would do well to keep a copy of "Measure for Measure" prominently at hand. For he or she will be only "drest in a little brief authority," not crowned and sceptered. And as Shakespeare warned, it may be "excellent to have a giant's strength; but it is tyrannous to use it like a giant."

HEADLINE: Unregistered Aliens Have Right to School

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your report on the economic fears of Long Islanders refers to a case in which an elementary school principal reported to Federal authorities two illegal immigrants, children who had come to register at his school (news article, Nov. 5). The case illustrates how immigrants become scapegoats in times of economic distress. The school principal's action reflects not only a blatant disregard for the law, but also widely prevalent misconceptions that immigrants are a drain on our economy. 
 The right of undocumented children to public education was firmly established by the Supreme Court in 1982 in Plyler v. Doe. In that case, the Court thoroughly examined, and rejected, the argument that undocumented children were a drain on public funds and should therefore be denied equal access to public schools. Instead the Court concluded that society's interests were best served by assuring these children a public education, particularly because many will become United States citizens, who will be unable to assume the responsibilities of citizenship if they have been deprived of an education.
The Court also noted that "illegal aliens underutilize public services, while contributing their labor to the local economy and tax money to the state fisc." This conclusion is consistently underscored by research studies indicating that immigrants have a net positive effect on our economy.
The economic crisis in Long Island that fueled this incident is, unfortunately, real enough. But targeting immigrant children is a misdirected and dangerous response, which keeps us from addressing the real problems we face.
 
JUDY RABINOVITZ
Counsel, Immigrants' Rights Project
American Civil Liberties Union
New York, Nov. 21, 1991

HEADLINE: THE LAST U.S. HOSTAGE;
Tea in Teheran: How Hostage Deal Was Born

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Dec. 5

 BODY:
As Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar recalls it, the moment he believed that all the Western hostages would be freed came when the Iranian President gave him his word of honor that Iran would use its influence to see that an intricate secret plan for ending the hostage ordeal would be carried out.
It was Sept. 11 and the United Nations Secretary General was having tea with President Hashemi Rafsanjani in his office in Teheran. 
 "I got a promise that the Iranians would help me as much as they could, and I was able to personally confirm all the arrangements with Rafsanjani," Mr. Perez de Cuellar recalled in interviews this week. "It was in those discussions that we prepared the final operation."
Although the United Nations had been actively seeking the release of the hostages for some months, the Teheran meeting started a new wave of United Nations-led negotiations that ranged from nuts-and-bolts shuttle diplomacy in nearly a dozen capitals to endless cajoling and convincing in Lebanon of the shadowy captors themselves by Mr. Perez de Cuellar's personal envoy, Giandomenico Picco. Mr. Perez de Cuellar, who is retiring at the end of this month after 10 years in his post, made the hostage issue a personal crusade, something he wanted to point to with pride when he left his position.
As a result of this unexpected United Nations initiative, 10 Western hostages were released beginning in August, along with dozens of Arabs held by Israeli-backed southern Lebanese forces and by the Israeli authorities, a process that culminated on Wednesday with the release of Terry A. Anderson. The Secretary General is quick to note that hostage ordeal is not over yet. Two Germans remain are still being held; about 275 Palestinian and Lebanese prisoners are still being detained by Israel, which is awaiting more information on the fate of its missing servicemen, and the bodies of two American hostages still have yet to be returned.
 
The Gulf War
Iran Fills Gap In the Region
 As Mr. Perez de Cuellar sees it, had it not been for the Persian Gulf war, American hostages might still be in captivity. The overwhelming American victory in the war produced a dynamic in the region that positioned Iran to fill the vacuum left by a weakened Iraq and to act as a reliable economic partner and diplomatic player.
In February and March, the Secretary General began a series of discussions with Kamal Kharrazi, Iran's Ambassador to the United Nations, in which he hammered home the new geopolitical reality, telling the Iranian that his country should seize the opportunity to strengthen its own position in the region. Whenever Mr. Kharrazi called, Mr. Perez de Cuellar gently turned the discussion to the subject of the hostages.
Mr. Rafsanjani was aided by his Foreign Minsiter, Ali Akbar Velayati, and by his close associate and United Nations envoy, Mr. Kharrazi. A psychologist educated at the University of Houston and former director of the Islamic Republic News Agency in Iran, Mr. Kharrazi was the former superior of Kazem Akhavan, a photojournalist and one of the four Iranians who were captured at a Christian checkpoint in Lebanon in 1982 and probably killed.
"I was myself very interested in helping to resolve the issue, especially since one of my colleagues was among the hostages," Mr. Kharrazi said in an interview. "I especially felt a sympathy for Terry Anderson because he was also a journalist."
But substantial opposition inside Iran as well as Iran's incomplete control of the captors made a swift resolution of the matter impossible. Iran enjoyed most control over the Revolutionary Justice Organization, which professed its allegiance to the goals of the Islamic Republic. But Teheran had less influence over the two other groups holding the Westerners, Islamic Holy War and Islamic Holy War for the Liberation of Palestine, which were committed to the freeing of Arab prisoners in Israel.
 
The U.N. Plan
Giving Something To All Players
 The United Nations' strategy was straightforward: give something to everyone without violating American and British determination not to make concessions to hostage holders. In the summer, Mr. Perez de Cuellar crafted a complicated plan that would facilitate the release of all "illegally held" detainees. Because the United States and Britain refused to negotiate, Israel became the broker for the West.
"I had the advantage that I was personally trusted by all the parties and that they looked on me as totally impartial," Mr. Perez de Cuellar said.
But it was the dogged negotiating efforts of Mr. Picco, the Secretary General's tight-lipped envoy who made it possible to bring to an end a particularly painful episode in recent American history.
Described by Mr. Perez de Cuellar as "more of a soldier than a diplomat," Mr. Picco passionately threw himself into the hostage project, shuttling to nearly a dozen capitals throughout the spring and summer in an effort to put together a wish list of all the demands. After Iran used its influence with Lebanese intermediaries to make contact with the captors, he traveled to them in the warrens of Lebanon, sometimes with a cloth bag over his head, an eerie repetition of the process begun by the Anglican envoy Terry Waite before he himself was seized.
By midsummer Mr. Perez de Cuellar was able to present Iran with a comprehensive plan. As Mr. Kharrazi described it, "The Secretary General came up with a package that took into account that the Lebanese people wanted their own detainees, the Western countries wanted their hostages and the Israelis wanted their servicemen. It was a step-by-step appraoch."
 
A Positive Note
'Good Will' Sign From the Iranians
 The first word of a hostage release as a "good-will gesture" came in a series of messages from Teheran, one from Hussein Musavian, Iran's Ambassador to Germany and a close associate of Mr. Rafsanjani and others from Iranian Foreign Ministry officials to David Reddaway, the British charge d'affaires in Teheran, and to a Swiss diplomat.
At the same time, Islamic Holy War, which held Mr. Anderson and another American, Thomas Sutherland, issued a communique that they would send an "envoy" within 48 hours to meet with the Secretary General. The envoy turned out to be a British journalist, John McCarthy, who carried an "extremely important message" from his captors upon his release on Aug. 8.
Although the written proposal in Arabic was frustratingly vague, Mr. McCarthy explained in a meeting with Mr. Perez de Cuellar near London that he had a more specific verbal offer, which the Secretary General recorded hastily in English on the back of a manila envelope: all the Western hostages in return for Sheik Abdel Karim Obeid, who was abducted by Israeli commandos in Lebanon in July 1989, and the release of hundreds of "freedom fighters" being held by Israel and European countries.
But the United States was opposed to any deal that would allow the early release of two Lebanese brothers in a prison in Germany for their role in the hijacking of a Trans World Airlines flight in 1985.
 
The Israeli Role
New Negotiator In the Process
 Israel, meanwhile, had actively entered the negotiations.
Mr. Perez de Cuellar, hoping perhaps for American help in dealing with Israel, asked Washington to identify and make contact with a potential Israeli negotiatior. The Administration turned to Uri Lubrani, the coordinator of Israeli activities in Lebanon and an Ambassador to Iran during the time of the Shah.
At first the Israelis expressed great irritation at suddenly being thrust into a pivotal role, arguing that Syria and Iran were the players who controlled events and could get the Western hostages freed any time they wished. Nonetheless, in meetings with Mr. Perez de Cuellar in Geneva in August, Mr. Lubrani and Yohanan Bein, the former deputy chief of mission at the United Nations, leaped into the fray. The Israelis made clear that they would release the Arab detainees held in Al Khiam prison, including Sheik Obeid, but only after they received authoritative information on its own servicemen.
Meanwhile, Mr. Picco's shuttle diplomacy and the release of hostages continued. On Aug. 11, Jerome Leyraud, a French aid worker who had been kidnapped only three days before, and Edward Austin Tracy, who had been held captive since October 1986, were freed.
 
The White House
Scowcroft Attends Secret Meetings
 The hostage affair was one of the Bush Administration's most sensitive foreign policy issues, prompting Mr. Bush to put Brent Scowcroft, the national security adviser, in charge of the brief. The relationship began by accident, over dinner at the White House, just days after Mr. Bush took over the Presidency. Mr. Perez de Cuellar recalled that when he mentioned the hostage problem to Mr. Bush, the President turned to Mr. Scowcroft and urged Mr. Perez de Cuellar to make contact with him whenever necessary. The United Nations official began regular telephone calls to Mr. Scowcroft, whom Mr. Perez de Cuellar described as "an old friend." Mr. Scowcroft even made several secret trips to New York to meet the Secretary General in his office or at his Sutton Place town house, sometimes not even informing Thomas Pickering, the American envoy to the United Nations, whose office was right across the street.
The meetings illustrated the quirks of secret diplomacy. When Mr. Scowcroft visited the United Nations just weeks ago, as Mr. Perez de Cuellar was heading for Europe to discuss hostage and other matters, he was recognized by a number of foreign delegates, who mercifully did not ask him about his mission.
The paradox of the secret channel, however, was that Mr. Scowcroft had been one of the three authors of the Tower Commission report, issued in the wake of the Iran-contra affair. The report recommended that the National Security Council avoid an operational role in policy making. "In part, the channel was a violation of that, yes," the Adminstration official said. "But this is an acknowledgment of the reality that sometimes there are certain kinds of diplomacy and there are exceptions to the rule."
 
A Crucial Juncture
U.N. Chief Meets With Top Iranians
 It was Mr. Perez de Cuellar's two-day trip to Teheran in September that solidified the hostage deal. He met not only with senior Iranian leaders but also with the families of the four Iranians who had disappeared years before in Lebanon, a gesture of good will that convinced the Iranian side of his humanitarian intentions.
On the same day that Mr. Perez de Cuellar met with Mr. Rafsanjani, the three weeks of United Nations-Israeli talks led to the first concrete Israeli move. The Israelis and the South Lebanon Army released 51 Arabs from Al Khiam and turned over the bodies of nine Lebanese guerrillas who had been killed and buried in Israel.
In return, the Israelis received the body of a Druse soldier who had been captured in April 1983. That left four missing Israelis unaccounted for. Most important for the Government was the fate of Capt. Ron Arad, an air force navigator who was shot down on the Lebanese coast in November 1986. The other three were lost in a battle with Syrian forces in the Bekaa region in June 1982.
On Sept. 24, the Revolutionary Justice Organization released a British hostage, Jack Mann. Less than a month later, Israel received confirmation of the death of an Israeli soldier missing in Lebanon, and two days later released 15 Arab prisoners, a "gesture" to keep the process moving, an Israeli Defense Ministry spokesman said. On the same day, an American professor, Jesse Turner, went free. Throughout the process, Mr. Picco pressed on.
 
Complications
Criticism Directed At White House
 By the beginning of November, Mr. Perez de Cuellar privately predicted that all of the detainees would be freed in one grand release by the end of the month. But he also began to complain about the unwillingness of the Bush Administration to lend more help to the process. He specifically had hoped that Washington would be "more helpful," he said at the time, by pressuring Israel to be more forthcoming in releasing Arab prisoners, and by supporting Mr. Rafsanjani and other cooperative Iranian officials by making conciliatory statements about Iran.
But the Bush Adminstration would not budge. "We were helpful in putting him in touch with Israel, but we were not prepared to give even a scintilla of a hint that we were involved in a deal making with Israel or anyone else," Ambassador Pickering said in an interview.
On Nov. 18, Mr. Waite and Mr. Sutherland were released in a gesture not precipitated by a move by Israel. The release coincided with an American-Iranian agreement at The Hague under which the United States returned $278 million for military claims by Iran and American exoneration of Iran in the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103, developments that Administration officials insisted were coincidental.
Even as Israeli officials said they would not free any more prisoners until they had authoritiative information on Mr. Arad, they also began to quietly express concern that they were being left behind in the rush to close the hostage file. Determined to stick the the comprehensive plan for a release of all detainees, Mr. Picco met with Mr. Lubrani and Mr. Bein in Europe on Nov. 22 to talk about the missing servicemen. He brought word from Iran that there was no objection to including the Israelis in the discussion.
Mr. Perez de Cuellar, meanwhile, asked the Israelis for a good-will gesture. On Dec. 1, they freed 25 more prisoners from Al Khiam.
 
Iran's Power
Decision Is Linked To Top Ayatollah
 The end of the ordeal for the American hostages was now in sight. Mr. Picco continued traveling, refining the final arrangements for their release. Three days in a row this week, an American hostage was set free.
But there remained a lingering mystery in the American hostage saga: just what did the captors get in return for freeing their charges?
Security officials interviewed in Lebanon said the decision to end the hostage saga came from the highest authority in Iran, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, who they said issued a "fatwa," or decree, ending all Iranian-linked covert operations in Lebanon. According to this version of events, there are new guidelines for the Party of God, an umbrella for pro-Iranian factions, to confine its activity to what was described as "resistance against Israel." As a means of pressure, Iran was said to have cut off financing to the kidnappers.
There were unconfirmed reports in Iran that the Teheran Government had committed itself to a large-scale reconstruction plan for Lebanon.
There were also reports from Iran that the kidnappers would not face retaliation. And despite official denials in Washington, it is highly unlikely that any such action will come.
"We finally have a peace process and a central government in Beirut extending its authority," a senior Administration official said. "Why would we ever want to get back into the quicksand of Lebanon?"
In the meantime, the United Nations will continue its efforts to win the release of the two Germans held in Lebanon and the Arab detainees held by Israel and its surrogate militia in southern Lebanon and to resolve the fate of the missing Israeli servicemen.
For the Secretary General, time is running out. He has vowed to do his utmost to end the hostage chapter before his mandate ends, in only 26 days.
"This has become something personal for me, something that must be seen through to the end," he said.

HEADLINE: MEDIA BUSINESS;
Daily News Files for Bankruptcy But Seeks to Continue Publishing

BYLINE: By ALEX S. JONES

 BODY:
The Daily News filed for Federal bankruptcy court protection yesterday, and while the paper will probably continue to operate for now, the possibility that it will soon be sold or closed has greatly increased.
The paper's bankruptcy filing came on the same day that the Maxwell family's privately held companies, which control The Daily News and hundreds of other family companies, filed for bankruptcy in Britain. The British court appointed four partners at Arthur Andersen & Company, the accounting firm, to act as administrators of the private companies. [Page D7.] 
 Should The News be put up for sale, Mortimer B. Zuckerman, a real estate developer who also owns U.S. News & World Report, and Peter S. Kalikow, the owner of The New York Post and a real estate developer who himself is in personal bankruptcy, said yesterday that they would be interested in buying the paper, but only under conditions that would probably require significant concessions by the unions.
 
Unions Examine the Situation
 Because The News is in bankruptcy, it is likely to seek concessions from the unions to cut costs and increase profitability. The court could also impose changes in work rules and compensation.
"I don't know what else can be done to help the paper, but we'll take a look," said John P. Kennedy, president of New York Newspaper Printing Pressmen's Union Local 2.
Kevin Maxwell, the paper's publisher and the son of the late Robert Maxwell, said yesterday in New York that there was "no question at this time of any sale," and that a reorganization plan was now under way, presumably to try to cut costs.
The rapid collapse of the Maxwell empire began with the death of Robert Maxwell last month in bizarre circumstances in which he disappeared from his yacht in the middle of the night and was found dead in the water. The elder Mr. Maxwell bought The News only last March in the midst of a bitter strike and was regarded as the paper's savior.
The decision on what will ultimately happen to the paper is no longer firmly in Kevin Maxwell's hands, but he is scheduled to meet with union leaders today. He flew from London last night and went directly to The News and spoke with employees in the newsroom to reiterate the family's intention to keep the paper. Reporters said Mr. Maxwell spoke of having employees share in the ownership of the paper and pledged to try to emerge from bankruptcy as soon as possible. Mr. Maxwell also spoke expressed confidence that The News could raise the money it needed for the short run.
In a statement earlier in the day, the paper said it had filed for bankrupcy "to protect The Daily News against the uncertainties involving the Maxwell family's creditors in England and from a capital squeeze due to the debt problems of the family-owned businesses."
The statement continued, "Although The News is ahead of its 1991 business goals, the paper requires a continuing short-term investment of funds to continue operations and achieve consistent profitability. The present situation has cut off the owners' ability to assure that money."
The News filed for protection in New York from creditors under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy code to obtain time to work out a plan to pay its debts. Generally, owners file for Chapter 11 when they want to continue to operate their businesses and the move seemed to be intended to insure that The News would not be closed precipitately, even though it was losing money.
"It seems to me like a very prudent way to keep The Daily News as distinct as possible from the Maxwell difficulties and to prevent Maxwell creditors from dismembering it," said James M. Lewis, a bankruptcy specialist at the law firm of McGuire, Woods, Battle & Boothe in Washington.
But Mr. Lewis noted that if the court-appointed administrators in London concluded that The News was not a viable business, they could move swiftly to petition the court for permission to close or sell it.
The News is owned by Maxwell Newspapers Inc., which in turn is owned by Maxwell Group Holdings Inc., a company incorporated in Delaware. But Maxwell Group Holdings is owned by Robert Maxwell Group P.L.C., based in London, which is now under the administration of Arthur Andersen and British courts.
In its bankruptcy petition, The News estimated its total assets as of Oct. 27 at $37.4 million and total liabilities of $53 million.
The petition projected that cash receipts over the next 30 days would be $21.6 million and that disbursements would be $23.3 million, for an operating deficit of $1.7 million. Just over half the disbursements projected were for payroll.
At a meeting yesterday with leaders of the paper's nine unions, company officials assured union leaders that the paper had access to sufficient funds to cover all payroll costs, though the source and quantity of funds to cover deficits remains unclear.
 
Big Unsecured Creditors
 Of the paper's 20 largest unsecured creditors listed in the filing, the greatest debt was to newsprint companies, which are owed over $16 million. The list also includes $312,00 owed to the 401k retirement plan for employees, $347,000 owed to the Newspaper Guild's welfare and pension funds, and $144,000 owned to the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union pension fund. More than $8 million is owed for rent, consulting fees, legal services, truck leasing, and other obligations.
John Talbot, an Arthur Andersen partner and one of the administrators appointed by the British court, said yesterday at a news conference in London that Arthur Andersen intended to examine The Daily News's operation to determine if it is near profitability, as the Maxwell family has claimed.
He said that his immediate intention was to maintain The News and as many of the other Maxwell businesses as possible, but that it was quite conceiveable that The News would eventually be sold.
 
Decision on Chapter 11
 An Arthur Andersen executive who spoke on condition of anonymity said that the decision for The News to file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy was made before the administrators were appointed and that while they did not necessarily formally concur with the decision, they apparently acquiesced.
But he said that the Chapter 11 filing here did not change the ultimate authority of the British administrators as effective owners of The News.
Presumably some companies will be sold by the administrators to reduce the Maxwell family's debt, but the court has not ordered a liquidation of the Maxwell companies, in which case a receiver rather than administrators would have been appointed.
Based on interviews with several Arthur Andersen officials, the plan is for Arthur Andersen to audit The Daily News to determine its prospects for a profit next year. If an audit concludes that the paper is losing a great deal of money with small prospect of turning a profit, the the administrators may decide to sell or close it.
If the paper is judged to have profitability within its grasp, the administrtators would probably decide that it was in the shareholder's interest to allow it to operate, and its losses would be covered, at least for a while, because a profitable business would bring more in a sale.
Despite the gravity of the situation, union leaders and many of the paper's employees maintained a dogged optimism that The News would somehow survive, as it has survived both a strike and the death of the man who gave it a reprieve, Robert Maxwell, during the past year.
 
Optimism Among Employees
 George E. McDonald, president of the Allied Printing Trades Council, the umbrella organization for the paper's unions, emerged from a two-hour meeting with News executives saying, "We feel optimistic about the future of The News." He added that there had been no discussion of union concessions to reduce the paper's costs.
"We're being told we've been killed again, but we'll be around for awhile," said Juan Gonzalez, a News columnist, whose defiant stance was echoed by many others at The News.
In large part, the optimism seems based on the presumption that as a last resort, someone would buy the paper because of its progress in recovering circulation and advertising since a five-month strike ended in March. For instance, during the strike The News's daily circulation plummeted to 300,000 from 1.1 million. The paper now claims to sell over 800,000 papers each day.
 
Seeking a Superior Paper
 But Mr. Zuckerman, who owns The Atlantic as well as U.S. News & World Report, said that before buying the paper he would have to be persuaded that it could be a superior editorial product and could also be economically viable.
Mr. Zuckerman, who was one of the two prospective buyers for the paper in March, said his plan then was to bring the unions in as partners.
But Mr. Zuckerman said he was concerned about the shutdown liabilities which he estimated to be between $110 million and $120 million in March. These liabilities include severance pay and pension obligations.
Should The News close, the unions would probably try to collect severance pay from the Tribune Company, because the sale was so recent. Otherwise, employees would join the ranks of other debtors. And the Tribune Company has responsibility for the Daily News pension plan for five years from its sale to the late Mr. Maxwell.
 
An Invitation Is Wanted
 Mr. Kalikow, who is himself in Chapter 11 bankruptcy, said he would try to buy of The News only if the unions came to him.
Mr. Kalikow said that the Bankruptcy Court would be certain to view any acquisition by him with great skepticism, and that the proposition would have to be very attractive to win its support.
He said he once considered the possibility of merging the papers in a morning-afternoon combination, which he said was less likely now.
Mr. Kalikow said he intended to start a Sunday edition of The Post if The News ceased publication.
Union leaders said they think Mr. Kalikow's objective in buying The News would be to salvage the Sunday operation, and close down the daily paper.
"He doesn't look like a white knight at this point," said Mr. Kennedy of the pressmen's union.

HEADLINE: BUSH AND ADVISERS GIVE MIXED SIGNALS ON ECONOMIC PLAN

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5

 BODY:
President Bush and his top economic advisers, undecided about what to propose to revive the flagging economy, sent mixed signals today on cutting taxes and on whether to violate last year's budget agreement.
The confusion was clearest on Capitol Hill. On the first day of a series of Congressional hearings on tax policy and the state of the economy, the economic advisers at first suggested that giving the economy a quick jolt was more important than holding to the budget agreement. But they came back from a short lunch saying that breaking the agreement was unacceptable. 
 The contrary messages seemed to underscore what public opinion polls show to be the President's most serious political vulnerability: his Administration's seeming lack of a coherent economic policy.
 
President Criticizes Congress
 The President himself heightened political tension over the economy at a news conference. While his advisers at the hearing were urging lawmakers to work in a bipartisan fashion, Mr. Bush blamed Congress for worsening the economy by not passing measures he had proposed over the last three years.
He said that after he reveals his new proposals in his State of the Union Message next month, he would go "directly to the American people, over the heads of the subcommittees and the Congress and say, 'Please support us in helping this economy.' "
The discussion of the economy today came as Mr. Bush named a new chief of staff, Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner, and a team of close associates to run his re-election campaign.
Mr. Bush also ordered the speedup of $9.7 billion in Federal spending, but economists said the amount was too small to kick life into a $5 trillion economy. [Page A27.]
 
Torn Between Methods
 The President and his chief advisers are under severe political pressure to take steps to speed the nation's recovery from recession, and the Democrats are determined to tighten the screws at every opportunity. But the Administration seems torn between conservatives who are interested primarily in tax cuts and care little about the budget deficit and moderates who see the deficit, about $350 billion this year, as a monstrous long-term weight on the economy that must be lifted. The President and his inner circle may not disagree so much among themselves as they are worried about the potential for political damage in picking one course above the other.
The budget law enacted last year after tortuous negotiations between the White House and Congressional leaders required that any tax cut be offset by tax increases elsewhere or spending reductions in domestic programs.
Early in a long day of testimony before the House Ways and Means Committee, Richard G. Darman, the budget director, was asked whether those budget rules should be broken in the interest of stimulating the economy.
He replied, "I would very much hope that we could continue to live within the discipline of the budget agreement.
Our first objective has to be restoring short-term growth on a basis that is sustainable with respect to long-term growth."
"If we can do that within the budget framework, we should," he continued, "but the first priority is growth."
And Michael J. Boskin, the chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, testified it was a "myth" that any measure that would increase the budget deficit would automatically lead to a counterproductive jump in long-term interest rates because of the fear of inflation.
 
New Tune After Lunch
 But the Administration's tune seemed to change after a 20-minute lunch break. Asked shortly after lunch whether he believed that the budget deficit should not be "violated," Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady replied, "That's correct. If it was violated, it would raise interest rates."
By the end of the day, Mr. Darman was saying that breaking the budget deal would shock the markets and central bankers around the world.
Mr. Darman told a Democratic questioner that it would be unacceptable to cut military spending or raise taxes on the wealthy to finance a tax reduction for middle-income taxpayers.
Dozens of Democrats are sponsoring bills that they say would provide middle-class tax relief. The measures differ widely. But almost all of them would cut by hundreds of dollars a year the taxes of households with annual incomes in the $20,000 to $60,000 range, and they would offset the cost with either cuts in military spending, increased taxes on the wealthy or both.
 
Exchange With Reporters
 At his news conference, Mr. Bush seemed to vacillate over whether he supported tax cuts for those people. He had this exchange with reporters:
Q. Do you think the middle class deserve a tax cut?
A. Listen, I think every American deserves to pay less taxes.
Q. Do you think, though, that the need is such that that is an area where you would consider breaking the budget agreement?
A. I don't want interest rates to go sky high. I noticed tht when one proposal was proposed, long-term interest rates, just on the proposal, went up through the roof. So whatever we do has got to be economically sound. But if your answer is, do I think the middle class are paying a very heavy tax burden, the answer to the question is, absolutely."
The Democrats sponsoring the tax measures are scheduled to appear before the Ways and Means Committee Friday, as are conservative Republican representatives who are backing a package of tax cuts that they say would generate economic growth.
 
Behind Political Tussle
 It was the Republicans' offering of that package just before Thanksgiving in the last days of the Congressional session and the President's endorsement of the plan when it had barely been drafted that generated today's hearing and the current political tussle. The Democrats believe they can score politically by showing that the vast majority of tax relief from the Republican plan would go to the wealthiest Americans.
The President's advisers bobbed and weaved today when they were asked about the plan. Mr. Brady kept repeating that the President was "enthusiastic" about the package but he added that "with regard to proposals in the package, some of them are ones that he has approved before, some of them are ones that he hasn't and some are the ones we are looking at."
Among the many elements of the plan are a lower capital-gains tax, a new form of individual retirement account, an increase in the amount of money older people can earn without having their Social Security benefits reduced and new tax breaks for small businesses and real estate investments.
The Congressional Joint Tax Committee, responsible to the Democratic leaders of Congress, have figured that the plan would cost the Government more than $25 billion over the next five years. But the Treasury, using an accounting system that calculates that some tax cuts actually raise revenue, maintains that the package would neither increase nor lower income over all.
 
Brady Limits Comment
 Asked whether he wished Congress had hastily passed the plan before adjournment, Mr. Brady responded, "I was enthusiastic about it, and I'm going to leave my comments there."
The Democrats base their views on taxation on what they call "fairness." In general, that means higher taxes on the wealthy and lower taxes on the poor and the middle class.
The President and his advisers say that redistributing income would do nothing to improve the economy. They favor tax breaks for the wealthy on the ground that they would stimulate investment and cause the entire economy to grow.
That is the basis of the long-running dispute over the taxes on capital gains, which are the profits from investments, a dispute that was rehashed in detail again today.
The President's advisers said today that such a tax cut would give the economy an immediate boost, and they emphasized a position they had mentioned only in passing in previous debates on the issue. That is the view that a capital-gains cut would improve real estate prices and help an industry that is in such bad shape it is dragging down the entire economy.
For their part, the Democrats repeated their fairness argument and emphasized that the investments that generate capital gains were mostly held by the wealthy.
Answering that argument, Mr. Darman declared, "If you can get the economy growing, that is fair. And if you fail to get the economy growing, that is fundamentally unfair."
 
Plea for Unity
 Throughout the Congressional hearing, Mr. Brady, Mr. Darman and Mr. Boskin insisted that the time had come to put aside partisan bickering and to find a way to fix the sorry state of the economy.
But the President seemed to be of a different mind. Although he exerted almost no effort this year to get his economic proposals, like a capital-gains cut, through Congress, he scored Congress for not acting on them.
"For three straight years," the President said at his news conference, "I have had economic growth proposals put before the Congress. And for three straight years, the ideas we've put forward have not been enacted by Congress."
Representative Thomas J. Downey, a Democrat from Suffolk County, did not know about the President's remarks when his turn came to question the Administration officials. But one of Mr. Downey's comments was probably descriptive of how the debate over the economy is likely to proceed during the Presidential election year.
Democrats and Republicans, Mr. Downey said, have "major differences in how we view the world."

HEADLINE: Bush Names New Staff Chief and Campaign Team

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5

 BODY:
President Bush tried to halt his political slide today by appointing Samuel K. Skinner and Robert M. Teeter, a pair of pragmatic moderates, to run his staff and his re-election campaign.
As he appointed Mr. Skinner, who is now Transportation Secretary, as his chief of staff, and Mr. Teeter, who is his poll-taker, as his day-to-day campaign manager and chief political strategist, Mr. Bush also made a new attempt to demonstrate his concern for what he called the "extraordinarily sluggish" economy. 
 He announced that he was speeding up $9.7 billion in Federal spending for 1992 in hopes of spurring economic growth but he made it clear that he was still planning to wait until his State of the Union address in late January to make any substantive economic proposals.
 
Sununu's Replacement
 Mr. Bush named Mr. Skinner to replace John H. Sununu, the combativeformer Governor of New Hampshire who tendered his forced resignation on Tuesday. Mr. Skinner is to take up his new duties on Dec. 16, and White House advisers predicted a sharp departure from Mr. Sununu's autocratic, exclusionary operating style. [Man in the News, page A27.]
At a White House news conference, the President also named the seven top officials of his 1992 campaign staff, who included Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher as the general campaign chairman. It was an array of longtime advisers and political tacticians chosen more for their closeness to the President and their campaign resumes than for their adherence to conservative Republican ideology.
As six of the seven immediately huddled in a White House office for their first organizational session, members of the party's rebellious right wing promptly denounced the lineup, including Mr. Skinner.
Mr. Bush brushed off the challenge to his candidacy from the Republican right. Instead, he seemed eager to clear the air of confusion in his White House after weeks of buffeting from Democratic and conservative Republican attacks on his economic policies.
Incongruously, Mr. Bush still declined to announce his candidacy for re-election, a formality that he said he was putting off until early next year. But Mr. Bush's appearance was suffused with the words and tone of a Presidential candidate trying to recoup lost ground, even as he acknowledged that he had lost some of the confidence of the public.
Asked why Americans' faith had been shaken in a President who once soared in the opinion polls and whether he could win the election if the economy is still bad next year, Mr. Bush said: "The answer to the first question is the economy. The answer to the second -- you said if the economy is bad can I get re-elected -- and the answer is, 'Yes, 'cause I'm a good President.' "
Mr. Skinner will control the President's schedule, have a strong hand in policy and help formulate what the White House has to say on all issues. In this way, he will have a major voice in the campaign from his office, an arrangement that many Republicans thought would have been virtually impossible under Mr. Sununu. Mr. Skinner gets along well with all of the members of the new campaign team, especially Mr. Teeter, whom he first met on the 1966 Illinois gubernatorial campaign of James R. Thompson.
Mr. Bush's appointment of Mr. Skinner immediately touched off anticipation in the White House that he would radically revamp Mr. Sununu's staff structure. Mr. Sununu had concentrated all of the power in his own hands and those of Richard G. Darman, the budget director, who has clashed in the past with Mr. Skinner but who is likely to remain a potent force.
"We'll more likely go back to a more normal White House staff, with a broader sweep in the domestic policy office and a broader sweep in the communications office -- four or five essential players instead of one or two," said one official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity.
 
Essential Challenge
 But Mr. Skinner's essential challenge will not lie in staff reorganization.
"We can improve communications a little, he can do this and he can do that, and it can be a friendlier place than under Sununu," the official said. "But the rap against Sununu was that Brent Scowcroft and those guys had a coherent and apparently successful foreign policy but where is the domestic policy?" Mr. Scowcroft is the President's National Security Adviser.
The official added: "The conventional wisdom is that a lot of Republicans around town think that the campaign has the heavyweights, the campaign's going to run everything. They will be very, very important. But in a re-election, you have to govern and you're going to be judged to some degree on your governing. Skinner's well aware of that."
As the removal of Mr. Sununu, a staunch conservative, had become an increasingly foregone conclusion over recent weeks, conservatives have been agitating for some presence in the White House staff.
"Bush didn't even throw a bone to the conservatives today," said Richard Viguerie, chairman of United Conservatives of America. "This announcement today is going to cause conservatives to realize that they have no stake in the Bush White House. This was an insult."
Although many conservatives have now targeted Mr. Darman as their primary adversary on the Bush team, Mr. Skinner has already undertaken damage-control efforts.
Vice President Dan Quayle polled Capitol Hill conservatives before Mr. Bush announced his appointment and is preparing to protect Mr. Skinner's right flank. Some White House aides have speculated that Mr. Skinner, who has a reputation as a get-along Chicago "pol," could bring in a conservative deputy, in much the way that Howard H. Baker Jr. did when President Ronald Reagan made him chief of staff and he brought in Kenneth Cribb, a conservative aide to Edwin Meese 3d.
Mr. Bush said today that he did not believe he had had a problem with his conservative wing, from which David Duke, the former Nazi and Ku Klux Klansman, has already mounted a campaign. Patrick J. Buchanan, the conservative commentator and former Nixon and Reagan White House aide, is expected to announce a challenge to Mr. Bush next week.
 
'Get Out Our Message'
 Asked what he could do to counter these challenges, Mr. Bush said: "Get our message out, help turn this economy around, help people and get our record, through a very active campaign organization, out to the American people. The playing field has had a handful of people out there who don't see things the way I do, this campaign field. And they've been dominating, because there's been nobody out there shooting back."
Mr. Skinner's appointment, which had been expected, was the centerpiece of today's news conference. But at the same time, the President moved to ease concerns within the Republican Party that he was taking too long to put his campaign into motion by naming the top staff of Bush-Quayle '92.
Although he will be general chairman, Mr. Mosbacher will not have overall control of the campaign strategy. Mr. Bush gave that power to Mr. Teeter, a Michigan poll-taker who has been a leading Bush adviser for years but has no experiencing running a national campaign.
 
Nuts and Bolts
 Frederic V. Malek, a businessman, former Nixon White House aide and a longtime friend of Mr. Bush, was named as the nuts-and-bolts manager in charge of the campaign organization itself.
Charles Black, a Republican consultant whom Mr. Bush today described as the successor to his longtime political tactician, the late Lee Atwater, will be a "senior adviser" to the campaign, an influential post that he will hold on a part-time basis.
Mary Matalin, a protegee of Mr. Atwater who is now chief of staff of the Republican National Committee, will be in charge of state organizations, ballot filing and delegates, a job normally given the title of political director.
Mr. Bush also said that Richard N. Bond, a Republican consultant who was his 1988 political director, will play an important role in the campaign, along with his son, George W. Bush.
Republican strategists said Mr. Bond will have a part-time advisory role, subordinate to Mr. Black. Mr. Bush's son, one official said, "will do what he always has done -- act as his father's ultimate confidant, eyes and ears, trouble shooter, problem solver, and appeal of last resort."
