HEADLINE: Reading Bush's Lineup

BYLINE: By R.W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5

 BODY:
The new leadership for the White House staff and for the re-election campaign that President Bush announced today emphasizes experience, technical skills and a nonideological approach, but it includes no one who has ever run a large-scale political enterprise.
The lineup shows how deep the Republican Party's talent pool has become after five successful Presidential races of the last six attempts. What it does not show is what kind of campaign Mr. Bush will run in 1992. 
 Mr. Bush is certain to emphasize his incumbency and his record, particularly the victory in the Persian Gulf war, and economic recovery if it develops. Charles R. Black, whom the President chose as a part-time "senior adviser," said some time ago, "His biggest strength is simply being President."
 
Waltz vs. Brawl
 Most incumbents run bland, low-content re-election efforts, like Richard M. Nixon's Rose Garden campaign of 1972 and Ronald Reagan's waltz in 1984. But Mr. Bush put a rough edge on his campaign three years ago, typified by the commercials identifying his rival, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts, with the black convict Willie Horton, and some have suggested he might use similar techniques this year, especially now that the race seems likely to be less of a walkover.
To a degree, that choice will be affected by the choice of a media director -- a conspicuous absence from the list of appointees announced today.
Roger Ailes, the New Yorker who put together Mr. Bush's hard-hitting advertising in 1988, will not oversee the media operation this year and may have no role at all. He is said to have told the White House more than a month ago that he did not want to be heavily involved, because he had gained profitable commercial clients in recent months whom he did not want to lose, because his wife had been ill and because he feared that involvement next year might cause controversy that would prove embarrassing to Mr. Bush.
Some Republicans expect Mr. Bush to use a variety of advertising experts eventually, and several experienced strategists warned that it was too soon to tell whether a lofty or a down-and-dirty approach would be followed.
Eddie Mahe, one of the most experienced Republican tacticians, said he thought there would be considerable sentiment within the campaign organization for "aggressively defining the opposition," or attacking his weak points, as soon as a Democratic nominee is chosen. That, he said, was the best way to avoid the danger of losing the initiative after the conventions.
Of the new appointees, only Mr. Black, a protege of Senator Jesse Helms of North Carolina who helped found the National Conservative Political Action Committee in the 1970's to help defeat liberal senators, has close ties to the party's right wing. And even he has a reputation as a pragmatist who defines success in terms of winning elections, not maintaining policy purity.
 
Role of Campaign Manager
 It is not entirely clear precisely what roles each of those chosen by Mr. Bush will play next year, although it is evident that Robert M. Teeter, the longtime Republican poll taker, will be the principal strategist. His title is campaign chairman, but he will in fact be the manager of the campaign, a role he has not previously played.
"How it all fits together -- that's the question for the next three weeks," Mr. Teeter said in an interview. "But what you always end up with in these things is four or five or six people running the show. You meet at the start of every day, divide up the work, then meet again at the end of the day."
Robert A. Mosbacher, who as general chairman will hold the hands of principal figures, big contributors and party stalwarts, earned his job not through political expertise or philosophy but because he is an longtime, trusted friend of the President who can be relied on to look out for his interests while also functioning as a campaign spokesman and helping out with strategy. George W. Bush, the President's oldest son, will handle somewhat similar chores.
 
A Potential Weakness
 Mr. Teeter's lack of executive experience is one of the relatively few potential weaknesses in the team, senior Republicans said, but they believe that Frederic V. Malek will compensate for that. A seasoned administrator and businessman who earned his spurs as one of the many hit men in the Nixon White House, he will function as the chief operating officer, Mr. Teeter said.
Mary Matalin, Republican National Committee's chief of staff, will leave that post to take on major organizational responsibilities in the campaign, a tipoff that the committee, under its politically inexperienced chairman, Clayton K. Yeutter, will play a decidedly secondary role. She is valued as a former assistant to the late Lee Atwater, the sparkplug of the 1988 Bush campaign, who knows and has maintained his national political network.
Mr. Bush has clearly sought to make up for the fact that he will have the services next year of neither Mr. Atwater nor James A. Baker 3d, now the Secretary of State, who were given much of the credit for his victory.
The departure of John H. Sununu, with whom Mr. Teeter found it hard to work, will clearly make the campaign run more smoothly. Indeed, the tensions between the two delayed the completion of the campaign roster. But it also upset hard-line conservatives, all the more so because Mr. Teeter is seen as a moderate and Samuel K. Skinner, Mr. Sununu's successor, is seen as nonideological.
"No sincere conservative" will believe Mr. Bush's statement "that his Administration is a conservative one," said L. Brent Bozell 3d, executive director of the Conservative Victory Committee. But mainstream Republicans cheered the appointments. Mitch Daniels, a former White House political director, said that "elections are won or lost in the center, and this is a strong unit full of real heavyweights that should serve George Bush well."
Mr. Mahe said he was most encouraged by the agreement of Rich Bond, who served as political director in 1988, to participate again this time. He is considered a highly adept field organizer. Without him, Mr. Mahe said, "there wouldn't have been a single person in there with street smarts."

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Japan's Cash Fountain Has All but Dried Up

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Friday, Dec. 6

 BODY:
The Tokyo stock market, which had been a fountain of cash that financed an investment boom in corporate Japan over the last five years, has all but dried up.
The closely watched Nikkei index of 225 issues continued its decline today, ending the session off 14.11 points, to 22,445.06, after falling 210.27 points Thursday. That leaves the index down about 17.4 percent from its 1991 peak in March, making this the second consecutive disappointing year. A slowing economy, tumbling corporate profits and a gloomy outlook on the part of corporate managers have dampened the market, even after Government steps to stimulate it this fall with two interest-rate cuts. 
 But those bearish figures tell only half the story. The amount of fresh capital raised with stock issues has plunged this year. And those issues that have come to market have often performed miserably -- another sign that the era of almost limitless cheap capital, which corporate Japan enjoyed for the latter half of the 1980's, is history.
It also suggests that the soaring level of capital investment by corporations, which fueled the competitiveness and economic growth of Japan Inc., is sputtering. Japanese companies have been outspending their American counterparts on plant, equipment and research by tens of billions of dollars a year. Some of that advantage may now be blunted by the poor stock market.
Perhaps the best measure of the market's malaise was the dismal reception investors recently gave to the sale of a big stake in Sony Music Entertainment, a spinoff of the Sony Corporation.
The record and music company's shares were offered on Nov. 22 at 6,800 yen each, or about $52.70. They immediately plummeted, and they closed here Thursday at 5,150 yen, or about $39.90. The company had been hurt by the defection of the Rolling Stones to another record label, but analysts said it was also a victim of the weak market.
"This acknowledges that the market is in trouble," said Liam Newberg, a senior analyst here at Merrill Lynch Japan. "Frankly, if you consider the factors in the market, I don't think it's fallen that low yet."
Because of experiences like Sony's, the issuance of new shares nose-dived, to 669 billion yen in the first 10 months of this year, from 3.4 trillion yen for all of last year and 8.5 trillion yen in the frothy days of 1989. Companies are turning increasingly to the bond markets, where they are paying much higher rates for their capital after years of being spoiled by the ease of selling new shares on the stock market.
In the late 1980's companies often issued bonds convertible into stock or with warrants attached to buy stock at certain prices. Because of the soaring stock market, companies at times paid nothing -- literally, zero interest -- for this capital. It was common to pay less than 2 percent.
When they turn to the bond market these days Japanese corporations pay more than 6 percent, often much more. For the first time in almost five years, Japanese companies are paying about as much as their American and European counterparts.
"Investor confidence is very weak everywhere you look," said Yuichi Matsushita, a market strategist at Nikko Securities, "and I think the trend is going to continue at least through the end of the year."
To try to halt the erosion in confidence, the Japan Securities Dealers Association has slammed the door on new stock offerings this year in the over-the-counter market, affecting about 20 companies. Although such decisions are left to the markets in many other countries, they are tightly controlled here.
Ten of the 22 issues that opened on the over-the-counter market in November before the ban took effect tumbled immediately. Five companies that had wanted to sell shares for the first time on the Tokyo stock exchange are reported to have dropped their plans, too.
The grim picture means that the Japanese market is closing the second year of a major bear market with a growl. Since the Nikkei index reached an all-time high of almost 39,000 two years ago, the market crashed twice in 1990, in response first to soaring interest rates and then to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait.
It languished most of this year, with investors hoping that the Bank of Japan would finally ease its tight grip on the money supply and that the Finance Ministry would remove the full nelson it had applied to real estate lending by banks.
But even with the central bank lowering its discount rate twice, to 5 percent, and the Finance Ministry reportedly ready to ease up on property lending, the market's psychology has not improved. It has had to contend with falling corporate profits and new forecasts that the Japanese economy may grow by less than 3 percent next year, which is a recession by Japan's exacting standards.
Analysts now expect that in the fiscal year that ends March 31, aggregate corporate profits will decline by more than 10 percent from the previous year.
The problems have also hit Japan's major commercial banks. Unlike American banks, Japanese banks are permitted to own shares in industrial concerns, and most of them have huge portfolios. They are able to apply 45 percent of the value of these portfolios toward their regulatory capital requirements. When the market tumbles, however, it threatens to push the banks below the statutory minimum capital level, 8 percent of their assets.
"The problems start for the banks when the Nikkei falls below 23,000, but it gets really ugly when it falls below 21,000," said Alicia Ogawa, the banking analyst at S. G. Warburg Securities here.
She said that Mitsui Taiyo Kobe Bank, Japan and the world's second largest, is already below the 8 percent level. If the Nikkei index falls below 21,000, Ms. Ogawa added, Fuji Bank, Tokai Bank and the Bank of Tokyo would be below the limit. The capital problems could further constrict lending and weaken the economy.
A number of other factors are bearing down on the stock market. One is that the December stock index futures contract expires next Friday, the 13th, appropriately enough.
Mr. Newberg of Merrill Lynch said the stock exchange recently reported that there was 1.19 trillion yen, or about $9 billion, worth of contracts outstanding that were part of complicated program trades. A portion of these contracts might have to be sold by the expiration, which could send stock prices tumbling further, he added.
Alan Bell, an analyst here for Baring Securities, said investors had also been worried about a high rate of stock sales by various kinds of mutual funds and trusts. "It's become a kind of vicious circle, with the worries feeding on themselves," Mr. Bell said. "People see the redemptions of these funds, so they sell more shares."
One of the more optimistic analysts was Andrew Ballingal, a strategist at Barclays de Zoette Wedd Securities, but even his optimism was tempered.
"We're on the back end of the bear market," he said. "Two years is a normal duration, so I feel it has run its course. The market is basically O.K., but it will probably remain choppy for the next three to six months before there's some real improvement."

HEADLINE: Mandela Seeks U.S. Backing for Goal

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5

 BODY:
In a meeting with President Bush and other Administration officials, Nelson Mandela sought today to convince the United States that establishment of an interim government in South Africa that included representatives of the country's disenfranchised blacks would speed the transition to multiracial democracy.
Mr. Mandela, president of the African National Congress, South Africa's largest black political organization, told reporters after the White House meeting that the lifting of trade sanctions against South Africa should be tied to the installation of a government more representative of the population. Under such a government, he said, a constitutional convention could be called and a new constitution written. 
 Leaders of South Africa's white Government contend that there is no need to change the country's political structure while apartheid is being dismantled and multiracial democracy introduced. Bush Administration officials, while apparently not enthusiastic about the demand for an interim government, say Washington would not want to intrude in what is basically a South African constitutional debate, on any side of the question.
 
De Klerk Called an Obstacle
 At a news conference today, Mr. Mandela called President F.W. de Klerk, who released him from prison and with whom he must negotiate an end to apartheid in politics, "the biggest obstacle to democracy in South Africa." He described the de Klerk Government as "a regime without credibility, without legitimacy."
"There is an overwhelming demand for an interim government," he said.
Mr. Mandela is visiting the United States two weeks before a national convention in South Africa on Dec. 20-21 that is expected to set the stage for negotiations on constitutional changes, and many of his comments on the trip are seen as intended to shore up the position of the African National Congress as it enters the talks.
Mr. Mandela made a point of praising President Bush today for keeping in constant touch with events in South Africa. He characterized his talks at the White House as very friendly and constructive.
 
A Meeting With Baker
 This afternoon Mr. Mandela met with Secretary of State James A. Baker Jr. and with officials at the World Bank. He had lunch with Washington's Mayor, Sharon Pratt Dixon, and met members of the Congressional Black Caucus.
He was asked today what he had told President Bush -- and would tell potential investors -- about the African National Congress policy calling for nationalization of industries. He replied that this policy had been adopted in the 1950's and that the organization was prepared to review it at a conference planned for March 1992. Proposals for policy changes were now circulating, he said.
But he reiterated his belief that in a country where ownership of land, industry and businesses was so unequally distributed, some government intervention was necessary to introduce a modicum of equity. He said that 90 percent of the land was in white hands and that 75 percent of the stocks on the Johannesburg exchange were controlled by four conglomerates.
"How does one address the question of rectifying imbalances like that without state intervention?" he asked."
 
Behind the U.S. Visit
 Mr. Mandela's trip this year, in contrast to his celebratory visit in June 1990, shortly after his release from prison, is largely a low-keyed tour of several American cities to meet business leaders and talk about future investment, once remaining sanctions against South Africa are lifted.
On Monday, he addressed the United Nations General Assembly, where he outlined a proposal to end international sanctions in stages, linked to political developments. On Sunday, he will be the keynote speaker at a meeting of a human rights foundation established in part by Jimmy Carter.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Football Debts May Force Kiam to Sell Remington

BYLINE: By KURT EICHENWALD

 BODY:
Victor Kiam, the man who liked his Remington electric razor so much that he bought the company, has decided it may be time to sell.
Mr. Kiam is exploring the possible sale of Remington Products Inc., the Bridgeport, Conn., razor and appliance maker that he bought in 1979 for $25 million in a leveraged buyout, a bank official said yesterday. 
 Mr. Kiam, chairman, president and television spokesman for Remington, retained the Chase Manhattan Bank in the last two months to explore options for the company, said Steven Rautenberg, a spokesman for the bank.
Mr. Rautenberg said that selling Remington was among several possibilities under review by the mergers department at Chase. "We are looking at several options," he said. "One is an outright buyer, one is a partner, one is some other form of investor and one is for Mr. Kiam to stand pat."
Remington has been put up for sale as Mr. Kiam, a man who won a reputation for business shrewdness because of his success at the company, is struggling with the results of perhaps his worst business deal, the 1988 purchase of the New England Patriots for $85 million. That deal left Mr. Kiam, who turns 65 years old tomorrow, scrambling in the last few months for $38 million.
As part of the Patriots deal, Mr. Kiam agreed to pay Francis Murray, his partner in taking over the Patriots, for his 49 percent stake in the team if Mr. Murray demanded it after three years. Mr. Murray asked for his stake to be purchased, and Mr. Kiam failed to raise the $38 million before two deadlines had passed.
The men have agreed to wait until the end of the football season, but the National Football League has, in effect, already taken over the team. If Mr. Kiam cannot raise the money, he will have to find another buyer for Mr. Murray's minority stake.
The dispute has already resulted in one lawsuit. National Westminster Bank USA sued Mr. Kiam and Mr. Murray, contending that a $13.5 million loan to Mr. Murray, which was due in October, was not paid.
A message left for Mr. Kiam at the headquarters of Remington was not returned last night. Mr. Murray did not return a telephone call to his office last night.
Mr. Kiam's search for cash could not have come at a worse time. After years of improving its business, analysts said, Remington has had a rapid loss of market share in shavers to Norelco, which is the industry leader, as well as to Braun, which only recently entered the market. Analysts have estimated that the company's market share dropped from 40 percent in 1986 to 28 percent last year.
While the privately held company had sales of about $250 million in 1989, analysts have estimated that the company's sales dropped by as much as $50 million by the end of 1990, to about $200 million.
The possibility of a new owner for Remington could harm Bridgeport, a city that has been damaged by the troubles in the manufacturing economy in the Northeast and that tried to file for bankruptcy this year.
Mr. Kiam has prided himself that Remington retained its Connecticut headquarters, even as competitors were transferring much of their manufacturing abroad.

HEADLINE: Seven Who Will Manage Bush's 1992 Presidential Campaign

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5

 BODY:
Following are the seven people who were named today by President Bush to run his 1992 Presidential campaign:
 
Robert A. Mosbacher
Campaign Chairman
 Secretary of Commerce . . . Charged with coordinating political, fund-raising and operations arms of the campaign as general chairman, but lacks skills to mastermind the race in the fashion of the 1988 campaign chairman, James A. Baker 3d . . . Recently conceded that Republicans face an image problem with the economy, and has pressed the President to move quickly to stimulate growth . . . Among Mr. Bush's most loyal and trusted political advisers . . . Veteran fund-raiser, can tap wealthy establishment where his roots lie . . . was finance chairman for Mr. Bush's 1988 Presidential campaign . . . As Commerce Secretary, Mr. Mosbacher has been active in White House deliberations on domestic economy and in promoting exports . . . 64 years old . . . His ties to Mr. Bush and Mr. Baker go back to Houston oil business in the 1950's . . . Headed family-owned Mosbacher Energy Corporation before coming to Washington.
 
Frederic V. Malek
Campaign Manager
 In his new post Mr. Malek will be chief operating officer, overseeing nuts and bolts of the race . . . Has less political experience than others, but is an experienced manager and enjoys Mr. Bush's trust . . . Masterminded the 1988 Republican National Convention and the economic summit meeting in Houston last year . . . Was deputy director of the Office of Management and Budget under Presidents Richard M. Nixon and Gerald R. Ford . . . Mr. Bush brought him to the Republican National Committee as deputy chairman in 1988 . . . Mr. Malek resigned that September after Federal archives showed that in 1971, at Mr. Nixon's behest, he compiled a rough count of Jewish workers in a Labor Department agency; Mr. Nixon suspected Jews in the Bureau of Labor Statistics were slanting unemployment data to make him look bad . . . Mr. Malek denied being anti-Semitic and has worked assidously to restore his standing with Jewish leaders . . . Vice chairman of NWA Inc. and its major subsidiary, Northwest Airlines . . . Also co-chairman of CB Commercial Real Estate Group and advisor to the Carlyle Group, an investment firm . . . 54 years old.
 
Robert M. Teeter
Chief Political Strategist
 President of an Ann Arbor-based corporate and political consulting firm, Mr. Teeter will operate as the President's thematic orchestrator, responsible for overall tone and direction of the re-election effort . . . He is considered adept at sizing up political moods to design winning campaigns . . . For 20 years he built his reputation as a pollster at Market Opinion Research, the Detroit-based firm . . . Worked for President Nixon in 1972 and President Ford in 1976 . . . In 1980, he worked for Mr. Bush and, after the Republican convention, for Ronald Reagan . . . Senior adviser and chief poll-taker for Mr. Bush in 1988 campaign . . . Opted not to join the Bush Administration, citing family concerns . . . But other accounts suggested that the incoming chief of staff, John H. Sununu, had refused to share responsibilities . . . 52 years old.
 
Charles Black
Senior Campaign Adviser
 A pivotal 1992 strategist, Mr. Black is likely to be the architect of Mr. Bush's campaign in the South . . . Among Mr. Bush's aides, Mr. Black is closest in spirit and political instincts to the late Lee Atwater, who engineered Mr. Bush's slashing 1988 victory . . . Will be the President's liaison to the right wing . . . Knows how to use "wedge issues," issues intended to split Democrats from their party . . . Founding chairman of the National Conservative Political Action Committee . . . Native of North Carolina . . . Political director of Jesse Helms's first Senate campaign in 1972 and advised his 1990 re-election effort . . . Partner in the lobbying firm of Black, Manafort, Stone & Kelly, which became enmeshed in influence-peddling scandal involving Federal public housing grants two years ago.
 
Mary Matalin
Political Director
 Ms. Matalin will run day-to-day state and local campaign operations . . . Knows Republican Party operations and personnel from the state committees to the headquarters . . . An Atwater lieutenant and close friend in the 1988 campaign, she will be counted on to supply a semblance of his political savvy . . . Unlike Mr. Atwater and Mr. Black, not an ideologue . . . Now chief of staff of the Republican National Committee . . . 38 years old . . . A descendant of Croatian grandparents in a campaign dominated by white males . . . Got a taste for politics in a 1980 Illinois Senate race (her candidate lost) . . . Worked in a number of Republican National Committee positions, and was Rich Bond's aide when he was deputy chairman in 1982 . . . In 1988 primaries, was Midwest field director for the Bush campaign . . . In the general election she ran Victory '88, the Republican National Committee's get-out-the-vote operation . . . After the election Mr. Atwater gave her the No. 2 job at party headquarters.
 
Richard N. Bond
Field Organization Chief
 Mr. Bond will be in charge of designing and overseeing state and local operations . . . Called a Long Island version of Lee Atwater, his longtime mentor . . . One of the early Bush advisers, dating to the mid-1970's . . . Made his mark as architect of Mr. Bush's upset in the 1980 Iowa primary . . . Later became his deputy chief of staff when Mr. Bush was Vice President . . . Was political director and deputy manager of the 1988 campaign . . . Very intensepolitical style, but is a tactician, not an ideologue . . . Chairman of Bond Donatelli Inc., a Washington-based corporate consulting firm . . . Got his start as press aide to the Nassau County, L.I., county executive . . . Later was press secretary for Representative Bill Green of New York . . . Crewed during a 1977-78 around-the-world yacht race.
 
George W. Bush
Campaign Adviser
 The President's oldest son and self-appointed loyalty watchdog for past Bush campaigns and for his Administration . . . Has been advising the President on 1992 race for a couple of months . . . From 1986 to 1988 he worked on the Bush Presidential campaign as adviser and speechmaker . . . After 1988 victory he screened job-seekers to insure that jobs went to his father's original believers . . . Ran for Congrss in the 19th Congressional District of Texas in 1978; won the primary but lost the election in a close race . . . Aspires to become governor of Texas, but his mother, Barbara, is said to oppose the notion . . . Nicknamed "Junior" , but takes pains to note his name is not the same as his dad's . . . While his father is a Connecticut Yankee in Texas, George takes prides in being the rough-edged Real Thing . . . Intense, extremely competitive and sometimes hot-tempered . . . Managing general partner of the Texas Rangers baseball team . . . Like his father, went into the Texas oil business as a young man . . . Business foundered in oil glut of 1980's and was sold to Texas-based Harken Energy Corporation . . . 45 years old.

HEADLINE: Moscow Seen as Controlling A-Arms

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5

 BODY:
The shriveling central Soviet Government holds firm control over its 27,000 nuclear weapons, Pentagon officials said this week, but the former republics are pressing for a greater say in the fate of the weapons on their soil.
The Soviet authorities are said to be in early discussions with Ukraine to give the newly independent republic greater control over the 4,000 nuclear weapons on its territory. Ukraine, which has pledged to create a nuclear-free state, has called for the republics with strategic nuclear weapons to form a collective military command to control and eventually destroy them. 
 The Bush Administration's decision to send Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d to Kiev this month to discuss Washington's concerns reflects the priority that the United States places on keeping tight control over the Soviet nuclear arsenal as more republics break free.
The Soviet Union has about 12,000 long-range nuclear weapons in missile silos and submarines and aboard planes as well as 15,000 shorter-range tactical weapons, including artillery shells, gravity bombs and ship-based weapons.
 
Security of Weapons
 Paramount to American interests, senior Administration officials say, is averting economic and social turmoil that could lead terrorists, thieves or warring armies to seize the weapons now under heavy security. On his trip to Ukraine, Mr. Baker and another American envoy, Assistant Secretary of State Thomas M. T. Niles, will also seek assurances that Kiev intends to honor international arms control agreements signed by Moscow.
"The most important thing is for the republics to achieve a peaceful separation," a senior Defense Department official said. "If the situation degenerates into the kind of civil war you have in Yugoslavia, no amount of good will will withstand that kind of battering."
Administration officials said Defense Secretary Dick Cheney was a leading advocate of the Administration's decision to move toward recognition of Ukraine's independence, which was opposed by the Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev.
Since the failed coup in August, Mr. Cheney and senior American military officers have expressed confidence in Soviet control over long-range, or strategic, missiles, and the more mobile tactical, or battlefield, nuclear arms.
 
Confidence in Safeguards
 Elite Russian-dominated military forces guard nuclear weapon depots. Warheads are typically stored miles from their launchers or aircraft and are secured by coded locks. Senior Pentagon officials said this week that American intelligence had detected no significant weakening in these safeguards.
There are strategic nuclear weapons in Ukraine, Russia, Byelorussia and Kazakhstan and tactical nuclear weapons in all 12 republics, most of which have declared independence in some form. Ukraine has about 15 percent of the Soviet nuclear weapons, including 46 SS-24 long-range missiles that each carry 10 warheads and 130 older SS-19 missiles that have six warheads each, according to Bruce G. Blair, a specialist in Soviet nuclear control procedures at the Brookings Institution.
Other American experts estimate that Ukraine has 2,500 to 3,000 tactical nuclear weapons, including artillery shells, gravity bombs and ship-based weapons.
The Administration has taken several steps since the failed coup to encourage a rapid reduction in Soviet nuclear forces. President Bush announced a unilateral initiative in September to dismantle all American tactical nuclear weapons on land and at sea, a decision that prompted a similar order from Mr. Gorbachev for Soviet tactical weapons.
Soviet and republic leaders have met with senior State Department and Defense Department officials in recent days to discuss the American and Soviet arms proposals and ways to build on them.
Last week, Congress approved a measure to spend up to $400 million to assist the Soviet Union and the republics in dismantling and destroying their nuclear weapons. The Ukrainian Foreign Minister, Anatoly Zlenko, told a news conference in Kiev this week that his fledging country was interested in taking up the American offer.
Senator Richard G. Lugar, an Indiana Republican who is the main sponsor of the Soviet aid proposal, along with Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia, said, "Right now, there's an eagerness to move to destroy these tactical nuclear weapons in the former republics, but the concern is that eagerness might not last forever."
 
Transferring Arms
 Ukrainian leaders have expressed a willingness to transfer tactical and possibly even older-model strategic weapons to the Russia republic, which has the capability to dispose them, American arms control experts said. But Kiev has taken an increasingly firm stance on retaining some control over the more modern SS-24 missiles, prompting some independent analysts to speculate that Ukraine wants to use the weapons as bargaining chips with Moscow and the West.
"The United States wants above all to see safe, secure and reliable control over nuclear weapons," the Pentagon spokesman, Pete Williams, said this week. "It is for the republics and the central authority to work out the arrangements and exactly how that will be accomplished. We certainly don't want to see a proliferation of centers of control over nuclear weapons."
In Brussels this week, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization urged Ukraine to renounce nuclear weapons, abide by all the Soviet Union's international commitments and define its relations with Moscow and other republics peacefully.
 
Sharing Control
 Mr. Blair of the Brookings Institution said reports from Kiev indicated that Ukrainian leaders had been meeting quietly with Soviet officials on sharing control over strategic nuclear weapons on Ukrainian territory. He said these talks would continue through next year on guaranteeing that Moscow would consult Kiev before firing strategic nuclear weapons. In a second phase of the agreement, to be carried out from 1993 to 1995, Moscow would need approval from Ukrainian leaders to launch a missile.
Scientists at the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Havard University have suggested that tactical nuclear weapons stored at 15 depots be moved to four central sites, where the weapons would be tagged, identified and eventually dismantled with American assistance.

SECTION: Section A; Page 27; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1446 words

HEADLINE: Man In the News: Samuel Knox Skinner;
A Model of a Competent and Wily Team Player

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5

 BODY:
In picking Samuel K. Skinner as his chief of staff today, President Bush went for the member of his Cabinet with the clearest record of domestic successes and a degree of political savvy that won tributes even from Democrats in the hard-bitten world of Chicago politics.
But the very characteristics that make him popular among moderate Republicans, his reputed pragmatism and disdain for ideological inflexibility, have sometimes cost him support among White House aides. Some of his proposals as Transportation Secretary were mercilessly picked apart by the man he is replacing, John H. Sununu, as well as Richard G. Darman, director of the Office of Management and Budget. 
 Mr. Skinner's informal and assertive style hardly resembles Mr. Sununu's, which is usually described as abrasive and combative.
It remains to be seen how Mr. Skinner will navigate among the President's other powerful aides, including Mr. Darman and the White House counsel, C. Boyden Gray, who have largely controlled the Administration's domestic policy.
 
Aides Have High Expectations
 A close aide to Mr. Skinner at the Transportation Department, Deputy Secretary James B. Busey, said his style would fare well at the White House. "He creates an atmosphere where everyone feels free to put their own ideas on the table without fear of appearing ridiculous or being put down," Mr. Busey said.
Mr. Skinner's political skills will quickly be tested in the 1992 Presidential race, with Mr. Bush under fire from Democrats about the stagnant economy and other domestic issues and facing primary challenges on the Republican right.
On issues where Mr. Skinner has wielded influence so far, he is a mainstream Republican. He emphasizes state and local governments and private investors over the Federal Government, believes strongly in unregulated competition and is willing to let weak businesses fail.
As Secretary of Transportation for three years, Mr. Skinner ushered a major shift in national transportation policy into law that saw airlines fail. As an adviser to Mr. Bush, he protested sharply and helped to kill a proposal last month for a major shift in civil rights policy that was circulated by White House aides but proved embarrassing to the Administration.
 
Prosecuted Otto Kerner
 As an Assistant United States Attorney and United States Attorney in the 1970's he helped jail many Democrats for corruption, including Otto Kerner, a former governor who was on the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Mr. Kerner was convicted in what many called a brilliant prosecution.
Mr. Skinner is viewed as tough on crime, although his reputation stems mainly from his role in prosecuting such corruption and organized crime, rather than the individual violence that causes fear among the electorate.
In office, he has worked effectively with Democrats.
William Daley, a Chicago lawyer who is the brother of Mayor Richard M. Daley, praised Mr. Skinner's credentials and said his appointment would present a tough political challenge to the Democrats.
Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum, a liberal Ohio Democrat who sparred with Mr. Skinner during his confirmation hearings and is now holding up Senate approval of Jerry R. Curry as Mr. Skinner's choice to lead the Federal Aviation Administration, said, "He is a straight-talking individual, whether he agrees with you or not."
 
An 'Organization Man'
 Republican political workers also had warm words.
Charles Black, a top Republican adviser who was named today as a senior adviser to Mr. Bush's 1992 campaign, said "he's very savvy" on campaign matters but that his principal strength is his managerial skill. "He'll get the team pulling in whatever direction the President wants," he said.
Mr. Black also said that Mr. Skinner would listen to other staff members. He added: "Sam does not have a big ego. He wants to get the job done."
Transportation experts said these characteristics helped pass the highway bill, one of the few legislative accomplishments of the year. While the $151 billion measure diverged in important ways from the Administration's year-old proposal, it has been seized on by the White House as the centerpiece of its job-creation effort now that the Presidential campaign is under way.
 
Seen as Up-and-Comer
 For years the 53-year-old Mr. Skinner has been touted around town as an up-and-comer, a likely candidate to replace either of two troubled Bush aides: Dick Thornburgh, the former Attorney General, or Mr. Sununu.
Time and again, he sloughed off reporters' questions about his ambitions with the most politic of demurrals. He had a wonderful job, he said, and was too busy even to contemplate a change, but of course he would do whatever President Bush ever requested.
Samuel Knox Skinner was born in Chicago on June 10, 1938 to Vernon Orlo Skinner and Imelda Jane Skinner. He grew up in Illinois and graduated with an accounting major from the University of Illinois in 1960 before serving as a lieutenant in the Army and then working for I.B.M. as an award-winning salesman. He took part in the Goldwater Presidential campaign and took evening classes at DePaul University, where he got his law degree.
He first worked for George Bush in 1980, during his disastrous defeat in the Illinois primary. In 1988, he was the statewide manager of Mr. Bush's landslide victory there.
He had been Assistant United States Attorney under James Thompson, who was later Governor, and then succeeded him as United States Attorney from 1975 to 1977.
Criticism at the time centered on his easy adoption into Chicago's old boy network. His law firm won lucrative contracts handling insolvent insurance companies, and it was reported by The Chicago Sun-Times that the work was handed out on the basis of personal connections, although no misconduct was ever demonstrated.
He came to the job of Transportation Secretary promising a broad strategy that would coordinate air, rail, road and mass transit and maritime affairs in a way never before seen. The idea ran into considerable resistance from Mr. Sununu and Mr. Darman, who viewed it as unacceptable social engineering.
Nonetheless, with allies in both parties in Congress, Mr. Skinner helped in 1990 to win enactment of what has been called the most important aviation legislation since deregulation.
 
'Master of Disaster'
 Mr. Skinner repeatedly stepped in to help Mr. Bush with unforeseen emergencies that sometimes involvinged transportation issues only tangentially, including rallying the Federal response after a hurricane struck the Southeast in 1989 and helping coordinate the Federal response to the San Francisco earthquake. His role may have been more symbolic than substantive, but the imagery at the sites of natural disaster was exactly what the White House wanted: competence, composure and compassion.
He helped supervise the cleanup of the Exxon Valdez oil spill, and later it was Mr. Skinner, not the Attorney General, who played an instrumental role in negotiating the legal settlement that set the Federal penalties against Exxon.
His accomplishments in these incidents earned him the sobriquet "Master of Disaster," and as Mr. Sununu was seen increasingly as a blossoming political disaster this year, Mr. Skinner's name again came to the fore.
If Mr. Skinner was sometimes overruled in the inner sanctums of the White House, he never became bitter, said Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, a New York Republican who is deeply involved with transportation issues.
"He always handled the rejection even of those programs that he had invested in personnally," Mr. D'Amato said. "He has been the loyal field commander."
At the Department of Transportation, Mr. Skinner developed a reputation as a demanding boss but not a martinet. He chose aides whom he considered talented, and gave them considerable responsibility.
Although some of his staff members had political connections, he drew from several realms. Mr. Busey, with whom Mr. Skinner worked especially closely, is a retired admiral; Jeffrey Shane, in charge of international affairs, is a career bureaucrat with experience at the Transportation and State Departments. Both his press secretaries, David Prosperi and later Marion Blakey, had White House experience. His deputy until recently was Elaine Chao, a relatively unknown bureaucrat who became head of the Peace Corps.
Some may end up at the White House. Apart from Ms. Blakey and Mr. Shane, names in circulation include his special assistant Cameron Findlay, his chief of staff John Gaughan, and Kenneth Quinn, the general counsel for the Federal Aviation Administration.
